author: {'steamid': '76561197995246330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1708306460}
review:
[i]Chasm[/i] is a more-or-less harmonious blend of two trends that have been done to death and then back in these kinds of one-man-show indie titles, which is to say it's both [i]procedurally generated[/i], with the level building itself from a modular tileset so that every world is random, and it's a [i]Metroidvania[/i], characterized by punishing action-platforming and recursive level loops with lots of backtracking.  The pixel art and the music are nice, but it was hard for me to take this game on its own merits simply because of the pervasive feeling that I'd played a million games like it before.

Combat and platforming are "sticky," rather than fluid, with fixed animations rather than multipart actions that can be canceled out of.  Level layouts take after [i[Castlevania[/i], but with every encounter procedurally generated from a variety of random layouts, it didn't necessarily feel coherent or designed with intention.  The platforming loop in these randomly-generated obstacle courses, in particular, felt very O.G. "Prince of Persia" to me, which certainly helps maintain the retro feeling but also isn't wholly a compliment on my part.

All in all, my impression of [i]Chasm[/i] was of a game that really wants to provide a contemporary indie spin on [i]Castlevania[/i], but it doesn't do enough to move past [i]Castlevania[/i]'s formula.  Instead, it uses budget-conscious random generation to regurgitate gameplay content, recycle it, and then regurgitate it again.  I simply got bored and put it down because I didn't feel the game was going anywhere as fast as I wanted it to, so I can't recommend it in good faith.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024130503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1707214066}
review:
I'd give this game about a 7 out of 10. It's got several good things going for it, but a few negatives that stop it from being as outstanding a platformer as 30XX, A Robot Named Fight, or Rogue Legacy. 

It's a Metroidvania that sticks pretty close to the Symphony of the Night formula with a semi-randomized map layout, though this doesn't add a huge amount to the game. This isn't Rogue Legacy where the entire goal is playing the random seed until you die, then start over. You get *ONE* map for the entire game, and dying means that you have to start over from the last save room you visited, Really, all the randomized layout does is prevent you from looking up map/item location spoilers online, and add some minor variation if you decide to start over again from scratch at a later date.  

This randomization aspect can be both frustrating and rewarding, depending on the gaming experience you're looking for. 

Personally, I found it more frustrating than helpful, since there are a few puzzles that need to be solved (like the combination lock) and several doors and chests that can't be reached until you obtain the usual array of Metroidvania items like ledge grab, wall-cling, double jump, and glide, but the lack of map spoilers or ways to place custom markers on the map (you can add a dot the the room you're currently in... that's all) means it can be frustrating to have to backtrack and try to remember exactly which rectangular room is that has the mural or the passage that you need to revisit to solve the puzzle or obtain the item that will get you to the next area. It also means that the rooms themselves tend to be a little generic and you'll encounter lots of standard left-right corridors linked up to large up-down ledge jumping rooms with pools of mud/lava/electricity at the bottom. 

The enemy variety is okay. You get just enough assortment to make exploring new areas feel fresh. Unfortunately, these baddies tend to be both overpowered and spread out. Which means that typically, you're alternating between fighting/dodging a single grunt enemy that can kill you in a couple of hits if you aren't extremely careful, grinding lower tier enemies to get a very slight stat increase/free heal/gold, and traversing boring empty space. Projectiles fly further off the screen than you can see... which is both a blessing and a curse. The knife subweapon is the best in the game since on a flat map, you can kill an enemy all the way on the other side of the room without ever seeing it. Unfortunately, you can also agro enemies from the other side of the room without realizing they're there, and they too can fire projectiles from off-screen that can easily kill you if you're low on health. 

Basically, the game does most of the standard Castlevania stuff right (like different weapons having different reaches and attack speeds, constantly getting new upgrades that will let you unlock new areas and finally open that chest you haven't been able to reach until now, and upgradable sub-weapons that follow the standard Castlevania attack patterns) but has some serious balance issues.  

I feel like if the enemies were less powerful and easier to tangle with, and the randomized map design a little more entertaining, I'd thoroughly enjoy replaying this game over and over again the way I do some other roguelike platformers. As it is, I finally beat the game (which has a very frustrating end boss, where the only strategy is to save a ton of money and buy as many health potions as you can afford) and have no real desire to pick it up again for a fresh play-through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967346265', 'num_games_owned': 627, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1706940637}
review:
I don't remember where I picked up Chasm (probably from a bundle deal somewhere), but while looking for a semi-relaxing game to play last night I saw this in my library and decided to give it a go. Overall I was really disappointed and probably won't play it anymore.

Graphically the environments look fantastic - I love the style they went with however that's where the positives stop. The levels are randomly generated which while it sometimes works, 9 times out of 10 I prefer a handcrafted level unless the gameplay is top notch and the game lends itself to multiple playthroughs which this doesn't feel like it was meant for. I think the devs did themselves a disservice by not taking the time to put together some gorgeous environments with what they had. Secondly, there is the main character himself - changing your equipment (other than your weapon) does not change how you look. Throw on chainmail and a bandana and you  still look the same from when you started the game. Just seems lazy. Then you've got the enemy designs which feel pretty generic and looks like they could've been included in an asset pack - again, lazy. Finally you've got the death animation for the non-boss enemies - they all just burn up and evaporate. Just boring.

My biggest problem though is with the combat - it's boring, clunky, and non-intuitive by today's standards. I came across 5 weapons in my 3 hours and they all feel the same and are not unique at all (sword, axe, etc). Sure they've got different base damage and some might swing a slightly different speeds than others but those are the only differences. Same for the magic attacks. Then you've got the limitation of only being able to attack left or right, or with the starting sword *slightly* downward. You can't swing up or down. What modern action platformer thinks that's normal? Then, perhaps worse, is the dodge mechanic. It slides you backwards from the direction you're facing - again, what? It's like the devs didn't want to have to deal with iframes so they went for the only other option they had. What's worse is the dodge mechanic won't cancel an attack, so enemies with a faster attack pattern hit you unless you slowly take your time and do one hit, dodge, repeat which is boring IMO.

Another minor complaint is the traversal through the levels/areas. You've got main level hubs with tunnel waypoints you walk through to different parts of the level and each main hub connects with one another through a warp/teleport point. Why not just make them all warp points and drop the "middleman" main hubs Diablo style? Just needlessly slows you down. 

So yeah, overall very disappointing and definitely not worth $20 IMO. If you want to try it out pick it up on a deep discount.

Designtechnisch sehr lebhaft mit knalligen Farben und mit Musik, die man auch nach dem Spiel noch im Ohr hat.
Was mit zufallsgeneriert erst abschreckend klang, entpuppte sich als v√∂llig belanglos. Man h√§tte es mir als linear verkaufen k√∂nnen, ich h√§tte es nicht gemerkt.
Das Beste (kreativste) waren definitiv die vielen geheimen F√§higkeiten und Belohnungen f√ºr "Perfect Boss-Kills"!
Wem dann noch aufgefallen ist, wie wenige Personen laut den Credits an dem Spiel beteiligt waren, der muss seinen Hut ziehen.

Alles in allem solide genug f√ºr seinen Preis und auch zu underrated in den Bewertungen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973984740', 'num_games_owned': 2127, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1150, 'last_played': 1706650979}
review:
chasm attempts something interesting with its map generation hook, but halfway through a second playthrough it doesn‚Äôt seem to matter. the layout isn‚Äôt 1:1 but key rooms feel like they didn‚Äôt move much if at all, and i‚Äôm buzzing comfortably through without any surprises.

with that said, the rest of the experience is great! the pixel art is detailed, expressive, and easy to parse in the middle of gameplay. movement is responsive and has just enough weight not to feel fiddly, which is good given how much of the game involves jumping around obstacles. the enemies are quite varied, but if you‚Äôve leveled enough that they‚Äôre not worth the time to fight you can usually weave through a room without engaging at all. bosses are cleanly designed and reward perfect fights with unique items. my only complaint with the map design is that signposting save rooms (similar to the way boss chambers are marked at their doorways) would occasionally save the annoyance of picking the wrong fork and missing a rest stop by one room.

what all that means, then, is that it‚Äôs an excellent game with an unnecessary and half-baked randomizer, and with that being its worst sin i‚Äôm comfortable recommending it to anyone with a soft spot for GBA-era metroidvania games. you‚Äôll feel right at home.

review:
I like a lot of the mechanics at play here, especially the item drops and build potential as well as the rarity of those items. I think the level system is novel for a metroidvania as well. Though I would have preferred if the focus of the drop rate on those items was tuned around singular runs rather than making it about picking and choosing gear based on what appears for the run you have and rushing through the game to the end. The grind if you want one weapon/item or another is too long imho. Still it was a good experience. I'll likely keep plugging away at it periodically. 

If you're looking for something different in the space, this is a nice distraction, but it's far from the best example of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046466279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1704425190}
review:
A genuinely impressive SotN-like Metroidvania. My only complaint is that the game lacks the animation cancels that most Igavania games have (on landing or into a back-dash), which makes combat against the rather quick enemies a lot dicier than it would otherwise be. Even faster weapons force you into a commitment, and if an enemy chooses that time to attack you're simply out of luck, because they also have no hitstun animations. The result is that you find yourself having to dance passively outside enemies' range waiting for a safe moment to attack instead of playing more aggressively, which can be a little frustrating.

Other than that one problem, it's great and absolutely worth a play.

author: {'steamid': '76561199062890372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1704948172}
review:
Metroidvania fans are a suspicious and cowardly lot....
I have a few issues with this game but I do think the reviews overall are a lot more picky and negative than this game deserves. There was some silly video essay which was attacking procedurally developed metroidvanias as being an "abyss off mediocrity" or some such portentous nonsense. But this game really doesn't fit in with that. I personally didn't feel like the levels seemed procedurally generated which is to their credit.
The enemy design in this game is also fantastic, each enemy is kind of a puzzle you need to solve and it's very satisfying to figure out their movesets. 
I personally think this would have been better with a soulsy style autosave, lose resources style system rather than an old school save points and lose progress. It just feels more respectful of my time if I don't have to lose a bunch of progress.
And there are a lot of platforming challenges sometimes to get quite worthless items, most of these are not mandatory but I personally don't love these kind of challenges. 
But I think this is a really great metroidvania.

review: Chasm plays and looks fine but there's just no reason to spend time with it. It's the white bread version of Symphony of the Night. It does everything that game does but toned down to the most basic, dullest format possible. Oh and there's no level design since the world is procgen even though this isn't a roguelike. There are no fun weapon, no interesting enemies, no cool areas, just nothing but blandness as far as the eye can see. Again, it's no offensively bad but there are dozens and dozens of better Metroidvanias out there. Only play Chasm if you've played everything else but at that point you're probably going to like this even less.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084452428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 784, 'last_played': 1702096027}
review: Nothing to write home about, but a good playthrough.  The boss fights can be cheesed pretty easily.  The potions are too strong.  You do not need to be any good at playing video games to dominate this game on Normal difficulty.  The rest are extremely tough and will require a ton of farming to get your stats up and money to afford potions.  Boss attacks are extremely hard to dodge, but your character tanks really well on normal difficulty to the point where you can easily out-DPS everything.  That all changes on extreme difficulty.  It is unfair and the bosses are stupidly difficult.  It's not as mechanically sound as some games in this genre, but it plays EXTREMELY similar to SOTN.  The environments are boring.  There's almost nothing artistic about this game.  The music is excellent!  Not bad.

review:
Pretty neat, but somewhat barebones Metroidvania with a little bit clunky mechanics.

It's got a leveling system simply awarding you exp for every kill with every new level raising all your stats. Some variation of weapon types for some simple level of playstyle variation. Enough new skills, locations and enemies to keep things interesting. A good number of NPCs to prepare your venture into the dungeon levels and a few nice secrets on top. 

Definitely worth the low price though. maybe pick it up during sale.

review:
I'm a sucker for 2D side-scrolling metroidvania type games, and Chasm is no different.

Chasm is your run of the mill metroidvania set in a medieval period where you're tasked to clear out a mine... that's it, that's all. The story is non existent.

What keeps this game interesting are the enemies, and equipment you fight and gain along the way. It mirrors Castlevania alot more than most metroidvania titles in terms of gameplay, while still making it different enough. 

Metroidvania games are like pizza. Even when it's bad/average it's still good. 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198057192014', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1699743113}
review:
I would only RECOMMEND ON SALE.

The guy that said this was the most 10/10 rated 6/10 game he'd played nailed it. Some of the game play was a lot of fun, but the backtracking across the levels with a hard to read map resulted in a very sluggish and frustrating feel midway through the game. Progression feels fairly aimless and while there is a journal it doesn't track any of the actual tasks you might receive. 

There was a point a where I honestly had no idea where to go to advance my progress / story and that was frustrating.

I did like that you can kind of upgrade your gear by farming better versions, and the companion hats were at least a nice first attempt (i wish they had been more refined with more choices).

I, however, don't see how people play through this multiple times.

The bones were there but the mark was a bit off for me. With that said, I wouldn't dismiss the developer or their future projects just yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371393766', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1367, 'last_played': 1698397896}
review:
"CHASM" is a pixelated masterpiece that flawlessly combines exceptional design, mesmerizing art, a captivating story, and an enchanting OST, delivering an immersive metroidvania experience that's nothing short of extraordinary.

The pixel art in "CHASM" is a work of art in itself. The attention to detail in each environment, character, and enemy is stunning. The visuals exude a nostalgic charm that transports players back to the golden era of pixel-based gaming while simultaneously elevating the experience with modern design sensibilities. 

The story is more than just a backdrop, it's an integral part of the experience. The game weaves a rich narrative that immerses players in its world, slowly unraveling its mysteries as you progress. The characters you encounter along the way are not mere placeholders but are imbued with personality and depth, making you genuinely care about their stories and paths.

An absolute gem and a great mystery to play through. It's a journey that will leave you with a deep sense of satisfaction and a yearning for more adventures in its pixelated world. Will you be able to save Karthas?

author: {'steamid': '76561197970601999', 'num_games_owned': 581, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1153, 'last_played': 1601586776}
review:
ahhh chasm. i have fond memories of that game, it certainly can scratch that itch, i'm even considering a replay. not making games myself, i'm always impressed by how such a nice experience was developed by just a small team / single dev. and after all this time, it still gets support and updates.
which brought me to the store page again.
which made me see the 'mostly positive' review score.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061539854', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1696109134}
review: Combining metroidvanias and roguelikes isn't an inherently bad idea, but Chasm hasn't sold me on that pitch yet. The map feels painfully generic, with upgrades and navigation lacking the handcrafted feel that I'd expect from better metroidvanias. On the flip side, you never get to really appreciate the randomized gameplay elements because you never have a chance to reroll your seed and see that variety. The result of those two negatives is a game that often feels AI generated in the worst ways possible. I think there's promise to what the dev is going for, but it really needs to go back for some more tinkering.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071403977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 2438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2438, 'last_played': 1695254436}
review:
This is a fun Metroidvania, but unfortunately it's a bit too shallow to be considered one of the all time great games in the genre. It's also missing any kind of gimmick that would set it apart from the countless other action-exploration games out there.

Pros:
- The graphics are beautiful. The music is acceptable, but the fact that you can switch it up to a chiptune version of the soundtrack at any time is awesome.
- The game has a nice progression. At first it's confusing, but once you figure out how the warp system works it's fairly intuitive. The challenge ramps up gradually. It's actually kind of hard at the end. 
- I like the system where you save villagers and then go back to town to see what they've unlocked for you. For example, if you save the lady who runs the potion shop, you can now buy potions. It reminds me of the underrated Soul Blazer on the SNES. 
- Lots of extra things to do add a couple extra hours to the game play.
- Enemy combat is a bit shallow, but I really like that the enemies have a few different attacks and they switch things up so you have to stay on your toes and remember the attack patterns to survive. Dying means you have to restart from the last checkpoint, so you don't want to screw up.
- It's really easy to level up. I put this as a pro because the game would otherwise be kind of grindy. Sometimes when your health is low it's easier to level up than to go back to a save point.
Cons:

- The combat is a little wonky. You have a backdash to avoid enemies, but it takes too long to react so it's basically useless. Also, if you attack while standing, you are locked into position. The correct way to play is to attack while moving because this keeps you in the running animation so you can go in for a quick jab and retreat.
- The magic is mostly useless. Once you beat the game you can unlock a mage class that lets you enhance the magic a bit, but in the default game the knife is the only useful magic you get. It's nice that you can upgrade the magic by using gems that you find around the dungeon, though. 
- The sub bosses are pretty weak. I would've liked a few more real bosses, as six bosses is too few, especially since this game can take ten hours to complete if you don't use a guide. The game overall could've been a bit longer though. 
- This game supposedly has procedurally generated dungeons, but it didn't seem to have any impact on my game. I guess this was supposed to be the game's gimmick, but it doesn't really have much bearing on anything.

Overall: A good, but not great game. For the indie genre of metroidvanias, though, it's solid. I really enjoyed exploring the dungeons, unlocking different items and going back to town and figuring things out. Oddly enough, it's not hard to 100% this game because the map will mark where the items you are missing are located and there are only a tiny number of hidden rooms. If you like running through games and then going back and unlocking all the things you missed, then this is probably a good game for you. If you like more strategic games that make you weigh the pros and cons of your decisions, then this is not really good for that since it's essentially mindless hack and slash until the very end, and you don't really have a ton of creative input on how your character develops.

review:
Solid Metroidvania game, although its not MUCH of a Roguelike game. Unlike other games where the maps that resets every time you die. This one doesnt, and instead it only changes the maps when you play new game. This prevents you from giving out directions to other players where they must go. So all you can do is give clues what to get, what location, but cant tell exactly where due to the maps switching up. When you do die, the game takes you to main menu and you can only start from where you last save.

Its a good game overall, recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981353644', 'num_games_owned': 1412, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1688773670}
review:
I sadly cannot recommend Chasm. I was really looking forward to finally giving it a whirl, even after the lukewarm reception it received.

To put it simply, Chasm is the most 10/10 6/10 game I've ever played. The potential for a great game was there, but it never landed the goal in a way that pulled me in fully. It felt like it was half-tugging me along for the ride, and I kind of stuck with it just to see where it took me.

My initial perception of this game was a 7.5, but as I continued, I became more and more disappointed. 


[h1] NEGATIVES [/h1]
The game started to feel more and more the same as I moved on. I'd traverse an area, beat a boss, get a power-up that allows me to progress, then repeat. This is pretty normal in metroidvanias, so this was expected. However, the real problem is how the traversal itself felt. There is a LOT of platforming sections, usually sprinkled with annoyingly placed enemies that only aggro you when you are in their attack range. If you get hit, you will most likely fall down and have to redo all the platforming. Usually the end result of this would be a mediocre item that was worse than what I already had..

Okay, so the platforming was overdone and repetitive -- and the loot from the platforming side areas wasn't rewarding. Well, surely the loot I'd get from backtracking with my new upgrades would be better than my current weapons, right? One of the final items I could obtain was a chest that required basically doing EVERYTHING else in the game first. The item I received? A sword that had worse range and less damage than my current one. It had a cool name, but that's all it had going for it. 

The obvious elephant in the room is the fact this game has procedural generation. It feels like it added nothing to the game, but could have been neat if done in a way less repetitive fashion. It's not even interesting procedural generation, as when I ran through the first area on a new save, I already knew where the direction of all all the key locations. Those were the same. I feel like this had potential, but ended up just adding nothing and making the game not feel as hand-crafted.  Saves and portals are also usually annoyingly placed, and there are some sections that really could have used more saves or ways to quickly navigate around..


The game also has a lack of environments, as only 5 giant 'levels' exist. I feel like I would have preferred way more interesting areas and enemies over just having 5 levels that repeat enemies. The pixel art is fantastic, but the backgrounds make every room feel the same. 

[h1] POSITIVES [/h1]
I do want to bring up the positives of this game, as I honestly still had a pretty great time. It's worth it for a fan of SOTN that's looking for that same kind of itch and has already played all the other similar metroidvanias (ds/gameboy castlevanias, timespinner, bloodstained, etc). 

The UI is very clean and enjoyable. 
The sound design felt pretty good. 
The animations were clean and most enemies were very readable. 
Enemy design was interesting, outside of the constant repeat designs..
Having leveling up in a metroidvania is something I'm very fond of :) 





[h1] NEUTRAL [/h1]


The game has item rarity. An item from a chest or enemy can drop as white, blue, or yellow. Yellow has a INSANE stat difference from the base white item. I feel like this would have been neat if the game was longer, as there is no reason to farm for these. It is exciting when one drops, and I was carried by one I got in the midgame for a while. I feel like this is a mechanic that is almost interesting, but the game isn't deep enough to warrant it. The depth it does add doesn't actually add anything to the game besides potential FOMO.

You can rescue villagers. These villagers give one time quests. You get rewards for completing their personal quest. Very basic design and I wish it was expanded on more, but I did appreciate it being there. I'd have liked it more if it was more akin to Castlevania: Order of Ecclessia or Castlevania: Portrait of Ruin quest systems. 

Weapon design could have been heavily improved on. You basically have short-ranged daggers, over the head weapons, and longer range swords.. I did get a unique weapon near the end of the game that was a throwing sword similar to the one in the Castlevania games. That was very cool, but I wish the game had more of these "holy shit" weapons. Everything kind of blends together.



[h1] Closing thoughts [/h1]

If you're craving a Gameboy/DS/SOTN Castlevania game - I'd maybe recommend this game for the sale price of $5 -- but it's nothing groundbreaking. I felt left wanting more. It's almost SO good. 

If you're craving a general metroidvania? Don't touch this game. There's a billion better metroidvanias to go play. Only play Chasm if you've already exhausted them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047800991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1686133782}
review:
This is decent little metroidvania. It clearly takes a lot of inspiration from Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, everything from the backdash to menus. It feels very similar, even with the gothic ambiance replaced with some very generic video game fantasy. SotN is a good source to draw from.

The procedural generation makes the environments kind of bland, and they put the puzzle solutions in different rooms to the puzzles themselves which is confusing and annoying. If you want to play a game like this on PC, you can do a lot better, but you can also do a lot worse.

review:
[h2]SUMMARY[/h2]

Oh yeah, I didn't review this yet.
[i]Chasm[/i] is a Metroidvania...-lite (?) with procedurally-generated biomes. That sounds like it shouldn't work, but it's mostly serviceable. In fact, I had a good time with it. The biggest knock against this game is just that the story lacks gravitas and the world lacks mystique. It's neither punishing or easy; neither serious or hilarious. The pixel art is pretty good though. You aren't helping an epic adventure play out like you are in [i]Hollow Knight[/i] or [i]La Mulana 2[/i]. It's more like concatenating a few [i]Super Mario World[/i] levels together. [i]Chasm[/i] is something to do while you wait for better Metroidvanias. Rank: [b]D[/b]

review:
Rough stuff. I feel like I have played this exact same game a few times now and this is the worst attempt at just another "symphony wanna be". One of the biggest problems I had is baked into Chasm, being the procedural generation. I personally like the idea of a metroidvania that on some level is generated. You can't look stuff up really, and the replayability is higher. BUT WOW do the rooms just become so repetitive, and in an adventure exploration game that is the worst. At the time of writing this I actually haven't played Chasm in about 4 months and I can't seem to remember a single boss fight or song that stuck out to me sooo I most likely won't be touching this one again. If you are looking for something similar but with more attention to detail, both Death's Gambit: Afterlife and Phoenotopia: Awakening offer unique adventure experiences with their own RPG elements.

4 / 10

Sadly generic and repetitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042420083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1681184509}
review: Was this a fun game? Yes. But was it fun to complete the entire thing? No. The idea behind the game was fun, artwork is nice but by the time I was halfway through the game, I was very ready to be finished with the game and I hate that feeling because I don't want to start something and not finish it if its just not outright unplayable. The having to backtrack after getting a vital item with a new ability just to clear one or two rooms was really underwhelming, unrewarding, and felt more like a chore than fun and furthering the progress of the game. There were things I feel that the devs missed the mark on this game but somehow the game still came out complete. I didn't run into any game breaking bugs or anything that made it unplayable. This was an ok game to stream, come check out our stream family at www.twitch.tv/honestaudie

review: The pixel art is simple, but very clean and the animation and controls are silky smooth. I have only encountered one problem which I hope they can address. author: {'steamid': '76561198025370485', 'num_games_owned': 1651, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1681001280}
review: It's a decent metroidvania, with clear inspiration from Castlevania Symphony of the night, but not as much content as that game. Not sure the procedural generation did it any good because the levels were ok but not anything special, and it's not really a game you'd want to play multiple times. Good presentation and it plays fine. Won't blow your mind but it's a decent game that will take you about 6-12 hours to beat depending on how completionist you want to be. But certainly there are better metroidvania games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023055657', 'num_games_owned': 2851, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1680818893}
review: I'm surprised at how not-procedurally-generated this procedurally-generated game feels. Exploration and leveling felt good, and I enjoyed the writing. Backtracking was managed well with the teleport system, and the combat felt true to its Caslevania roots. Magic could have felt more useful, but could just be my playstyle. A little short for the genre (15hrs), but I still think its worth it, especially if you like to replay games like this.

review:

Screw the save points not restoring mana.
Screw there minuscule amount of mana you get back from the lamps.
Screw the lamps not giving you anything half the time.
Screw the amount of grind it takes to get magic items upgraded.
Screw backdash and parachute being on the same button when you still have the trigger buttons left over.
Screw there not being a item magnet functionality so you need to jump into danger because gold spawn rate is abysmal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035118560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1678148961}
review:
Combat system is simple, although some weapons lock you in a long animation that will make it a feelsbad hit moment. Some enemies are really hard to kill without getting hit, even if you know the pattern.

Story is simple, yet captivating. You don't need to read it to pass the game, but it'll make it more interesting the first playthrough.

Sidequests feel umderwhelming, need some grind/time to farm quest items, and most rewards aren't really worth it in comparison to the gear you'll likely have.

Pixel art was pretty good, gotta say I loved it.

The only really bad thing I have to point out, is the save Spot on the last dungeon. Felt so horrible having to travel through  or 8 more rooms with 2 enemies (2 of those deal a lot and take a lot of hits) before the boss room, along with having to run all the way again if you want to get back to the village for potions, for example.

Overall a good and fun, chill game, Idk about 17 euros, compared to other games for the same price, but definitely worth it on sale.
7/8 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198252338752', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1145, 'last_played': 1677699351}
review:
Overall an enjoyable game, however I have a few gripes:

Very disappointed in the "randomly generated, rogue like" aspect of this game. I did 3 full playthroughs for achievements and I was going into the 2nd playthrough really looking forward to see what changes between seeds. There were definitely some changes, but those only went to the extent of the 2 puzzles having different solutions, enemy positions being slightly changed, and the rooms being mixed up just slightly enough to where its noticeable in some places, but not noticeable in others. If the rooms didn't all look so similar I think this would have been much better. Even the rooms that I could tell were different layouts from what I had already seen, looked exactly the same visually as the rooms before it, so nothing felt new or special during my playthroughs of the different seeds.

(Slight spoilers in this sections if anyone cares). This game also does a horrible job at explaining things, which for the most part is fine because of how straightforward it is, but I spent a good 3 hours of my first playthrough just wandering around confused trying to figure out what to do next. One part of that was from main story progression, where the game suddenly goes to a dead end after a bossfight and you're supposed to figure out which place to go to next. It threw the basic idea of "kill boss, go to next area after boss" out of the window and I had a very hard time trying to figure out where to go next. The second part of it comes from the sight potion having a weird description and me not understanding that it reveals hidden chests in some rooms. I figured it would do the same thing as the secret detector and reveal hidden pathways, but this potion was required for the last item needed for me to 100% my first playthrough, and I spent a really long time confused on what to do next until I looked it up and realized exactly what the sight potion does. Spending 2-3 hours on these things that shouldn't have been issues just wandering around confused and backtracking through the areas I've already backtracked through many times was very annoying, and I would have much preferred my first playthrough didn't have this.

Even with these complaints, I still enjoyed this game. I enjoy the combat and I think the game looks very nice. Very solid game overall, I just wish these 2 issues weren't as prevalent as they were.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968739543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1683230725}
review:
A nice, light RPG/dungeon-crawler/combat platformer. The controls are smooth and the combat style is subtly different from anything I've played before. One interesting twist is that *no* enemies have health bars, not even bosses. 

I've gotten one 'artifact' (powerup providing a new ability) so far, and am curious to see what the others do. Definitely a nice, slow burn on introducing new capabilities for the character.

The music is superb. The song for each area isn't super long, but it loops smoothly and all have fit the tone of the area well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996962573', 'num_games_owned': 645, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1485, 'last_played': 1697734450}
review:
i probably fit the hardest category of gamer to satisfy:  lousy players.  i've never had great reflexes, so any games requiring precision platforming or perfect timing are, to me, a recipe for frustration.  usually, games that present a fun ("normal") level of challenge for your average gamer leave me in the dust, as i'm often not skilled enough to progress beyond the opening levels.

that's why i'm always thrilled when devs include several difficulty options, or accessibility toggles, to make their games enjoyable for a wider swath of the community.  i don't sweat the fact that i will never be able to beat Chasm on its more difficult settings.  i appreciate the fact that a setting existed that allowed me to slowly work my way through the game.

with that aside, what's not to love here?  so many classic metroidvania ingredients, blended into a visually appealing whole, with tight controls and tons of weapon options.  i had a ton of fun...  and at the end of it all, the best compliment i can pay Chasm is: i, of all people, actually want to go back now and replay on a higher difficulty setting.  just slightly higher!

author: {'steamid': '76561198357338511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 900, 'last_played': 1699911683}
review:
Really short not-very-polished game that might hold your attention and entertain you for some time.


The game environment and design is definitely what caught my eyes and made me go through the whole game for the first time. Pixel arts and animations are not bad, but they are captivating in their own way. The soundtracks sets the environment well but there is not variety whatsoever, you'll be listening to the same tracks throughout the whole scenario.

Art-wise: this game is cute, it does its work trying to captivate its players and maintain them engaged and immersed, in my opinion, but it doesn't stand out in any means.


Gameplay has its high and lows. At the same time there are some incredible potential with mechanics that allows you to express yourself throughout exploration and combat, they are not there during most of the gameplay, and are absent especially at times when you would make better and more frequent use of them.

Your mobility is almost non-existent when you start the game, and basic move speed is not really fast (it isn't slow either); gears and potions that you can get from merchants in the game have awful cost benefit; and some progressive/evolution-based items are not accessible in the beginning.

It puts a nail in the coffin by provoking you with areas that obviously have loot but are inaccessible with your current movement options, requiring you to backtrack very, very often.

Once you unlocked all skills needed to loot and clear all stages, you already finished the game, literally. There is also no NG+ by the way.

Enough with negative criticism, the combat feels good and rewarding on its own way. Albeit it really is repetitive, you can embed movement into your aggression and optimize your damage output in minions or bosses, which is great. After some point in the game, all monster have different patterns and strategies to deal with you, such as lunge attacks, "anti-airs", blocking, ranged attacks, often they jump or fly evading some of your options too, and they are also cycling through these options when available, reacting accordingly to what your decisions are. 

The combat is not hard by any means, but it permits you to express yourself in the most creative way you can find to deal with each opponent. And there also enough variety of monster each room so you don't ever get bored.

Added to that, the platforms are made in a way that you also have to be careful about how you pass through them and sometimes even alters the combat dynamic when monster are present. Parkouring through platform challenges is also very fun and you feel great when you finished courses quickly with perfect movement.

Gameplay-wise: Lots of potential and it progressively feels better as you progress, being the start of the game the lowest point in this regarding.



Story wise there isn't much to tell, the game isn't very focused in story-telling. There are no cutscenes other than the introduction, the whole plot is developed through speech bubbles when you interact with NPCs or when some specific events occurs. Maybe it's better this way but the story is not super elaborate or involving.



Yeah, short game, not much to it. It's a hidden gem if it feels cheap for you. Yet it is not a great game I would pick before looking for better options.

Whoever, I do suggest you keep it in track and play it whenever you have the possibility. The game is not a waste of time, had lots of fun with it.

review:
This game looks beautiful, and it's a roguelite, so I bought it despite the mediocre reviews I read at the time.  It stayed in my backlog until now, and I finally beat it as I try to get through my enormous backlog.  The main issue with the game is that it's very slow, dull and boring for far too long.  I powered through the absolute dolldrums until I was about 2/3rds of the way through, when things started to pick up.  Unfortunately, even though things started to pick up towards the end, it was still marred by constant backtracking, somewhat clumsy controls, and obtuse direction as far as progression.  As a lover of both classic roguelikes and roguelites, I have to say that this game does not benefit from randomization; it would have been far better if it were hand-built.  Like Spelunky or The Binding of Issac, the biomes are made of pre-made levels that are randomly assorted.  Unlike Spelunky or The Binding of Issac, none of this matters.  There's no fun/exciting/chaotic systems that interact and give meaning to the random arrangement of assets.
So basically you're left with a mediocre metroidvania, a genre that is packed to the gills with amazing games, so why would you play this when there are so many better games in the genre to play?  There's nothing really exciting or unique here to draw you in, especially considering how slow and boring it is from the start, and although I adjusted to the controls, they aren't as elegant as many of the better games in the genre, which also marred initial impressions.  If someone were new to the genre, and wanted to check it out, I would recommend Hollow Knight, Bloodstained, Castlevainia: Symphony of the Night and all of the subsequent GBA and DS games, any 2D Metroid (Especially Fusion), even other randomized metroidvanias like Rogue Legacy before this game.  That said, I did enjoy the final 3rd of the game (if you can trudge through it it does get better), so if you are a die-hard, veteran fan of the genre there may be something worthwhile for you in here.

review:
Good! Definitely a lot of potential in the creators of this game. The pixel art is all pretty darn good. The enemies and backgrounds are all great and the character sprites are good if a little less so than the rest of the art style. 

The story was not engaging in any way but it serves well enough to play through the game at least. 

The gameplay and controls were so much fun though. I played this pretty endlessly because the gameplay was fun. Eventually you can get to a point of breaking the difficulty of the game if you min max a few things and have more than enough money to buy health and strength potions to turn any boss into an easy battle. 

I'd give it a solid 8/10

Above average but not super good.

Very much look forward to the creators other games as they definitely have a good idea of what makes a metroidvania fun. This really gave me the itch to play a Castlevania game now. 

My biggest "complaint" of the game would be that the treasure chests you find in difficult to reach areas after getting new abilities were almost always weaker gear or useless items. My best items through the game came mostly from random monster drops. However that did make killing so many of the same monsters as you backtrack feel more worthwhile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023681921', 'num_games_owned': 651, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1675130459}
review:
I wish i could give a mixed review. Chasm does almost everything well... Except the absolute core of the experience, the combat. Otherwise, this game is absolutely gorgeous, a top-notch metroidvania i'd compare to games like Blasphemous.

The deal breaker for me, that now made me put the game down - long story short, your attack animations take too long to finish. The majority of the enemies in the game sort of just walk at you (many of them have an additional attack or two) and deal contact damage upon touching you. This is par for the course for Castlevania-esque games, but the problem here is that your attack animations lock you into the attack for far longer than the enemies take to recover from getting hit. It's almost impossible NOT to trade hits with a lot of the enemies in the game, and it's not because they are inherently hard. It's because you spend more time fighting the controls than the enemies.

It's not impossible to play around, but there's something inherently wrong about a game where you spend more time learning to play around a problem rather than actually master any gameplay mechanics. When i succeed, it's typically not because i used the tools available to me to their fullest potential - it's because the arena i'm fighting in has the necessary space, and the enemy i'm combating gave me enough time to recover from the awful slow swings of literally any weapon available to me other than the dagger, for me to be able to jump out of the way before they reach me.

It's probably fine on easy and medium difficulty, but i mostly enjoy these games on hard. The game is visually beautiful and it sounds great. But because of this clunky, clumsy, awkward combat, i found myself never truly enjoying the game - it was always kind of tedious, i was always forcing myself to push on in the hopes it'd get better. Halfway through "world 4", it hasn't gotten better, and after dying to one of these issues (enemies that walk at you while you're swinging at them with your attack - you hit the enemy, the enemy freezes for a split second, then it keeps walking at you while you are still stuck in your attack animation) and realizing i just lost ~10 minutes of progress because of the extreme sparsity of save points, i decided the game isn't really worth the frustration anymore. It's just... Such a slog. I'd rather go play Death's gambit or Bloodstained, another two gorgeous castlevania-likes that i believe does this right. 


Don't get me wrong, Chasm is a gorgeous game, but this problem with the combat breaks it for me. I just don't have fun because of it. Just 0.1-0.2 seconds less recovering from attacks might be all it takes to fix it. But considering the game has been out for many years, i don't know if the developer(s) would consider it, for fear of alienating the people that do enjoy it as it is, or breaking something unintended.


In the end, i have to give this a positive, because it is otherwise a really really good game. But the combat is seriously getting in the way of my enjoyment, and you might likewise feel that it ruins the game for you. If you can look past it, though, you have a gorgeous little game and a very solid homage to the older Castlevania games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026663817', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 354, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1674222868}
review:
"How bad can this be?" I thought to myself when I saw this. It looks great, classic Metroidvania design, something about a roguelike... well, I'm sold. I started playing it, and after some 30-40 minutes I realised something isn't right. Something about the environments, the enemy placement... and then it clicked:

This game has randomly generated environments which contain handcrafted rooms, but everything is cut from the same cloth.

It's not like the game doesn't explicitly state that, mind. It's written on the store page and you're given a seed input when you're starting a new game... but the way the game starts, with its plot, varied starting environments and other little things you pretty much forget about it. And that's why it stings so bad - because of the unfortunate truth that we found out about way too late in the gaming world:

[b]Procedural generation cannot create meaningful content.[/b]

I don't know why that is - I've seen someone speculate that it's because of "lack of intent" that is clear to see. What this means for the game is that exploration very quickly becomes a slog rather than an exciting adventure. In good Metroidvanias there's a lot of variety even between individual rooms - either due to different enemies, little graphical details or different backgrounds. Point is, you can always tell that you're "elsewhere" - but here it's almost like you're on a treadmill; moving forward, but the world stays the same.

Of note is the fact that this game's combat is clearly inspired by Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, with its distinct swing mechanics and the backdash, not to mention the way the inventory is presented. And yet, nobody in the reviews seems to mention it or even be aware of it. This is absolutely terrifying to me - that such a foundational text of the Metroidvania genre is already so forgotten. Getting old sucks, you know? Then again, by today's standards SotN isn't too special, so maybe that's for the best...

Anyway, I'm mentioning this not because I want to out myself as an old man yelling at clouds, but because putting those two games side by side showcases perfectly why the drab, randomly generated environments and uninspired enemies completely ruin any good that Chasm could've inherited from its classic predecessor. 

And that's all there's to say, really. It could've been something good, but the mechanical "level design" and boring enemy variety make the gameplay simply not very fun. Everything else loses all relevance because of this central flaw.

review:
I enjoyed this game, Chasm isn't without it's problems, I wouldn't class it as anywhere near top-tier for a metroidvania, but it was definitely enjoyable.

I would recommend to fans of the genre and equally say to the developers know that randomisation isn't always your friend, you had a good quality set of assets/art/characters and if you'd only made a world without it being random (I know randomisation was an intention) you could've made something far more intriguing and enjoyable. The games not bad, but it feels uninspired simply put.

Recommended, but only to those hardcore fans of the genre as a whole, nothing new is here nor is there anything tangible to grasp onto for a sequel sadly.

review: Good pixel art let down by the repetitive backgrounds, good music but few tracks, and decent but sluggish controls. Where it falls apart for me is the procedural generation. In a metroidvania, you can't have rooms look this similar this often. It's a genre that relies on knowing where you are, which is difficult when I've been in "this" room 3 times in the last 10 minutes. Add on the inherently bland room and game design that comes from throwing out random things every room, and you have a good looking game that's lackluster where it counts.

review:
The game is demanding, on par with similar games from the NES and SNES era, so sometimes it may even feel frustratingly unfair, but I eventually found the progression system rewarding and felt like my character is going forward without too much grind and/or repeating the same part over and over. Although at its core the game can be enjoyed, I wish the loot would be much more frequent and varied, the trade system more balanced in terms of item prices, and a higher emphasis on developing a magic-oriented character would be put, as the available spells never felt to able to reach the point where you wouldn‚Äôt need to rely on using regular weapons. Or at least give us a new game+ mode, that alone would make future playthroughs much more enjoyable! 

In short: Highly recommended for fans of oldschool metroidvania platformers, who expect a challenge. While not perfect, It still offers a fairly enjoyable experience.

review: I recently played this as part of my YouTube series going through my backlog of games. Chasm is a game that has a great premise; a metroidvania that is procedurally-generated in order to make each playthrough unique. Sounds great. It isn‚Äôt. Due to the random nature, interesting secrets or loot is few and far between. Fortunately, the combat is where the game shines; it feels tight and responsive with multiple types of weapons and enemies for you to learn. The pixel art graphics are great with the only downside being that your equipment is not visible which is a real let down. The music is also very solid albeit a bit short with one main track per area but there is a toggle option to enable a chiptune version for some variety. Overall I would give this game a 6.5/10 definitely buy it on sale and give it a try if you‚Äôre a fan of this style of game but it‚Äôs not exactly my cuppa tea.

review:
Chasm est un jeu sans grande ambition mais qui fait bien le travail.

J'ai √©t√© d'abord attir√© par le c√¥t√© Metroidvania du jeu, et sur ce point-l√† il est plut√¥t d√©cevant: vous arrivez dans un village vide et entrez par la porte des mines, pour explorer des environnements souterrains (pas tr√®s nombreux et compl√©t√© dans un ordre pr√©cis) dans le but de sauver des villageois et battre quelques boss et sous-boss. Il n'y a pas beaucoup d'endroits uniques et int√©ressant, √ßa se r√©sume tr√®s souvent √† avancer en battant des ennemis et en traversant des phases de plateformes pour arriver au boss, √† un bouton ouvrant une porte ou √† un accessoire qui augmentera votre palette de mouvement.

Cependant, les combats sont plut√¥t sympa (surtout avec une dague comme arme selon moi), le bestiaire est vari√©, le pixel art est vraiment beau surtout dans le village, le jeu est accessible (voire trop simple m√™me en mode difficile pour ceux qui cherchent du challenge, une fois les potions d√©bloqu√©es on peut spammer les soins et les attaques ennemies sont toutes esquivables facilement quand on connait), les armes principales et secondaires sont sympas √† utiliser et les boss sont cool √† affronter.

Pour finir, le jeu se veut avec une grande rejouabilit√©, o√π vous d√©bloquerez le syst√®me de classe de d√©part (guerrier, mage, voleur) apr√®s la premi√®re victoire sur le jeu et sa g√©n√©ration proc√©durale qui ne se ressent pas vraiment √† la premi√®re partie mais fais plaisir pour les prochaines, si vous avez toutefois envie de refaire le jeu.

review:
Great Metroidvania. Tight platforming, weapon and armor drops are worth experimenting with, cool enemies and bosses. 
Pixel art and sound track are awesome. 
I do wish there were more combat mechanics like counter, block or parry or something. The magics are also quite underwhelming and niche, not sure in what instance one would want a mage build in this game. 
The backstep is the most complex thing we get which is quite useful and needs some skill to use but just jumping backwards is often equally as good to avoid and time attacks. 

Also Whip is so good compared to every other weapon. I use it even if it only does half the dmg.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202981520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1983, 'last_played': 1670720775}
review: Solid classic style metroidvania. I think that the mechanics were pretty well done even if the movement is a little clunky at first. Also the pixel art is beautiful. Definitely one of my favorite parts of the game. I think there are certain things that aren't very well explained and could have benefited from maybe a help/tutorial section in the menu to explain things. That way if people wanted the fully immersed experience that I think the devs were going for, they could still have that by just not looking at that menu and figuring it out themselves. I think the reliance on enemy drops and random chance for the progression of your equipment outside of the very limited shops is a somewhat poor choice. I was near the end of the game before I was able to upgrade my spells, although I appreciate the ability to quick swap between them. Also the very limited shop selection that never refreshes itself is not great either. If you don't do what I did, which is saving pretty much all your consumables for bosses, then you will easily find yourself only able to rely on the potion seller for healing in combat. Also I think that certain NPC questlines were a bit lackluster and underdeveloped, not to mention the cooldown on the mana pool in town. Would it really hurt to be able to let your players experiment with their spells freely in the hub area? Overall, it is a good game, but some issues that could be solved through either updates or a sequel. Worth the price, but it is a close thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099102768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1668475603}
review:
I might finish this game, despite the negative review.  It's going to take awhile to finish though because it has some major issues that leave me wanting to put it down not long after I pick it up.  It has a lot of the things I desperately want that developers refuse to put out.  It's not a roguelike, which it feels like every game like this these days is a roguelike that acts like the ability to save is going to ruin the experience.  It has a lot of old school SNES type mechanics, some good, some very dated.

The Pros are it looks great, the art and assets are all nicely done, it has an inoffensive soundtrack, and I haven't encountered any bugs of glitches in my time playing so far.  It plays well and the controls are responsive, mostly.  The story isn't anything crazy unique, but it's honestly not bad for the era that this game emulates.  I want a hack n' slash platformer, metroidvania experience.  This game does that.  It also has some insanely glaring flaws though that leave me extremely frustrated.

The cons aren't all that many to list, but they are rampant.  Enemy design is awful, mechanically.  Enemies are either extremely boring to fight, or make me want to just uninstall the game.  Ranged enemies are often standing on the edge of something, so that you cannot jump up to them to fight them.  You have to dodge their projectiles while making a series of jumps to get to where you can jump toward them, attack from the air, and then fall and repeat that process.  They deal contact damage (an extremely dated mechanic that should have died a long time ago imo.) so you cannot just jump onto the same platform as them.  Repeated jumps, attack from air, fall, repeat.  It's tedious.  There is a spider enemy that is lightning fast in every direction, has the ability to lock you in place with a projectile that you cannot dodge while also being able to attack, and stays out of attack range unless you are locked down.  This makes them nearly impossible to hit while they harass you with high damage, high speed attacks, while there are other enemies around.  Scaling is also really bad.  Enemy damage nearly tripled from one area to the next, while they also gained a bunch of frustrating mechanics like the one mentioned.  It's not a gradual climb in difficulty that scales with your growing power.  Your power barely moves while enemies skyrocket.

It's worth mentioning here that player attacks aren't any kind of sophisticated thing.  You can attack in one direction, and jump, and have a nigh useless backstep.  Mechanical complexity for the enemy while you have NES era capabilities on the player character is not a fun mix.  

Player movement is well done, mostly, but the platforming in this game is honestly tedious because of level design and the insanely slow progression of the "metroidvania" aspect where you get new movement tech that allows you to reach new areas.  Larger platforming sections often come with tons of hazards and require pixel perfect jumps or you end up falling and having to start the section over.  The controls are fairly tight, but they are not tight enough for what's required to not be annoying.  Wall jumping gets especially tedious because the controls for this are done very differently from other games like this, and it feels pretty janky.  Sections that would be simple in a hundred other games like this turn into a massive chore because you're fighting the clumsy wall jumping controls while trying to remain perfect.  The controls for grabbing things mid jump are also very unresponsive.  

The game, on paper, looks like I should love it.  But every time I play it, I eventually hit spots that are frustrating, and not even close to in a good way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980391455', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1668044322}
review:
I would literally not say it is randomly generated.  I did 3 playthroughs and they were over 95% identical in room layout.  You will get the same equipment in the same order, follow the same path through the areas, fight the same enemies, and do it all with nearly the same items and almost exactly the same rooms you traverse.

So what's left is a pretty generic, alright Metroidvania.  My first playthrough I thought fairly highly of it- "oh the rooms are kind of samey but that's because it's randomly generated".  It is not randomly generated.  It is just generic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076361833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1109, 'last_played': 1667523297}
review:
Apr√®s 18h de jeu √† vouloir faire √† peu pr√®s tout je l'ai ENFIN fini.

Je vais √™tre honn√™te, je suis un √©norme fan des metroidvania surtout les Castlevania dont il est clairement inspir√© d'ailleurs, que ce soit le bestiaire, l'HUD, les armes ou les sauvegardes. Malheureusement en terme de plaisir de jeu/exploration on en est loin.. peut-√™tre est-ce son c√¥t√© old-school voulu qui fait que le level design est aussi d√©sagr√©able mais en tout cas c'est pas un point positif du tout.

Au fur et √† mesure des niveaux les sauvegardes sont de plus en plus √©loign√©es et si vous avez le malheur de mourir un peu trop souvent vous en aurez vite marre de refaire le chemin. Perso j'ai jou√© en difficile, m√™me avec les meilleures armures on prend assez cher. La magie est anecdotique, les armes le sont aussi malheureusement donc on a pas le plaisir de tomber sur des armes ultra puissantes et rares.

Pour √™tre honn√™te ce n'est pas un mauvais jeu mais il est pas incroyable non plus, tout juste moyen. L'histoire est classique mais suffisante, sauver un village et devenir un chevalier qui n'en a jamais r√™v√© ? La musique est sympatoche, le pixel-art est beau, les fights sont rigides mais jouables et les boss sont pour le coup des vrais boss, √ßa se first try pas ais√©ment sans potions. Le jeu est court, comptez entre 7 et 15h selon la difficult√© et votre niveau de jeu mais c'est bien pour √ßa que je le recommande, si vous le trouvez √† bas prix c'est raisonnable mais pour son prix sinon vous serez forc√©ment d√©√ßu.

review:
L'exp√©rience de Chasm ne m'a pas envo√ªt√© plus que √ßa. Ce n'est pas un mauvais jeu, mais je l'ai trouv√© plut√¥t rigide. Il se fonde sur des fonctionnements classiques, donc, il fait penser √† d'autres jeux. Cela dit, la gestion du monde en proc√©durale et bien foutue. Le d√©but est assez peinard, et en approchant de la fin, √ßa devient de plus en plus rogue-like.

Le pixel art est bien ma√Ætris√© √† mon avis, et j'ai trouv√© l'univers assez beau. Il n'y a pas non plus une √©norme vari√©t√© d'environnements car le nombre de niveaux est restreint.

J'ai beaucoup aim√© les musiques. Je les ai trouv√©es simples et efficaces, et m√™me si elles ne sont pas nombreuses, jamais elles ne m'ont lass√©.

Le gameplay ne m'a pas sembl√© extraordinaire. J'aime bien le c√¥t√© exploration, mais les combats m'ont barb√© par moment, du fait de la possibilit√© de ne frapper que devant soi, ce qui peut √™tre assez lourd quand il faut vaincre un ennemi volant sur une plateforme minuscule. De plus, le personnage ne se retourne pas tr√®s bien, et parfois, je frappais d'un c√¥t√© alors que je sautais de l'autre, et √ßa n'a pas toujours √©t√© pratique. Je n'ai fait qu'un seul run, et je me demande pourquoi on peut forger des armes en m√©t√©orites (qui n'ont pas l'air d'√™tre les meilleures) alors que je n'ai jamais mis la main sur le moindre lingot de cette fameuse m√©t√©orite. Quand j'ai eu fini, il me manquait plusieurs choses √† trouver, mais je n'ai pas eu le courage de retourner les chercher. Faut dire que le gap entre le dernier niveau et les pr√©c√©dents et quand m√™me assez costaud, et √ßa m'a un peu saouler. Pour vaincre le boss final, je suis retourner au village, j'ai achet√© plein de potions, et j'ai bourrin√© en restaurant ma sant√© quand il le fallait, donc j'ai trouv√© √ßa un peu bidon.

Sinon, l'histoire est basique, mais c'est coh√©rent et bien amen√©.

Le jeu a bien tourn√© sous Windows 10, et √† part ce bug de retournements qui ne marchent pas super, je n'ai rien remarqu√© de g√™nant.

C'est pas que ce soit un mauvais jeu, mais je pr√©f√®re ne pas recommander Chasm car on peut largement s'en passer. Il n'y a pas de v√©ritable d√©fi (√† part passer par moments certaines phases de plateformes avec des contr√¥les pas tr√®s pr√©cis, ce qui pour ma part, √† tendance √† m'irriter), et, le fait de ne pas vouloir chercher ce qui me manquait refl√®te le fait que je n'ai pas trouv√© ce jeu tr√®s accrocheur.

Merci et bon jeu.

review: I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984180355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1271, 'last_played': 1662679838}
review:
This game has a lot to offer: 2 types of music to listen to, amazing graphics, a cool little story, and things you except from a metroidvania. And on the other hand it's not give you things you except from a metroidvania game. I found odd that the devs decided to put in randomization in level design instead of a well designed layout. It adds only frustration when you try to find some hidden place, and gives no advantages (only restarting the game randomize the layout anew). And this is not the only problem I encountered during my playthrough. The upgrade that gives you the ability to travel much faster is given to you very late in the game. There are a variety of weapons to use, but after getting the club, I never used any other weapon than the ones that give this overhead swing, it hits in a wide arc. You have to learn to time these attacks, but it was working for me best than anything else. Well I had a ton of problems with this game, but I also had aa ton of fun.
And this is why I recommend this game, it's no that hard, there are enjoyable parts, the graphics are really good, and I am very forgiving with games that let me progress and play it through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005374824', 'num_games_owned': 1051, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1663552154}
review:
I think I'm a sucker for Symphony of the Night style rpg/action/platformer type games.  I don't think Chasm is a great game by any means, but I enjoyed my time playing it.  

The biggest thing for me in this genre is feel.  Rogue Legacy 2 is a great example.  In that game, jumping and attacking feel awesome.  Chasm feels decent, but the weapons could be snappier, and there's this weird hitch on long jumps.  I think the game is trying to decide whether to attach you to a wall or not, but it definitely feels strange.

 There's also this random, what is supposed to be rogue-lite. element to the game, that I think Chasm suffers from.  Rather than spend time on a carefully curated experience, the developers implemented this randomization that shuffles around the dungeon every run.  That sounds great in theory, but keep in mind this is a Metroidvania, it isn't a run based game.  I just can't see the benefit of a random dungeon over one that is well designed. 

All in all, the game could be better, but I enjoyed it.  3 Stars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040295426', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1663384620}
review:
Let me start praising the amazing polish of the game. The art is fantastic. 

It falls apart in the level design. It's quite uninteresting and boring, and also gigantic, which doesn't help at all. Drawn out corridors connected to another drawn out corridor, connected to a vertical shaft identical to the last one. Traversing the map almost puts me to sleep. 

Like many others have said, I blame the procedural generation. Combining metroidvania with procedural generated maps is a cool experiment, but one I recognize as not quite successful. There are no advantages to the procedural generation in this case, since you are unlikely to play the game more than once, but you do get all the disadvantages of it.

I really hope people read these negative reviews and still consider getting the game though. I think the devs are extremely competent, and I hate when some failed experiment penalizes them too much. Experimentation is the key to originality and not a lot of devs risk it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008991843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1663026551}
review:
As a person who likes exploration games where you progress, level up and get some better gear. You know your general CASTLE + ALIEN PLANET stuff. It just feels inoffensive? I am putting a question mark there cause that is how i feel about it. Nothing is wrong with what is done, but the implementation just feels like luke warm water. The random map generation kept flipping my map sensor and I spent more time going down the RIGHT PATH instead of the dead ends where gear was. And it was a bit of a ughh when going back to find out that I could've saved time / pain by just not following my instinct?

Anyway, the controls are fine. They respond and definitely try to play SUPER safe of any tricks like backdash cancelling or whatever. But leave in the best normal of land cancelling attacks. So the game just has this kinda stiff feeling to it that isn't bad but I wish there was a bit of something more there. I was less worried about my damage number and more about how to just use the longest range option that wasn't horrible. 

At some point there was a grind for drops and it also just felt not great. At the heart of the game, there is something there its rough and probably went in some angles to try to be different. But what makes it different, doesn't make it shine. It kinda hurts it? I would recommend on a sale, or if you want to really experience it. It's just that I wouldn't be surprised if at the end you feel different than how you felt starting it.
