author: {'steamid': '76561198992563884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1305, 'last_played': 1661808998}
review:
Chasm is a game that takes inspiration from games like Castlevania and Metroid. While I do believe the game does have a decent foundation there's just too many things I didn't like to be able to recommend it to others. The biggest issues being the gold gain vs cost, item drops, and level layouts. 

The largest and most glaringly obvious issue I had playing the game was the item drops. The average enemy kill count for me to obtain both drops was likely around 120-150 kills. The smallest being under 50 and most being over 300. Not only would farming for these items take a ton of time, there is also another rng factor on top of an item drop and that is rarity. Drops seemed to be based off of the luck stat which I averaged about 50 by the end of the game, but wasn't a stat that would really get boosted unless you got items or drops from enemies. As such I didn't get to start playing around with building my character until around the end of the 2nd dungeon, going into the 3rd. 

The second issue was the accumulation of gold. Lamps and enemies had a small chance to drop money either when destroyed or defeated. Often times however it would be a bag of 5 gold. This meant that the main income for gold was to be good at the slot machine that seemed mostly based on luck, or to sell equipment drops from enemies that the player doesn't use. The issue here being that most equipment drops come from farming enemies, so a player that doesn't want to sit and grind for 6-10 hours killing enemies for drops is going to find gold hard to come by. On top of this many enemies require multiple hits to kill even early on. With healing items once unlocked being expensive, this means the main way of healing comes from save rooms. However, these save rooms are often few and far between in maps. It should also be mentioned that enemies do not drop health orbs so the only ways of healing were either items such as food, potions, or save rooms. 

Which leads me to the level design. While the levels themselves weren't bad many of the rooms felt either needlessly big or simply just empty. It was also often in these rooms that I would find enemies standing at the corner or edge of a platform I needed to get to in order to progress making it difficult to not only kill them but from falling and having to go through the rooms platforms again. My first instance of this was in the mines when I needed to pull a lever but a rock orc was in my way throwing projectiles while I was trying to jump up onto the ledge. There were instances where I as a player didn't know where I was supposed to go as once you finish going through the keep you will then start backtracking to previous areas to use key items in rooms that aren't shown to be special rooms on maps, making progression after this point tedious to the player.

A couple more minor issues I had were systems like the roulette minigame that I found twice. This game could either grant the player a stat upgrade or a stat downgrade. Whatever you get being permanent. I found it not worth playing as there was simply too many slots to loose versus what you would gain. Another minor issue I had was magic. I assumed magic would be a spell, and to an extent they are. However, I didn't realize the magic was only purchasable and was things like magic (insert weapon name here) or magic shield. Because how to use magic isn't clearly explained I didn't have any viable magic I could use until late game, making the pool of mana I had absolutely useless. 

My final issue came from potions. Many of the shops you gain access to by saving villagers when exploring the many areas. One of these villagers sells potions. Upon rescuing her you may already have a recipe or two which she will take and make it a purchasable item from her. However, many of the potions, especially the better quality ones run for about 200 gold, a hefty price if you don't have much. On top of this a few chests require potions you will unlock later in the game, and one requiring you to go back to her just to purchase one that you just unlocked to then gain the final potion that's used only for one reason. Not only does collecting all the potions require a lot of backtracking it also requires the player to have all the artifacts. The most easily missed is the diving suit used only for a few locations in the garden and obtained by beating the arena. In my game the arena was a chore as there was no save room nearby that I could go to between attempts, and losing meant game over.

I want to like this game, and I think it has a lot of potential but in it's current state I just simply can't recommend it to others. Much of the rng that make up a lot of my problems could be fixed with a few tweaks. While some items are rarer than others it shouldn't take 30 minutes of grinding just to get a single rare drop. Other problems could simply be solved if the game had more direction for the player such as the issue I encountered with magic, and not realizing how it worked until late game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962035438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1658110862}
review:
I played on Steam Deck from beginning to end. I would not recommend a keyboard and mouse.

I will update this review if I continue to play and have more to add and will leave comments on.

PROS:
- The music and sound design were completely appropriate and fit the world.
- I really enjoyed exploring each new area thoroughly even if you don't need to. There's a lot of discovery here, and it's mostly worthwhile.
- The controls are tight and do exactly what you want when you want them to.
- Ran great the whole time.
- Excellent spritework.

CONS:
- Sometimes you'll get lost and have no idea what to do because signposting isn't super clear after a point. If you don't remember what you found two hours ago and where it was, you may be screwed into doing a ton of wandering. This made things drag on multiple occasions to the point where I had to consult the internet (which I think is a cardinal sin). Even then, the random nature of the game makes even this imprecise.

CONCLUSION:
All in all, one of the best metroidvania games I've played since the DS era Castlevania games or Bloodstained.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021442265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1657375570}
review:
It's OK (yet Steam won't let me rate it as such). I enjoyed parts of the game but others made me want to kick a puppy. I definitely wouldn't pay full price for it. There's clearly love in it though, and I'd try a sequel.

My biggest gripes are the obnoxious hitboxes, hurtboxes, contact damage and fact that your character needs a cooldown between each action. It's just not fluid. This is a shame because every single enemy is unique and encourages a dance of combat...except your movements just can't keep up and the environments are often too narrow to properly maneuver. By mid game, I was bunny-hopping everywhere, just because it increased swing speed and mobility. By endgame (especially the final area) I was skipping all combat and then tanking the last boss with an inventory full of healing items.

I understand it's a bit easier if you stack magic and spam throwing knives. Your mileage may vary.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Plenty of things to grind, like XP, upgrades, drops, cash, logs, secrets
+Proper metroidvania in terms of exploration and length
+Frequent hub areas for fast travel
+Enemy drops generally useful
+Rare versions of drops for higher stats
+Most enemies require a little bit of strategy
+Can swap gear to focus more on magic or melee
+All 80-some enemies are nearly unique with no recolors
+Colorful and well-animated
+Boss doors are marked, with saves nearby
+Multiple difficulties
+Arcade and Race modes of play for those that want a challenge

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Enemies never really drop health
~Health items can be stacked and used anytime to cheese bosses
~Very few iframes after being hit. You can get ping-ponged in a few spots.
~Could have benefited from some iframes when backdashing (like a dodge roll)
~Enemies aren't staggered by attacks and just keep charging you
~Occasional annoying platforming
~Music is ok. Nothing memorable, but nothing terrible.
~Bosses drop some OP gear if you manage to kill them without getting hit
~Some enemy drops are rather grindy
~Not much of a story or any kind of character development
~A few spots where the game gives little or no direction
~A few powerups that are only used in one or two spots

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Movement is stiff, with long cooldowns between actions
-Melee weapons are just too damn small and slow
-Enemy placement necessitates taking damage in many areas
-Enemy contact damage
-Difficulty rollercoasters a few times
-The order in which you obtain gear is baffling. Some pieces are vastly superior to others, and are obtainable early (not even including the boss drops).

author: {'steamid': '76561197992856964', 'num_games_owned': 1022, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1657098558}
review: Solid metroidvania, emphasis on the castlevania.  There are tons of weapon options that come in different quality/rarities, many of which drop sporadically from mobs. You'll want to do some grinding for XP (leveling up helps), crafting ingredients (sell nothing), and wearable equipment (beating a boss without getting hit makes them drop a special item, so being overprepared is good).  My only real gripes are that there are a few jumps off of vines that I was not good at, and the guides available will also tell you what monsters drop what, but not what movement abilities you get in what order or what zones you should look for them in.  I keep getting stuck/lost and having to explore, which handles the grinding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042393606', 'num_games_owned': 996, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1501, 'last_played': 1607468738}
review:
Personally, I absolutely loved this game. It's clear it was a labor of love, and when I played it, it was filling a niche I desperately needed filled. It's your standard metroidvania, but the art style is gorgeous and the gamefeel is very satisfying. I waited a long time for this to come out and when I finally had it I was completely engrossed for days. Part of what makes it special is that this game was largely the work of one person.

If you like metroidvanias, you can't go wrong picking up Chasm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050566062', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1656297449}
review:
I read some of the bad reviews on here before purchasing this game, and 5 hours in I thought everyone was nuts and that Chasm was a masterpiece, but that impression changed the more I played. 

There are a lot of things I love about this game, and I was really enjoying my time with the first half of it, but I think as others have said what ultimately undoes it is the random world map. This isn't a roguelike where the caverns change every time you descend into them, it's a metroidvania with a set world that persist for the entire game (in my case an 11+ hour 'run' so far) - basing that world off of a random seed really does a disservice to what could have otherwise been an amazing game.

I really wish the random seeds (which I assume were added for replayability) were confined to new game+. As it is I found segments of my world generation were insanely hard to complete, with bosses at the end of long sequences of unusually high difficulty rooms set miles away from a save or travel point. There were times when I was forced to farm 'safe' enemies over and over in the middle of a journey to a boss just to try and heal from levelling up - which understandably became harder and harder to do the higher my level got. I will add I'm an experienced metroidvania and roguelike player - I don't think my perception of the random spikes in difficulty/grind come down to me being a bad gamer.

Sadly after many hours of enjoying myself, the generation of my world seed has turned the latter half of the game into an impossible grind fest that I just don't want to slog through anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053345539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1656261844}
review:
Enjoyed this a lot. Controls are slick and combat feels nice, and the difficulty curve was really good too, went from being simple in the early areas to becoming quite a challenge towards the end, with some decently designed bosses - although more bosses with unique attack patterns would've been nice.

The main negative points seem to point out the amount of backtracking, and yes there is some, but it never really bothered me - fast travel points are generous enough that it's never too much of an issue, and some backtracking is to be expected from a game like this. 

Story is minimal but again I've always been much more interested in gameplay in games like these.

I'd definitely recommend if you like the Axiom Verge, Salt & Sanctuary etc brand of Metroidvania.

review:
Perhaps more than any other game, I'd rate this a "neutral" if possible. Truth is there is nothing wrong with it either on technological field, art, music, and so on. It's a metroidvania dungeon crawling game with some leveling up, a hub world, a fair storyline, and so on. Again: there is no problem with this game.

It's just: I've been playing platformers pretty much for decades now. I've had some great ones, interesting ones, bad ones, bland ones...and chasm is just so darn "middle of the road". There's simply nothing here I haven't seen equally good or better in other games. It doesn't have a hook, unique (or even uncommon) abilities or interesting storyline. It's just...standard in any way. Sorry...it's not this game, but me. But this review is equally how I feel about it...

author: {'steamid': '76561198005719768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1789, 'last_played': 1655543977}
review:
Tight control and enemy patterns makes combat feel good. In Chasm, enemies don't swarm you but ask that you carefully dispatch them by reading their attack patterns. If you made mistakes, you can only blame yourself. 

The procedural map generation is sort of Chasm's replayable point, but also its weakness. The generation is limited, due to having map progress being gated by essential items that grant you mobility abilities. Truly randomizing the map could have caused softlocks and break the game, which is why replays WILL feel the same with minimal difference.

Does it justify the cost? Maybe, wait for a little discount if it makes you feel better. It also takes minimum 3 replays to gain all achievements

author: {'steamid': '76561198052778576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1655163207}
review:
The game doesn't feel very good at start, but rest 2/3rd of the game were ok, mainly thanks to variety in enemy attack patterns and available weapons.

Downsides:

Controls aren't up to modern standards, they're not completely terrible but there are some annoyances - 
1. no attack buffering means you need to time your attack very well or they just don't happen and your DPS drops significantly
2. missing "coyote time" means you will miss important jumps from time to time
3. lack of leniency on jump height - sometimes you reeeeally gotta hold that jump button - or again, you miss your jump
4. problems turning around in-between attacks
5. You have more control mid-air than on the ground

Fetch quests - this is basically the only kind of quest you'll see, be ready to get reeeally familiar with the route back to the "base"

Music is alright but over my 13h playthrough it started to get very repetitive

Very weak knockback on attack made fighitng a bit annoying at start of the game, but on the other side having to respect enemy's ability to move probably made the combat more interesting for the rest of the game

Punishment for death is a bit too much (normal difficulty), you lose ALL progress since last save - including exploration and collectables.

And I wish there was a better stats comparison between items when you equip/buy/sell them, as well as ability to sort in some of the popups

--

Other than the listed downsides, the game was mostly a decent time for me, so I rate it 7/10 - grab it when on sale if you have an itch for metroidvanias

author: {'steamid': '76561197970674841', 'num_games_owned': 2103, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 1673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1673, 'last_played': 1651895618}
review:
(7.5/10)

An interesting tweak on the Metroidvania Formula where a number of elements of the map are randomly seeded.  This unfortunately doesn't quite go far enough to make the game really fully replay-able as there are still all the same basic setups for each of the same basic areas, but it does mean that things remain structurally coherent and basically seamless in ways fully randomized games sometimes do not.

The underlying game is overall though quite decent, with solid bitmap style graphics and good sound/music.  The overall progression somewhat suffers a little from the randomization as you are never fully confident you find all the things in the right order and sometimes you can end up missing something without realizing it and needing to do significant back-tracking to determine just what that actually is. That also becomes an issue with several 'potions' you need to get recipes for to do single secret treasure rooms which feels a bit like an afterthought as most of those have basically no actual gameplay utility, and are only used to solve the one treasure/puzzle room they are needed for which can more often than not only actually get you one other thing to solve one other treasure room somewhere else.  

Despite suffering a little from that randomization it is still quite impressive how much of the game does remain solid to the point of feeling more like the areas were hand-crafted and that tech is quite impressive in the results on that front, it just feels a little under-utilized without more direct gameplay impacts or replay value.

In the end I do recommend it for anyone who does like Metroidvania style games, but don't be too ashamed to go peek at some walkthroughs to really figure out how some of the progression needs to work, as you are never going to be 100% confident if you are missing an in-game ability to progress, or whether you just missed something in an area you need to back-track to complete.

review:
No neutral option so will leave thumbs up. It is decent but not something i would recommend getting.

Combat not too bad but sometimes feels a bit too clunky. Backward dash is kinda useless. I have use it couple times here and there for couple monsters, but jumping is more responsive and better in most of situations.
Good audiom variety of monsters and art style however there is lot of backtracking and long distance moving to do small things sometimes.
In one part of game you have to move block which I had to google out because that is the only block that you can move through entire game, which indeed - has different color, but I didn't notice it until finding out information online.
I recommend getting some sort of magic because it helps a lot during later boss fights.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996752306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1649382578}
review:
Nicely-balanced pixel-art Metroidvania. If you liked Hollow Knight and you're ready for more melee-combat exploration gameplay, give Chasm a try!

Additionally: It runs perfectly on Mac, and what's more, my obscure gamepad (a Pokken Tournament controller) that I use with 8-way-move games worked perfectly as well -- which is not true of many Steam games with Mac support!

author: {'steamid': '76561198090512021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 897, 'last_played': 1649208173}
review:
A competently made, but not particularly inspired entry into the metroidvania genre. This game's biggest hook is the randomization of the map, but the only way you'd get to enjoy that is if you play it more than once.

What you have here is an attempt to make a Castlevania game in the mold of Symphony of the Night and the games on the Game Boy Advance and Nintendo DS that followed its design. When it comes to the core gameplay, it mostly succeeds at reproducing what worked in those games. So much so that I found myself humming Castlevania music over the game's own, forgettable score as I played. The pixel art is nice if you're into that aesthetic, although I admit I spent way too long flip-flopping on leaving the CRT filter on or off. (Off, I decided.)

I am giving it a thumbs up because I don't think it would be fair to call it a bad game. I still had fun, I still finished it. I just don't think it would deserve to be a part of the conversation when it comes to the greatest titles of an already very crowded genre. People who want to play a metroidvania are already spoiled for choice, and there are much better choices to play than Chasm. It's not bad. It's mid.

Mehcommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198208299437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1648808108}
review:
- Traditional castlevania-leaning metroidvania.
- Apparently some of the layout is procedurally generated, but honestly for me that was not much of a bonus, it doesn't seem very replayable.
- The graphics were very nice, atmospheric and detailed. I liked the different animations for different classes of weapons. I would have liked to have seen the armour my dude was wearing on his sprite though.
- Sound design and music was good. Some of the tracks were very atmospheric and well put together. Some of the intrumentation was a little retro-sounding, which seemed to be on purpose. Very characterful.

- The upgrades/abilities were not very inspired at all, with literally half the upgrades being basically wall-jump upgrade stages: grab certain parts of walls/ledges, jump off two walls, jump off one wall.
- Movement upgrades didn't feel nice to use. The wall jump was finicky and un-fluid.
- Bosses were significantly less challenging than normal enemies due to inbalanced amounts of health.
- The backstep was practically useless since the telegraphs were so late compared to the speed of controlling your character. You end up just learning the rhythm of enemies if you need to fight a lot of them.

Overall, I'd reccomend if you're really jonesing for a metroidvania and you played all the good ones.

This game is very mediocre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080493208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1172, 'last_played': 1627268495}
review:
I love Metroidvanias and sometimes I'll venture off the beaten path to see if I find something interesting and different in the genre. In that quest, I played a game called Chasm. You begin as a novice knight in a kingdom and are tasked with traveling to a hamlet called Karthas, a village that has been beset with some tragedy. There are a number of locals who have disappeared within the town's mines, and it is your job to recover them, discover the cause and save the day. Without going into the whole story, there is more to the mission than first appears, and in the course of rescuing the denizens of this place, you will uncover a deeper, darker, ancient mystery (of course, lol). The narrative is presented via documents that you find and text-based interactions with the villagers. I found it fairly intriguing, but it certainly wasn't the main reason I remained engaged.

The structure of the game is a procedurally generated series of underground maps. The layout is randomized, albeit with pre-formed rooms. There is still the familiar metroidvania pattern of unlocking new skills and tools to progress to previously unreachable areas, so if you only play it once, you'd never know that there is any element of variability to the appearance of the maps. There was a very nice sense of being rewarded when discovering a new artifact or tool that enabled you to parachute, climb, double-jump or maneuver yourself into previously inaccessible regions. So exploration was consistently engaging with only some typical, but moderate, frustration when you didn't know where to go next. There were some rpg elements in the form of magical weapons, leveling, RNG drops including rare items, crafting, gear, healing and buff items, and so on. There were plenty of options to make your character and his abilities fairly unique. There were also side-quests that the rescued villagers doled out that, if completed, rewarded you with some additional benefits.

In terms of the mechanics themselves, everything controlled very tightly. Things were smooth, very responsive and fun in a moment-to-moment sense, and it made learning the patterns of the game's many enemies all the more satisfying as I wasn't fighting with poor input. There were a variety of bosses, including a pretty tough final boss, and they were - along with the many normal baddies - designed well and had an interesting appearance for the most part. Speaking of appearances, the overall look of things was quite nice. The different maps were varied, from jungles and caves to lava and otherworldly locales. The map feature was as Castlevania as can be with the square rooms everywhere, and viewing any map could make you think you were playing a Castlevania game. I also really appreciated the ability to mark rooms that may have had something interesting, but inaccessible so that I didn't have to guess where I wanted to return later on.

On the down side, this was obviously made by a smaller developer, and it shows in the sense that it's missing some of that special sauce in terms of presentation you would expect from a game that was developed with more funds and resources. It's got its own personality, but it's just clearly a work of a more modest budget, which is fine, but sometimes you miss the glitz. But in the bigger picture, I have to acknowledge that it was hard to put down once I started. I played close to 20 hours to complete things, including some side-quests/extras, and I did it all in a pretty short span, so there is no doubt that it kept me engaged all the way through. It's not a classic in the genre, but I don't regret playing it at all, and can certainly recommend it to anyone who considers themselves a fan of the genre. 4/5.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993778444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1647776125}
review:
I'm gonna start by summing up why I would not recommend this game: tedious.

Every aspect of the game feels like a chore rather than a fun challenge. Every game design decision feels like it is made to just make the player's life a tedious grind rather than a fun exploration RPG.

Here's more details on why I felt that way.



Level design

The  platforming in this game is incredibly tight. Most of the actions you're required to do to progress have very little leeway. Rooms are littered with mostly small platforms that quickly just become 1 character-length blocks as you progress.
And when you think it can't be worse, the game adds more obstacles because, for some reason, it felt like it was still too fun.

Of course, around those small plaftorms are traps and other mecanics like crumbling or timed platforms that will make it even harder not to fall.
You will eventually get an upgrade allowing you to grab on ledges, but not all platforms are eligible
Also you'd better not want to do any other action, like attacking, during that jump because you cannot attack and grab in the same leap (unlike most other games of the genra.)

But if you fail you'll just have to try again right ?
Yeah, but you'll also pretty much always take damage because the floor is lava in most of the rooms.

Of course, a fair number of rooms are also designed in a way where if you fall, you have to redo the whole room from the start without any single mistake.

Coupled with the constantly tight platforming and traps that will undoubtedly make you fall relatively often, the level design and platforming is tedious.


But can it be that bad to take damage and retry when you have an RPG system to heal and become stronger ?
Why yes, it can.



RPG & Combat

Stronger is not the word I would use to describe the combat progression in this game.
Levelling is grindy from the start. And while it does provide a much needed full heal on level up, one will find out that you do not gain level often enough that it will actually save them much.

Levelling up also feels underwhelming. You don't get much stats and/or it doesn't seem to make your combat abilities that much stronger. 
At some point I even cheated to get from level 19 to level 49 and saw that my damage had gotten from 40 to 57 with the same weapon.
And while I would accept some grind to get there, I did cheat for one reason: XP given by mobs decrease with each level you gain. 
So to attain that level 49, which was around 100 000xp when I was at less than 10 000, I would have had to defeat around 80 000 enemies since they would have started to each give me 1xp per kill by the time I had gained a few levels.

Levelling is tedious, and the rewards do not justify the investment.


And then there's combat.
Your character doesn't feel like a brick, but they do not feel nimble either.
If you're not constantly jumping while attacking, you'll get hit because of the delay at the end of your attacks.
There is no backdash cancel, so most of the time it you timed your attack wrong you're done. No way for you to avoid damage.
You also have to constantly keep close to mobs if you actually want to hit. No matter what your weapon is, your range is very limited and mobs will have better range than you most often that not.

Basically you have to git gud pretty fast, otherwise combat will be you attacking the air while mobs bash you from a safe distance.
Also their AI is better than you. They know their perfect distance of attack and use it constantly.

On another note they also have a tendancy to stay on the side of the platforms you wanna go to, so that you'll either abort your jump or take recoil damage from them when platforming.
Of course, you'll end up in the pit of instant DOT damage whenever that happens.

Back on combat a fair number of mobs are either faster than you or have ranged attacks, making them even more of a bother with your very limited range and not so nimble movements.

As for you, you have one ranged option: magic. However, magic is a misnamer because it's actually just throwable items that consume mana, and it's not mana but actually ammunitions.
Basically it's not mana: it's the heart system from castlevania games. It throws some manner of distance weapon that consume a fixed number of "mana" point, that you can ony recover from drops on mobs or breakable lights. No "mana" regen there: it's just ammunition-based.
So yeah, you have a relatively limited amount of distancee options, and the drop-rate is too low to make it worth it. Also you don't get a free refill when you level up, unlike HP.

And that's it for your combat capabilities. You're pretty limited while mobs can outrange and outspeed you constantly. So you keep taking damage all the time unless you play like a god.

I forgot to mention that mobs and traps hit for usually around 5~10% of your HP. So 20 "mistakes" (or unfair platforming moments, or mobs that outspeed and outrange you) and you're dead.

Of course, there is no option to regen your HP that would sufficiently balance out these losses. You have three possibilities:
-Drop from mobs
-Brought potions
-Save points

Mobs don't drop health items often enough, and obviously if you're already struggling to keep your HPs fighting mobs is not really a viable option.

Potions cost money, and they're not available until you rescued the NPC that sells them. Money is still a drop by the way, but at least you can get it from breakable objects... at a low rate. So it's super grindy and makes the game even more tedious.

Save points will heal you completely, if you can make it back to one before you die. Most of the time you can, of course. However, it's not fun to have to constantly run back to one as the most valid option to get health back. No fun to be found there.


I could go around and describe more of the game, but I've already described the core of any game: its gameplay. And this one feels like a chore to play.

There is a reason why, as I discovered earlier, only 1/4 of players got to the 3rd boss and beat it (the achievement Titan says 24.6% of players did the job)


As such I cannot recommend this game. It is clearly not what I wish to play.

If you're into a challenge, you might find something you like there since the game is indeed challenging. Otherwise, there are other metroidvania games out there that will give you a better experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967997881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1645125749}
review:
I'm sad to say that I cannot recommend this game. This is actually a bad game in my opinion. Lets look at the pros and cons though:

Pro: 
- an excellent pixel artist designed this and the graphics are beautifully drawn (maybe the only selling point of this game)
- The menus and options are well coded, look nice and are easy to use and understand
- There are many different languages you can play this game in

Neutral points:
- the gameplay is solid but also very simple. It gets old very soon. 

Con:
- the music is annoying. You feel like turning off the sound because of it. 
- It feels like you're doing the same thing over and over again with no feeling of accomplishment
- I only played this for an hour but I felt really bored from the repetetive nature of everything. 
- There was no way to speed up the character (maybe it comes later in the game) but it felt exhausting to run around like that for so long
- the game overall seemed to lack originality. 

Very sad to not recommend this even though the graphics are so nicely done. I finally died because of boredom: I kept playing more and more recklessly to make things more interesting. When I died I didnt feel like ever turning it on again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972330714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1369, 'last_played': 1644875162}
review: Chasm may well be the blandest Metroidvania ever: You obtain stereotypical weapons and progress skills (e. g. whips, sub-weapon axe, double jump) to overcome trite enemies and environments (e. g. crawlers, zombies, a mine, a castle). Story and setting are unimaginative, the NPCs are cardboard cutouts and have no notable characterization. Art and animations aren't shabby, but not spectacular, either. The worst part, however, are the stiff controls. I defeated Dracula in the original Castlevania, I survived Dark Souls and I suffered through LaMulana. Neither of these games had great controls, but Chasm manages to be worse still. The floor in Chasm appears to be covered in debilitating superglue that drains the momentum out of your attacks, and the only chance of escape is perpetual jumping - which also seems oddly imprecise. Yes, you can still learn to dodge the well-telegraphed enemy attacks - doing so just doesn't feel fluid and rewarding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043268673', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1643491613}
review:
It has nothing notable: good or bad. A prime example of an average metroidvania game.

A few things I think lead to this being average experience.
[list]
[*] Loot is overall boring slot filler items with RNG stats. I imagine this problem turning worse later, as your drops inevitably start to outperform all the chest loot. 
That leads me to my next point.
[*] Exploration is not rewarded. I've played the game for something like an hour, explored everything I could. I found a bunch of npcs and 4 chests. Only one of those chests had a better item to offer and it soon became obsolete too.
[*] Contact damage. There are very few games that pull off contact damage being fair, and this is not one of them.
[*] Movement is a bit floaty. It's hard to land precise jumps and I bumped into enemies instead of jumping right next to them more than I would like to admit.
[*] Some enemies (including starter ones) don't have obvious tells and openings to react to. So for example, if you enter a room and see a drill goblin standing, there's a very good chance it will move (and hit you before you recover) after your first strike, but if you wait for it to move and stop you can land 2 hits safely.
[*] Attacks have recovery times, which cannot be cancelled by back-dash. Combined with previous problem It just makes combat against some enemies feel unfair unless you're using longer weapons. 
[*] It's probably just me, but I got tired of mine music in like 10 minutes.
[/list]

Don't get me wrong, it's not a BAD game. Enemies have readable behaviors, character controls are passable and there ARE metroidvania style ability-gated chests, but this is literally what every game in the genre does. I couldn't see a single thing this game does different or better than competitors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963287051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1641186337}
review: If you like Symphony of the Night and its successors, you will probably enjoy Chasm. The movement and combat mechanics in particular show direct inspiration and will seem immediately familiar and comfortable to anyone who's played the later Castlevanias. The movement upgrades, unfortunately, aren't especially well-done: As the game progresses, it tends to become slightly less enjoyable to move around in, as you get different types of wall grab which behave unpredictably differently and clunky glide mechanics, with the ever-so-vital double-jump unlocked only quite late in the game. The randomization seems to be minimal, and overall I felt it slightly overstayed its welcome, but the solid mechanics and great soundtrack and art made Chasm an overall very enjoyable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018275730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1642275101}
review:
Middling.

Procedural generation doesn't actually add much variety to your playthrough due to hard gated progression items. You cannot deviate from the developer's intended path.Map is composed of sprawling corridors which makes backtracking a chore.

Combat feels a little stuff due to lack of backdash cancels, hard animation locks on most weapons. 

Pacing is disappointing. A new weapon is immediately invalidated in a new area as the hp/damage of enemies takes a stark jump, making you never truly feel like you are getting stronger until the very end game. RPG elements have little impact on the game besides the hp/mp replenish upon level up. Your stats are truly dictated by gear and little else. Not really enough unique weapons and armour. Somewhat long for a game of this type (10hrs), due to how the game progression is locked behind specific items and powerups.

Despite this, its still a decent metroidvania. I'd only ever really consider it if it was on sale.

review:
Truly a great and (IMO) underrated (or under the radar?) game!!
Chasm is a metroidvanian game that plays just like the old games back in the day, especially Castlevania : Symphony of the Night. 

So if you are a 90's kid like me, and you played and liked Castlevania. This feels at home.

Apart from that, the art-style of this game reminiscences the classic JRPG looks (Xenogear, FF tactics, etc). Made me  feel like a teenage boy  even more. It truly brought a satisfying smile to me when the credits rolled.

I recommend playing this game on Hard difficulty. Just do it. Buy it! play the hell out of it!  :)

review:
7/10 "The pixel art is the best part of the game"

My biggest gripe with Chasm and probably the reason many people gave it a harsh review, it's that Chasm takes way too long to get as fun as it should be from the beginning, I feel like the many movement tools the game gives the player as you progress make combat a lot more interesting and fun just like the weapons you obtain in the later stages, which are more unique and should have been obtained way earlier into the game.

However, it takes quite a while to get there and the first half felt completely stale in my opinion while the second half feels quite awesome, there also little details such as a lack of atmosphere in sound design, decent, but underwhelming music, boring and annoying backtracking and grind, combat system doesn't feel as fluid as I had wished, etc.

review:
It's a good game worth picking up when it's on sale (I got it for under $9). It took me just under 15 hours to complete with 18/20 achievements.

I enjoyed the art style and variety of enemies a lot. The difficulty was just right for me (not trivial but not unforgiving either). The exploration is fun for the most part but could use some quality of life improvements to reduce the amount of time you're just running the full way back and forth between rooms and save points, especially if you want to unlock all the optional stuff such as the [spoiler]sword of light[/spoiler]. The items are interesting and unique and the optional quests and unlocks felt worthwhile.

One thing for me that would have been a huge improvement is the different gear actually appearing on your character model.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985802948', 'num_games_owned': 962, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1640304477}
review:
Razor's edge positive recommendation. 

It's just not finished. By the time it's over it feels like the 30% point of a much grander adventure. The randomly generated maps are boring to traverse and feel empty. It also seems to take clear inspiration from Casltevania: Circle of the Moon, where progression is gated by unlocking abilities specifically meant to force backtracking rather than actually make the gameplay more varied and fun.

Looks good, combat is okay but needs more enemy/weapon/magic variety, and has decent music, but is sorely lacking in the parts needed to make it feel complete. C+ if you're desperate for new 2D action-exploration games but there's so many others to choose from. It's not terrible but it's definitely disappointing that it never reaches its true potential.

review: Chasm is an extremely fun Rogue-lite dungeon crawler. You play as the top knight recruit your outpost has seen in many years. You are sent to investigate disappearances at the nearby mining town that your outpost relies on for ore. You will face monsters, puzzles, traps, and more! Dungeons are procedurally generated depending on the seed assigned your game when you start it. Explore, survive, and rescue! The controls are more fluid than any other game I've played so far in my life. The execution is simple, but varied and the replay value is through the roof. I cannot recommend this enough. If you have a chance to check Chasm out, please do so! You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199008688025', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1706819623}
review:
This game does not deserve the bad rap it had gotten at release. IIRC, I think there was confusion over the proc-gen elements of the game? Regardless, Chasm is a fun Metroidvania romp that stands well on its own.

You take control of a lone Squire, spelunking through mysterious biomes deep beneath a mining town. With each new file, the stages shuffle about their layout and the locations of key items and townsfolk to rescue. Each member of town has a small sidequest line, and many of them offer supplies to the hero. Along the way you will uncover lore about the civilization that lived in this region before... and its dark secrets.

Gameplay-wise, the game is a comfy one for those well-versed in Igavanias. There's a bigger precedence of finding items in various spots, or as enemy drops, than buying stuff. It's closer in feel to Order of Ecclesia or Symphony of the Night in that regard than other Castlevania titles. The weapons you wield also reflect that series -- swords and maces swung laterally, fast daggers and knuckles for up-close carnage, overhead-swung great weapons, forward-thrust polearms, and even long-ranged whips can all be brandished! There are few subweapons to use your MP on, upgraded over time -- three staple Castlevania sidearms, with three unique ones.

Exploration is both exciting and challenging. Resources aren't so easy to come by, so every potion or food item you can secure will matter. Bosses are a test of your skills, but just getting to those battles won't be a walk in the park. Varied enemies, environmental obstacle courses and punishing hazards stand in your way. Because the maps change each time you start a new file, you can't always rely on the layouts you'd encountered in past runs. Add in the optional "classes" you can pick from for replay run -- a warrior, a magician, a thief, or the default jack-of-all-trades -- and your skills will be put to the test plenty of times. And if you seek additional glory and tests of skill? Chasm also provides daily and weekly challenges of predetermined maps!

In the end, Chasm is a fun adventure for a seasoned Igavania vet. Familiar mechanics come together with fresh ideas and procedurally-generated dungeons for plenty of adventures ahead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047740091', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1653, 'last_played': 1638570850}
review:
SUMMARY:

Chasm is your typical hack-n-slash metroidvania game. Start off with minimal abilities, progress through the dungeon, and unlock new skills to help you proceed further and uncover new hidden rooms and content. The only drawback to this game compared to others of this genre is the level of difficulty. During my time playing, it didn't provide much in terms of a challenge and was pretty easy to beat.

THE GOOD:

Chasm does a really great job making you feel like you're on an adventure. You have a small town (your hub) that slowly updates and adds new content/shops as you proceed further into the mines and rescue villagers. You find a nice variety of equipment along the way, as well. The best part being weapons. Each weapon has its own unique speed and style. This, along with a variety of spells, makes combat very fun.

The visuals and artwork is also well done. The first thing I noticed was the fact that each room has it's own unique backdrop. I found this to be a nice feature because it really helped immerse me into the world your main protagonist is exploring. The animations (character and enemy) is very fluid and feels balanced. Enemy deaths are done very well and gives you a sense of accomplishment when you defeat them.

Finally, there's plenty of places to explore and secrets to unlock. This is definitely not lacking in Chasm. You'll uncover tons of hidden chests, items and rooms, with some needing to be returned to once you acquire a specific item (just like most metroidvania games).

THE BAD:

The difficulty. While there were some mobs that gave me some challenge when I first encountered them, their move sets were easily learned and avoidable. I figured, at this point, maybe the bosses were going to be a challenge. That was not the case. I beat each boss (with the exception of the final boss) my first go. I did, however, beat the final boss on my second attempt.

Backtracking. This is very common in metroidvania games and the one part that I absolutely cannot stand, and Chasm doesn't hold back here. It's very common for you to unlock a new area, find climbing gear, and have to backtrack two floors just to unlock another chest... and then proceed further into the new area you unlocked. While many enjoy this, I find it to be repetitive and boring. Especially since you fight the same mobs, which at this point... only take 1 hit in a game that already presented little to no challenge. This would have been better if newer, stronger enemies showed up in the older zones, making them more enjoyable to re-explore.

And finally... armor. While it does increase your overall defense, magic resistance, luck, speed, and other stats... Chasm is missing the one thing I love about most adventure games... your character's look changing. It would have been a nice feature, especially since you find so many different types of helmets/hats and armor. Even a basic color change, or additional shoulder pad, belt, maybe some texture updates to your current look, would have helped. This isn't important to a lot of people, but I've always enjoyed it because it keeps your character interesting, and makes you feel like you're becoming more powerful as you venture further into the game.

CONCLUSION:

The good definitely outweigh the bad. Overall, I highly recommend this game. It's done very well, has some fun combat, and the story is interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268936773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1637872860}
review:
I'm not going to reccomend for or against Chasm, it does plenty of things well but also does some things vary badly.

So, where to start ... Chasm is a metroidvania in the Castlevania style. Lots of equipment options, inventory with recovery and utility items, backdash, et. cetra. This extends to mp being reminiscent of hearts in Castlevania installments with a Bellmont protagonist. Level design is above average, but the randomized tile placement holds it back somewhat. Enemy design is an extremely mixed bag, with plenty being "fair" enemies that can be defeated without taking damage with skill and observation of attacks - but many enemies being "unfair", either by having extremely brief delays between their tells and attacks, or charging the player - but having more hp to reasonably destroy before they make contact. A large portion of the problem with enemy design is the arsenal of weapons and abilities given to the player - all weapons are short range except the occassional whip (and a single, endgame weapon), and spells' are backloaded - requiring chunks of your precious mp (which does not regenerate on it's own), needing spell upgrades to become useful and being extremely reliant on equipment to deal adequate damage. This game is enjoyable if your a longtime fan of Castlevania series, but is generally worse than any 2d sidescrolling chapter of that franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088209673', 'num_games_owned': 733, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 1405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1405, 'last_played': 1636216118}
review:
Chasm is a metroidvania style game that is surprisingly in a class of it's own in some ways it plays well, the upgrades are really nice both in terms of progression and in how it makes travelling around the world a lot easier in the earlier levels, the equipment is varied but they do something I'd like to see more often in metroidvania style games and that's having blue (rare) and gold (legendary) equipment which can have increased stats of a varied nature allowing for different styles of play whether it is purely offensive, or even defensive dood.

That said there are some issues with the game, for starters no NG+ (new game plus) now granted believe it or not if this wasn't a seeded game (Maps are randomly generated) I would say that's fine, NG+ is needed even if it's a nice bonus but the thing is most people don't want to lose all their progress to start from the beginning, this especially hurts the Blue and Gold equipment mechanic as they are extremely hard to attain in the first place which leads me to the drop rates being a bit too abysmal for a one run game, it's the kind of thing where if the game were multiple runs and you could restart on harder modes on  new seed for better levels and the like it would be fine but that just isn't the case and you could easily never come across a gold item if you just run through dood.

All in all it's a great game despite those flaws, if you play I suggest not grinding too much unless you are a trophy hunter as you will have more fun just playing the game with the drop rates, although even despite that my main suggestion is to not go for gold equipment unless you really have some free time and are desperate for that one item you super love, especially as the effects are random and no one want's to have a high INT build on a strength/ATK build character, keep that in mind and you're in for some real fun times with monsters with cool designs and attack patterns and some decently okay music dood ^-^

author: {'steamid': '76561198062872937', 'num_games_owned': 1186, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1635425181}
review:
This game is the most grindy and repetitive mess of an indie pixel game I've had the displeasure of having to try and beat for the sake of my completionist personality but in the end its just not worth it and I will stop roughly around the final boss area of the game because I dont see this as being enjoyable to play in the slightest. the weapons are unenjoyable the spells are underwhelming the armor and accessories might as well not even be part of the game since it has no impact on your characters looks at all and most of the enemies are put in some really frustrating positions given the clunky and sometimes unresponsive controls on PC, lack of Iframes also is a huge negative for me like why even have this back dash dodge maneuver if it doesn't provide any real benefit to the player.

Conclusion: this game had potential but with how it insists on this gimmick of procedural generation and how it has a very poor tutorial and direction in general for the player I'm going to have to say nah pass on this game its not worth your time or money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095752373', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1633695535}
review:
I really enjoyed playing this game (finished it once 100%, no replays)
I played the 1.079 version.

The good:
- The generated map that I got with my playthrough very enjoyable.
- Combat is easy, but enjoyable (all enemies have clear tells)
- Platforming with tight controls, I never missed a w
- The art direction : graphics + music.
- Ingame hints are very clear, no need for walkthrougs to 100% this.
- The game provides enough additional modes/content to spice up any replays.

The average:
- The story is basic, but provides just enough atmosphere.
- The swords are clearly the best weapons, you will probably only play with the other weapons if you want to challenge yourself.

The bad:
- Bossfights are very easy, because you can tank damage like a champ due to the abundance of food items (like in Bloodstained), but you can up the challenge yourself by refusing to use food items.
- The shovel mechanic, why do you need to equip this item.
- No quick respawn upon death, manual reload needed. This does not occur a lot because the game is not very hard.

The game is slow, most enemies will either be extremely useless or spam you with all the projectiles in the world. Mobility is non-existant, you move slow as hell, the levels are all straight lines or loops with the occasional side rooms. Music track is not worthy either. The weapons are pitiful and boring, the spells are dumb and boring. The bosses are boring.

In short. Boring. 3/10. The last 2 levels are somewhat decent. For the same prices, you can get spectacular games. Look for these instead. I got to the ending boss, fought him twice and didn't have the heart to finish the job because it's just a lame-dummazz giant flower that cycles between projectiles attack on a tiny platform. Lame. It took me 5.7 hours to reach him, so at least the game has the courtesy of being short and not wasting too much of my time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165915226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1383, 'last_played': 1634717812}
review: I want to like Chasm. I really do. The art style is fluid and expressive, the weapon variety is large, there's a lot of lore and story to sink your teeth into... But it fails at so much of the basics of a metroidvania, heck, even of a 2D platformer. There's a very noticeable stiffness to the controls, with such a lack of animation cancelling that you can often end up swinging your sword in the wrong direction because the game just didn't register the input. Low ceilings plague the platforming, often causing you to whiff easy jumps. And there are just so many poison pits. And that's not even to mention the underwhelming procedural generation. You end up with several bespoke maps that connect entirely incoherently, when not bookending one another, and you're left with a good looking game that has uninteresting and bland maps which plays like a slower, stiffer Symphony Of The Night. It is almost a passable game, it is so close to being something I can recommend but it just falls below the mark.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020092160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1702948855}
review:
[h1] Chasm is a mixed bag, and getting an informed opinion on the game is a challenge in and of itself. [/h1]

Many critics of Chasm cite the game's procedural nature as its downfall. I partially disagree. The main criticism I would leverage towards Chasm is a lack of character, primarily within its environments. It is certainly possible that the lack of character found could be a result of the game's roguelike nature, but I do not think that has to necessarily be the case. A game like Darkest Dungeon uses randomized dungeon layouts, encounters, etc., all while having incredibly memorable dungeon environments. Chasm has the impossible task of competing with environments from its predecessors, namely Castlevania. Games such as Super Castlevania and Symphony of the Night have some of the best environments, and presentations in general, of any game I've played, old or new. Chasm has subpar environments, most of them feeling like stock fantasy cliches: the abandoned mine, the crypt, the castle, etc. These environments have been used time and time again, which is fine, as they are archetypal of the genre for a reason. However, Chasm does nothing special to integrate these environments into the world it has created.

The setup for clearing out these environments is forgettable. The game's story is told through various NPC's, none of which have any charisma. Additionally, there are lore pamphlets scattered throughout each dungeon, but they do not tell a compelling narrative. I feel what was missed in Chasm's story can be summed up in one word: emotion. At no point did I feel anything for anyone found within the game. If you are the kind of person who prefers lore to dialogue, maybe there is something here for you. There was nothing here for me, and what was there was often grating.

In summary, Chasm's environments are bland and its story lacking. What this game accels at is its combat design. Classicvania games are a bit one note, in that their enemies are all dealt with in more-or-less the same manner: whip them before they reach you. There is some variety in what angle enemies approach from, but rarely do enemies deviate from simply moving towards the player. Beyond its most basic adversaries, Chasm's enemies have differing methods of attacking the player. It is not uncommon for an enemy to retreat from the player for a few steps, and then wind up for a lunge before retreating again. Some enemies advance, some enemies retreat, some enemies lunge, some enemies move steadily but quickly, etc. What is important here is that the player must utilize the game's mechanics in order to overcome these enemies efficiently. There are many instances in which if one were to swing multiple times at an enemy, one would have to utilize Chasm's backdash in order to escape retaliation. Walking backwards or jumping would not be sufficient. With other enemies, ducking is required. Others still, jumping over them. The list goes on. What is important here is that there is legitimate interaction between the player and their opponents. No one strategy beats all enemies, and the core mechanics cannot be ignored. The sad reality is that this is not often the case in the genre, as most developers do not understand how the tools they have given the player function, and therefore do not design the player's enemies around those tools. Chasm is one of the few exceptions to this trend. Not all enemies are a dps race, not all enemies can simply be jumped over. Each interaction is unique.

It is worth mentioning that Chasm is deceptively challenging. The game gifts the player enough health to cover for many of their mistakes, but mastering the game is quite difficult. One of the reasons for this is that Chasm's protagonist is at a range deficit in comparison to virtually every other metroidvania hero I'm aware of. Chasm's protagonist has very stubby limbs, and the reach of something like a knife, or even a shortsword, is extremely small. These shorter weapons, particularly the knives, daggers, and gauntlets, tend to have insane damage potential. This means that in order to be optimal, one must be incredibly precise with their spacing, lest the player run into their opponents and take damage. Chasm is a game that rewards skill, and has a fairly high skill ceiling, which is somewhat uncommon for the genre, outside of self-imposed challenges, like speedrunning. However, I would have preferred the difficulty settings change more than just health and damage. While these changes are fine, I would have liked to see easier difficulty settings make things like reacting and dodging easier for newer players, whilst also speeding up enemies on harder difficulties. Oddly enough, the former is actually possible once one has beaten the game. After completing the game, the player unlocks the ability to select a class. Doing so will grant the player various buffs and debuffs that cater to a specific playstyle. Specifically, the Warrior Class will allow the player to swing faster, which in turn means kill enemies faster and have more time to dodge attacks, as you spend less time in the swing animation. A Warrior's lack in magic is hardly missed, and I would consider the Warrior Class to be something of an "Easy Mode." Unfortunately, this is locked away until you have beaten the game already, making it pointless as a new-player aide. Admittedly, that was not class mode's intention, and this was merely an example of how I would have made the game easier for newer players, rather than an implication that class mode was somehow an oversight.

Even as I write this review, I am debating whether or not to recommend the title. While the combat design is great, the game as a whole is lackluster. I have only chosen to revisit the game due to its Arcade Mode, which lets you play the game as a roguelike, and compete for highscores. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a Castlevania-esque game with excellent combat. If you are the type of person who does not have any qualms with the combat in other metroidvania games, particularly in the Castlevania series, and plays these games for exploration, story, setting, etc., than I would not recommend Chasm. Luckily, there is a demo, so if you are on the fence, I would recommend checking it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078034751', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 1705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1705, 'last_played': 1633786254}
review:
I'm not a big fan of metroidvania genre, I haven't played a lot of them. Only other metroidvania I've played was Hollow Knight and I couldn't make myself finish it when it turned out I was farming for an item I didn't need at the time to progress with the game. This one however I finished and I enjoyed it for the most part even though I had some issues with it.
First of all the retro graphics are really enjoyable and the game has 6 biomes You go through when You progress through the game. Soundtrack isn't the best but has some variations depending on the biome You're on and the music for Boss fights is there.
The story is simple but there's some lore in the Journal entries that You can find across the map. The NPCs offer You 1 side quest each which reward You with some consumable items, gold or an additional option unlocking for some of the NPCs. I felt rewarded for doing the side quests which helped in progressing through the game later on. Side quests aren't a big part of the game but give You some options.
There are plenty of weapons and equipment to choose from. While the drop rates might not encourage You to farm some of the items, You'll definitely feel rewarded with some of the Boss drops if You can kill them without taking damage. The Bosses mechanics are made in a way that You can learn them and evade most of the attacks if You wish so. The thing that was lacking for me in terms of equipment and items was that the NPCs have a limited supply of items which can be used for Crafting Gear or Upgrading Spells. You can farm a lot of weapons that just doesn't feel good to play with even though their stats are much greater than Your current weapon so You sell them and buy items that would allow You to craft more suitable weapon - but the item supply is really low.
The Spells aren't really overpowered or useless - some are more useful some are less but they're always helpful in getting rid of mobs in places You cannot reach because You would have to tank damage on contact. I saw someone complaining about having to grind money to buy gems needed to upgrade the Spells. That's not the case in the current build anymore - supply of gems you can buy from NPC is so limited that you could probably upgrade only one Spell to max level. I didn't have much trouble upgrading the Spells as I got plenty of them dropped from the mobs instead.
The replayability is there for some extent but it wasn't enough for me to play the game for more time after getting 100% achievements. Still I was enjoying my second run where I got some of the rooms with the traps a little easier to pass through. I also did every Boss that had no hit challenge without taking damage to get the drop and test it out and it felt really rewarding after beating the [spoiler]Titan[/spoiler] boss and getting op weapon.
The last of the issues I had with the game was poor map navigation for me. Some of the areas that are required to pass through to progress with the game aren't marked on the map. One area that isn't needed to progress with the game but is needed to 100% the game is also not marked. I had a lot of trouble running through almost whole levels again when I got abilities that let me get to the places I couldn't get before because I couldn't find the right area. If You're playing the game for the first time just remember there is a SET MARKER option. Remember to set markers in one room levels that are needed to progress with the game so You won't have to search for them for a long time. Here are the areas if You're wondering: [spoiler] area to place the Black Feather[/spoiler], [spoiler]area to place the Black Gem[/spoiler], [spoiler]area with the Gate and a sign next to it[/spoiler], [spoiler]tower area with 4 bells[/spoiler]. Also remember that treasures, Journal entries and other stuff is marked with 1 pixel in the middle of the square on the map and that the passages are marked with a hole on the border of the areas. You should also remember that if You have a blue square on Your map without an arrow and an icon indicating which area it leads to - it's probably a place You didn't go to. Just an advice from someone who got lost more than he should've.
With all of the above being said, I've enjoyed playing this game. The story was small but fun to play through, combat felt rewarding and the equipment pool was big enough for me. Drop rates didn't really matter that much to me as I mostly used long range weapons to avoid the contact damage. Crafting needs a lot of grinding and NPCs item supply is really limited and that could feel dissapointing. Navigating the map in Your first playthrough might be hard so I hope the tips I gave You help You even if just a bit. The game is a bit unpolished with all the stuff I talked about but it's really enjoyable so give it a try.

review:
It's an OK Metroidvania game, but it got nothing special about it and the reason is the inherent limitation that comes with the world being procedurally generated each time you start a new game.

This games was influenced by games like Castlevania Symphony of the Night and Order of Ecclesia -  exploring different environments, rescuing NPCs and find new equipment and unlocking new abilities to progress further.

You may find different environments in the game with the area specific mobs in them but you won't get special elements in the level design that would make them stand out from other environments other then the background and mobs.

For what it's worth I did have fun with the game for what it is.

review:
Positives (good and quirky alike): Really good game if you like games like handheld castlevanias which felt like the main inspiration. Crisp movement and abilities. Something is ever so slightly off with spamming attacks which makes it not seemless to do so, both on controller and keyboard. Wished there were more secrets and hidden away stuff. Found it interesting/strange that a couple potions had only a one off use pretty much. Lots of enemy variation. Not too long of a game, seems well paced. 

Negatives (well one negative really) The one and only bad part of the game is the horrible item droprate, you can and will have to spend 2-3 levels to get both drops from some enemies. Luckscrolls seems to do nothing in regards to this issue and they are a finite resource too. Farmed for 2 levels with 80 luck much of the time thanks to all the luckscrolls. Still no itemdrop. Ended up reloading just to keep the scrolls. Used em all up again at another place with nothing to show for it. Seriously, this really bad if you want to make a complete savefile. I myself gave up on it since it got so bad and ive farmed all bestiaries and drops for completion in all handheld castlevanias which i find very fun. Here however I just cant justify doing the same, due to how extremely awfully elusive the drops are.
