author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 1685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1685, 'last_played': 1632651489}
review:
[b]Playing status:[/b] 100% achievement, 2x playthroughs
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (13 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (1 achievement).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Chasm[/b] is a metroidvania game where you play as a knight delving into a chasm that leads to various regions. There are 5+1 explorable regions with a boss fight at the end of each region.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 4 difficulties
- Enemies and bosses with unique attack patterns
- Various weapons with different range and attack speed
- Bonus reward for exploring optional areas

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Sometimes it's hard to know where to go next
- You need to get used to the dodge mechanic to utilize it properly
- The game can be a bit grindy at harder difficulties
- No save point before the last boss fight

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like to play metroidvanias, buy this game. Achievement hunters need to be skilled at the genre or risk grinding for drops and enemies and/or retrying the same areas several times.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
A lot of care was taken into both backgrounds and characters, allowing you to see the beautifully crafted regions. Backgrounds are made in great detail with multiple layers to give some sort of depth to them while still having a unique theme for each region. It's nice to see the variations given for the enemies too. Some enemies might be of the same type, but they are made differently to distinguish them from the other.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story is well written to give some context on what's happening. On the surface, [b]Chasm[/b] tells the story of a young knight that embarks on his first mission. Most dialogues are skippable for those who are not interested in such things, although people who want to know more can find more info in the form of journals scattered in the regions. I still didn't make out how the whole thing happened even after reading them, but at least you get the idea of what's happening before the main character comes into play.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
The game is played like other metroidvanias, featuring interconnected areas with some that require certain items to progress. More items will be obtained as you play, allowing you to reexplore these areas to get optional rewards. However, some of these areas are mandatory to explore, and the game never gives any indication about it. There were times when I was stuck in the game simply because I wanted to obtain as many items as I could before reexploring previous regions.

The game might be randomized on each run, but I don't find the randomization to be that appealing. They only randomized some rooms while still leaving the important rooms intact. I know that it might be difficult to randomize everything, especially since some areas are tied to progression, but I'd rather play the game without any randomization instead.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612663786

The areas can be difficult to traverse at higher difficulties, mainly because of enemies that can damage you for 1/4 of your HP pool with a single attack. You'll end up traversing checkpoints to checkpoints later on, retrying it several times until you can clear it without dying if you are not good enough. Sadly, you are forced to load your latest save whenever you die, so the amount of time that you took to retry these areas can turn into waste. You can always try to consume potions and items to prevent dying, but since the game isn't generous in giving them nor money that can be used to buy them, you might need to grind to afford it, especially if you use it since the first few regions.

Some platforming sections can be dreadful for those who are not good at platformers. Luckily, most of them are optional and serve as a test to give you some rewards. Moreover, they tend to give non-unique items that can be easily obtained elsewhere, so there's little reason to get them if you know what the chest contains.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612663847

Different types of weapons allow you to choose your weapon of preference. [b]Chasm[/b] offers various weapons with different attacking ranges and speeds, with a shorter range weapon having a faster speed and a broader range weapon having a lower speed. I myself got used to a one-handed sword due to its faster attacking speed and tolerable range, although it might be problematic to use for flying enemies; they might slip from my attacking range and deals a lot of damage from that.

[b]Combat[/b]
Enemies are varied and unique. This applies to all enemies, including the normal enemies. Their attacks might seem to be impossible to dodge at first, but there is always a way to defeat them, whether it's by using your weapon or magic. It's fun to learn how their attack works and how to dodge them. The game has somewhat of a difficulty spike in the third region though since there is one enemy that can't be killed without taking damage due to their way of walking.

Bosses can be tough to beat. All bosses have different and varied attack patterns that need to be dodged. Some attacks can even fill the whole screen, forcing you to dodge them just like in bullet hell games. Luckily, they can always be cheesed with potions if you have a problem with them. In fact, I even used potions on the final boss fight because the save point before the fight is very far from it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612663841
[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in the hard difficulty in 21.8h and replayed the game again in the easy difficulty for an achievement in 6h. The game offers 4 difficulties, with hard being the third hardest and easy being the easiest difficulty. To be honest, I found the hard difficulty to be hard. I had trouble clearing the area several times and got bored playing the game because of it. It wasn't fun to retry the area several times and rely on your luck to not getting hit. You can always use potions for these, but I chose not to use them before the very last region because money are quite scarce. You might need to farm money for it, and I'm already occupied with farming enemies to level up and raise my stat already.

Enemies drop rare, unique items. You might spend a significant amount of time grinding for the same enemies over and over to get that rare drop, or even grind enemies just to fulfill a weapon's requirements to make it stronger. Moreover, the game also has some sort of level system, so you might even need to level up a few times just to be strong enough to clear the areas in a harder difficulty. Luckily, I only had a problem with this in my hard run. The game becomes more enjoyable in the easy difficulty too since I didn't have to spend time reloading my save over and over because of stupid mistakes.

[b]Problems[/b]
Dodging can take time to get used to. You didn't get an iframe for dodging and pressing the left button while dodging will move your character to the right since it always moves backward from where you are facing.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Chasm[/b] is a solid metroidvania for all kinds of people. The difficulty helps to adjust it for different kinds of people, while those who still want an extra challenge can try to beat the bosses without taking damage and get rewarded for it. Moreover, there's also a roguelike mode that can wipe your save if you die if you want to activate it.

The game can be hard at first, but it is fair. Enemies that seem to be impossible to hit with your sword can encourage you to try different weapons or magic, while others that have complicated attack patterns can be dodged if you know what you are doing. I could easily recommend this to those who like metroidvanias, especially the difficult ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013961319', 'num_games_owned': 1497, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1630714181}
review:
A solid metroidvania, but it doesn't really add anything new to the formula. It plays pretty much exactly like an amalgamation of the latter Igavanias to a degree that makes me think the developers didn't really know what elements made those games good. The fact that the games it's aping are so good means it inherits a lot of that quality, but if you didn't really like metroidvanias I don't think I could recommend the game. 

Without playing through multiple times, and I don't intend to, I can't comment much on a lot the game design. In my playthrough there were often enemy placements that felt unfair or at least not how a human would design them. If the game is composed of room-tiles, this would be a knock against it, but if it's composed to sub-room-tiles, it's fine, I guess. It feels like a lot of effort that could have gone into the procedural design would have probably been better spent on proper level design and content. The game feels a bit sparse, with a relative lack of items compared to the games it's imitating, which makes the exploration feel less rewarding. Drop rates seem really low, which is fine in an Igavania where you're given a compelling reason to backtrack and a long list of items from a large list of enemies, but less so when there's just so little to obtain. The balance always felt a bit off, not too difficult, but I guess that might just be because of the procedural generation.

Overall, a fine game to play through once if you like metroidvanias, which I do, but probably not worth it otherwise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972303784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1630854263}
review:
Chasm isn't perfect:  Certainly things like the 60 fps lock (including the reason it's there) isn't ideal, but overall I'd say it's a fine game.

It has good balance too.  Nothing is slanted against the player in an unfair way.  There's a little bit of grinding necessary if you want to keep high defense at all times but just a minor change would fix that issue and it only wasted about 30 minutes of my time anyways.

One solid criticism I do have for the game is the lack of in-game markers for the map.  The map is great about labeling rooms with chests you haven't gotten yet but I'd still like to be able to mark the map myself to add notes like "need double-jump" or "need slide" for later.  This is especially bad in this case because the map is randomized for every player based on a text-string seed minecraft-style, so there isn't an online map/guide you can look over.

If you like metroidvanias then you should have a fun 10-15 hours with this game doing a run.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070842180', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1606971774}
review:
I went into Chasm pretty excited; For a while I had considered the idea of a rogue-like Metroidvania where each playthrough shuffles the map and collectibles to be great idea that I was surprised hadn't been done. So learning a game did exactly what I was thinking of was like a match made in heaven! Add some very lovely visuals and themes and you get what should have been a new all-time favorite... So what went wrong?

Well, technically speaking, nothing. Chasm didn't do anything particularly wrong, but it didn't do anything particularly right.

Chasm's primary concept doesn't quite work; Randomized level design is, on paper, a good idea but in practice Chasm's room design is repetitive, flat, and in no uncertain terms boring. Because of the nature of random generation, each room essentially needs to be built to fit against any other room, and this results in rooms looking, feeling, and in my playthrough literally *being* the same room. I found myself checking the map dozens of times just to make sure I didn't go down the wrong identical hallway.

Because of this level design, item progression and balance are also an issue. One of the biggest selling points in Metroidvanias is the feeling of growing stronger the more you go. To me, part of this is being able to get through rooms faster the more movement options you get, but Chasm fails in this department entirely. All the movement upgrades you get, save for the very last one, almost never resulted in room-traversing getting any faster. And because rooms can be against any other room, it's possible to get gauntlets of long corridors filled with tough enemies with little breathing room, which can result in you wondering if you're under-prepared or just unlucky. This particularly stings early on, where healing options are scarce, with only the occasional save point or random-drop-chance based healing items.

However, Chasm does have it's fair share of good to it as well. For starters, the game looks, sounds, and feels very nice! The sprite work is top-notch, the soundtrack is, admittedly a bit hit-or-miss; The themes of The Keep and The Mines being my personal favorite, and genuinely songs I go back and listen to. And the controls feel very smooth, with few times where I felt they worked against me. And while Chasm's level design is flawed, their method to fast travel was actually very well thought out; Each main area has a main hub with 4 sealed doors, and each door is located in the same area generally on the map itself, giving you an indirect method to knowing where to go; If a door is at the top of the hub, the corresponding door will likely be somewhere north on the map. These hubs also allow fast travel between the main areas of the game, and since the first area's hub houses a save area, these hubs double as healing and progress recording which is all too convenient.

Overall, my opinions on Chasm are very neutral-positive; The game doesn't do anything amazing, and it's only gimmick is it's biggest weakness, but if all you want is a decent Metroidvania that isn't one of the usual big name ones thrown around, go ahead and give Chasm a try, for as simple as it is I still enjoyed my time with it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963366484', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1701990192}
review:
Incredibly boring game that adds nothing to the genre.  Played the game for 3 hours and the character never actually developed any abilities that were remotely interesting or fun to play.  Nearly every item drop in a treasure chest was either a duplicate armor piece or a weapon that did slightly more damage and had a range of 1 pixel.  I had to resort to using the whip weapon which did terrible damage but could actually let me have somewhat of an advantage in combat.  Platforming works most of the time but you will find yourself missing jumps because half of the platforming revolves around grabbing ledges.  You have to actively push in the direction of the ledge in order to grab it, making it incredibly easy to miss a jump.

The game appears to have some kind of mana system although I have no idea how it works or what it is used for.  I imagine that it would give some ranged abilities as your character feels incredibly underpowered with only stubby weapons that take 5 swings to kill something.

I am not a particular fan of Metroidvania games but I can appreciate the genre when it is done right.  This game meets the bare minimum for the genre and seems to take very little risk.  Slogging through the same corridors over and over again is a chore but obviously a staple of the genre as a whole.  

The basic mechanics of this game could function on an NES cartridge and maybe that is the point, but nostalgia shouldn't be the prime motivator to play games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003506597', 'num_games_owned': 1145, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1629655754}
review:
I've beaten this game and it's *okay* but, from a gameplay standpoint, it never rises above that. I really wish I liked this game more than I do, but there are a lot of weird choices that I don't quite agree with.

* Merchants never restock - once you buy out their supply of warp scrolls/baked goods/gems, you're resorting to farming for the rest of the game. Given the amount of times when I was REALLY happy to have a warp scroll and the amount of gems needed to fully level up your magic? Would have been nice to be able to pick some up, even if there was just a fairly long cooldown or something.

* No saves in a late-game zone - One of the late-game zones (the Temple) is a teleporter 'maze' that has you doing a lot of backtracking; it would have been great to have some save rooms here and I'm not certain why they chose to go that direction.

* Meteoric gear - Meteor gear seems to be... pretty useless? Maybe I got lucky by finding a gold crown in the Keep, but between that and a golden hammer (made at the blacksmith way earlier than you get access to meteor ingots) I found myself not even considering going for meteor gear, which is weird because it seems to take so much more effort to farm and is ostensibly a late-game item.

* Movement - The movement is *incredibly* stiff to me; I got used to it after a while, but compared to many other games, it just feels unpleasant. I'm not opposed to stiff movement (I played Dark Souls 1 before coming back to this one), but something just feels off about the movement and end-lag and general control feeling.

Again, I wish I liked this game more, but right now I could only recommend it as a deep, deep sale or part of a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110957387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1629643311}
review:
After finally finishing the game I can share my opinion with you, fellow readers.

Chasm is one of that Metroidvania-Games which try to look good in the store page but don¬¥t do anything special while playing.

  [h1] PROS [/h1]

- The pixel-artstyle isn¬¥t that special, but it looks pretty, aswell as the animations.

- The music (standard and the retro version) is nice, nothing impressive, but atleast they got 
  something right.


  [h1] CONS [/h1]

- Story couldn¬¥t be less relevant in this one.

- The combat  is bland and doesn¬¥t feel completly balanced (stiff and slow).

- Spells feel like a neet extra instead of being essential to the core combat

- Backtracking doesn¬¥t feel fun or accomplishing.

- Everytime you die, you get kicked out into the main menu and need to start the game from 
  the last safe 
  [b] EVERY [/b] [b] DAMN [/b] [b] TIME [/b] instead just respawning quickly, like in all other 
  games from this 
  genre.

- Farming Monsterloot doesn¬¥t feel good at all, cuz of the lack of creativity for the drops.

- The way enemies get much stronger and your equipment completly useless in every new 
   area is ridiculous. 

- Fast travel, but the positioning of it feels off due to the procedurally generated map.

- The areas don¬¥t feel unique, neither do the enemies in their distinct area.
   (Enemies look way too generic)


[h1] LAST WORDS [/h1]

Overall I was hyped when I saw chasm in the store, it looked appealing, but after some hours into the game, it just got boring and frustrating due to the poorly made gameplay. I bought it in sale and I really can¬¥t recommend it for anyone that likes to play Metroidvanias. It does nothing to be in some kind unique to other Metroidvanias or to be a [i] good [/i] game at all, it just tries to be the [u ]most mediocre [/u] one it can be and that¬¥s what bothers me the most.

3/10 wouldn¬¥t play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004515240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2390, 'last_played': 1629580134}
review:
Pretty solid retro-style Metroidvania. Controls are mostly tight aside from some weapons having janky animations or swing speed and this is much more forgiving than a lot of games of this type especially early on, but sweet baby Yoda play this game with a controller and not keyboard and mouse. You can style around short to medium melee either unarmed or with a variety of standard sword & sorcery type weapons or do ranged with magic and you are not really locked out of respeccing or changing things up if you find you prefer one route over another. 

Graphics and music are great, the story is as interesting as it needs to be and there is a fair amount of replayability since most of the dungeons are procedurally generated and you can share seeds or keep track of your favourite ones. 

A few minor complaints are that the game is mostly too easy until quite late even on Hard, and the last significant dungeon is easily the most difficult area of the enitre  game with complex rooms and hard-hitting enemies, has NO save points at all and you really hit this point with no real expectation or warning.  Chasm also falls into the same Metroidvania progression trap of being fairly linear since you need certain abilities to progress further so your playthru will always sequentially be roughly the same even if the layout of your dungeons are different but that's more a flaw of the genre than the game itself. 

If you liked Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night, Hollow Knight, Vigil: The Longest Night or Blasphemous you'll probably enjoy this game.

review:
A good average Metroidvania game. 

I find the procedural generation of the game world more interesting as a piece of marketing ('every single run is unique') than a real thing, since the essential elements of the game are fixed. Furthermore, I would have prefered a fixed map, because It makes doing maps and guides about the game easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986413856', 'num_games_owned': 2330, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1628990739}
review:
An entirely mediocre addition to the metroidvania genre.

The game isnt bad, but incredibly forgettable. After finishing it, all I could say was "Eh. It was a game."
I would say that the best thing about it is the art, but even that is bland and just good enough.

It calls itself a "roguelite", but that is mostly a lie, as most of the game doesnt changes, only a few rooms between key areas. The exception is the Arcade mode, where it is an actual roguelite.

The game feels a bit hard, but you quickly notice that the biggest chunk of the difficulty comes from one place: the main character.
Aside being the most generic main character I have ever seen, he is basically worthless. All I can guess is that they wanted him to die or there wasnt anyone else available at the moment.
He is slow. And I mean SLOW. He runs slowly, he attacks slowly, he cant backstep during attacks and has a huge hitbox.
Before you find the double jump near the end of the game, he is one of the most non-agile character I've ever played as.

This game takes a lot from other metroidvanias, so a lot of stuff isnt original.
The main character has the "motion blur" effect as he moves (even though he runs at a slug pace) and has that fancy slash attack like Alucard's.

You can equip magic spells that are the sub-weapons, but leveling and recharging your MP is all based on luck.
Unlike other Castlevanias, candles only have a chance of dropping MP, and leveling spells are based on random gem drops.

Most of the weapons in the game are also terribly unbalanced. If you dont pick a normal sword, whip or spear, your attacks wont have enough reach. 
Knives are so short that you need to be hugging the enemies to hit them, since the character swings them so close to them. And due his big hitbox, that also means you always take damage.
Maces, axes and broadswords do the overhead swing, but they are even slower, dont do that much extra damage and leaves you open for more attacks, as you cant dodge until the attack animation finishes. By the time you did one swing, you could do three with a normal sword.

If want some metroidvania to play and already finished Hollow Knight, Bloodstained and Momodora, this one exists, but dont expect anything above average.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977668520', 'num_games_owned': 2247, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1628920454}
review:
Quick Summary 7.5/10
Metroidvania with the right amount of heart and soul to make for a fun little romp. The music & pixel graphics while may not be master class is worth the price tag that comes with it. 

Graphics 8/10
Pixel graphics, while maybe not as animated and detailed as in some other games of this genre, the overall job and presentation is still great. Every area feels fresh and fun with little details sprinkled within. The characters/monsters all feel distinct and made for there levels. It's not going to win any awards for being the best pixel graphics, but they get the job done with charm and love. 

Sound/Music: 6/10
The sound effects are adequate for what each thing it's trying to portray while the there is no spoken dialogue in the game. The music however is ok. After a few hours of playing there's quite a few little songs that become kinda catchy and each biome has it's own theme. The jungle one stands out as one that gives me flash backs I swear to "Wild Arms" a JRPG for the psx. 

Story: 6.5/10
You're a would be knight sent out to a small town to help after a attack from some monsters. When you arrive everyone missing. As time goes on you uncover a ancient evil and save the town. It's you're generic fantasy story, but done in just a way that brings it some charm and life. There's notes scattered about that add some lore and townspeople will give you small tidbits here and there. Don't expect deep elements though.

Gameplay: 8/10
A metroidvania with some classic throwbacks. This has a decent set of balance to it, I never felt cheated when I died. Knowing anything done was my mistake and could easily overcome it with time and skill. The boss fights were all fun and had tele-marks to learn. The exploration was the highlight with so many secrets and hidden things to find. Each new item and area felt and flowed well. This is just a really well put together game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972512754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1627867416}
review:
This is almost a good game. It has all the workings of a Metroidvania, but it's missing the mark in quite a few ways.

The ledge grab mechanic is infuriating. For some reason, you have to be falling to grab the ledge and you have to be positioned at a precise pixel to grab it. This makes for frequent misses. Additionally, it rarely doesn't grab it even when you are way above it and hold against the wall the entire time. You end up just falling down past it and in some rooms that is a long fall and a lot of wasted time. If you attack in the air, you also are unable to grab a ledge for quite some time. There's lots of places where you need to do this though, which makes for a poor experience.

There's a bunch of weapons in the game, but so many are unusable. Anything other than spear or sword is either too short range or too slow. Enemies can deal damage to you by just walking into you and the short range weapons don't produce enough knockback to prevent you from being hit during your attack animation. The slow attack speed weapons don't do enough damage to justify the slow attack speed. You can get multiple attacks off with a sword in the time it takes to make one hammer swing and the multiple sword attacks will do more overall damage.

There are rooms that let you go to other areas of the map via shortcuts. This is messy. If you want to go to a specific area of map 3 and you are in map 1, then you have to use the central teleporter, pick map 3, then figure out which door you need to go through to get to the area you want to be. In other Metroidvanias, you would just enter a teleporter and select on the map where you want to go. It's far more efficient and far more intuitive. The first maps version of this room has a save point in it, however none of the others have one. This leads to going through the central teleporter to the first maps room to use the save point and then going back through the central teleporter to the map you were on. If you were going to put a save point in one of these rooms and they are all connected, why not just place one in every one of these rooms to save time?

The bosses in this game are terrible. The mechanics are clunky and the fights end up devolving into attack through the damage and heal up when low health until the boss is dead.

There is a shovel and digging mechanic, but for some reason it's placed in the weapons menu and you have to go into the menu, equip it, dig, go back into the menu, equip your weapon, and then continue on. Why? Make it an artifact that just works when you are over a diggable spot. Press down and attack or something...

Apparently, the layout of the maps are random based on the seed. This explains why I would often find identical rooms and would get confused if I looped around to the same area. I even had some areas that were multiple rooms of the same layout as another spot in the map. It also explains why some rooms have pointless traversal mechanics in them, like a ledge grab spot right next to a pit of acid with no purpose...

author: {'steamid': '76561198019047931', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1683315198}
review:
Lacks meaningful progression. After 4 hours, I never feel like I'm really getting ahead on anything. Spells feel wholly useless because the amount of resources to upgrade them require you to grind out tiny 10 gold bags infinitely to afford materials...

On the whole the game looks really good but I've figure out I am just not having fun with it. Killing enemies should be kind of exciting and yay loot, but it comes more across like an annoying obstacle between me and the next save point so I don't lose all my progress....

It looks pretty, the music in original and retro sounds cool, but even the bosses I find myself just brute forcing with potions. Maybe i just dont like metroidvanias that much, idk. Bloodstained was fun because I could throw out these spells that made some encounters trivial and it made me feel like I progressed to get that far.


Edit July 2022:
I picked it back up to see if it was just a mood thing, started to get into the swing of it, began farming Kobolds for the mutton or whatever needed for a quest and just as I got my last piece, I began to head back... only for my game to crash. I lost a good hour of progress so I think it's safe to say I have no intention to play this game again.

review: Fun game, you can spend as much or little time with it as you want, save and come back to it later.  Negatives:  Could really use a better map, and a better indicator of where shortcuts will send you (take notes if you don't have a great memory, and/or don't play the game often).  The game has a LOT of backtracking, which isn't hard since you will be overpowered when returning to initial areas, but it is annoying how much you have to go back to old areas once you get new abilities.  Positives:  Easy to level, easy to get good equipment, fun exploring, especially the first time, I enjoyed the story line, and the controls are good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973200565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 307, 'playtime_forever': 629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1625104286}
review:
This game is pretty Meh! fails because it tries to be bullet points. 5.0/10

It lacks something that I can't quite put my finger on and That is a quality good game. If you look into the history of this game you will find it is what makes it. It tries to to be everything that everyone wanted. metroidvania, yup: it has square level rooms, so square it puts every castlevania to shame, floating lantern, why not add these easy drops when BG level torches are thing, clunky movement scheme, I played them all, well most of the CV's and hardly ever used dash when it wasn't forward propelled. I always found it easier to Jump back as I could attack while doing so. The same is in this game. The controls are clunky just like these older games, because why not improve it, that's the way they were and so shall we. And the last piece that everyone wants procedural generation. Why not create levels and play test them to get a balance to them, just PG them and that creativity can be used for the lanterns. with the RPG elements it feels really unbalanced in one area I was ripping through enemies with the environmental hazards dealing more damage. and then the next section was so OP I took 4x damage, enemy health was 4x, but exp was 4x so I could have grinded there for a bit if it wasn't also the shortest area up in a position with no save shrines. 

Coming from recent "metroidvania" games or shall I say non-linear platformers of the likes of Ori and Blasphemous this game is very shallow. The art is good in places while other aspects are cluttered or noisey. The animations are all straight from the 16-bit era, The run is very castlevania, well actually most of the movement, the glide is Aladdin, There is even a blatant ripoff of a Shambler. I don't think there was much in the way of a metroid game other than the square map system, which is really the only thing that ties any castlevania to metroid to form this "genre". Maybe I should stop complaining and go play a good old fashioned doom clone like Battlefield or Thief, or Sniper Ghost Warrior. 

Put your money into something Better like Blasphemous, the Ori series, or Owlboy.

review: A really solid Metroidvania, I was pretty much surprised how much I enjoyed it. Sure, it doesn‚Äôt invent anything new, and it certainly borrows shamelessly from everything you like (especially Castlevania, e.g. the magic attacks or the bestiary), but definitely in a good way. I didn‚Äôt even mind that the levels get procedurally generated for each new game, because, honestly, it didn‚Äôt feel that way at any time (you can even choose certain builds to compare with your friends). So all in all, not really much more to say. Kind of an underrated game in my opinion, pretty long, too. at least 10 hours of fun if you‚Äôre bored, good music, well-done pixel graphics, secret areas, lots of different weapons and items, rare drops, interesting bosses, side quests, so what‚Äôs not to like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263223329', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1031, 'last_played': 1686491577}
review:
I've been playing this game a lot, and I noticed a lot of things that I didn't realise that was in the game, some of them are good, but the majority is just awfull. I didn't managed to finish it, and not because it's hard, but because I don't find a reason to keep playing this game. Everything, and I mean, EVERYTHING in this game doesn't seem original, and this makes it bad and repetitive, and here's a bunch of things wich I think that makes the game look like this:

-Annoying enemies spawns that are almost impossible to pass through. For example: a zombie that spawns on the edge of a plataform with lasers under it (sure, you can use the "spells" to kill it, but then another almost indentical spot apears right after this one).

-The "spells" are almost useless, the only spell that are at least usable is the knife, wich btw, you need to spam 6 or 8 times to kill an enemy on a safe distance. Also, they don't make the player feel that he's using actual spells, just makes the player feel he's using weaker versions of Castlevania's SOTN subweapons.

-Most ocasions, you can't actually fight the enemies, you need to find a safe spot to start spaming a "spell" to kill him, and if you don't have enough mana, then you need to start dodging the enemy's attacks until you find a oportunity to hit him, then you repeat the process until the enemy is dead. By reading what I said, you must be thinking that I don't like the "hit & dodge" combat, but I really like it, when it's well implemented, because Chasm doesn't give any usefull mobility to your character at all.

-Like I said previously, apparently the developers wanted to implement the "hit & dodge" combat style to the game, and they did it, but they forgot the fact that you need to give actual mobility to the player instead of a backdash that is slower than your character running back, and you can't cancel your attack by doing other action, like jumping, if you attack, you'll be stuck into an animation that only ends when your character stop swinging his weapon, during that period, the enemy that you're attacking probably is going to hit you back.

Chasm really disapointed me, I watched some playthrougs and I bought it, thinking it was going to be a great game, but no, it's just another game awfully trying to pass the same vibe of Castlevania SOTN. If you're thinking about buying that, please change your mind, this game is terrible.

review:
Chasm ins't a bad game by any means, it contains a great pixelated graphic and it is well made, however, the game doesn't innovate anything on the metroidvania genre making the experience pretty generic.
Although it brings back many nostalgic feelings with its art style, there is much more to be desired and no real sense of accomplishment once you've completed the game.
I thoroughly enjoyed playing through once, but I‚Äôm not rushing back for more.

review:
The game was nice mechnically. The music was good and the art style was great. However, after beating a certain boss in "The Keep" and basically rescuing everyone I could, I am stuck in terms of progress and don't know what to do. I already have the gloves that let me grab ledges, and I have the slide ability and lantern.

A lot of chests I have let can only be accessed through "Double Jump," which apparently the game has, but I can't use yet. There's also a second light stone I currently don't posess for a chest locked behind a gate. I've used all my tokens and lost every single slot machine roll, and have lost every spin mini-game thing so far.

There's no direction it seems at all anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028769894', 'num_games_owned': 1844, 'num_reviews': 267, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1623510522}
review:
A decent little castlevania sibling, nice length, quite a big amount of stuff to find, all in all, good fun.
They introduced novelty in procedural generation of the levels, you get a lot of "seeds" from which you can tell the layout is completely different, however, as I played one playthrough, I already see that some rooms are repeating within the same seed, basically since metroidvanias require some careful design to not be stuck, and they went the extra mile to make the stuff like needed pickups and saves in places where it's not frustrating, as well as guaranteed loopbacks to some preplaced rooms, it's clear that the room for experimentation is not huge, and it's probably reaaaally hard to pump a lot of rooms into the machine.

Soooo, those variations are a nice touch if you want to replay the game on harder difficulties, but it's clearly not something to replay a fkton like roguelikes/roguelites. The combat is basically castlevania, some people complain about annoying controls, in my experience they're ok, with one exception - turning around mid jump, some bats can mess you up big time because you swing the opposite way from them. Also some wall jumps can be a little nuisance if the wall is at the max height of your jump. Weapons vary a bit, but the slow ones have barely any additional damage, so I used the most dps heavy sword I found at that time, swift sword being used for like half of the run. The magic is rather weird, usually it's not super useful, unless you're changing the spells all the time in inventory, to suit the situation, that is less of a problem once you upgrade them though. You upgrade it through armor and accessories, then later through gems. Definitely way less straightforward compared to melee builds.
You also have stats and levels, I think you usually get more levels from enemies you recently discovered. The enemies also have droprates, affected by your luck stat, so if you're going for 100% or specific items, you can do a big chunk of farming. I'm not sure there is anything else in terms of mechanics that I would describe, that makes this game stand out from the crowd. Maybe special drops from bosses if you no hit them? Though personally I never bothered.

The music is composed well, I had a pleasant time listening to it when playing, they're not huge bangers, but if I heard it from outside the game, I think it would be recognizable enough to say it's from Chasm. Sounds are appropriate for the pixely game, so in terms of quality - bad. Not annoying to listen to of course, but absolutely not something to write home about.

The visuals as mentioned before - pixelated, 16 bit like, the animations are pretty easy to read, and the environments are recognizable. Some stuff you interact with, which might not be clear from its looks, usually has a glint to catch your attention. They're executed in a pretty damn competent way, however I am so deaaaad and tired of the pixel art games. Some might have more charm than others, but I am craving detail and effort in my games. You don't have to make everything pixelated to convey it's an indie game for indie audience, I'm not that single minded.

Story is there, it's not bad actuallly, nothing insulting about it's delivery or particularly stupid elements, though it is nothing special at the same time, a demonic ruler sitting at the bottom of hellish magma filled caves at the bottom, and some other ancient places, all connected through a mine at the top, where villagers lived, before being abducted down to those depths. Predictable, standard, but far from awful.

So the game is at around 70% recommended on steam, I think that's fair, if you enjoy metroidvania games, you're gonna have a fun time, like me, but if you're considering some top shelf games from the genre, it's not near stuff like hollow knight, minoria or blasphemous. Those last 3 are a must play in my book, in comparison I might forget I actually played this one day.

review: Loved this game not sure why its mixed reviews and receiving much hate. The one thing that I could say is bad about this game is the backtracking but even then I did not mind it at all and that's how you can get replay value when you have to go back through and progress since you unlocked something else. It was a fun game all the way from the beginning to the end, I sure had to look up some guides on the way since I was stuck at certain parts but overall it was fun and I got a good 22 hours in the game before I finished and unlocked most of the things. There is much more to do after I could also do more runs with even better equips and abilities but I am done for now and always can go back to replay if bored.

review:
Le doy una nota positiva dado que objetivamente el juego esta bien hecho, no tiene bugs y es funcional, y los dise√±os son visualmente hermosos desde los escenarios y personajes (particularmente los enemigos), sin embargo eso es todo lo bueno que tiene, la m√∫sica no es √©pica ni memorable, la exploraci√≥n esta mal dise√±ada: las salas de teletransporte y de sanaci√≥n est√°n mal ubicadas ya sea porque est√°n muy cerca/lejos entre si o mal interconectadas haciendo del mapa algo poco org√°nico, los puzzles son un chiste y la historia es muy poco inspirada, casi que el argumento solo existe por puro protocolo o compromiso, de verdad la historia y personajes son tan irrelevantes... no aportan nada, en m√°s de un sentido ya que no creo que sume a la experiencia de ning√∫n jugador con un poco de experiencia, si has jugado los castlevanias de gba o nintendo ds, este juego esta muy por debajo de esos t√≠tulos (incluyendo super metroid y metroid fusion), quiz√° exceptuando castlevania harmony of dissonance, que tambi√©n es soso.

Sinceramente parece un producto hecho con esfuerzo, pero sin cari√±o como si los desarrolladores estuvieran obligados a hacerlo y simplemente no le pusieron coraz√≥n, he notado que muchos metroidvanias carecen de ambici√≥n y se limitan a hacer un juego "largo", funcional, y que cumpla con los elementos clasicos: como salas secretas, sistema de nivel y muchos items (consumibles y armas), y al final producen un juego muy cuadrado, como si su √∫nica referencia fuera el castlevania sotn y no pudieran atreverse a si quiera intentar algo m√°s, en los noventas y la primera decada del 2000 entiendo que esos proyectos tuvieran limitaciones entre otras cosas por las plataformas en que se lanzaban esos juegos, pero hasta konami supo ver que podia hacer m√°s. Trabajos como este simplemente son anacronicos y solo desgastan el genero. ¬øquieres un metroidvania que si vale pena? prueba iconoclast, blasphemous, o hasta midnight castle succubus; ninguno de esos juegos es perfecto y pecan de algunos problemas que he se√±alado en esta cr√≠tica, pero son mejores propuestas que este juego, literalmente pienso que solo disfrutaras de chasm si tienes poca o nada de experiencia jugando metroidvanias o si no eres nada exigente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025823574', 'num_games_owned': 3339, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1622320206}
review:
Uninteresting, unfun, unresponsible.
The weapons actually attack in different ways, but offer no alternative. A bat attacking from above you will mean a lot of issues if you have a sword. Clubs are slow but least they attack in a wide arc. But all of this matters little because the level "design" and enemies make it unenjoyable.
You see, you basically don't have knockback, it's ridiculously low. Yet as you progress, enemies get enough health to land a hit or two, slowly wearing you down, because the level "design" is so random that it often leaves no place to actually fighting back. Like if there is a zombie in a tunnel coming to you, and attacking with a dash, you can only hope to kill it faster because you can't go back up, nor dodge to the other side of the enemy.
It's really clear that the developer's pride, the procedural generation doesn't really work. Rooms started repeating as soon as level 2 and 3.  One room had a secret crevice with a mana boost that was also repeated - this is the level of rooms being re-used.
That's just the extra that the game started out by having the steamcommunity popups being mostly out of my screen. And when I tried to fix, the game claimed it is running at my native resolution, while having thick black bars around the screen.

The game tries to be Castlevania so hard that it physically hurts. Backdash that is faster than walking, crashing lanterns... the tryhard attitude is coupled up with the stock enemies, uninteresting and bad combat, and unoriginal premise and design.. all of this showing that copying just looks without understanding what makes a game fun does not work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198914187424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1621709861}
review:
One of the best Igavanias/metroidvanias available. I own every port of this game. It's that good! Movement is just like SOTN, music is great, pixel art is great, etc. I asked the developer to please make a Chasm 2, but he said he's making a new game with a brand new IP that will also be a metroidvania, so I'm very happy to hear that. Maybe Chasm 2 gets made in the future (fingers crossed). People have been criticizing the map generator (new map made for every new game), but I think this was a good move by adding replay value to the game. 
If you are a fan of Castlevania (the good ones, not this lords of shadow crap), then this is a must buy. It's Dev's like this that have stepped up and kept this great genre alive, cause konami absolutely sucks now. Thank You Mr. Developer! 
Buy this game. It's criminally underrated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970512066', 'num_games_owned': 790, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1620783573}
review:
Chasm is a hard game to review with just Yes/No. The Bit Kid devs clearly *love* Castlevania, and they've made some truly excellent pixel art animation. On the other hand, they love Castlevania *too* much; Chasm lacks a distinct identity, both in its narrative and mechanics.

I wouldn't recommend it to a general audience, at least not over alternatives like Deedlit, Bloodstained, and Ori. That said, if you like the genre as much as I do, you'll still enjoy it. Just get it in a bundle or on a good sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105646601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1620834922}
review:
This game has everything in it's right place, but doesn't bring anything new to the metroidvania genre.

If you want to play a game that resembles Symphony of the Night quite a bit in it's gameplay aspects, this might be for you. If you want something new and genre defining, this game will NOT do the trick.

I got this game as a part of a Humble Bundle and as such it was worth checking out.

If a sequel is developed, I hope it will take this solid foundation and build boldly on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973612833', 'num_games_owned': 1889, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 3558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3068, 'last_played': 1620646132}
review:
So having played chasm pretty much all the way through ill tell what i think

The bad:
Controls are slow and unresponsive
Levels are badly generated
Items do not drop when they are useful anymore
Last boss has stupid save point
Little to no story
Dumb beast achievement

The good:
Graphics style is great
80's to 90's like game play
Requires very little hardware

So this requires the player to journey to small mining town investigate the townspeople disappearance and why this towns mines are filled with monsters. That is it that is the story in fill because you can already fill in the blanks. The monsters are here to destroy the world and you need to defeat the grand monster behind it. So having little to no story is the first problem as there is no real side missions beyond one. No but this is the reason just insert evil monster and you get the idea.

All of this would not be a problem as many other games could be summed up as such but its core game play is basically designed to be a retro like game. So it suffers from this, you will hit a key on the keyboard for no action to be taken, when jumping, fighting basically anything. This is deliberate apparently the original game it is trying to mimic did this, so as such you need to time everything to the pace that this game wants you to play at.

When talking about level generation for a open world game like minecraft, terraria etc. random generated maps are great. They let the played explore a map that is different, they allow for a fresh gameplay experience every time. They allow the player to create there experience etc. you get the idea. Now with a linear game i.e. one that is meant to be played from start to finish once and then shelved this is horrible. Just looking up a guide on the web i can tell you that my map to at least 30% smaller when filled in. It has bugs like one part of the map required you to submerse your character in lava to fill in the map blank. The maps look bland because its all just copy and paste. This map would of been 100% better if the developers had taken the time to create a map. They could of placed the save points at better locations, made monsters at better spots, made items that are hidden in more inventive locations etc. etc.

As for the items drop this really not well designed, some of the items are locked behind the requirement to defeat the games bosses without getting hit. This can be done for most players with a few hours of practice to get bosses attack moves memorized then develop a technique to fight them and finally maybe get a little lucky. But there is little to no reason beyond these weapons to do this and all it does is just make this game longer. besides the strongest weapon in the game is not unlocked this way.
Then you get to the minerals drop, which is once again not done very well at all. The best metal in the game is not dropped and thus cannot be used until you are almost one or two rooms away from the final boss and besides the metal at this late stage of the game crafts items that are worse then the ones you properly already have.

The final boss is located from the final save point after about half a section of map. So you are simply forced to get to him wait around for you character to heal before taking him on every single time. This means that assuming that you need to heal with the healing amour on its going to take you about 20 mins every time. Because of this you strategy will probably just end up being buy shit loads of potions and use then every time you health gets low. Which for a boss that has as many attacks as the last one has is a real disappointment. Unfortunately it also leaves you with very little to think hey i just completed this game and that last boss was hard but fair. Good game.

Finally the game forces you to kill every single monster like 15 times over even if its not encountered very offen. Once again this could of been fixed with non generated map.

The GOOD:

You will probably get alot of fun out of this title if you played the original game this is inspired by. I personally have not and as such DO NOT RECOMMEND BUYING OR PLAYING THIS GAME.

Please find another game to play. You will have much more fun then playing through this mess of a game.

review:
Too many puzzles and backtracking. I was forced to google around and go back to almost every area in the game at least 2 or 3 times. Also too much jumping from wall to wall and falling down into spikes or acid.
I want a metroidvania hack and slash - not a platform game.
More than half of my game-time was spent trying to find the solution for puzzles and backtracking in areas where I had been.

I do NOT recommend this game.

review:
To summarise, the game is fun but held back by a few things. 

Semi-gameplay spoilers from now on:

People say the random map generation holds the game back, I agree, if that was tightened up a little this game would be a powerhouse but as it stands there are some instances of being too far away from fast travel, a puzzle being too far away from it solution, an npc being locked at the end of a long gauntlet or a checkpoint being a bit far away from the boss. None of those map issues were significant but they were still present. Combat is good but some enemy attack patterns are tough, although if I had taken more time to learn then I'd probably be more lenient. I liked a lot of the npc interactions and I thought (most of) their quests were fun. Backtracking at the end of the game was amazingly smooth (with a tiny bit of help from the wiki). The map is comprehensive enough to tell where nearly everything is and even tickles your expectations at one or two points. If you'd like to experience the same game as me, my seed was [spoiler]2A3A3886[/spoiler].

author: {'steamid': '76561198079169838', 'num_games_owned': 956, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1114, 'last_played': 1619136764}
review:
Consider this review as neutral.

I enjoyed my time with Chasm: the combat is fine, the enemies and bosses have a nice variety, populating the town is rewarding and exploring the map was fun and not that much frustrating.

However, there's very little I will remember fondly. On the whole, the game just feels bland: the story is basically non-existent, there are no particularly interesting gameplay mechanics, enemies end up being annoying more than challenging and the world building is just mediocre. Many reviewers noted many design problems with the game, but the biggest problem is that the game is just forgettable.

This also makes its main selling point, the replayability, simply not worth it: there's very little to gain by doing a new run. By being a game made of two parts, a metroidvania and a randomly generated game, it feels like the developers' efforts were split too much, making both aspects just mediocre. That makes me wish they focused more on the second part, maybe by also taking some elements from randomizers: make the game shorter or more exploitable, offer ways to add modifiers to a run and focus less on combat and more on movement.

The only thing I will remember from the game is the music: it has a nice cozy feel to it and it's stuck in my head.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020052322', 'num_games_owned': 1127, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1601161499}
review:
Sometimes old-school games were hard, and sometimes they were just poorly designed.  Chasm is both.  

The hard parts are great.  After 100%+ing Hollow Knight, I was looking for a polished and challenging Metroidvania.  Chasm felt pretty good.  Controls felt a bit less polished, but still fine.  Just the right amount of BS deaths.  Boss fights were interesting enough.

The poor design mostly is annoying, but can be forgotten when it isn't rearing its ugly head.  Except if you ever get stuck on a boss.  Then there is some real bullshit.  Not the dying.  Not the run up from the nearest save. (Except maybe the final one.)  Not even the sometimes questionable hotboxes.  That's all par for the course if you've ever tried a souls-like.  Its the extra time to takes to boot you back to the main menu and watch the animations to get there.  Whats so hard about having a "load from checkpoint" button at the death screen?

Losing and trying again is fun.  Wasting time in the process is not.  (And suggesting easy mode when someone asks about why you can't load a save from the death screen is insulting.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198063202889', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1618039035}
review:
[h2]General Thoughts:[/h2]
With polished controls, solid game design choices, and a great look and sountrack, [i]Chasm[/i] presents a fun little Metroidvania that presents a variety of well-executed ideas that fans of the genre should find well worth the $20 asking price.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
[i]Chasm[/i] comes to the table with a fusion of action platforming, adventure puzzles, and RPG mechanics that blend together seamlessly. Your hero will level up as you progress, and levels come pretty naturally; you're unlikely to need to grind as the challenge is pretty balanced for a natural playthrough. For the most part these levels are just a numbers game, and the weapons and armor feel similar, although there are a few varieties of weapon that do change things up a bit. The village offers stores and roads to improved items and abilities as well.
Like any good Metroidvania, you'll find roadblocks that will be overcome using items you acquire as you explore. The map has a welcome (I even say necessary) marker feature that lets you mark important spots on the map; make sure you mark  roadblocks and other unusual rooms so it's easier to remember where they are later! Puzzle rooms also offer welcome diversions from the combat in most other areas.
The movement and combat controls feel snappy and polished, though your options are fairly limited; I would have liked to see more advanced options like attack cancelling, parrying, or other such concepts, as I found many combat encounters either to be a swing-and-jump affair, or just trading blows. You'll also acquire "spells", many of which you'll recognize from Castlevania games, which give you alternative ways to approach combat.

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
The art direction of this game is top-notch modern pixel work; this game doesn't seek to emulate classic consoles, instead fully utilizing modern capabilities (although there is a welcome CRT mode in the graphics option; I always prefer a well-emulated CRT for pixel games). Character designs are interesting, animations are fluid, environments are detailed and varied, and the user interface is bespoke and clean.

[h3]Audio[/h3]
The soundtrack in this game slaps, and I appreciate that there is an alternate 8-bit retro-style soundtrack option if you like more blippy tunes to accompany the visual style. Both versions are excellent. The sound effects aren't standout, but they are punchy and clean and contribute to the game's polish.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story is this game's weakest element--which isn't to say it's [i]bad[/i], just [i]minimal[/i]. A small chunk of setup explains that you're delving into some mines to clear out enemies and rescue missing townsfolk, and while you're down there you learn what's at the heart of the problem so you can solve it. The character interactions are pleasant, but none of the interactions are particularly deep. Overall, little bits of fun lore but not something you'll likely get invested in.

[h3]Additional Thoughts[/h3]
I took a break from this game for a while and when I came back, I couldn't remember what I had done and what I was still working on in terms of the little side-quests for the villagers; a quest log or notes system would have helped in that regard. Also, while the map markers were definitely welcome, I'm always in favor of multiple marker options--different colors or symbols--to help distinguish why any given area is important. I like being able to say "this is a small passage roadblock" vs. "this is a high jump roadblock" to help me remember where a new item will help me and minimize unnecessary backtracking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285059929', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1617658949}
review:
Pretty basic and fun metroidvania with nice visuals and sound effects. It has a good level design and the exploration is very fun, considering how everything is procedurally-generated for every player, as long you don't play using someone else seed. The combat is pretty basic, but it offers variation through different kinds of weapons and magic spells.

Even though it's not really the point of the game, it baffles me how the "end game" equipments are useless in general. You can either grind rare drop from foes, or craft stuff offered by the NPCs from the town, and yet there's no content for this kind of equipment in the game. By the time you encounter monsters that drop [spoiler]Meteorite Ingot[/spoiler], you're literally at the last boss door, with probably way better equipment that you've "accidentally" dropped from some mob, or you were lucky enough to find a hidden room with legendary-stats weapons, and is killing foes with 2 or 3 attacks.

Again, grinding stuff it's not really the point of the game to begin with, but it's a pointless system in general. A waste of potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993502256', 'num_games_owned': 2488, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1595878573}
review:
Tiefer in die Mine und wie kommt man hier eigentlich weiter?

Chasm ist ein Platformer mit Rollenspiel-Aspekten. Man wird als Aushilfs-Ritter nach Kharthas geschickt, um die Umst√§nde in der dortigen Mine zu untersuchen. Man macht sich dann erstmal mit den Bewohnern der Stadt vertraut, um zu wissen, was Phase ist. Nachdem man ein paar Quests bekommen hat, geht man in die randomisierte Mine. Was dort lauert, das findet ihr am besten selbst raus.

Grafisch finden wir hier h√ºbsche und durchdachte Pixel-Grafik. Jedes Biom steht f√ºr sich und hat den eigenen Style und auch das eigene Gegnerdesign. Die Animationen sind auch passend. Soundtechnisch gibt es keine Sprachausgabe, allerdings daf√ºr Soundeffekte, bei denen man sich zu Hause f√ºhlt und Musik, die nicht nervig wird und auch jedes Mal zum Thema passt.

Da die Map sich bei jedem Playthrough neu generiert hat dieses Spiel einen gewissen Wiederspielwert. Die Rollenspiel-Aspekte machen es zudem interessant. Welche Waffe passt zu einem? Welche Werte sind wichtig? Alles Fragen, die man sich im Laufe des Spiels stellt und wo man sicher viel erkunden kann. Dazu kommt eine simple Steuerung, die allerdings viel Timing abverlangt.

Alles in Allem ist das Spiel also genau das, was es sein will. Es gibt kaum Punkte, die ich negativ auff√ºhren w√ºrde. F√ºr Fans von Platformern ist das hier also auf jeden Fall was, vor allem im Angebot kann man ohne Bedenken zugreifen. Es ist auch definitiv nicht das leichteste Spiel. Die Story ist √ºbrigens in sich geschlossen. Darum gern einen Daumen hoch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964722740', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1613540239}
review:
*** Review of the Linux version ***

The Linux port ran perfectly.

Chasm might be one of the most underrated games on Steam. At release time, it got plenty of negative feedback because players had some issues with the game design, people claimed it was bland and that the idea of a randomly generated metroidvania is not as interesting as one with a well predesigned map. But the game has been polished and developed since, and as 2021 this a solid game, one of the fewer metroidvanias that fit the Igavania subgenre, the ones that carry RPG elements with levels and gear. 

The pixel art in this game is absolutely amazing. Sound and music are great, nothing is annoying or out of place. Gameplay is tight, controls are precise and there are a lot of jumping and backdashing. When you first start the game, a seed is generated and the game map will be randomized, although there is a specific order of biomes you will go through and secrets that will only slightly change (such as codes). There is a lot of backtracking that made the game fun to me, since every time I was getting upgrades to explore that hard to reach places, but not all people are too fond of that. Game length was nice, I felt it could be a bit shorter though.

I agree that the randomization is not that useful because most people won't play it twice (I doubt I will) but it was a good and unique idea and props to the devs for the courage to try something like that. Also, the puzzles were not very straightforward and I had to read the forums for help. I also managed to finish the game before I completed some optional puzzles and I doubt I will go back to them now. The gear variety could be better designed as I found very few items I wanted to use, but the game allows you to pick different builds (basically pick between melee and magic even though you will still use both).

Overall, I recommend this game for those looking for more Igavanias to play  and this one has unique controls and graphics, if it is on sale it is well worth it. The reviews are not too favorable but it has nothing to do with bad quality. This could be a 90% if it was released without randomization, a nice map design and all the current improvements, 95% if the puzzles were redone in a more straightforward way.

**PROS**
- Amazing graphics
- Great music and effects
- Igavania style levels and equipment
- Enough game length
- Secrets
- Fun backtracking
- Tight controls
- Fast action
- Normal difficulty done right

**CONS**
- Randomization is probably not useful to most people and made the game less interesting 
- Puzzles were sometimes not straightforward or a bit cryptic, tips might be required
- Gear variety can feel bland unless you want to force yourself different builds for subsequent playthroughs

All in all, I am looking forward to what these guys will do next, they have the talent I look for when picking up indie games. I am glad to show them my appreciation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034928324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 172, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1613507143}
review:
Chasm √® ottimo metroidvania e pur non amando questo genere di giochi devo ammettere che mi ha tenuto incollato per quasi 8 ore senza provocarmi stress da backtracking.
Infatti nonostante ogni partita sia diversa grazie a un sistema di creazione del mondo procedurale, Chasm sembra quasi guidarti nell'apprendimento del gioco, dandoti i mezzi e le informazioni per proseguire verso la meta grazie al gameplay.
Gameplay ed estetica sono un enorme omaggio ai suoi titoli di ispirazione, fluidit√† e controlli ben calibrati invece incorniciano il tutto impreziosendo lo stile 16bit che lo caratterizza.

L'avventura ci porter√† ad attraversare sei diversi dungeon, tutti realizzati da ambienti e nemici diversi e man mano che avanziamo nel gioco sbloccheremo diverse abilit√† che ci permetteranno di superare zone altrimenti inaccessibili.

Ho apprezzato davvero tanto che le varie difficolt√† riescano a creare un livello di sfida adatto a qualsiasi fascia di giocatori, dando del filo da torcere ai pi√π temerari ma accompagnando istruendo il giocatore per chi invece vuole approcciarsi al genere.
La variet√† di ambientazioni, equipaggiamento e nemici ci costringe ad adattare il nostro stile di gioco in base a ci√≤ che ci troveremo ad affrontare e seppur ci sia una forte presenza di backtracking, la mappa riesce a non essere dispersiva e con il vecchio metodo di carta e penna alla mano si riesce facilmente a districarsi fra le varie stanze.

Consigliatissimo a chi si approccia per la prima volta al genere metroidvania, 16‚Ç¨ non sono tanti e li vale fino all'ultimo centesimo.

Pro:
- Difficolt√† adatte a tutti i giocatori
- Stile tecnico e gameplay ben realizzato.

Contro:
- I livelli "procedurali" non sembrano offrire chiss√† quale feature

author: {'steamid': '76561197960687970', 'num_games_owned': 2488, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1613239992}
review:
Visually appealing, yet mechanically terrrible game. It is amazing that this game gets "mostly positive" in Steam, yet it is very very weak compared to better Metroidvania style games around here. Doesn't even worth to install this poorly made game. I wish they cared about the mechanics as much as the visuals.
Storytelling is weak, and heavily depended on the books we collect around. They didn't even care to implement storytelling to the dialogues or the level design.
They used a RPG style level up system inside the Metroidvania style. However combat with mobs are just plain boring.
When you hit a monster, the attack doesn't affect it and it continues to walk towards you, and due to delay after your attack, you can't run away from their attacks and take damage for unavoidable reasons. You get movement delays after you attack, yet monsters don't get any delay or stun after getting damaged. This system is plain stupid. Check out Hollow Knight for better combat mechanics.
And just to salt the wound, they removed any "combat animations" from the monsters. Monsters simply walk around, and damage you whenever they touch you (even from behind).
Waste of time, waste of money.

2: Intolerable - Bad enough to make you refund the game.

review:
could have a bit better controls since it seems to have a problem when getting a lot of inputs (mashing buttons etc, even with keyboard, and much worse with controllers). and backtracking gets pretty old since some maps feel a bit slow to walk around in, despite the devs trying to mitigate this by making tunnels and portals for fast travel but its pretty sparse in between levels though the map isnt too big so they might not have too much choice there.

but that aside, its an impressive game especially when its made with only like 2 people (or so i've heard) music and art is lovely. not much going on in the story but overall should be pretty enjoyable for people who like metroid-vanias. i beat it surprisingly quick and didnt really bother finishing all the sidequest which takes around 7 hours. i'd say get it when its on sale, got mine from the humble bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079525163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1258, 'last_played': 1706837991}
review:
Bottom line: if you like Castlevania, you will like this game. It takes some pretty heavy inspiration from Symphony of the Night but in a good way; the developers actually understood what was fun about that game and executed it in their own way, rather than just copying its mechanics.

Game's also got some replay value. The fact that it's randomized from game to game, although the differences are superficial, gives this game the most character out of anything. And stuff like the unlockable "class mode"(Which alters stats to align with a warrior, thief, or mage kind of playstyle) and nightmare mode are nice to have.

review:
[h1]A cool game - Your good ol' Metroidvania[/h1]

[b]9/10
Nice characters and art style
Cool exploration and levels
Good enough story
Buy it on a sale[/b]

you know the drill. a guy goes on a mission to check on a mine - the usual stuff you do when you're not a soldier yet - and then you have to save the world from an era of darkness. it's a little similar to games like shovel knight (there is a hub town), with all the usual Castlevania tropes (locked places, power-ups to reach them, bats, save points), but it's pretty well executed. Every level has its style, and the story is entertaining enough to keep you playing. Once you get the double jump it's way easier to explore, but not spoon-fed, so it's great. I'll give it a 9/10 (maybe because I've been playing metroidvanias too much... )

author: {'steamid': '76561198005944371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1612144372}
review:
I am really sad to leave this review because on paper Chasm has everything I want in a Metroidvania, but unfortunately it is hampered by a series of critical flaws that basically caused me to abandon the game out of frustration.  I am sure my review will echo others there, but first we'll start with the good:

Pros:
- Beautiful pixel art that I genuinely enjoyed.

- A fine if rather generic storyline, but I appreciate and actually like the way the game progressed and how you bit by bit restore the village.

- Unlike others I like the world design overall, while not perfect I thought it worked.

Cons:
- The controls are just a mess; a hallmark of a great Metroidvania game are the snappy, responsive controls, and the controls here are just sluggish (and its not the game that is sluggish; plenty of enemies have the kind of snappy/quick movement you would expect, but your controls just can't keep up).  I consistently felt like you could never quite jump high enough, far enough, or fast enough, and after nearly every action the character takes a pause, which usually results in taking damage.  Therefore one is constantly faced with the option of dodge endlessly or hit the enemy and take damage.  This would not be a problem if there were plentiful save points or item drops to help restore HP, which there are some, but not enough.  As others have commented, the wall-jumping mechanic is also a mess.  I see how it works and think I understand what the devs were trying to go for, but it just feels terrible, which to me is the antithesis of a good metroidvania.

- As others have commented, there are just not enough save points.  Given the sluggish controls, the game can be kind of brutal, and I found it easy to be stuck in a situation where I had little HP, no food or potions left, and miles away from a save point.  As others have commented, the item drop rate is low (and while that does not bother me in terms of weapons, if the game is going to be designed as it is, it should really have more HP item drops).

Overall I can only recommend this to the most committed of metroidvania fans.  If you want to like this game but looking for a better alternative, I would recommend Timespinner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1611582046}
review:
This is a console (Switch) ported 2D retro pixel Castlevania ripoff, basically a platformer with lightweight ARPG aspects.  Jump around clunky retro pixel  environments brawling with lazy retro pixel enemies. 

Clunky is the theme here... the controls are a godawful mess.   It's obvious this isn't designed for PC.   You do get some "decent" (for a crappy retro pixel bundle filler) graphics settings, so there's working 4K support and even UI scaling.   It's inexplicable why so much work went into making a game that looks so bad, on purpose.  Retro pixel graphics are a terrible substitute for modern PC graphics, and are only used by developers who lack either talent, or budget, to arrange contemporary, compelling visuals.   However, despite giving up on trying to make the game look decent and using pixel "art" instead, they still put a huge amount of work into it.  What do they say?  You can't polish a turd, but you can roll it in glitter. 

So, ugly retro pixel graphics, godawfully bad controls (and controls are what make or break crappy 2D retro pixel platformers),  there's no entertainment value in this.  Oh wait, there is... they gave this bundlecrap an insane $20 USD price tag.   It's definitely entertaining that they thought this was worth the same price as AAA games like Divinity: Original Sin 2 or Monster Hunter: World.   Sheer comedy.  

Anyway don't buy this bundle-worsener, it's junk.   If you really have to play a crappy 2D platformer, try Hollow Knight, the controls work properly in that.
