author: {'steamid': '76561198032488999', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1593437006}
review:
A decent attempt in the metroidvania genre; a passable game that is quite unpolished, but fun for a metroidvania fan like myself.

[b]Pros:[/b]

- Art
- Gameplay
- Difficulty/Level progression

[b]Neutral:[/b]

- Level design (needed more work)
- Character progression (same as above)

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Lacks atmosphere (mediocre OST)
- Absolutely useless subweapons/"magic"
- Short duration

TL;DR: Get this if you're a metroidvania fan, else skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967976610', 'num_games_owned': 1387, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1179, 'last_played': 1592911122}
review:
An decent Metroid-Lite type of game.

A few issues however.
Fountain type buffs do not renew, so they are a one off use buff.
No quest location shown (got lost looking for an NPC's story-spawn point).

Pricing - as per most games these days (online in general, very few physical games available)
This game is over priced in general (usually A$28.95), As per the recent sale it was A$14.47.

While I've been tracking this game since original release, it was over priced for what is a very short game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060632407', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1593367343}
review:
Well this is disappointing, only 8 hours in and I just wish it would end.

Get weird audio issues at times were the music seems to lag but not the game. Some times loading screens randomly take some time where most are almost instant. Once the game just crashed out of nowhere.

The game is mainly a slow never ending jumping puzzle with some enemies placed here and there. When you do fight it is slow and is mainly you jumping around them. 

Having the map split between areas is a real shame but that is because its based of a seed system. While that is something different it means that their is no uniqueness to the areas in a zone so when you get the ability to allow you to proceed your gonna spend 30+ minutes trying to find that one exact spot you need to go to.

Also the wheel of fortune where you can get a permanent de-buff is horrible. Having your max health lowered permanent because you decided to talk to a dude is not great; I ended up going back to last save making this game last even longer.

It looks nice and has some nice story elements but the game play is not great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105646510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 310, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1592839039}
review: [b]Chasm[/b] is just okay at best, borrowing much of it's core gameplay from Symphony of the Night and other titles. Sadly it just plays safe and doesn't innovate or develop further on any of those ideas. The procedural generation addition doesn't really add to the replayability of the game, sure some rooms are shuffled (slightly), but you still go through the game in a specific order, so I have to ask what's the point? The RNG-factors in general just drags the game down if I'm honest. I can't really say it's worth the time to go out of your way to play unless you've already exhausted every other option in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991576316', 'num_games_owned': 2515, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1592823525}
review:
Chasm is an interesting take for fans of Metroidvania and classic adventure platformers. Visually it is an excellent game, there is so much detail in every room. Another strong point is the musical score, most of the tunes add more flavor to each location.

 However, there are some aspects of the game that have a negative impact in the outcome. First of all, there is a procedurally-generated map each time you start a new adventure. You may find yourself deep into one of the dungeons and a save room is still many rooms away, if you die you return to your last save room so there will be many infuriating moments. Secondly, the combat is a bit fiddly, the animations are fine but to make every weapon different there are too many recovery frames in most weapons. The result is that you get hit too often because the main character is still recovering from your last action. Finally, the price of some of the most useful items is too high, use them too many times and you will need to grind enemies for gold.

All in all, I recommend the game to fans of the genre but this is a game with some issues. The developers are often stuck  in classic games rules and that hurts the final result.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016999910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1592620299}
review:
I want to start by saying the artwork is great. Excellent use of sub pixel animation really brings the environments to life.

This game tries really hard to be a SoTN Style Castlevania game. The main weapons all behave the same as their Castlevania counterparts. All of the spells are reticent of the sub weapons front the classic Castlevania games. And you can even cancel your attack delay by landing.

This game has a serious problem with the drop rates. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if the chance for anything to drop was literally just your luck stat as a percentage. You will never have money for anything in this game.

The map is procedurally made with pre-built rooms. I don‚Äôt think that the enemies are baked into the rooms though, so a repeat room might have different monsters in it at least. As far as the actual layouts go though, it wasn‚Äôt so bad. Segments of rooms are mixed together to make a lot of similar rooms with slight differences.
This can lead to some sadistic placement of enemies and save points. Healing items are not easy to come by. Enemies will rarely drop light heals. In town you can buy from a very limited supply of cheap food or some expensive potions. Otherwise you are at the mercy of the save points.

I played on hard and got a alright challenge. I really had to memorise enemy placement and attack patterns to get by. 
I was pretty frustrated that the town portal scroll was crazy expensive. I already don‚Äôt have enough cash for healing items or equipment. But it cost double the price of the big health potion just to keep my exp?!

The game is pretty light on puzzles but can have some rough platforming at times. I blame most of this on the wall jump. It feels bad. Just having the wall slide makes it hard to grab ledges. It pushes you far out from a wall so you can't vertically climb a single wall. Which isn‚Äôt a bad decision, but in the Temple zone, it pushes you out towards laser walls and it sucks. Also when you instinctively move the way you want to jump, you will just let go of the wall like that and fall. It makes sense in the sequence of events, but it feels bad. There should be some coyote time to do the wall jump.

Speaking of the upgrades. Some were super situational and others invalidated previous upgrades. There overall wasn‚Äôt a ton of variety with them, but that's fine because this is a combat focused game.

I wasn‚Äôt a fan of the loot modifiers. When I open a hard to reach chess, I expect some fat loots. But because of the modifiers I‚Äôm encouraged to save scum until I get a good version of whatever is in the chess. Again the drop rates of money and gear suck, so what's in that chess is the only new gear I‚Äôm going to see for a while.
I did like how similar weapons aren‚Äôt all just re-skins though. For example, the long sword is long! This lends itself well to a more balanced gear selection like Dark souls has. However the gear is tiered. So you will eventually have to trade out your weapon's unique quirk for something that just does a lot more damage.

Also the magic system is pretty busted. Its super spammable and mana potions are super cheap compared to everything else. Upgrades spells only cost gems, which aren't used for anything else. So its the one thing you can reliably spend.

If you can‚Äôt tell I am super salty about the drop rates. Because when I got to the final area I didn‚Äôt have a lot of heals or money. The space between the save point and the boss room has a lot of lava and tanky monsters, so it‚Äôs crazy hard to reach the end with any resources. I was already at my limit with the difficulty so I just gave up.

Overall the game isn‚Äôt bad, I definitely could have enjoyed myself more on a lower difficulty. But I think the procedural map is a massive crutch. I would have been a lot happier if I had a better seed, or better yet, the devs made a map with actual pacing‚Ä¶ I just don‚Äôt think it works for long form games. Moreover I don‚Äôt think it helps replayability, because the bosses, zones, and upgrades are all still the same.

A similar game ‚ÄúA Robot Named Fight!‚Äù has a ton of alternatives to upgrades and bosses, and even zones. And the runs only last an hour, so any repetitiveness is easily overlooked. This makes every seed feel like a unique game and I think it all just works better there.

review: I was mislead on what this game was like (I thought it had more rogue-lite qualities) and that is on me for not doing enough research but still I think the game makes some key mistakes for a metroidvania. The levels don't really flow into each like they do in great metriodvanias, the random generation of in-between rooms doesn't help replayablity that much, the stats can keep increasing without actually increasing the related damage, and looking and the wiki it seems that a lot of the more interesting items are backer-only (wiki is very incomplete and looks like stuff actually got removed).  All in all, still a good game one can enjoy, just not high on the list. Hollow Knight or Ori would be a recommend.

review: Some of the most repetitive and uninspired level design for a platformer that I've ever seen, sometimes on par with what you would expect from a level made by someone messing around in Lunar Magic: big rooms with platforms interspersed without rhyme or reason, only there for the sake of keeping you busy. Add that to the fact that your character is extremely slow, heavy and unresponsive, put in a handful of annoying bullet-sponge enemies just for good measure, and you have yourself an amazing gameplay loop of just barely missing platforms and constantly trying to keep your distance from enemies that inflict damage upon touching as you swipe your one-inch-range melee weapons at them. Fun, right?

review:
This feels like one of the later 2D Castlevania titles (with leveling, multiple weapons, etc).  It's magical weapons even feel like the castlevania heart weapon staples: axes, crosses, holy water, etc.  The procedural generation of the map is a mildly interesting mechanic that thankfully does not shift each time you start up the game, only on a new game file.  Boss fights are tough, fun, and engaging. Exploration is encouraged and rewarding, although you do notice a few room forms that repeat themselves. 
TLDR: A really fun randomized Castlevania-type game. Id recommend it.

review: I watched the development of this game for years. I was disappointed when it came out and had mixed reviews. I can honestly say I had to buy it after several updates. It feels like a snes metroidvania. It is true to the snes style gameplay. It is a well done game. author: {'steamid': '76561198078930018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1591713937}
review:
Well I have other issues than most people here.

Lack of a map. For reference I have played Hollow Knight without the compass addon and im fine with
not knowing where on the map i specifically am and figuring it out myself.
But not having a map at all is fucking annoying. Especially in this game where there are just empty rooms.
Backtracking is a pain and without a map you will get lost in dead ends all the time.

The weapons are basic. Extremely basic. 
The choices really are only attack in front of you at different ranges and an overhead swing.
Its boring af. The only (laughable) skill factor is how you use them which is you jump,
cause if you use the weapon on the ground, enjoy being rooted for the duration of the swing.
So if you want to keep up any momentum while attack, enjoy bunny hopping.

The magic just straight up pissed me off.
Its Castlevania items. And only the most basic ones. 
Throwing knife, throwing axe, throwing boomerang.
I was extremely disappointed that my magic molotov turned out to be Castlevanias holy water,
and it was weak as fuck on top of that.
Then I got the shield ... I thought I could maybe block attacks with it,
I mean what was i thinking, of course the shield isnt an actual fucking shield.
Its 3 orbitals that rotate around you and deal barely any damage. 
(this is also a Castlevania skill. in Dawn of Sorrow it was called Buer)

The enemies are boring. Their ai is stupid, they barely do anything.
Their patterns are crap. Theyre target practise at best.
The most damage I have taken from them was me taking contact damage from literally 
standing inside of them to burst them down.

The bosses arnt fairing much better. They have patterns at least.
But thats literally the good things I can say about them.
Their "Arenas" are empty rooms, havnt seen a platform in a bossroom yet.
Their attacks are either easily dodged like dashes or swipes, 
or you dont know what the fuck to do since your maneuverability is limited.
Like some worm thing shot homing plasma balls at me and I couldnt really do anything,
so I just stood inside of it and kept hitting it. As you can imagine its riveting gameplay.

And now the worst thing about this game. Level design.
Compared to all of the above, this is the true plague of this game.
There are so many goddamn empty rooms. 
I climbed up an empty passage, with the most basic repeating platform patterns only to find 2 empty dead ends at the top.
Thats how bad it gets. And even if it isnt completely empty, that one enemy that barely does more than
walking in a straight line is hardly a threat.

Conclusion I guess:
You know, I like Castlevania a lot and while it is cheap, unoriginal and unimaginative,
I would not mind a game copying its features if the result was good.
But they only took the worst parts and made everything else shit too.
I am majorly dissapointed

author: {'steamid': '76561197976418610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1591708936}
review:
This is a very simple metroidvania, and there's very little in the game to make it stand out from others in the genre, but I still found it enjoyable. I've seen some complain that the game is too easy, but I definitely think playing on hard is a decent difficulty. The controls and combat are pretty fluid, and there's decent enemy variety, however most of the enemies' attack patterns are very predictable and easy to dodge after a couple of fights. Unfortunately with the weapons, I've found no reason to use anything other than regular swords, as heavier weapons generally have a minor damage increase but at the cost of much slower attack speed, and weapons like fists and knives just don't have the attack range to be effective.

The procedural world generation seems like it was just tossed in the game without much reason; I only have one save file, but I don't think another playthrough with a new layout would change the game very much. So overall I'd give a "light" recommendation, as I had fun with it, but it was nothing remarkable.

review: It seems like i've only just started Chasm, and maybe I have, but so far, this game has proven to be an extremely fun experience for me. It's very basic and easy to understand from a gameplay perspective, but as you traverse deeper and deeper into the dark, youll find it's no longer so easy. This is no Souls game, but it does present a challenge of its own. The farther you dive into the cursed mine and uncover its secrets, the more dangerous your surroundings become, and the more fearsome your enemies prove to be. Every enemy has a unique attack style, you'll have to learn them if you want to survive. Every fight is like a chess match (until you start one shotting lower level enemies.) I'm very excited to keep playing this game and continue the story that comes with it. I heavily recommend this game to anyone who may be interested.

review:
I would have chosen mixed instead of negative if Steam allowed it since Chasm isn't a bad game. However, the slow, clunky combat, uninspired powerups and enemies, extreme grindiness, and the infrequency of save stations hold this game back in a crowded genre. 

The art is great and saving villagers is somewhat rewarding, but with so many excellent metroidvania titles out currently Chasm just isn't up to par. If you've somehow exhausted all the better metroidvanias, this might be worth the playthrough if you pick it up on sale. I'll probably dip back into it on occasion, just not with a ton of enthusiasm.

review:
A well-paced, thoroughly enjoyable action platformer with metroidvania elements.
It has varied locations, good graphics, a great soundtrack and is challenging but not overly difficult. 
Exploration feels rewarding and you always find something new.
Also, in case you're reading "procedurally generated" and are immediately put off (like I am to be honest), don't be. If it didn't mention it in the description I would have never known, it's not noticeable at all.

If you've already played the top games in the genre and are looking for more, Chasm is not a bad choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974618029', 'num_games_owned': 2769, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1589844348}
review:
Chasm is a good game I can't honestly recommend.  

As a Castlevania-like platformer it is nice and fun, with one big BUT... The controls are a bit clumsy, but that's not a huge problem, it just costs you when you miss some platforms or so. This however grows as a problem, when you get deeper in the dungeon. There comes a real issue - save system. 

You can save only in special rooms, which is fine, but they are too faaaaaaaar away. It's not uncommon that you search dungeon for an hour. After you make few mistakes (either by your fault or because of controls), you are almost certainly low on health. There is not enough items to heal yourself, so only possibility is to backtrack all the way to last save. All the enemies respawn when you leave and re-enter the room (even though it was 1sec ago), so backtracking is the same danger like going forward. Well, let's say you survive that and get to the save point. After the save you gain all your health again, go forward to the final point you reached in the dungeon before, hopefully with less errors than before.

Big problem is in some places you can't see what you can expect during first run so it's common you loose your health until you realize what is happening.  When you make few of those mistakes you couldn't really avioid in a new room, you are low on health again... that means you need to backtrack all the way again. 

From some places there is not even possible to backtrack to save point (because of story). The result is you are sometimes in a position you know you will die soon, for example when the only way is to go in a boss battle, but you can't do anything about it and you know in advance all you have done in last hour will be meaningless. 

I'm sure there are many players that are more skilled or patient than me and are ok with this. But to be honest, I don't get this concept. For a proper hard-to-win game it's far too easy, almost a casual game as common enemies are really simple to match. If you seek just fun, it's unnecesarily annoying and punishing for small mistakes, because of save system, game design and you pay for errors with too much time consuming repetition.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970530938', 'num_games_owned': 2733, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1589379905}
review:
It started so well. Looks good, feels ok, lots of items and stuff dropping, it's all very exciting. Even the randomized levels are fine. Having played A Robot Named Fight I know they can work in this genre. ARNF it should be noted is designed to be 30-90 minutes a run. This I would learn is an important detail.

And then it just keeps going. Backtracking over the same randomized nonsense levels. Fighting slight variations of the same enemies, watching the same items drop most of which are useless. Oh cool, another new ability that's just a glorified key. Oh this one's just an actual key, and now I'm stuck again.

I don't like handholding, but when you don't have handholding you need some logic to connect the dots in your brain. This works out a few times quite well in the form of some semi-obscure puzzles. Other times you're expected to remember the shape of a hole in a door you saw 5 hours ago. Maybe if the levels weren't random blobs you could have a logic to the level design that would aid in that, but no.

There's a number of things that aren't properly thought out in this game and the longer you play the more you encounter them. For instance it became impossible for me to complete the bestiary because no one thought things out. The shops outside of the potion vendor become useless very quickly because again, no one thought things out. The game stops being fun because of course, no one thought things out.

Or worse, they thought the wrong things - like perfecting a randomized map system that sabotages the game - out instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009752238', 'num_games_owned': 953, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1589145758}
review:
.....I really want to like this game, I truly do. But I can't get past the frustrations it causes me when I play it. If you played Castlevania Symphony of the Night, then you'll feel right at home with the controls of the game. Slow walk speed, nice sprite animation quality, and back dashing is faster than walking.

The story is that you are a soldier sent to investigate the mine of a mostly abandoned town to save the townspeople who were abducted by monsters. The further you explore into the mines, you start finding other areas and lore based on the monsters and where they come from.

Most reviews I have skimmed have said that the problem with this game is the grinding and annoying combat. I agree that the combat is slow and very punishing. You have to learn enemy patterns or lose a CHUNK of health. They get harder and harder with little room for error the further you get into the dungeon. And if you want decent gear, even when you save townspeople, the shops are EXPENSIVE. Gold is few and far between and you'll really have to work your butt off leveling up and just trying to survive. 

My other main issue is the save points. You can't save at anytime, you can only save in certain rooms (just like Castlevania). The problem is that these rooms are few and far between. So imagine searching for an hour through the dungeon, your health is low because there is barely any health items in the game and suddenly WHAM you die. Guess what, that hour of progress is gone and you gotta do it all over again. Add the many leaps of faith and perfect timing jumps you have to make with how stiff your character is, and you're in for a rough start. I know you get some new abilities as you continue like wall climbing and the slide, but I grew so tired and frustrated from losing hours of progress because of the annoying combat, inability to save, and the grinding.

Final verdict? Give this game a try if you like metroidvanias with a challenge. Be prepared for lots of grinding, precise jumping, and tough gameplay. This is not a bad game, it's just really tough and precise and I do not have the patience to finish it. Thank you for reading!

TL:DR: A nice metroidvania but plagued with unforgiving combat, lots of grinding, and barely any save points. Looks very nice, but you gotta bring your A game or you will suffer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985373995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1589086378}
review:
I feel like there is a good platformer in here somewhere, just below the surface. But everywhere you look, there is jank and jank and poor design and more jank. I just couldn't take it anymore and had to write this review after the parachute failed to function after a "double" jump yet again. 

The bad
-Developers were far too conservative with movement skills. Where's the high jump? The grapple? The Roc's Feather? The Black Panther Soul? The <Insert other iconic interesting movement skills>? Nah, we two types of wall jumps and a neutered 1.5x jump masquerading as a double jump. And no, you cannot increase the character's slow movement speed - have fun backdashing and sliding everywhere just to get around slightly faster. Maybe the devs watched Symphony of the Night speedruns and thought "wow, all that backdashing looks fun, let's make our entire game that!"
-Half of the enemies in the game. Many of the game's enemies are either pathetically easy or stupidly difficult. In the same area: "Takes 3 hits to kill, deals 20 damage: I jump over his attack and stab him in the back until he dies." vs "Takes 12 hits, does 30 damage, huge so takes up the entire hallway, has highly inconsistent attack so you're going to take huge damage practically every time. Better have potions to chug."
-Most of the bosses. The bosses use attacks reminiscent of bosses from other popular platforming games. This isn't a good thing. As mentioned before, the character moves around like a lead brick and has a giant hurtbox, so avoiding fast attacks or weaving through bullets Touhou-style does not work very well. In most cases, you will take less damage by taking a hit and using the iframes to damage the boss, thereby reducing your number of hits taken by killing the boss faster.
-Backtracking. To clear Area X, you have to backtrack to a number of areas equal to X/2, rounded up, to find that one item that lets you progress. The problem isn't the backtracking, but the lack of any real content in the areas you need to go to and, again, a lack of fun movement skills. "Go back to Chapter 2 and slide through a passage to a room where you will receive an item that lets you wall jump, so you can go back to Chapter 1 to wall jump to a room where you will receive an item that will let you breathe underwater to let you complete Area 4 and move to Area 5, before which you will need to backtrack to Area 3 to get an item to let you double jump leading you back to Area 4 to get a lamp so you can progress to the second half of Area 5 before backtracking to Area 1 for..."
-Itemization. Why are red chests dropping me items inferior to a white item that dropped off of an enemy two areas ago? I had to go through the Arena to get to the area that dropped Iron Armor, so why is the Iron Armor worse in every way than the chest that I got from beating the Arena? I have been using the same blue sword for most of the game and it would be great to get an upgrade, or at least a sidegrade that I can switch between when the sword is less effective. Early in the game I had options, but as I progressed the interesting weapon variety disappeared.

The good
-The other half of the enemies. There are a lot of enemies where you have to recognize their tell and act in different ways, where if you act properly, you can successfully and consistently avoid and then punish the attack. This is good gameplay.
-Sound design. Music, etc.

I thought my list of good points was going to be larger.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963858057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1589514000}
review:
From the very beginning I found that the game was going to be something I will enjoy.  

I like the story, the controls and character movement are smooth as I am using a Gamepad to play. I also love the Castlevania 'esk style of the game. 

I would recommend this game for any one who enjoyed the older Nintendo games such as Zelda 2 or Battle of Olympus.

I gave up towards the end as I was able to find all of the townsfolk but it was unclear as to where I needed to go or what to do to finish the game. Probably because I sold an important item.

I feel that there is too much Backtracking over the same 4 areas which slows the game down and makes it more of a chore than fun.  Super Metroid had more areas which were just inaccessible and you didn't have to remember where things were, you could just look at the map and see what area you haven't been to yet. Thats what made Chasm difficult and time consuming as you would pass by areas and it would highlight the map forcing you to have to stop and remember what you passed by. If you forget where something is prepare for at least an hour of backtracking or searching the entire map to find it. 

When I started a 2nd play through of the game I found that it didn't change much. This is due to certain parts such as boss fight areas and main entrances staying same. Its as if each room on the map is simply shuffled like a deck of cards and put in a different order each new game. This doesn't compare to a game called Terraria where the entire world is random and is never really the same.

Nonetheless, I had a good time playing and feel that its worth the effort to at least invest a few hours of time into Chasm just for the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157170208', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1588847300}
review:
"Chasm" √® un metroidvania nato su Kickstarter, grazie a tanti contributi. Questa cosa mi fa molto piacere, perch√© c'√® tanta gente con buone idee che merita un finanziamento.
Nel caso di "Chasm" posso dire che il gioco √® venuto bene, seppur con delle mancanze.
Questa recluta dovr√† scoprire cos'√® successo in un piccolo villaggio, dove tutti i suoi cittadini, tranne il sindaco, sono spariti.
Se dovessi descrivere questo gioco, la parola giusta sarebbe "anonimo". Ed √® anonimo perch√© √® buono in tutto e non eccelle in niente. Una volta finito non c'√® niente di "Chasm" che ti rimanga. Questo perch√© la storia che narra, approfondita da pochi documenti, √® abbastanza semplice. Inoltre i personaggi del gioco, compreso lo stesso protagonista, non sono per niente descritti ed approfonditi. Non ti senti legato a nessuno. Nonostante questo, il gioco si lascia giocare con piacevolezza, sia per il buon numero di nemici che popola le varie mappe, sia per la buona quantit√† di segreti che potremo trovare. Anche per quanto riguarda le armi posso dire che sono diverse nelle skin, ma troppo simili nei pattern d'attacco. Buone le location, carine le musiche. Nota storta sono le boss fight: fatta eccezione per gli ultimi 3 Boss principali, questi saranno poco pericolosi e poco ispirati sia come design, sia come pattern d'attacco. Le boss fight segrete sono da dimenticare. C'√® poi una simpatica modalit√† Arcade, dove potremo completare dei livelli random con un tempo di scadenza.
Non c'√® stato il minimo impegno neanche nel creare un finale un p√≤ pi√π articolato ed approfondito.
"Chasm" lo consiglio a chi ama i metroidvania, ma sappiate che esistono tante produzioni fatte meglio. Un buon gioco e basta.
VOTO: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198024634645', 'num_games_owned': 738, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1534105712}
review: Critical disappointment.  I just now realized that I never actually posted my review for this absolute travesty of a game.  Everything that was present in the demo, with the exception of the graphics is gone.  You can't choose your stats or abilities on level up, everything is automated, leaving the player with no agency in how their character actually performs or advances.  The magic is boring; it just feels like generic projectile attacks like the items from Castlevania, very tacked on.  None of the magic feels like it is worth it when you can just get better items anyway.  Magic doesn‚Äôt make you feel powerful, or even magical.  The graphics are okay, I like the art style, but the motion blur is annoying, and some people have problems with it making them nauseous.  The enemies are incredibly stupid, and only walk towards you menacingly, not to mention their iffy hit boxes.  The level design is also annoying.  Since it‚Äôs semi-randomly generated at world creation, you get important rooms, such as save points and bosses, at roughly the same location no matter what, but the rooms between them are random.  On paper this is actually an excellent idea, but unfortunately, there‚Äôs no actual guarantee that those rooms will be any good.  For example, in most Metroidvanias, the rooms outside of critical need locations, such as healing, or saving rooms, are made to be easier or safer to traverse, so you don‚Äôt die at the last minute, and have to start all over again.  In game design, challenges are meant to be punctuated with safe easier areas to give players breathing room, if not check points.  Because the games ‚Äòin between‚Äô rooms are randomized though, you may get two challenges in a row that must be overcome in order to progress, or a particularly difficult challenge right outside of a boss fight or a save location.  Overall, this is a hard avoid for me.  I wanted to like it, as the PS3 demo was absolutely excellent, but the final product is devoid of everything that made it more than just a platformer.  If you like Metroidvanias, there is better elsewhere.  If you absolutely have to play this game, then get it at a discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063628919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1587609759}
review:
[h1] Overall Disappointing [/h1]

Overall,  on  a range from "Woohoo!" to "Cat coughing up hairball noises", I have to give Chasm a solid "Meh".

I had anticipated this game once it was announced on Crowdfunding, but due to my serious reservations with the whole crowdfunding idea, I waited until the game was 50% off and paid $9.99 for it.

I'm glad that I only paid $9.99 for it. I like to judge how much fun I will have, or have had, with a game based on price and how much time it would take me to work for the price of that game.

I don't feel like I overpaid for it, and but also don't think that the experience is worth a full $20. Playing the content within the game for "18 hours" (7.5 hours of actual game time), the value of the game for me was about $1.33 an hour. I felt like the game was worth $1.33 an hour.

Overall, I felt like Chasm was tired though. After the games originally created content of the Mines location, the content felt repetitive and dry. The monsters had very similar characteristics, and the actions and "puzzles" seemed expected. I like when a game surprises me, but Chasm didn't do this other than rare occasions.

Parts of the game felt disjointed like: [spoiler] Ringing the bell tower bells [/spoiler]. Like why?

I felt myself just kind of playing the game not because "I just had to see what happened next!", but because I kept telling myself, "maybe it will get better?" 

Well, it didn't really.

It is a "Metroidvania" style game, with backtracking for almost always useless things that don't make you feel more powerful.

these reasons are why I give Chasm a "Meh."

author: {'steamid': '76561198054712891', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1588534397}
review: In terms of how well Chasm stacks up against other Metroidvania games I'd say not very much but that does not mean that the game doesn't have its own strengths that separates it and makes it special. The seed generator for starters is its most notable feature allowing the player to go through rooms in different orders with different enemy placements in every new game thus guaranteeing that each play through will be different. The music is another strength since each level has a catchy tune which is a must when the player is required to go through them for extended periods of time although I did listen almost exclusively to the chiptune version which to me just fit the game better given its pretty 16-bit graphics so my thoughts on the original track are inconclusive. In terms of overall gameplay I had a pretty good time. There's always a sense of progression due to the level up system, you're always finding new loot, and it feels good to kill stuff. One thing that made me almost hate the game by the end of it are the last two levels. They were an absolute CHORE to get through. One stage consisted entirely of teleporters so I was never sure which ones I had to take to progress and by the end of it I didn't even bother collecting any of the optional items because I just wanted to get the hell outta there as soon as possible. Unfortunately the final level was somehow even worse with projectile spam that made it almost impossible to avoid taking damage. Worst of all the final boss was 8 rooms away so when I died it'd be a while before I'd get another shot. God forbid I got hurt though because I needed every last bit of HP for the boss. I finished the game at level 31. Overall I'd still recommend Chasm because what it has going for it is honestly really good but don't expect something truly great.

review: I'd give Chasm a "so-so" rating if I could, but on the whole, it's an acceptable metroidvanai game. Chasm tries to set itself apart from the pack with procedurally-generated levels, which is unfortunately lost on most players since they'll only play the game once and be unimpressed by areas whose design is somewhat loose.  However, my main gripe is the lack of attack-cancelling, which make combat less fluid than I like and you end up taking a lot of avoidable hits or contact damage just because you're stuck in an attack animation.  It would have been nice if there were more weapon variety too, but still, I never though "ugh, Chasm" until the very end. The game is only about 9 hours long, so it can be nice way to spend a weekend if you're a fan on the genre (and get it on sale).

author: {'steamid': '76561198051819615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1588534454}
review: This game checks all the metroidvania boxes but doesn't go beyond that.  The core game play is ok.  Nothing really stands out, the bosses and enemies are so-so and game progression feels like a slog.  Armor and weapons are almost completely reliant on the random drops since the in game shops offer very little even once you unlock them.  You can craft items from drops, but  the drop rates are really low, so you'd have better luck hoping for a rare weapon drop or farming like it's an MMO.  The random map generation doesn't actually make the game stand out, because there's no real point.  New game + isn't a thing, so it's doubtful completionists will start more than 1 new game (once they realize that perfect clearing bosses gives special drops) and no one else will bother because the characters and story are as mediocre as it gets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042948809', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1625751866}
review:
Its pretty neat at first - but it doesn't go anywhere any time soon. 

Greatly dislike how fast and random the bosses are initially, makes fighting them a real pain when your movement options are slide jump or walk without a divekick or anything (at least from what i experienced - you might get one later I only got slide the wall hang on certain ledges and the lantern), not that fun when a boss does a tenth of your hp every hit and you have to restart the fights repeatedly to learn proper timings to dodge things for phase 1 before triggering a phase 2 if there is one. 

Wouldn't particularly recommend unfortunately, would personally go obtain one of the older castlevanias or buy bloodstained just due to the sheer slog Chasm has to get back to wherever it is you died.

Unless there's something I'm missing regarding the weapons, there is no "go-to" that solves most of my issues, as the greatswords/clubs are very slow (as they should be admittedly, but there's no way to speed them up to my knowledge), the swords are quite clunky when you need to hit something smaller than you, the dagger is a death sentence and the same for fist weapons unless there's some hidden parry skill I missed. 

Magic can be quite broken from what I heard but because I found the vendor for it late I probably didn't get the full mage experience and it wasn't broken for my runs so I was forced to rely on melee.

Perhaps its just not my thing, I don't know - I just feel that something like bloodstained would be a better choice :shrug:

author: {'steamid': '76561198041956308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1587964529}
review:
Chasm falls short in a lot of ways, I think.  

Its claim to fame is its "procedurally-assembled areas from hand-crafted rooms".  I was ready and willing to like this aspect of the game. However, what this really means is that each level is a patched together slog of long rectangles with 3-5 enemies in it, a fork in the road, several dead end rooms with a buff or chest, some environmental hazards, then the boss.  It feels incredibly shallow and not worth ditching an ACTUALLY hand crafted game for.

The combat and movement is clunky and unsatisfying.  You do not have enough options to make regular enemy encounters  interesting, so despite there being 80ish enemies in the game, most of the have similar movesets from level to level.  Even with what is on offer, sometimes I was still asking myself "how was I supposed to dodge that while still being able to deal damage?" I know there are those who find this style nostalgic or whatever but honestly it just doest feel fun to play half of the time.  

The upgrades you get fulfulling the "metroidvania" part of the game are some of the most boring, worst integrated upgrades ive seen in a game like this.  Almost half of the upgrades are never utilized in more than a few fringe cases, and a quarter of them are completely invalidated by future upgrades.  There isnt a single unique thing to experience in this game in this regard.  I suppose thats the cost of not being able to, again, actually hand craft the levels.

Chasm suffers tremendously from what feels like dozens of oversights which make it a chore to play.  Some enemies's attack animations take way too long to end, resulting in them holding out their weapon waiting for you to walk into it.  Instead of there being a save point in each level's hub, the first level is the only one that has one.  Added to this, the only way to replenish your mana is to make the trek back to the hub town, or by destroying lanterns for 1-3 mana...sometimes.  The loot is baffling, as probably within my first few hours of gameplay I got a legendary leather armor that I never replaced because everything else was worse.  Some pieces have semi interesting effects, but more often than not youll just pick whatever has the highest numbers.  You never get crazy strong so backtracking remains annoying, coupled with enemies that respawn when you exit and reenter a room.  So getting a chest at the end of a gauntlet isnt just a challenge once, but twice.  There are more, but thats enough from me.  

*Edit:  I have 100% completed this game, only missing the 4 rarest achievements.  At the time of writing this original review, I had seen the final boss and decided the game hadnt bought enough good will from me to do what it was asking.  A few days later, I decided to just grit my teeth and finish what I had started.  An hour later after cleaning up some chores, I beat the game.  Afterward I uninstalled, content that after editing this review, I never needed to think about this game again.

If none of what I said bothers you, then youll probably enjoy Chasm.  Its art is pretty good, and despite what Ive said, if youre looking for something to scratch that exploration itch, then this game can certainly try.  Its just to rough around the edges for me.

review:
I'm not sure how bad the previous versions of this game were, but judging by the current version (1.076), I'd say I disagree with most of the negative reviews. 

Out of all metroidvanias on Steam, this one is probably the most similar to igavanias. That means that you have a medieval/fantasy setting with tons of weapons and armors, subweapons, consumable items, a bestiary, relics, etc. The game's difficulty is also more on the easy side, just like the igavanias. 

I enjoyed my first playthrough a lot and I simply could not find anything bad about this game. Perhaps the art and the music are too generic,  and the story isn't great, but the gameplay was very solid nonetheless. The randomly generated world didn't feel bad at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043473689', 'num_games_owned': 690, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1583040620}
review:
I have mixed feelings about Chasm. The artwork is very charming, but beyond the nice visuals it is a bog standard Metroidvania.

I remember when I first heard about Chasm a lot of the hype surrounding the game was tied to the potential of playing through more than once with different map layouts, but honestly by the end of your first playthrough there is no reason to go back. 

Frustratingly, the game has a good amount of backtracking (as one would expect in a metroidvania game) that requires revisiting rooms that have no unique marking on the map, meaning you can waste a lot of time looking for them. The weapons you gain throughout your playthrough are also very bland, there is very little variation to make different builds.

All in all despite the bitching, I'd recommend Chasm if its on sale, if you plan to play on normal, and if you've run out of other Metroidvania games to play.

(Seriously it is not worth playing on hard. I play all my games at the highest difficulty but this one was not the enjoyable kind of difficulty, more the tedious kind)

author: {'steamid': '76561197994851714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1585343641}
review:
I've enjoyed this game more than I thought I would. The art style is pleasing in general. I especially liked the enemy design and animation. Otherwise, the protagonist's sprite is a little bland but is also well-animated. The environments are fine but they lack variety.

The gameplay itself is enjoyable and will be very familiar to anyone who's played metroidvania games before. The game is clearly influenced by Symphony of the Night, which is not a bad thing in itself. Weapons are sufficiently varied and most items have their use. Controls could be a little less stiff but they are responsive, at least. Traversal can be a but of a chore, though. Artefacts that grant new movement powers are a little awkward to use at first and backtracking can tedious.

In general, though, this is a very nice effort and it's clearly a game crafted with love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049380486', 'num_games_owned': 1131, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1585257975}
review:
It's derivative from SotN, make no mistake. If you get this game, prepare for a SotN-type game, all down to the after-images when moving around.
That said, this is a very comfy game. Some bits of gear can be better than average, giving you some extra physical or magical attack, or extra luck. The magic options you have are pretty much 1:1 to Castlevania subweapons and can be upgraded to the point it can possibly out-damage your physical attacks. The enemy variety is pretty neat and the music comes in two flavors on top of being pretty high quality.
As of now I haven't finished it, so I can't say anything about the different difficulty modes, or seeds, or how those are even worth it, but depending on how much more I have to go, I can see this being a fun thing to go back to every now and again to try out another run.
I have no clue if there will be any DLC for this or not, but with how every run can be randomized, there's room to grow.

Overall, pretty nice game to play. If you want something unique or out there, this isn't it. It's the type of game you play when you've gotten tired of beating SotN in 5> hours and want new yet familiar ground.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263316031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 462, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1605993057}
review:
Wow, realmente es un juego que merece mas amor a pesar de tener unos puntos que molestan un poco, no podia pensar en otra cosa que jugar a esto.
Es un metroidvania tirando mas hacia el lado de los castlevania, con un pixel art que me gusto mucho a pesar de que me parecia un poco borroso, me gusto el efecto que daba en movimiento.
El camino del juego esta enmarallado como lo haria otros metrodvanias, para que tengas que regresar cuando tengas la reliquia adecuada, pero no asi los caminos secundarios que apenas y son un par por reliquia, me falto un poco eso, pero esta bien.
Ya digo que tiene muchos elementos castlevania, recuperas salud con comida que sueltan los enemigos y la usas desde el resguardo del menu (que en un mundo post dark souls, ya no se ve tanto), tambien los enemigos tienen loot, pueden soltar equipamiento de distintas raresas, para mi tenia una tasas muy bajas porque apenas y me salio una rara, en todo el juego. Tambien tienes un dash hacia atras para esquivar y un pu√±ado de magias que recuerdan mucho a otros juegos, una bomba de fuego, un hacha en arco, una daga, etc.
De lo poco que me fallo es que los enemigos apenas y reaccion a tus ataque casi que ni los empujas entonces avanzan y te hacen buen da√±o. Y que cuando mueres no solo pierdes todo desde la ultima vez que guardaste sino que te manda al menu principal, ¬øpara que?, me hubiera gustado que me mandara directo al punto de guardado.
Me gusto mucho, recomiendo que se le de una oportunidad, un juego muy confortante, que da gusto explorar, no muy dificil ni muy facil.

review:
As a lover of Metroid and Castlevania games alike, I have been quite excited about this game for years now. So many critics were saying they couldn't wait to try it out and then after the game's release... silence. I had forgotten about it. Fast forward to now, I got it for "free" in Humble Choice and was pumped to give it a go! Unfortunately, it didn't live up to it's hopeful hype...

Yeah some enemies are a pain and yeah the drops to restore HP are to few, but the game's main problem is It's just... so boring. Like there's some anomaly I can't quite put my finger on that makes it feel like an unexciting slog.
3 hours in, I gave it a solid go, but I'm gonna move on at this point. 

Thankfully my money has indirectly gone to the dev already (and thankfully I didn't pay $20), so I hope they can learn some lessons and improve on their next game.

review:
Seriously, don't. It's great fun and all. Nice, if a little rudimentary mechanics. Cool graphics. Tricky, but not too hard gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025185275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1610744429}
review:
Metroidvania (action rpg platformer) - 8/10

One of my overall favorite genres of games. If you're into them, this is absolutely a solid entry. Can't wait to see what comes next from this dev!

Interesting variety of areas and enemies. Movement abilities get interesting, like clinging to ledges or wall jumping. The game could be a little more heavily populated with enemies in my opinion, I generally like more combat than I'm getting here. The jumping puzzles are really enjoyable though, makes exploration pretty fun.

In addition to melee weapons, you can also build your equipment to focus on sub-weapons, although I haven't seen a decent way to recover mana reliably yet, so it could be an interesting challenge to try a magic build. So far, you get drips of mana from breaking candles. Can I just whine about having to break every candle in this entire genre?

Story isn't bad, but it's nothing exciting either. Essentially, you're on an expedition into the mines, and some townsfolk are trapped inside, and there's something about an ancient civilization, which might lead to a cool ending, here's hoping! Story usually takes a back seat in this genre, so it's not really a point against this game, but just a gripe in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066784959', 'num_games_owned': 1090, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 971, 'last_played': 1583961275}
review:
When the game came out I read a lot of on mixed and negative reviews.
I must say after completing the game I was blown away by the quality.

-Fluid controls - I cannot stress this enough, controling your character is pixel perfect and smooth
-Rich enviroment - each biome is fresh and new
-Excelent pacing - not one minute was I bored or annoyed
-Perfectly placed save spots

A lot has been said about random generated map and how it ruined the game. Honestly, if I never knew this game has random generated map I would never know. I played games with much worse manually generated enviroment!
I played a lot of metroidvania but I have to place this one at the very top!
Great job devs!

I'm glad you stuck with the game and polished it. Final product is a true gem!

review:
Got this in a bundle and I enjoyed my time with it! 

[h1]The good:[/h1]
+ The artstyle is great!
+ Enjoyed the enemy variety (there are different types for each zone.
+ Combat was okay. (Almost exclusively poke and run gameplay)

[h1]The bad:[/h1]
- the story and world building could definitely be better. Although there were in-game book collectables, I felt that it didn't really sell me the story of the game.
- you need a wiki/guide to know how to progress in some areas. 
- YOUR CHARACTER LOOKS THE SAME REGARDLESS OF THE GEAR YOU EQUIP. It rubs me the way - "Oh look at this cool dark armor I found! Too bad I cant see my character wearing it :("
- Could use more weapon and spell variety

Definitely give it a try at a discount. Would recommend this if you enjoy metroidvanias.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844708181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1431, 'last_played': 1583524054}
review:
Chasm is a simple and pretty fun metroidvania game.
If you have played any of the castlevania titles you will recongnize a lot of things right from the start like the kind of upgrades that you'll get or the weapons and sub-weapons that you'll use.

Chasm main selling point was supposed to be it proceduraly generated world that would give you and unique and inovating experience, but i would said that's the main flaw that this game has. I beated the game twice ( 1st time on HARD mode and the 2nd time on Normal - mortal aka  die once and your save file is gone) and i didn¬¥t notice big changes in the rooms or locations except from some random rearranged rooms. Theres no room or location in the game that will get written for ever in your mind like Hollow Knight's City of Tears or the entrance to Riddley's lair of Super metroid, everything feels a bit simple and uninspiring, in other words, Chasm lacks a sense of identity to make it set apart from other metroidvanias titles.

The story is pretty simple, the OST has some good beats on it but it kinda gets repetitive a bit quickly and the animations and pixel art are (by far one) of the BEST POINTS of this game, it's a pretty good example of a beautifully crafted pixel art.

BUT don¬¥t get me wrong, Chasm is still a pretty fun game to play and if you like this kind of titles give it a try but don¬¥t expect to be mind blown by it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025287051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1583, 'last_played': 1582344362}
review:
Apesar da ideia por tr√°s de Chasm ser interessante, o diferencial dele acaba trazendo mais problemas do que novidades memor√°veis para o estilo de jogo. 

Um metroidvania com salas e mapas gerados de forma procedural soam at√© que interessante, mas no final, acabou destruindo o ponto mais forte dos metroidvanias: a explora√ß√£o. 

O enredo do jogo √© simples e bem raso, apenas apresentando a raz√£o da aventura acontecer. 
O combate do jogo n√£o tem nada de incr√≠vel, mas funciona muito bem. Armas com diferentes tipos de golpes, alcances e claro, n√£o podiam faltar as magias: arremessar adagas, machados, po√ß√µes e at√© mesmo shurikens. Na pr√°tica parece incr√≠vel, mas no final, √© tudo muito simples e sem gra√ßa. 

Ficava ansioso achando que a pr√≥xima magia que eu ia comprar seria incr√≠vel ou super interessante, mas quando eu descobria como era... acabava sendo frustrante por todo o dinheiro investido nela.

Os inimigos s√£o at√© que legais, mas o brilho fica mais pros chef√µes, que tem suas dificuldades, principalmente se voc√™ quiser matar eles sem tomar nenhum golpe (fornecendo um equipamento de recompensa, que facilita a jogatina). 

Geralmente ap√≥s os chef√µes, voc√™ vai encontrar habilidades especiais, que te v√£o permitir acessar √°reas que antes n√£o eram poss√≠veis, o cl√°ssico metroidvania... e ai come√ßa o grande problema.

O maior problema desse jogo √© o backtracking, ou seja, retornar a lugares que voc√™ j√° passou no jogo, pra descobrir novas √°reas e usar suas novas habilidades. Em um jogo onde os mapas s√£o repetitivos pelo fator procedural e com lugares nem um pouco memor√°veis, a experi√™ncia de backtracking acabou sendo muito frustrante e cansativa. Precisei passar pelas fases, sala por sala, v√°rias e v√°rias vezes, tornando o progresso do jogo t√£o irritante, t√£o frustrante, que me fez questionar minha sanidade mental. 

Infelizmente o jogo teria um potencial muito mais bem aproveitado se o mapa fosse feito a m√£o pelos desenvolvedores, pois essa ideia de criar um jogo √∫nico pra cada jogador, acabou criando um jogo chato, repetitivo e irritante. Seus pontos positivos s√£o completamente anulados pelos pontos negativos, e por conta disso, n√£o recomendaria a nenhuma pessoa o jogo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969374860', 'num_games_owned': 791, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1533516776}
review:
I kickstarted this game way back in the day, what was it 6 or 7 years ago? And it's unfortunately one of the biggest gaming disappointments I've ever encountered. I'm a big fan of Metroidvanias, but this game is by far one of the weakest that's come out in years. Nothing about the game stands out, combat, progression, the random level design, enemies, abilities, the music, etc... all are just incredibly mediocre.

Even  over a year later and multiple patches in, the core design of the game is still fundamentally flawed. There are so many more interesting and better indie Metroidvanias out there, as the competition has grown fierce over the past decade... even on sale or for free, I just can't recommend this game. It's just uninteresting and excessively generic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127427880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1582902216}
review:
All-in-all, as a game, it does a good job. It focuses on a deliberate (borderline frustrating) play style where you have to pay attention to the enemy's attacks rather than hacking n slashing your way through. I'll argue that this play style becomes annoying when there's so much backtracking and looking-around involved. But maybe that's the vibe the developers were going for; the perilous adventure of combing through a dungeon filled with monsters. (Needs better narrative writing, though. Like this review; too wordy.)

Pros:
- Good music
- Great pixel animation
- Simple and easy enough to play.
- Final boss fight was okay
- Controls feel responsive (when you're not clunkily falling into poison/electric pits) 
- Reminiscent of SotN (Except all the dying)

Cons:
- The narrative, while simple, is tedious to follow. Very text-heavy, and I feel it could've been more concise. Plus, reading through the dialogue won't really give mush (if any) clue as to what you're supposed to be doing, tbh.
- A LOT of backtracking. Which is fine if you've don't have a day job.
- Those little dot's in the map are treasure chests!!!?? I've been running around trying to look for the ones I missed and they're been staring at my face all along!?
- Poor conveyance. You WILL be looking up walkthroughs. 
- Can we please be done with "enemies damage you even if u brush against they're shoulder" thing? They have "Attack" animations for a reason; to cause damage. What's the point of an attack animation if all they have to do is invade my personal space to kill me? At least lower the damage caused by non-attack contact?
- You'll die A LOT. So much you'll think this is a Salt & Sanctuary sequel.
- Potions are expensive (after you actually unlock the person who sells them to you) + you earn money veeeeery slowly. So you best git gud, or get used to seeing the game over screen.
- Jump+Attack is your go-to mode of attack, since anything else will lock you in place for 5 years and leave you open to attacks (99% of the time)

review:
*got the game through humble choice*

The game is not particularly bad, it looks all right but I played for an hour and it simply doesn't grab my attention or make me want to play any further.

On the plus side: It is visually appealing, it looks like there is a lot of content and a rich story.

On the minus side: fighting is a pain because it isn't very reactive which is frustrating.

Apparently, the layout is randomly generated, I discovered that after I stopped playing: in principle, that could be a great concept, and I guess it is kinda well executed since I didn't notice, but I fail to see the benefit of that rather than handcrafted layout.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162239521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1582753243}
review:
En mi caso no ha superado la prueba de las tres horas. Si tras tres horas, un juego de estas caracter√≠sticas no me dice nada, no puedo recomendarlo. Comenzaba muy prometedor pero conforme vas jugando, se va viniendo abajo.

Chasm es un peque√±o metroidvania de libro. De hecho, se juega de forma extremadamente similar a symphony of the night, aria of sorrow o cualquiera de los castlevanias de ds... pero peor. Es extremadamente parecido en su propuesta jugable. ¬øEl problema? Que los desarrolladores, sean novatos o no, se comportan como si lo fueran. Me explico.

No tienen coraje ninguno. Son unos cobardes con respecto al dise√±o del juego, lo que se manifiesta tanto en la jugabilidad como en el dise√±o art√≠stico. No hablo aqu√≠ de presupuestos o potencia gr√°fica. Estos t√≠os tienen un arte de p√≠xel bastante avanzado pero completamente desaprovechado. Si quer√©is que emplee una terminolog√≠a menos hiriente, a estos chicos les falta ambici√≥n.

Se nota en todos los detalles, que hay muchos porque adem√°s duele lo detallistas que son los desarrolladores. Se lo curran, pero entienden todo mal. Por ejemplo, quieren hacer una mazmorra que parezca infinita, laber√≠ntica, sin fondo. Muy bien. ¬øPor qu√© todo parece una mina r√∫stica? ¬øNo tendr√≠as que haber creado un par de paletas diferentes, distintos tipos de roca, algo que rompa la monoton√≠a del paisaje? Siento que todas las salas son iguales, aunque propongan puzles (sencillos) diferentes. Ellos creen que est√°n siendo consistentes pero no, est√°n siendo repetitivos. Haz la mazmorra m√°s corta o fragm√©ntala en √°reas m√°s peque√±as que ofrezcan un cambio en las vistas al jugador, Blasphemous lo hace, Hollow Knight lo hace, todos los que tienen dos dedos de frente lo hacen. He jugado metroidvanias de presupuesto cercano a cero que consegu√≠an aportar algo m√°s de variedad en las primeras horas de juego.

Y echan sal en la herida: Ves a tu personaje viajar por tierras hermosas, valles, monta√±as, y est√°s deseando explorar... para que en cuanto llegas a tu destino, te metan en una mina no s√© cu√°ntas horas. Eh... ¬øqu√©? ¬øPor qu√©? ¬øPor qu√© no estoy explorando un sitio hermoso y fascinante si me has ense√±ado que sabes hacerlos? 

Otro ejemplo de dise√±o equivocado: Las zonas de guardado. En los metroidvanias vais a pasar mucho tiempo en zonas de guardado, porque intentar√©is visitarlos con frecuencia. Normalmente se intenta que sean lugares llamativos, fascinantes, est√©ticamente diferentes. Aqu√≠ tambi√©n lo intentan: Es una estatua de un viejo con un candil. En serio. Le intentan insuflar un aire m√≠stico con el lore pero es un viejo con un candil. Y de dise√±o bastante simpl√≥n y cuadrado. Parecen tonter√≠as pero ahora voy con una que afecta al gameplay.

En casi todos estos juegos empiezas con armas d√©biles. Pero enseguida encuentras armas que molan, que da gusto utilizar, o habilidades que compensan un arma r√∫stica. Generalmente sucede en los primeros 10 o 20 minutos. Aqu√≠ el segundo arma que consigues es un cuchillo... tras un par de horas de juego... que es mejor que tu espada corta en estad√≠sticas, significativamente para ese momento del juego, pero que da asco usar porque no tiene alcance. Te est√°n proponiendo un dilema cl√°sico de los castlevanias pero en los castlevanias no se hace tan pronto, primero te dejan degustar la satisfacci√≥n de armas divertidas, con alcance, que permitan combar o semejante. Luego te dar√°s cuenta de que son d√©biles y las cambiar√°s por otras. Lo cu√°l suele ser f√°cil porque suele haber armas a porrillo. Aqu√≠, no. Aqu√≠ puedes pasar una hora entre que consigues un arma y la siguiente.

Y los puntos de guardado. Ver√©is, cuando ten√©is que jugar con un arma cutre en un juego de estas caracter√≠sticas, con poco alcance, d√©bil, etc., durante mucho tiempo, vais a sufrir da√±o. Es inevitable. Cualquier enemigo que haga algo m√°s que quedarse quieto esperando morir te puede acabar hiriendo. De forma que aumentan la dificultad del juego d√°ndote enemigos d√©biles pero un arma m√°s d√©bil todav√≠a. Lo guay de los castlevanias es sentirte fuerte. Aqu√≠ te ves calculando las distancias a la perfecci√≥n contra un pu√±etero murci√©lago o una rata porque cuidado como sufras da√±o, est√°s apa√±ado. Ya que otra cosa que al cabo de un tiempo empiezan a hacer es distanciar bastante los puntos de guardado. No siempre est√°n en lugares l√≥gicos. Atraviesas un √°rea grande, esperas un punto de guardado... pues no.

El aspecto rolero m√°s b√°sico tambi√©n se cae. Subes tres, cuatro niveles, y no notas ninguna diferencia. No ves cambiar las tornas. Las subidas de nivel son casi irrelevantes.

En conclusi√≥n: Pasas sala tras sala id√©ntica una tras otra, con enemigos pat√©ticos pero que te suponen una amenaza porque tienes que jugar con un arma pat√©tica. Una hora... dos horas... tres horas... tres horas y media... y en ese punto te preguntas, ¬øpor qu√© estoy jugando esto pudiendo jugar un juego mejor? 

Preg√∫ntatelo t√∫ tambi√©n. Hollow Knight, Blasphemous, Bloodstained, incluso Mirror of fate, siendo un cutre port de 3ds es mejor que esto.

Por poner algo positivo, voy a estar muy atento a m√°s juegos de estos chicos porque tienen potencial. Chasm tiene potencial, no es un absoluto desastre. Si le echan un par de... narices (pegi 10), el siguiente juego puede ser muy bueno. Pero tienen que dejar de asumir que por ser un juego de bajo presupuesto se pueden permitir apuntar al barro. Tienen que aspirar a algo m√°s. Hay talento aqu√≠, falta la ambici√≥n.

review:
I findsome reviews unfair to this game so let me just say it is a great game in what it does. The controls are good, the progression is good, it has a great pace that keeps you engange and doesn't drag. The story also keeps it to the point. I see some comparisons to Blasphemous saying that game is the better one, well after playing both I can say that is not true. The UI in this game is far superior, the soundtrack as well. Story related I much prefer one with a clear focus or goal than a kind of Dark Souls "what's going on here" story where you kinda never really understand the "whys".

All in all a great metroidvania game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007145340', 'num_games_owned': 1506, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1433, 'last_played': 1581194463}
review:
[h1]Decent Low-Budget Metroidvania[/h1]

Chasm is one of those Metroidvania games that does not push the genre towards any new revolutionary direction. Combat involves repeatedly hitting enemies until they fall, once you've learnt their attack patterns of course. I usually put down any game that forces a hard difficulty for the sake of it and I was close in this game a few times but eventually it clicked and the game was somewhat enjoyable. A general lack of checkpoints in-between lengthy areas was rather painful.

Having played enough Hollow Knight, this doesn't compare to that quality but it has its own place in the genre. I got the game in the last Humble Monthly so value-wise, I got my money‚Äôs worth here with a combined playtime of about 24 hours.

There are six biomes to explore in the game, starting with the Mines and there's a linear path to take from therein. The game imposes this by locking away basic functions such as sliding under small crevices, double jump, wall jump etc. If you've played Dead Cells this might be a bit off-putting but it's just how it is and you get used to it.

The maps are generated procedurally with a seed system which you can note down to use for multi-runs but areas themselves tend to repeat themselves in later playthroughs as the general structure seems to be the same, just rooms swapped around. Puzzles are still randomly generated though and for a first playthrough, they seem to have been done well. Expect a lot of backtracking.

Gauntlets can be frustrating in other games but the most challenging rooms in Chasm are child's play compared to Hollow Knight and I'm relieved somewhat because I just wanted an easier time with a game for once. Rescuing the townsfolk slowly and rebuilding the town was a good way to take a break in-between the "chasm runs" - just wish there was to do in the town itself as it never really felt alive as much as it should have been.

Chasm excels in other areas such as ambience and general BGM but it suffers in how effective a lot of the weapons are. 

Whips and short-swords are great but daggers require you to almost touch the enemy and the heavy weapons are too slow to use - maybe intentional by design but it is impractical in this game as there is no way to block.

Magic skills are varied enough to switch out but pausing and unpausing just makes it not worth the effort. I stuck to Throwing Daggers most of the time, sometimes the Throwing Axe for the boss fights but rarely used it other than to clear off enemies standing on the edge of ledges blocking the path ahead - you get knocked back if you touch them. 

Equipment has its own RNG element and you can get marginally better drops in chests and off monster loot. Each area has its own boss to face and a mini-boss too and it takes about 12 hours going at a leisurely pace to finish it (on Easy). 

I played through the game three times to get 100% and thoroughly enjoyed it but I would only recommend this on a heavy discount or as part of a games bundle.

review: Decent Metroidvania, if rather short. Interesting difficulty curve in that you more or less cap out very early in melee strength (Chasm has RPG stats and different weapons to find), which makes the game significantly harder as you progress. Enemies get more hp, become harder to avoid, and do huge amounts of damage. Magic abilities basically consist of fancy ranged/semi-ranged weapon tosses, and until you upgrade them to Level 3, they just aren't that great. Movement compared to, say, Hollow Knight is much slower and more tactical. The best comparison might be with Mega Man, minus any speed upgrades. The story is ok, but nothing we haven't all seen before (mystery civilization, evil cult, etc.). Overall, certainly not Hollow Knight, but worth the price if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971404422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1582008351}
review:
This is a cautious recommendation. While I did finish the game, I enjoyed far less of it than I thought I would.

I (as I imagine most people) was drawn to this game by its art style and the fact it was another metroidvania. However, once you get past the scripted and story driven intro section (which is great mind you), what remains afterwards is a set of poorly generated levels filled with bad pacing. It could have been caused by a bad seed, but therein lies the issue so your mileage may vary.

The game borrows a lot from Castlevania (weapons, spells, combat, exploration), however it doesn't do enough to set itself apart. The "thing" in Chasm is the procedurally generated levels. 
I experienced bland and uninspired rooms and corridors repeating all too often. Because so much effort went into this concept, it feels very little went in the way of actual pacing. Weapon variety is low, it's possible to get the best weapons within a few hours of play, there are only 6 spells, the grind to level up spikes up around the mid-30's so it doesn't even make sense to do that either. 

If you came here looking for another Hollow Knight or even Axiom Verge, then this isn't it. What this is however, is a castlevania-light with procedurally generated levels that you can experience in a bite sized 10 hours.

[b]The Good:[/b]
[list]
[*]Art style - stellar work on that end.
[*]Plays like castlevania right down to how combat is executed.
[*]Another metroidvania!
[*]Chiptune soundtrack (overall a very low variety of music however).
[/list]

[b]The Bad:[/b]
[list]
[*]Pacing and progression seems at odds with itself. What I thought was just a side activity ([spoiler]Arena[/spoiler]) and ignored it for most of the game, ended up being a major arc to acquire a new artifact ([spoiler]diving gear[/spoiler]). However the areas I now had access to and the rewards I received were not worth the effort. It doesn't make sense. The whole [spoiler]sight[/spoiler] potion and two [spoiler]invisible[/spoiler] chests is another one, there's just no direction or purpose for it all to even be there, no story behind it, glimmer of its capabilities or other purposes, it's just there and once you get it done you'll never use that potion ever again.
[*]There was far more platforming than actual metroidvania-ing. Huge sections felt like playing Super Mario Bros.
[*]The menu/inventory is poorly implemented - no filter to sort weapons.
[*]Badly located save points.
[/list]

[b]To the Dev - great job on the game. I can see you're still actively updating the game so to that end:[/b]
[list]
[*]I know it's a big ask/recommendation, but the sequence and progression of artifacts to the areas you gain access to, the risk/time vs reward is poorly designed. I feel that re-evaluating either the order you get the items in or simply design the levels in such a way that there are more areas to use them in (water sections, slow potion etc) would not only create more uses for some of these items but also flesh out the game world a bit.
[*]Why give the player a special item to dig up dirt, but then force them to navigate the poorly designed inventory just to equip it for a few seconds and then back to their main weapon? Allow using it without having to equip it.
[*]Grant the ability to sort our equipment by strength, intelligence... anything. Searching for the best weapon/armour while they're hidden amongst trash loot is no ones idea of a good time. Trash loot can be sold, sure, but then we'd have to navigate each item one by one in order to see their stats, price alone shouldn't be what determines the 'value' of an item.
[*]More on the above point, why do we have to click into an item to see its stats? Why force a player to select an item to see how much it heals them? It just feels like there's always one too many clicks to get something done.
[*]Please don't waste a players time. You could introduce a checkpoint save system or better save/gateway locations. For instance, why place a save point only in the mines portal zone and not any of the others? It's as if you want to penalise the player for wanting to save by forcing them to go through those extra couple of zones just to save.
[*]Allow us to use the parachute several times during one fall. Increase it's utility for some quality of life fun - it won't ever get used once the feathered shoes are unlocked.
[*]If you're going to be inspired by castlevania right down to the movement style - a small suggestion is to stop mana drops from lanterns once mana is full, it's a redundant pickup. Instead provide more low-tier money drops if MP is full.
[/list]
