author: {'steamid': '76561197983536968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1587882797}
review:
Chasm is a fun little metroidvania game worth at least 12 hours of gameplay. If you enjoy it, there is some amount of replayability but a 100% 'normal' playthrough took about 12 hours.

I don‚Äôt really have many complaints about the game; controls are solid, atmosphere is good, traveling around the world was quick and accessible, the RPG elements were effective without being grindy, variety of equipment was good, etc.

My only two niggles with the game were that some of the items needed to unlock other items were too long an arc for too little of a reward; things like getting the light sword was a bit of a disappointment for how much work you had to do to get it and how the water relic was used in two places to get two items and that was literally it. Maybe this was just what my seed did and other seeds would have better pathing or more interesting uses for some of the relics but my experience was less than ideal in these circumstances.

My other issue was that most of the relics give you a small boost and allow you to do new and interesting things to reach new areas and traverse the world in different ways right up until you get the feather boots (vague non-spoilery terms used on purpose). The boots are a huge game changer in the way you move around the world- too huge really. The options you have once you acquire them are required for you to have access to with the way the game is built of course, but the power increase that this one relic gives you feels very unbalanced next to everything else the game provides. It also almost completely invalidates one of your previous relics (almost). I would have rather had some of the 'power' if this relic infused into others to balance out the gains and make those, shall we say, less useful relics more interesting.

With that said, I still 100% recommend the game to anyone who likes the genre. At the time of posting, there are 'mixed' reviews on Steam and I don‚Äôt really understand why. I see a lot of people saying it's as 'a worse version of SOTN' and while even my rose tinted glasses feel like SOTN was "better" than Chasm, there is still nothing wrong with this game. If you liked SOTN, this is a great love letter to enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198315483653', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1678513726}
review:
Let me start off by saying, I see why this game has mixed reviews. Most of the people who don't recommend this are saying two things.

1. The game is a lot like Castlevania or other Metroidvania games. 

2. The game doesn't have enough save points.

And I agree with both of those opinions. I've never played Castlevaina, but I have played Hollow Knight, which is one of my all time favorite games. Right off the bat, as soon as I was in the mines I could see a lot of similarities between the two games, from the enemies to the landscape, it looked very similar. What I think happened is that Chasm drew a lot of inspiration from other Metroidvania games, but so much so that it looks like the Devs just copied a bunch of different games and rolled them all into one to create Chasm. There is a lot of room for originality and it doesn't look like there will be too much of it. 

As for the save points, yeah, I wish there were more. This is a mildly difficult game, and it's a real pain to have to go back so far when you die. But, in a lot of cases, there are save points nearby. It's often times a matter of choosing right over left. So, instead of making more save points, I wish there was some kind of marker or sign that lead you to save points nearby. 

The only other problem that I have with this game is that if you want to equip or use an item, or if you want to check the map, you have to pause the game and navigate to what you want from the pause menu. That is kind of a pain, and I think it would be much easier if you could bring up the options in game. Like, lets just say you could press 'M' for the map, 'E' for Equip and 'I' for inventory, or use tab or something, that would just make it a bit more convenient. 

All of that being said, I still do recommend this. It's not the best game in the world, but it's fun, and it's good if you are bored.

review:
A solid metroidvania. It's not a super-challenging game by the genre's standards, but the harder difficulty modes feel really well balanced, requiring a great ratio of level/gear:skill.

Graphical quality is great, although I did come across a couple of visual glitches during my 2 playthroughs. Nothing significant though, so hardly worth mentioning.

Game has a nice amount of content to keep you hooked for a while, but not so much that it outstays its welcome.

Warmly recommend. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198038582320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1581283626}
review:
I try to be understanding and more forgiving with indie devs. This game had been in development for quite a long time, and I had it on my wishlist for years. So long that I actually forgot it existed until I was surprised to see it up for sale one day. I went ahead and bought it, as it had a lot of what I enjoy. I love sprite-based games, and am a huge fan of metroidvania-style games. As others pointed out, this game doesn't do anything innovative, but for me that wasn't a concern. If it played closely to Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, I'd be happy; and for the most part it does! However, there is one major thing that gives this a "no" from me. Following are my pros and cons, mostly cons, sadly:

1. The biggest thing is that this game is poorly optimized. It's programmed in XNA, and I don't know much about that framework, but I've never had a 2D sprite-based game drop frames like this game. And keep in mind, it isn't my system. I JUST finished playing and reviewing Doom 2016, and I played that game on Ultra settings without losing frames (with two minor instances). Not only does this game stutter, but actually, as of now, it's been rendered unplayable. I cannot open the game without it stuttering to the main screen, and even then it takes several minutes to get there. I had to fully reboot to get it to load properly, and it played well for another 10 minutes before the slowdown happened again and I'm not going to keep rebooting my computer to play this game that I had already grown bored of. 
2. The story isn't interesting enough to keep me invested in playing on to see what happens. Normally I wouldn't care about the story if the gameplay was fun, and while there isn't anything necessarily wrong with it, your character just isn't as acrobatic as Alucard or other metroidvania characters are. It makes the backtracking absolutely annoying. Your character is slow, and the artifacts you get to add to your moveset are also slow. Samus Aran you are not. At all. I was super excited when I initially got the slide, thinking I could finally zip through the levels and get the ball rolling, but there is such a long delay between your movesets, it just isn't fun to me. If this was supposed to be more realistic, like Salt & Sanctuary, that'd be fine, but it isn't. 
3. The music is virtually non-existent and unmemorable. 
4. Combat gets old fairly fast. I will say that, one problem I had with Castlevania SOTN was that, it too, got old regarding combat, but at least in that game  you had a lot of options to ignore or tear through enemies as you advanced in power. I could transform into a wolf and just zip right through them. However, in Chasm, I can Megaman-slide and then wait a solid 3-4 seconds before I can slide again. 

I legit feel bad writing this review because I'd hate to put in so much work in a game to have some idiot whose probably never created anything shit on it after just a few hours. There is a lot of potential here! The artwork is absolutely beautiful, and I love the pixel art. There are unique weapon animations for each weapon type, and I may not have given it a "No" if this were just a generic SOTN clone, but the performance issues I had make this a solid "No" for me. If there are future updates, or a DLC, or even a sequel, I will certainly be checking it out, because I think this is a great, responsive developer, but I can't say yes to a game I can't get to perform correctly when I can play Triple A games on their highest settings without issues. 

I WILL check back from time-to-time and change my rating should this issue be addressed. I want this developer to do well, and wish him the best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049790598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1581094213}
review:
The art, music and, from what I've seen, narrative are all great. The platforming is ok. But the game is completely ruined by its bad combat and terrible progression/saving system. 
The weapons, at least the ones available in the early game, all feel terrible to use. Each weapon has something different it's good at, but that's because it is garbage at everything else. For example, the knife has good damage and mobility, but extremely low range, requiring you to stand right beside the enemy - which means that it will move into you while you can't move. Because you can't move while using a weapon. The club, on the other hand, has good range and even attacks things above you (good against flying enemies), but has an extremely long swinging animation, during which you can't move, so anything that isn't one-shot by it will damage you. Compounding these issues is the bad enemy placement. Sometimes an enemy will hang out on a ledge that you need to jump on. You can't damage the enemy without jumping on that platform, but every time you try it just knocks you back off.
This by itself would still be tolerable, after the first one or two times you die to each enemy you figure out the timing and tricks to defeat it, but it is completely unacceptable coupled with its other major defect: every time you die you lose all progress since the last time you saved. Checkpoints are very sparse and in non-obvious locations, so sometimes you can even pass them by completely. There is no way to regenerate health except at checkpoints so every hit an enemy gets in on you counts down to your doom and if you don't find the next checkpoint in time you have to do it all over again. You can't even go back to the last checkpoint because all enemies respawn as soon as you leave the screen, so going back is just as dangerous as going forward. There are destroyable lanterns all over the place, but they drop mana, not health, for which I still haven't found any use. Presumably I'll be able to use spells later. After a while you unlock the potion shop which can sell health potions, but that doesn't solve the problem because they're very expensive and you only get a little bit of gold sometimes when you kill an enemy. The rate at which I was dealt damage by enemies is greater than the rate at which I got money equivalent to the same amount of health.
As if having to replay large parts of the map when you die wasn't enough, I kept coming across chests blocked by obstacles I didn't have the ability to remove yet (large jumps, not-yet-breakable walls/floors), clearly indicating that I'd have to redo that entire area later when I got those abilities.
I ragequit multiple times after the game forced me to redo large sections of the game, but I resolved to come back multiple times because the great art and music and interesting lore really made me want to give it a chance. I was always hoping that maybe I'd find that spell which let me regenerate health, but I never did. I won't try anymore though. The straw that broke this camel's back is when I died for the last time: I was two rooms past the last checkpoint when I noticed that I didn't actually save there: I entered the warp hub, but didn't remember that I'd also have to warp back to the warp hub of the previous world and from there get to the checkpoint to save before going back through both warp hubs into the part of the game that isn't just mind-numbing (and slow) walking back and forth. I had just fought against a new kind of enemy, whose patterns I didn't know, so my health was at a bit less than 1/2 of the maximum. Unfortunately, those two rooms were chock full of enemies. I tried to avoid fighting them by jumping over them and running away, but one still managed to land a hit on me. I was half a screen away from the end of the second room when I was boxed in between two ranged enemies (boomerang-throwing skeletons) and two short-range/melee hybrids (spitting and dashing snakes). I died in two hits. I lost ~20 minutes of work. The game didn't even have the decency of respawning me at the checkpoint, it put me into the main menu for some stupid reason.
In summary: 
art/music/presentation: great.
narrative: good.
main gameplay mechanic (platforming): fine.
secondary gameplay mechanic (combat): bad.
UX: absolutely terrible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053075672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1580924422}
review:
This isn't an amazing game, but it does what it sets out to do well. If you like the Metroidvania genre, than this is a nice short excursion.

Pros:
-Good graphics, a lot of detail in the sprites and the backgrounds look nice.
-Diablo inspired (probably) loot system means that enemy drops can have additional stat boosts or effects. This is nice and probably the most original aspect of this game. I don't think any other metroidvania has done this.
-Bosses are fun to fight, and sub bosses keep you on your toes.
-Shortcuts are frequent, which makes backtracking and getting back to town easy. It's nice.

Cons:
-Music, while not bad, is very forgettable. It aims for ambiance, which suits the style of the game well, but besides the Mines theme it's barely noticeable and might as well not be there. There's a lot of potential for the composer, try different styles!
-Getting lost in this genre is common, but for how short the game is I felt lost for way too much of it.
-Not much originality. It's hard to be innovative in this genre for sure, but with a few exceptions like the loot modifier system, it's all stuff you've seen before. Almost every powerup is predictable the second you see an obstacle you can't get around yet.

There are better games in this genre for sure, but this one is fun and worth playing. It's randomization brings some replayability to the table as well.

review:
You begin as a weakling? Check.
Pretty graphics? Check.
Lots of exploring? Check.
Lots of weapons? Check.
Difficulty increases as you play? Check.

Honestly, if you like metroidvanias then this is a no brainer. Can you get lost sometimes? Yes. Not understand where to go? Sure. Checkpoints far apart (especially when under equipped)? Many a times, but the community is pretty good in answering questions and you just have to be smart with saving often and not going too far without health supplements. The few puzzles there are a bit immersion-breaking but you'll figure it out in no time.
Now off you go to save the town and be the hero.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963491995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 1210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1580617264}
review:
Just barely good enough for a positive score though really deserved a neutral rating instead. There are so many detractors throughout the game be prepared to be mired down in mediocre. 

[strike]1) The game completely fails to explain what each character stat attribute does. This is passable to veteran gamers but less experienced players will be dumbfounded. It‚Äôs obvious this game takes inspiration from the NES 8-bit titles but those games came with a manual to explain any nuance. A trip to the discussions will get you a vague understanding.[/strike] Looks like there is a steam manual these days and the stats are explained inside.

2) Procedural generated dungeon hype. The whole concept is wasted as there just is so little reason to replay again; especially if you picked hard difficulty the first time. And even so the procedural generation just doesn't affect the game play enough at its foundation. 

3) Combat does not have a fluid feeling due to the design decision to lock the character into an action for a bit after taking it. In addition the complete lack of reach on some of the weapons is absolutely laughable; can just toss those dagger-type weapons straight in the bin. 

4) Monster drops are far too infrequent; even with a luck boosting scroll it could easily take 50 kills or more to get both item drops.  

Art, music and novelty of initial the vision save it from being a complete train wreck. Unless you are obsessed with metroidvanias I wouldn‚Äôt be in any rush to play this one.

review:
The art is gorgeous, especially the backgrounds, but I didn't care for the general gameplay. I think this is a fine metroidvania, and if you really enjoy that genre then you would probably really enjoy this.

Combat is often very confining, with low ceilings, narrow platforms, and very short attack ranges. There's also a bit too much filler between the interesting bits. Lots of backtracking through the recycled content. Add to this the amount of attacks it takes to kill enemies and that they respawn each time you enter those rooms and it's just a painful slog.

Again, I don't think it's a bad game just not the sort that I like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000662689', 'num_games_owned': 1479, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 879, 'last_played': 1579585975}
review:
Recommended, with caveats.

As Metroidvanias go, the /mechanics/ are tight - combat and movement usually feel pretty decent, with a couple of quibbles for a few rooms. Equipment feels SotN-like, with items often hiding special effects that you have to discover by use.

The random generation is a nice thought, but the game's gating is strongly linear, and items generally seem to end up in the same regions, so it's at most an aesthetic difference which rooms connect which major points each time. Don't go in expecting a roguelike either - the map generates once when you start a given savefile, and doesn't randomize on death.

The art is quite pretty pixelwork, but the designs of most zones aren't distinct enough to make the enemies truly shine.

All-in-all, it's a solid platformer, with a modicum of replayability if you really feel like being a maximal item completionist, or hitting up the highest difficulty, or trying a different class. As it stands, I'm satisfied with the 10-hour playthrough on regular, and have no inclination to return for more - I feel as if I've mastered the game sufficiently that just adding more health / damage to push through wouldn't be all that much more fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018812372', 'num_games_owned': 426, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1579572072}
review:
The good:
[list][*]The static graphics are great. It's interesting that there is an optional CRT mode.
[*]The audio is great. It's interesting that there is a chiptune-stylized alt for each track.
[*]There are daily and weekly high-score-focused time attack modes for those who don't care about the story mode, which is cool, and they're currently active with lots of players.
[/list]
The bad:
[list][*]I don't know why my character looks so angry all of the time. I'm not sure of the design choice that went into this, but it actually annoys me a bit.
[*]I don't understand how I can logically put on two Leather Belts simultaneously as accessories ACC 1 and ACC 2.
[*]There is no explanation of anything for the two-story house at the beginning. At least putting up a sign or something to let early-game players know that it should be populated or something would help them not waste time... üôÑ
[*]Note that I said above that the [i]static[/i] graphics are great. However, the motion blur that your character constantly exhibits is terrible, and there is no way to disable it in the game options.
[*]Map color is not distinct enough with regards to holes. There is also no way to mark "tiles to remember" if you see a region of the map that clearly requires a specific skill or tool that you don't yet have, so if it's been a while since you last played, you may end up wasting time revisiting that part if you forgot.
[*]Inertia is not properly rendered on moving platforms. If you jump onto a moving platform right as it's about to pull away from the direction in which you approach it, and then you move back in said direction, you whoosh right off of it, even though you should have begun to accumulate momentum towards the opposite direction already.
[*]Why don't the spike traps trigger when an enemy steps on them?! (Egyptian zombies, I'm looking at you...)
[*]Basic UI problems involving custom keyboard shortcuts: https://imgur.com/a/O6auMG8 (I'm not sure of why the entire screen is darkened; my screenshot program must be incompatible with the way Chasm handles full-screen resolution)
[*]I'm just not convinced of how fair it is to put healing stations increasingly so far away from each other, with the only other options when you're low on health being either to spend a truckload of money on Warp Scrolls to return to the town-of-a-main-hub, or risk regaining health by consuming extremely rare food items that seem to come more from pots than ever from any enemies. Granted, I only reached the second dungeon thus far, but even so, in Axiom Verge, Hollow Knight, etc., you don't have this kind of highly specific, "ugh"-fueled tension from risk of death due to injuries from easy mistakes, because enemies in [i]those[/i] games can heal you fairly easily. From what I could gather in Chasm, there wasn't even a magic spell that could perform self-healing (even when mana is gathered at a snail's pace, itself). Granted, I didn't get the witch doctor her Book of Incantations or whatever, but it sure seemed more-than-a-bit discouraging.
[*]Speaking of those spells, it was sort of a blind man's game to try to decide on what magical skills to buy next. The descriptions were so vague that you weren't even informed that magic axes are gravity-influenced while other magical weapons are not. Even the "shield" is offensive, not defensive. Some type of brief, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/893180/Catherine_Classic/]Catherine[/url]-like animated GIFs previewing what each one does would be way fairer to early-game players wary of paying so relatively much for things that do what they're not even sure of.
[/list]
And the ugly:
[list][*]You lose 100% of all control of the character when you take a swing of any weapon at an enemy while you're on foot, even if you were running forward at the time of the swing. Your character unrealistically just grinds to an instant halt, and stands still while swinging. You can't even interrupt the attack to defend if you change your mind or see that your foe will beat you to it, timing-wise. I understand that this won't be fixed at all because the dev wants people to memorize and master specific enemies' attack patterns to time their usage of the game's [i]really[/i] awkward backwards-dash feature. I get it; it's a design decision, which probably makes it easier to animate the protagonist. This is also why games like Hollow Knight and any Metroid title will stay ahead of the pack in this genre.
[*]Even if character control was not an issue, here is actually my biggest pet peeve: the level design feels like it "tried" to be a roguelike, but excellent roguelikes don't feel like they tried. One with superb level generation should feel totally organic. I got very annoyed when passing through the second dungeon (Egyptian-like catacombs, complete with zombies and venom-spitting snakes), because I came across multiple rooms that were very close together that followed an almost identical structure of a reverse Z shape (you have to travel to one side, hop backwards the other way across a series of hanging platforms above the ground, and then traverse yet a third tier of suspended terrain above both of those). So I was, like... "All right, I can feel the dev put every square meticulously together," because spaces were well placed for jumps. But... it's unimpressive if a relative [i]lot[/i] of tiles on the map follow an exact upside-down "U" shape, and so on. Like, the reverse-Z-shaped rooms were never even in reverse order. It was [i]always[/i], so far, an opening in the bottom-left, and then one opening on each upper side.

For another example: in the previous dungeon, the caverns, there were multiple tiles on the map that followed exactly the same structure: pools of acid with oscillating floating blocks of always two pools with two blocks each, or a larger pool with three blocks. There was never, like, a pond with one block and then two, or a short wall to surmount, or something. Essentially, there should have been five times as much level variation, or else Axiom Verge, Hollow Knight, etc. win with their handcrafted asymmetrical, interesting, never-repeating layouts.[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198301252255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1067, 'last_played': 1679306027}
review:
My thoughts after finishing it once. I avoided buying this because of the earlier reviews but after seeing the last round of updates I thought I'd try it out. I am glad I did.  Overall it was a fun albeit short game and there were no real hiccups along the way.  

Game play: It's very much cut from the same cloth as SOTN/Bloodstained. You'll be constantly on the lookout for better items. Due to it being shorter than the previously mentioned other games I found it to be a lot less grind focused than they were. There is SOME grinding but I never felt that it took up enough of my overall experience to give it much notice. (These were mostly situations where I would find a monster that gives a lot of XP near the edge of a screen and would take advantage of that to level up once or twice and then move on. That happened maybe three times at most not including an NPC sidequest.)

You will do a lot of back tracking as its a Metroidvania type game.  You will battle your way through long stretches to get items that aren't what you need or are less powerful than what you currently have but you can sell them to aid you in finding something more to your liking.  This brings up a kind of short cumming of the game - I never felt there was enough divergence between options for your character (spells, weapons, ect.) to make for anything much more than the swordsman you start out as in the game. Even with projectile spells you're going to stay the dedicated swordsman.

Map:  The biggest worry for me was that the procedurally generated map wouldn't 'unfold' properly and thus would leave me unable to complete the game (or leave me with some unplayable map layout that would ruin the experience.) Well it never happened for me. The map was fine as far as I was concerned and I got the hang of it in about the same amount of time I would have with any other Metroidvania.  

The areas were different enough to provide incrementally difficult platform jumping and the monsters became more complex the deeper into the mines I went. Each area has a shortcut room which makes switching between areas a much more tolerable experience. 

Story: SPOILERS. - It's a simple one about an inexperience soldier on his first real mission. He is charged with going to a small town and getting to the bottom of their troubles. This leads him into the mines of that town and a lengthy dungeon crawl where he learns about the forces of evil that held sway over an ancient civilization that once called the area home. There are also some NPC sidequests but they all amount to "find me X".

Controls: I stayed with the default layout and found them to be more than adequate.  There is a lot of wall jumping, ledge grabbing, and even some tricky platforming along the way and I can say I never found myself at odds with the controls. The movement of your character is responsive and I never felt there were situations where I died and it wasn't my fault.  Any kind of movement I wanted to initiate in order to make my way through a room was possible. 

Graphics: It has fairly well animated sprite graphics that give it a charming look. There was some thought put into the animations of the main character and it shows. (I liked the little details like him continuing to breath as an idle animation while he's holding onto the ledge.) Stylistically the game borrows much from games like Bloodstained/SOTN.  For example the animation to swing your weapon looks just like the mentioned other games animations. 

The monsters are also animated well and there are some interesting foes to come across in your travels as well as some standard ones. Cave? Bats and Goblins. Castle? Haunted suits of armor and skeletons. But there is a large bestiary of monsters to keep things fresh and some decent bosses/minibosses along the way. 

There are some interesting areas to explore but they do feel a little similar in the beginning and its not until you get to the Garden where the color pallet finally breaks out of its solemn scheme.  

Overall: It's a standard Metroidvania game with the twist of having a new map layout each time you start over. It doesn't really bring anything new to the table.  You've had this meal before (and prepared better) but you know what you're getting and you'll probably enjoy this one too.

review:
Got this from humble bundle.

Chasm is a good game with some bullshit decisions made by devs. Like many others i got stuck with the catacomb lock puzzle where you need to enter 3 digits between 1 and 9 in order however without googling it the hint for this puzzle was not obvious at all, apparently you need to find 3 rooms with randomly generated count of items, stars, cups and swords. wow..................... this is a simplistic game and they made a puzzle that you would need an observation skills of an eagle to figure out what you need to do without google? pff stupid. It's also randomly generated so noone can tell you what the code is. If you get the code wrong you need to climb all the way back up, which just adds to frustration and annoyance with otherwise great game. 

Premise is that you are young knight sent to some random town to save the miners that are trapped in mines. Controls are smooth, it supports chinese controllers and it's a great game, minus the annoying platforming sections and bullshit puzzles like the one described above. Who knows what more terrible puzzles these devs could have added in later stages? I recommend but be ready to be annoyed and have a google search ready..

author: {'steamid': '76561197972836357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1579215492}
review:
I only played for an hour so take this as you will, but the combat is slow and unresponsive, the controls are floaty (which is a problem, because there's quite a bit of platforming for a Metroidvania title) and there are entire stretches of corridors with enemies that make the game feel like a slog (because of the procedurally generated levels, I assume). Nice pixelart and pretty good music, but that's not nearly enough to compensate for core issues. It's playable, but it's extremely average in its genre and progression doesn't feel rewarding. 

Also, procedural generation isn't a magic pill that instantly makes a game more interesting and it has little business existing in a Metroidvania.

review:
[code]If you enjoyed this review, please consider following my Curator Page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33864135/]Nep's Gaming Paradise (Nepiki Gaming)[/url] for more reviews![/code]

[h1]Nepiki's Stats[/h1]
[table]

        [td]Overall length[/td]
        [td]5-7 hours for beating, 10-20 hours for completion (can be done in one to three playthroughs).[/td]
    [/tr]

        [td]Overall difficulty[/td]
        [td]Low to medium difficulty.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Overall score[/td]
        [td]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Review[/h1]
I've played through Chasm a total of three times since I am an achievement hunter. At this point, I also felt like I could give you the most accurate review I could provide you myself since Chasm is an.. interesting game. Let's start off with this game's defining feature and the one you're probably most curious about: the procedurally-generated dungeon design. Yes, this does indeed mean that with every new save file you start, a random world is created for you. And yes, this also sounds better than it does because really, since it's a Metroidvania that relies on you getting upgrades in a specific order they can't go all-out. In my three playthroughs, I can easily say that perhaps only 30% of the entire map changes with each new savefile. And since they are handcrafted rooms, it is very well possible that you might have seen those rooms in a previous playthrough, perhaps just in a different position. It's unfortunate that it's not as random as I hoped it would be, as my three playthroughs all very much felt the same with minor differences like every chest item being random. What hurts even more is that because of this feature, the world feels limited as well. It is still a Metroidvania, but don't expect a rich map where every exit leads to more exits. Instead, it is very linear and only demands you to go back to previous places on a few occasions. There's of course a lot to find in previous areas but most are optional and occasionally also worse than what you already have. I feel like a world in a Metroidvania can make or break a game and while Chasm's isn't bad or anything, for a Metroidvania it's slightly underwhelming. I will appreciate the map showing you where something of interest is however. On that front Chasm is also very noob-friendly.

The other part of a Metroidvania however, is the gameplay. Chasm does control pretty smoothly and very much reminds me off a Castlevania game. Not surprising as the magical weapons are literally Castlevania sub-weapons, and normal weapons are reminiscent of the weapons Alucard could use in Symphony of the Night. The upgrades our main protagonist gets aren't too surprising either. Stuff like a double jump, wall jump and a lantern to illuminate dark places should not come as a surprise. I was a big fan of the bird and sword hats however; they are summons that attack enemies and can level up independently. You can also choose right from the start what class you want to specialize in. Magic in this game is very broken though, especially the knives. This does not necessarily come as a surprise but if you want an easy time even on the hardest difficulties, just upgrade the knives to the maximum and you won't have to worry about anything. Lastly, I want to mention the challenge mode which is actually pretty interesting as it actually puts you into a randomly generated dungeon and you're on a time limit to get a highscore. I personally was done with Chasm after the three playthroughs, but this is a fun addition to the people who want more out of this game.

This is however the extent to which Chasm goes. It plays well overall, but at its core it's just a basic Metroidvania with a basic map. There is nothing wrong with that, but if you are a veteran Metroidvania player you might not get much enjoyment out of it as there are a serious amount of good ones out there. I can't stress enough that Chasm is not bad, it really isn't. But because it set out to do something so ambitious, it had a lot to sacrifice and as a result is nothing more than an average-to-good Metroidvania.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000671579', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1578699488}
review:
Surprised to see so many negative reviews. Chasm is a solid, little game that unfortunately brings nothing new or groundbreaking to the metroidvania table. Lovely tilesets, good music, bosses (especially after Hollow Knight) are rather on a weak side. Procedural approach to levels increases replayability in some way but harms level design quality in general. Almost no powerups made me excited to backtrack and reexplore unlocked areas. Late game pickups closed behind potions and other items are near useless. None the less we all got spoiled by games like Hollow Knight, Momodora and Chasm still is a good game just not a good 
[strike] Fallou [/strike] .. ah fuck off, just play it.

PS Kudos to BitKid as an omnipresence on literally every forum or community board dedicated to this game, helping users, resolving issues and taking criticism like a champ. Respect and we need more devs like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082606558', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1578520150}
review:
Je viens ENFIN de terminer ce jeu. Et quel jeu fort plaisant !
J'ai t√©l√©charg√© ce jeu dans l'espoir d'y d√©nicher quelque chose ayant un rapport, de pr√®s ou de loin, √† Hollow Knight, un jeu 2D que j'ai jug√© beaucoup trop h√¢tivement. Evidemment, Chasm est loin d'√™tre un Hollow Knight, mais il fait tout de m√™me le caf√©, √† mon avis.

Le principe est assez similaire; on a un jeu 2D (pixelis√© d'ailleurs, ce qui n'est pas sans rappeler les jeux r√©tros), et on parcourt divers donjons en parcourant la map. Comme Hollow Knight, on fait divers allers-retours afin de r√©colter certains items ou objets importants pour avancer dans l'histoire, et ainsi progresser. Cependant, la grosse particularit√© du jeu est que la map est ... g√©n√©r√©e de fa√ßon al√©atoire ! Cela donne une tr√®s grande autonomie au jeu, puisque le recommencer vous permettra de vous imposer de nouvelles difficult√©s par les chemins. De plus, vous pouvez tr√®s bien jouer sur la map d'un ami, en modifiant la graine. C'est bien pens√© bien que peu utilis√© en pratique √† mon humble avis. 
En bref, ce jeu a su attirer ma curiosit√© et m'a plut√¥t plu.

Cependant, il a n√©anmoins divers points n√©gatifs ... et ils sont nombreux malheureusement. Tout d'abord, je trouve la musique correcte. Juste, correcte. Elle est pas mauvaise, mais elle est pas assez cool non plus. Je trouve que √ßa manque de rythme tr√®s globalement, notamment dans les combats contre les boss. 
Parlons en ensuite des boss ... Je trouve la difficult√© de certains boss (notamment le boss final) un poil abus√©. On est tr√®s tr√®s loin de la difficult√© l√©gendaire de Hollow Knight, mais c'est un peu complexe quand m√™me. Le flemmard que je suis a d√ª faire le plein de potions pour se kamikazer sur le boss de fin. En clair, si comme moi vous aimez moyen la strat√©gie, ce jeu risque de vous mettre de s√©rieux b√¢tons dans les roues. 
Parlons ensuite de la map. Ce jeu dispose, bien s√ªr, d'un syst√®me de carte, pour vous aider √† ne pas vous perdre. Cependant, mon dieu, la carte est si pauvre ! Elle indique les sorties, quelques tr√©sors par un malheureux point ... Et c'est tout. Vous n'avez aucun moyen de placer des marqueurs (enfin, si ... Mais seulement un seul, √† l'endroit o√π vous √™tes). Autant dire que si vous n'avez pas autant de chance que moi dans ma partie (o√π globalement tout s'encha√Ænait assez bien, je n'ai pas eu besoin de passer trois jours √† chercher un endroit en particulier), vous √™tes tr√®s mal barr√©s avec une carte pareille. Je pense notamment au syst√®me ing√©nieux des "grottes". Dans le jeu, vous allez parcourir diff√©rents niveaux, qui sont assez grands. Chasm a eu le g√©nie de cr√©er une esp√®ce de salle avec un t√©l√©porteur pour relier les niveaux, et des grottes pour acc√©der rapidement √† diff√©rents endroits du niveau. Le hic, c'est que, √† moins de le conna√Ætre par coeur, vous ne savez pas quel chemin vous m√®nera l√† o√π vous voulez qu'il aille. Pourquoi ne pas l'avoir indiqu√© sur la carte ? Ce serait plus agr√©able ! 
Et tant qu'on y est, la carte a parfois des rat√©s ... Il m'indique la pr√©sence de tr√©sor dans des salles d√©j√† d√©pouill√©es de leur tr√©sor. Bof bof, mais c'est qu'un petit bug.
Enfin, et c'est je pense le plus gros point noir du jeu; OU EST LE BACKGROUND ? Certes, il y a une histoire, mais √ßa part un peu dans tous les sens, notamment au d√©but. On vous parle un peu de qui vous √™tes, dans quel pays vous √™tes etc ... Et ces infos l√†, typiquement, on s'en tape en fait. Le plus important, c'est la suite. L'histoire avec le Roi Trell, la tribu, Ulak, etc ... Ces √©l√©ments de l'histoire sont racont√©s par des journaux trouv√©s dans le jeu et par les PNJ. En soi, l'histoire est tr√®s int√©ressante, cependant je suis tr√®s d√©√ßu par le bestiaire. Le bestiaire regroupe les diff√©rents ennemis que vous avez tu√©s. Cependant, pour les amateurs de background comme moi, vous serez tr√®s d√©√ßu de voir qu'il n'y a aucune description ... Si vous avez tu√© par exemple l'ennemi "D√©mon", vous n'avez aucune id√©e de son histoire; √† quoi il sert, quand il a √©t√© cr√©√©, etc ... C'est tr√®s dommage quand on voit que l'histoire a l'air g√©niale.

N√©anmoins malgr√© ces points n√©gatifs, Chasm est un jeu, je trouve, assez addictif. Il faut n√©anmoins garder en t√™te qu'il faut bien aimer ce type de jeu similaire √† Hollow Knight. Il se finit plut√¥t rapidement, mais on est quand m√™me tr√®s satisfait quand il est termin√©. Je vous le conseille, mais regardez bien des vid√©os sur le jeu avant de sauter dessus. author: {'steamid': '76561198032424682', 'num_games_owned': 2012, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1578427567}
review:
The game in general is quite well executed, but doesn't do much renewing the genre or anything. It builds on the foundations that have been laid out for Metroidvanias, so be prepared to mark areas that you can't yet proceed through to make it easier to know where to backtrack too. Personally I'd have liked the ability to have different coloured markers (as to indicate new skills needed or just treasures). For me this was quite annoying once, since I forgot to mark a certain gate, and it was the only point of progression, which meant I had to go throughout all the maps and check everything out (I feel like this is more on me than on the game though). Besides this the soundtracks are quite basic but nice to listen to anyway and won't annoy you into turning off the sound. The environments look really nice and fit well with the rest of the style of the game. The magic feels a bit basic (and honestly strong as in most of these games) but to be fair I haven't used much of it since I prefer combat over magic. The different types of weapons are quite nice, however since it's (somewhat) randomly generated you quite often find weapons weaker than the ones you already have.

The only real performance problem I encountered was quite odd and I'm genuinely not sure if anyone else would ever encounter it. I'm using a Xbox Bluetooth Controller, which means it might sometimes (temporarily) lose connection, most of the time this is just for a second, however Chasm really doesn't seem to like this. Whenever my controller would lose connection the game would slow down to being pretty much unplayable, yet recover to normal speed when the connection was restored. In general this wasn't a problem (as you don't lose your connection that much) but since my controller was apparently low on batteries it had a real problem keeping up the connection (which took me a while to figure out what the problem was).

In conclusion I'd recommend buying it, especially when on sale as I feel it's worth around 10$ easily.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049134301', 'num_games_owned': 4192, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 922, 'last_played': 1578359225}
review:
It's... fine. Uninspired Castlevania.

What you need to know:

It's a metroidvania with random layout. The random generation isn't apparent. Based on some guides lots of stuff appears in fixed locations.
New monster. What's your attack routine? I am now invincible.
Give me XP. Level up. Monster is now worth less XP. 
Very easy to tank boss attacks with healing items.

You know what's lazy? The Bestiary. There are 80 odd entries that unlock after killing a fixed amount of each enemy. There is no description of the monster, just some basic stats and what it drops. You scroll through each page 1 at a time so it's hard to find any given entry.

You know what else is lazy? There is no way to sort your equipment. So you go to the blacksmith and look to sell some stuff, and you've got 7 knives all in different places based on when you get them. Some are enchanted but you can't easily compare stats. Want to wear your 2 Jade Rings? They sure aren't next to each other.

It's not bad, but it doesn't feel like a passion project. It feels like the devs had an idea for a procedurally generated metroidvania but got bored with it and put out a decent but ultimately pretty boring game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997328781', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 2554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1644286750}
review:
[h2]A Brief Summary[/h2]

You are The Main Character, knight apprentice who is sent to check on a small mining town when they lose touch with the rest of the kingdom. What you find there might go a bit beyond the skills of an apprentice, but it's not like you could just go get reinforcements, right?

Right?

[h2]A Brief Review[/h2]

Well, here we are - another procedurally generated Metroidvania. I dunno, man, there are just a hell of a lot of Metroidvanias running around out there, and this randomly generated stuff is all kinda samey. So how about Chasm? How does it stand up?

It's... not bad.

Chasm has a pleasing 16 bit quality to it, with attractive environments and a choice between great chiptunes or great orchestrated music - either way is a win, and having the choice is neat. There's a feel of exploration that I enjoy, and there are plenty of things to find and uncover as you rescue the villagers. The controls are pretty darn good, too - not Dead Cells perfect, but pretty close.

The procedural generation is per save in this one, instead of per run. That means that every time you descend into the Chasm on one save, it'll be the same, but if you start a new game, you'll get a new layout. This is an excellent way to give a game replay value, but it's somewhat let down by the lack of variety in the dungeons. They're great, but I don't think (I haven't beaten it yet, so I don't know for sure) just shuffling them around is going to make a significant difference; it's just going to make one person's play-though a bit different than another's. That's fine as far as it goes, but I don't think it was the goal.

Another thing that could have been addressed with the procedural generation is to have put more found equipment in the dungeon. This is especially true of the sub weapons, which are mostly purchased from a vendor in the village (at least, so far). I would have preferred to unlock them as random drops or to find them in different places depending on the RNG, but this is fine. 

One thing I really don't care for though is the crafting system. It's not that it's bad, it's that it's not especially interesting or well implemented, so it doesn't really ad anything to the game. I'd rather just buy the stuff from a vendor or find it in the dungeon. 

Another small complaint is the shovel. This is really petty, but you get a shovel to dig through certain areas, and you have to equip it and de-equip it as a standard weapon. Not all of the buttons on a standard controller are mapped in the game, so mapping the shovel to a dedicated key would have been much, much less annoying. It wouldn't be so bad if the shovel was a decent weapon, but it's not, so when you need it it's pause, equipment menu, equip shovel, unpause, dig, pause, equipment menu, equip better weapon, unpause, continue the game. It's tedious and it really didn't have to be that way.

Fortunately, the core gameplay loop is entertaining enough to carry multiple playthroughs (or it it for me so far, anyway). The game is charming, the music is quite good, and it presents a decent challenge. All in all, I say go for this one. 7 out of 10, there are much worse ways to spend your money. 

Side Note: I got this on sale, but I think it's worth full price. I guess I just got lucky on that one ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198029186921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1344, 'last_played': 1578753062}
review:
[u]Positives[/u]

+ Wide range of weapons, allowing for different attack strategies.
+ Varied environments for each area, with their own unique styles
+ A good selection of skill upgrades, allowing for more skilful movement as the game progresses
+ After finishing the game at the normal difficulty setting, the challenge seemed spot on.
+ The random loot drops and procedurally generated levels make for a nice twist on the genre

[u]Negatives[/u]

- The procedural generation of levels means that the game has missed out on creating some truly intricate and memorable levels or areas within those levels
- The skill upgrades have not been utilised to their full potential, with some feeling like they are only used to get past a specific section or puzzle as opposed to adding to later game strategy

[u]Overall[/u]

I had a great time playing this game and would recommend it to all fans of platform games. I picked it up for around ¬£6 in the sale, and it was fantastic value for money. I cannot say whether the procedural generation is going to add in terms of replayability, but I am looking forward to re-attempting at the next difficulty level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961951106', 'num_games_owned': 1565, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 1385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1385, 'last_played': 1578175753}
review: Disclosure: I play almost no platformers and among those few this might be the first metroidvania - can't remember. I did two playthroughs - first on Hard, second on Easy. I'm gonna spare you a tirade that I already had typed out and just say that I find the game ridiculously difficult - in terms of level scaling, enemy HP, player HP etc. I was seriously considering giving a thumbs down just because of this. The game expects you to grind in place, stockpile consumables, overlevel to have a chance and this is acceptable to me in a JRPG but not in a platformer. Onto the positives. The biggest one that comes to mind is the atmosphere. The snowy village, [i]it's music[/i] and the aesthetic of the first world all combined made me feel like I was playing Icewind Dale 1 or Diablo 1 way back when, captured in a side-scrolling format. This is high praise coming from me. The game world is not at all fleshed out in terms of what goes on beyond but it has this delightfully generic quality akin to a quickly hacked together AD&D campaign in middle school. I got no complaints about the pixel art or underlying engine (only saw two minor bugs) and the music is very good. Occasionally the vibration on my gamepad would get stuck on full blast, requiring me to replug it. Winning the game once unlocks a bunch of new options for playing again, such as permadeath mode and "classes" (heavily influences level-up stat gains to force a particular build, ex. magical). On my second playthrough I encountered lots and lots of rooms which were not present in the first. This might be due to the different difficulty level or there may be enough of them prepared that only a random handful get chosen for a newly generated world. Either way - pretty cool. So if you're experienced in the genre I can safely recommend this. If not, this is more of a question mark, and if you want to get all achievements as well then I recommend [i]against[/i] it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071985830', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1578156589}
review:
I remember back in the day when there was quite a bit of excitement about this game and after the release how much disappointed those who played it were. Having played it I can see why. 

The Chasm borrows heavily from Castlevania. The leveling, monster drops, equipment, even subweapons are almost identical and that's not really a bad thing but there's nothing to the game besides that formula. It gives off a feel like there was something else there, some ideas of its own that were scrapped later on.

On a mechanical level the game is pretty solid. On my playthrough I didn't encounter any bugs or jankyness. One big problem I did encounter is weird difficulty; every boss except the last one were a cakewalk since you can chug potions or sometimes even stand still spam the attack button. In fact I haven't died until about 7 hours into the game. Things got a bit harder in two of the last areas. With the last area having mobs that would kill me in about 3 hits. Having less and less saverooms was a real pain when you died and wasted about 15 minutes. I stopped before I beat the final boss because I just couldn't be bothered anymore.

To finish on a positive note the music was quite enjoyable, although I mostly listened to the chiptune version. While there wasn't much detail in the tilesets they looked nice and fit well into the theme of the area.

I can only recommend  this game if you're a fan of the metroidvania genre, but don't expect anything new from it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025557930', 'num_games_owned': 1359, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1578136940}
review:
I do recommend this game, BUT only if you're very into metroidvania stuff and don't know what to play.

The whole point of random generated map is seriously flawed. It's pretty much just reorder the room and that's it? you still fight same bosses, get same key items in the same order. And because every room is randomly placed based on seed, the whole map is boring as hell. Gameplay-wise I like the feel of this game. It's responsive and really feel like playing GBA/DS Castlavania (like, even the animation is there). So if this isn't what you're looking for, it's not worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980371475', 'num_games_owned': 2410, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1578035845}
review:
While I have overall enjoyed my time with Chasm, this thumbs down comes exclusively due to the crash bugs that I have experienced while playing this game. While two crashes in four hours of playtime might not seem like enough to warrant a negative review, these crashes were severe. The first corrupted the entire game installation and required me to uninstall and reinstall it. Then after rebooting my computer the game would finally launch again. Of note, I know the exact cause of this bug although due to its severity I have not attempted to reproduce it. My wireless keyboard ran out of batteries in the middle of playing (I was using an Xbox One controller and so didn't notice). Upon plugging the keyboard in the game crashed and corrupted. 

The second crash was so bad that programs on my computer would no longer execute and I had to perform a hard reset of my whole system to fix it. Note that my computer is custom built with a very limited number of programs running on it at any time. It also has the latest drivers and Windows firmware updates, and exceeds the system requirements of this game by several orders of magnitude. 

I have nearly 1500 games in my Steam library. Probably over 500 of them played on this computer. Of those not a single one has ever caused me to hard reset my machine. That includes AAA titles, indies, classics, and random forgotten relics that I'm running in emulators like DOSBox. And if an already awful game from the mid-nineties can manage to not crash my whole system, I expect an otherwise good game that is only a year old and still receiving regular updates to achieve that bare minimum requirement.

As such, despite very much enjoying this game, I have to recommend people stay away unless these bugs are fixed or people want to risk damaging their systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980054291', 'num_games_owned': 2277, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1578002991}
review:
A genuinely good Metroidvania that is mechanically excellent. But lacks that truly beautiful world design, probably due to the procedurally generated map. It's not a roguelike, just every new game world is procedurally generated.

It might never live up to the likes of Blasphemous or Hollow Knight when it comes to presentation, but the gameplay is very solid, exploration is satisfying and the upgrades, while none particularly original, make progression very satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2121, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1581068987}
review:
Wondered why so many reviews praise the early game and then give it a thumbs down.  Well no more. This game has brilliant first hours and then pace slows down until you either get bored - or in my case just plain stuck. I spent the last 1¬Ω hours systematically going through maps and looking for something - anything i might have missed as i could not advance any further in any of the areas i had access to. 

Broken world generation? hard to tell but i gave a very good effort trying to figure what it could be but then it's just time to give up and uninstall which i did. Better luck next time. This dev is worth keeping an eye on as this game has some really well done parts. Gameplay, pacing early game, graphics... all of it well done until it runs out of steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972087465', 'num_games_owned': 2036, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1576982900}
review:
(Note: I played most of this in Offline mode, hence the playtime.)

Chasm was one of my most anticipated Metroidvanias this decade; sharp art design, SOTN influence, procgen world leading to infinite replayability? How could I not be excited?

Well, a few things happened. One, a billion games came out, and wanting replayability no longer became a value add to me. And procgen games had already started to wear thin, with aggravating dupe rooms, dead ends, and an overwhelming feeling of malaise. Two, A Robot Named Fight came out, and was everything Chasm had promised but for Metroid. So how would that impact my enjoyment of Chasm now that it‚Äôs finally here?

It‚Äôs going to be impossible not to compare the two games, so I will talk about why both inhabit the space without pushing the other out. Like a double helix, these two games!

What ARNF gets right is all in the seed generation and content. Because it takes inspiration from games like the Binding of Isaac, you are constantly unlocking new ways to play in your runs, which the seed generation incorporates. Both games do an adequate job of building a world map that does not result in an unwinnable state, but because ARNF gets content updates and has all the unlocks to manage, that makes it all the more impressive that it continues to hold together.

But if it doesn‚Äôt feel right, then it‚Äôs all for naught, and this was my constant issue with Fight, and where Chasm shines. ARNF‚Äôs movement and aiming is clunky and feels like a low budget Axiom Verge, while Chasm is responsive and fun to traverse. Combat in Chasm is along the lines of Castlevania, with meaty axe swings, quick sword thrusts and swift daggers (a high risk/reward option as their range is very short). You also have magic you can wield in a pinch, although I did not use it much.

But the map is a deficiency for both in certain ways. In ARNF I experienced dead ends, a roguelite crime. In Chasm, was encountered at least five duplicate rooms in my play through. Chasm also relies on the vertical tunnel too often, and in the early going... hey, it‚Äôs exciting to see where each path leads. But when you haven‚Äôt saved in twenty minutes and none of the paths lead to a save room, it‚Äôs a bit aggravating. Especially when warp scrolls cost as much as two health hi-potions.

Speaking of saves, ARNF is about do-it-or-die single runs, so its fast travel and saves are limited (is there even fast travel? I forget), while Chasm has no permadeath or even a penalty for dying, so the challenge is not quite as high. Naturally enemies get stronger, but that‚Äôs about it. So you can be aggressive in scouting further and further, as long as you have the healing items to keep you alive.

Rescuing villagers will send them back to town to open up shops, but I was a bit disappointed here, because I had hoped for a bigger visual revamp as the town gets back up to speed, and the shops don‚Äôt carry a ton of products even after you fulfill each townie‚Äôs side quest.

Visually, Chasm kicks ARNF in the tush (pardon my language!!) with gorgeous character animations and map detail. But let‚Äôs be honest here, this was not a hard competition, as Fight traces over elements of Super Metroid with reckless abandon.

Your purchasing decision will ultimately come down to what kind of game you want. I feel that both are a 7.5 out of 10, so which do you prefer: a conventional SOTN style game whose procgen feels pointless and detracts from the experience (Chasm) or a Metroid-like that will kill you over and over, which you‚Äôll play for 100 hours (Fight)? Personally I prefer Chasm because I like to finish what I start and move on, but your tastes may be different.

Chasm doesn‚Äôt live up to the expectations of the Kickstarter, but it‚Äôs a perfectly serviceable game in the genre.

review: Overall a pretty positive first hour of gameplay, which is more than I can say for a lot of metroidvanias/indie games/humble bundle stuff. On the whole, I agree with the critical points made by most of the positive and critical reviews that the procedural element doesn't seem to add much, it seems very much like something you're likely to only play through once, although honestly the procedural elements are fluid enough that I kinda forgot every now and then it was randomly generated. First boss fight was pretty fluid and a good mix of options for dealing with enemies and enemy progression seems okay. All in all pretty solid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162388568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1577594807}
review:
The game at its core is great, if you are interested in lore, it is there, soundtrack feels atmospheric, but I believe it could be just a bit better.
Combat wise it feels very limited, I have been meaning to use different weapons, but the fact that swords just overpower every other weapon is a bit underwhelming. Armor upgrades feel very satisfactory.
Magic is where i find the game to be very lacking, the spells are useful, but the very small selection of spells really let me down, not even mentioning that there is no elemental spell whatsoever, since they were removed.
Overall, I recommend the game if you want a quick, but definitely not bad experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198807269583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1577594058}
review: Chasm is a perfectly average platformer. It is not necessarily that bad, but almost every aspect of the game is just ho-hum okay to bland. The soundtrack; passable, but not stellar. The gameplay; solid for what it is. The graphics; again, a solid pixel game. The story; it does indeed have a story. I can't complain much about Chasm, largely due to the method by which I acquired it (a random online giveaway). I also haven't played much, compared to the amount other players seem to have sunk into the game. But I digress. Chasm may be a worthwhile experience for you. The asking price is quite high, so waiting for a sale if you want to take the game out for a spin should be a given. All in all, Chasm is an average game. Simply put, a so-so game at worst, a solid one at best.

review:
Ho visto tante recensioni negative su questo titolo. Mi sento dunque in dovere di dire la mia, cercando di fare un po' di ordine e sottolineare quelli che sono sia i pregi sia i difetti di Chasm.

[h1]Introduzione[/h1]
Chasm √® un metroidvania procedurale nato su kickstarter. La storia non offre chiss√† quali novit√†, siamo un cadetto inviato in un villaggio di minatori per far luce sulle disgrazie che da poco tempo si sono abbattute sugli abitanti. E' proprio a partire da questo punto che muniti di spada ci avventureremo nelle gallerie sotterranee, uccidendo mostri e affrontando boss.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Chasm presenta la [b]classica struttura dei pi√π classici metroidvania[/b], ci saranno una serie di aree collegate tra di loro da scorciatoie. Ogni area avr√† zone irraggiungibili o segrete, almeno fino a quando non otterremo degli upgrade che ci consentiranno di farlo tornando indietro e riesplorando la zona.
I nemici sono molteplici e abbastanza variegati. Ognuno di loro, anche i pi√π comuni, possiedono un paio di move set che li rendono discretamente interessanti. 
La difficolt√† generale √® [b]medio/bassa[/b], ulteriormente abbassata dalla possibilit√† di fermare il gioco a inventario aperto ed usare pozioni a manetta.
In compenso la [b]struttura delle zone √® molto buona[/b], sia come ambientazione che come disposizione stanze. [b]Esplorare non mi ha per niente annoiato, anzi.[/b]

[h1]In generale[/h1]
+Un titolo abbastanza solido...
+Buona l'atmosfera sia a livello di musica che comparto grafico (pur parlando di una pixel art abbastanza minimale)
+Si lascia giocare fino alla fine
+Bilanciato sia a livello di minions che boss...

-... ma rimane un classico metroidvania. Nessuna novit√† o qualcosa che mi abbia particolarmente colpito.
- Storia quasi assente e lineare
- ... come gi√† scritto nella sezione gameplay la possibilit√† di far scorte di pozioni permettono di fare fuori i boss al primo tentativo senza difficolt√†. Mi rendo conto che resta a discrezione del giocatore, tuttavia anche mentalmente il pericolo "Morte", diventa quasi assente.
- Un platform procedurale ? Ebbene s√¨, la struttura del mondo dovrebbe essere leggermente diversa da giocatore a giocatore. Nonostante questa unica novit√† il risultato √® deludente. Insomma anche se le stanze hanno ordine leggermente diverso nulla cambia se giocato da me a qualcun altro. Anzi, l'unica cosa che si aggiunge √® una leggera difficolt√† nel caso in cui si cerchino delle guide online con mappe che ovviamente mai corrispondono alla propria.

[h1]Conclusioni[/h1]
Pur avendo elencato non pochi difetti penso che Chasm faccia il suo lavoro. E' un gioco che intrattiene e diverte fino alla fine. Non il pi√π memorabile dei platform vania, ma una run ve la farete volentieri.

-Al

author: {'steamid': '76561197992142036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3105, 'last_played': 1577046844}
review:
Despite the improvements made over the years, way back when it was in beta, Chasm is not only a lengthy game, but is also very drawn out. It isn't unlikely that your first run through will require some to keep backtracking, say, from the keep back to the mines just to get an artifact and head back to where you once were. Many times I head back to where I think I need to progress but end up finding only a junk chest and have to head back and find a teleporter room.

It is a fun game. The weapons are fun to play around with, the [always respawning] enemies have a fairly unique pattern, and there is no need to grind for any levels once you get used to the easy, smooth, and responsive controls. 

However, like I mentioned earlier, for the amount of backtracking you have to do, the respawning enemies after just going from one room to the next, and uselessness of going back to the surface is annoying is enough to make me not recommend this game to everyone. The concept of a randomly generated Castlevania-esque adventure was quite ambitious, and a great idea on paper, but the game feels so terribly drawn out at a consequence. I wouldn't see myself searching for everything that there is to find in this game, just finish it and move on.

review:
I beat Chasm on Normal mode, and to me, it's a fine metroidvania! The art is pretty cool, the story is ok, the controls are good, the gameplay and exploration are enjoyable, some enemies can be challenging to fight... it IS a good game.

As you advance, rooms start feeling kind of samey, and there isn't much of a challenge in regards to platforming. But even then, if you enjoy metroidvanias, I definitely recommend you give Chasm a try, but ONLY on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017033103', 'num_games_owned': 1426, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1576781282}
review: It's a fine game, but has nothing that would make it special among its peers. The fact that the game world is randomly generated from parts instead of being fully designed by hand creates an messy maze, with the possibility that rooms will have the same design and enemy/corridor placement. I've had at least one dupe room in every area. The progression also gets really bad later on, with worse drops than those in midgame, and game ending before you can even manage to get stuff for endgame crafting. At least enemy diversity is quite nice, art direction is good and combat is fun, but easy to break with game's magic system.

review:
A solid metroidvania but one whose approach doesn't really fit with its 'selling point' of being procedurally generated.

The game would have been better with a fully handcrafted experience so you can enjoy a better game in your first and usually only playthrough rather than try to entice you with multiple runs just to experience the same rooms in different order. The haphazard approach the the random generation of room structures invariably means the level design as a whole suffers relative to a well thought planned approach to proper level structure that the metroidvania genre in its best iterations is known for.

If you want to try a similar game that does this procedural concept better try Rogue's Legacy. This game is worth a shot too if you're a genre fan though. It's still solid even with those level layout issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979982910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1575689545}
review:
Ehh...I'm going to go back and give it one more fair shake, but this game feels pretty much "fine". It would earn a mythical "sideways thumb" if it existed, but in absence my hand has been forced. 

The combat feels pretty bland - which surprised me, as I noted one update was focused entirely on improving combat. If it was worse before this, I can't really imagine how; this feels like the most basic that combat can get. 

Chasm doesn't feel like it does anything interesting or new - which doesn't disqualify it from being good in-and-of-itself - but it's mechanics also aren't good enough to make up for it. It also lacks things like a deep pool of game changing power ups - powers that do exist are spaced out strangely, can come too slowly, and make too little difference; you don't really feel more powerful or like you can play differently. The overall game speed feels slow, the jumping is kind of floaty/finnicky (even though it works fine in practice)...

Bottom line is it just doesn't *feel* good to play. It's fine. It doesn't do anything poorly, but there are much better examples of this kind of game out there.

review: So... how do I put this? This is the okest game I have ever played. I dont want to play it any more but I do at the same time. There is nothing good about this game but there is nothing bad. I feel satisfied yet I want more at the same time. Every single aspect from the way it plays to the art to the music feels fine. There is story there are some memorable characters, yet I still dont know what it is. I feel way too lost while playing it, it's like an open world that is also a closed world at the same time. This comment isn't a yes or no so if I could pick that I would, but I will go with I wouldn't recommend it. If you get it for free by all means go for it but if you are spending some hard earned money, there are better places that can go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193576345', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1576443882}
review:
I've played through this once on hard (be warned, starts out easy and gets much harder and you can't change the difficulty later on).  The visual aesthetic has a charming, grim Black Cauldron meets SNES appeal to it. The story is beyond forgettable and the music is pretty low-key.  

Its a metroidvania heavy on the castlevania side of the equation. While it has equipment and leveling up like SoTN the combat requires patience the way linear castlevania games do.   Traversing several corridors between save points can be rather daunting, I died countless times due to a combination of tricky monsters and getting sloppy when I'm in a hurry (such as when backtracking).  Strangely, the bosses frequently proved less difficult than the path to reach them because if you save 2 or three health potions you can spam attack them to death before really learning their patterns.  Most of the weapons and equipment are pretty boring, and the 'spells' (sub-weapons) are lifted directly out of the Konami series.  I found a couple hats that summoned familiars and I would have preferred that was a separate equipment slot so I could use other hats and keep the familiar active.  

The level design is pretty decent for a game that uses an RNG seed.  The rooms are well-populated with platforms, monsters, traps and treasures. Very reminiscent of Rogue Legacy, except the map is set. There is a lot of slow back-tracking in this and the fast travel spots can be kind of clumsily organized.  There are hidden corridors in walls, almost all of which I missed initially until I got an item that pings when they're nearby.  There are some minor puzzles ‚Äúwhere do I take this item‚Äù kind of stuff scattered throughout, and it can be kind of annoying if you want to look up solutions because everyone's play-through is different. 

I've played 19 metroidvanias because it is one of my favorite genres. This one is about 12th in over-all quality for me, but it depends on how much you enjoy the aesthetics or heavy castlevania emphasis.

review:
The game was okay until I reached the presumably last area. Suddenly there are no more savepoints or quicktravel rooms. Instead you are faced with a lot of jumping puzzles and enemies that do abnormally high damage compared to anything you have met before.

That last part leaves the metroidvania area and becomes a roguelike. It's a pity. I somewhat liked the game. It was not stellar but still entertaining. There lies the problem: The mediocrity does not really motivate me to overcome the frustration of that last area.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970477037', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1576390641}
review:
I enjoy the Metroidvania genre, but am in no way an expert player. While I finished the game on the default difficulty and enjoyed my time with it, I feel most of the value here will be for players that are interested in replaying the game multiple times, taking advantage of the random map generation and arcade mode.

The random map generation seemed very competent during my playthrough; the spacing of the save points was reasonable and for the most part rooms didn't appear repetitively. However, on more than one occasion did I open a chest to find an inferior weapon or piece of equipment, which was frustrating. In general I feel I missed out on seeing several pieces of equipment due to my map seed, so I would have preferred a default map with more curated treasures, and then the option to use a random seed for further play. 

If you're the type of person to only play through a game a single time, I wouldn't recommend this game unless it's on sale for under $20.
