author: {'steamid': '76561198188201725', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1670350579}
review:
3/5 Stars.

The game feels great to play, the core mechanics are there that you want. It is fun to play and i had a blast... while it lasted. There is an art to level/game design that allows you to guide the player along their journey without actually instructing them, but still leaving a clearly defined "this should be where you need to go" direction. Sadly... they dropped the ball here and lost my interest after wandering around aimlessly for over 2 hours tracing back and forth over the same 3 maps, checking walls, levers, paths ... everything... only to find that my progression had been hindered by a "hidden" secret tunnel.

I had just had enough, That was a total waste of my time due to bad design.

Would i recommend it? Yes, it is fun and generally a great game. Would that recommendation come with a caution? Yes... it would.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993268783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1576357383}
review:
This game is good to start, then slowly becomes exhausting, draining the enjoyment of the game, and that is the unfortunate side.

There are a lot of great aspects about the game itself, but I quickly began to realize the downside of the procedurally-assembled areas. For one, it causes mechanics for things like using the shovel to be in a spread of places, and the outcome of using the shovel is often an underwhelming reward. This means "inaccessible areas" may not always be progressive, they may in fact be worthless and underwhelming. That slowly grew on me, causing me to not want to finish the game. I was not overcoming challenges at that point, just roaming in between those challenges in a way that felt wasteful.

While I was having fun in the beginning, I quickly started to feel tired of the game. The challenges presented by combat and some of the rooms felt awesome, and I quite enjoyed learning boss mechanics and getting past parts...but the
journey started to make those end points feel not worth the time.

There is a lot of potential here, and I wish I could be more enthusiastic about, but it unfortunately fails to be 'exciting' and heads towards tedium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061895759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1576350914}
review:
Only one hour in and I'm already pissed, frustrated and bored. And I dig Metroidvanias to boot.

Game is slow, and you can't skip "cinematics" or dialogues.
Everything's a bit clunky. The character seems frail, and he attacks really slowly.
Even scrolling the map feels clunky.
Many enemies types are introduced in a way that you will be punished for not knowing how they work.
Nothing new under the sun. It just seems like a bad Castlevania.
There is a case of double inputs in the menu, and I use a Microsoft controller.
You can't change difficulty halfway through.
You don't even have any indication about what are the specifics of each difficulty level.
Fights resemble a one-button rythm game.
The art depatment's just meh.

And that's not the pointless achievements ("slain 100 foes") that will keep me trying not to die exploring samey aeas.
And I read it gets worse afterwards !
I even wonder if these guys played videogames before making this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990027567', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1576342373}
review:
I went into this as the first metroidvania style game I've buckled down to play since Super Metroid. As a kid. Which I was -super- bad at. I was a bit...iffy at the procedurally generated dungeons up front, just because of the negative connotations that term has managed to get. However, I was very pleased with the game! A nice, simple control scheme, plenty of exploration, and bosses that challenge you. 

The only direct shortcoming, to me, is the magic system. Requiring jewels to upgrade meant that I was just ignoring magic for the most part, as farming for jewels to upgrade wasn't super worth the time to me. Be nice for a bit more experience given per gem, or higher drop rates when you get to the depths of the mines for the better ones.

All in all, on an arbitrary number scale, 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055530457', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1576226541}
review:
This game is legitimately inferior to other popular metroidvania games like Hollow Knight and Blasphemous. I put barely any time into this game and already feel the need to uninstall. 

Some of my primary complaints are to do with the user experience and the quality of life. Simple things like tweaking audio and video are severely limited. Audio slider tweaks in increments of 5, while video has a simple resolution picker and a fullscreen Y/N feature. There is no windowed full screen and you can't drag the window to resize. 

Control scheme is clunky at best. Press a to jump, hold A to jump higher. Apparently there is a ledge grab but I never got far enough to find it. Y to dash backwards bu that very often hinders you more than it helps. I made it to level 3 before dying but never figured out what leveling up actually does for you, as there didn't seem to be any level up or ability or skill menu to speak of. Maybe one exists further in, but again, with no tutorial or explanation, I just felt like I was floundering. 

The story feels pretty half-assed. You're a generic knight in a generic country doing generic quests for generic reward. Fight skeletons and slimes and save the kingdom. Whoop-d-doo. 

I got to the first boss or mini boss, don't know which, in the first dungeon I came across. He had a simple attack scheme, but with no discernible way for me to heal myself mid fight and before long I died. Instead of throwing me back to one of the save statues or a city I've been in, it kicked me back to the title screen. This alone made me quit playing. In metroidvania games you die. A lot. If I'm gonna be going all the way back to the title screen every time I die, then I'm just going to take that as a sign from the developers that they don't really want me playing their game, and you know what? I don't want to be playing it anyways. 

Overall, I'm glad this game was in a Humble Bundle because I don't think I'd want to spend money on it otherwise, but I definitely cannot recommend this game to anyone. There are just far better metroidvania games out there, and some of them even feature pixel art.

review:
Just got done finishing Chasm and I have to say it was just alright. There isn't really anything wrong with the game, but there wasn't anything that wowed me either. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed it, but it felt pretty generic and mediocre overall. I certainly wouldn't pay $20 for it, so I am glad it was included on the Humble monthly. 

If you can get it for $10 or less, then it wouldn't be a terrible buy, but I can't recommend it at the current $20 price.

review: A neat mixture of procedural generation and purposefully set pieces, with gorgeous music and art. This is one of the most polished metroidvanias I've ever played. Rather heavier on the 'vania than the Metroid, the homage to Symphony of the Night is obvious across the board in the controls and gameplay, although I've still yet to get used to the obligatory Castlevania backdash not cancelling out of attacks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984325200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1585504738}
review:
Inferior to Symphony of the Night. 

The recent/local creation of the SotN randomizer also nullifies this game. Slog of a pace without a guide, and quite frankly, boring. Still surprisingly better than Hollow Knight for getting to the point (mostly), but with RNG maps, it's pointless to try and learn 'where to go' since rooms are different most every run.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158413648', 'num_games_owned': 2144, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1576015726}
review:
This game is boring; it's difficult but not challenging.  The enemies don't have a real technique to avoid taking damage from them, but the game basically tells you you have to beat them without taking damage.  It's not worth it.
If you love Metroidvanias, you'll sink too many hours into this game before realizing you dislike it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054213808', 'num_games_owned': 886, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1593058328}
review:
it's been fun. I wish I hadn't learned that bosses give you extra drops if you kill them without getting hit, because I'm an obsessive completionist. that said, the bosses patterns are easy enough to figure out in a couple of kills, and then it's just a matter of finding the right actions to counter their few difficult attacks to counter.

I find that a good knife or glove blade are best for most bosses if you can get in range with them to stab them several times, with a larger weapon for platforming and the remaining bosses.

the variety of spells is interesting, but with a lack of mana regeneration it makes using anything other than the dagger (or shuriken/axe for some bosses) a waste of mana. the biggest waste of mana is the boomerang, that only goes in extremely close range, but does less damage than just hitting the enemy with your sword.

I was also disappointed to learn that the console version has classes that give you perks. I'd have preferred to play as a mage, with double the mana efficiency, or a rogue with guaranteed crits on backstabs. alas, no class selection on the PC/Steam version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071206305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1665245277}
review: As a huge fan of Symphony of the Night, I found a lot to like in Chasm. The pixel art is superb, with detailed animation and great character design. There's a lot to explore and discover and a good variety of weapons to experiment with. The music is a little weak overall, favoring atmosphere over any truly inspiring tunes. While I know the game features procedural generation, it was seamless to the point where I wouldn't have noticed had I not already known. Worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055509418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1235, 'last_played': 1578164411}
review:
TL;DR - The update made things so much better, if you didn't like this game before, consider trying it again, they've fixed backtracking and a few other things with version 1.070.

A while back, I played a demo of this game at my local big-box store. From what I played of the demo, it was lots of fun. With a throwback to classic Gameboy Advance Metroidvanias such as Circle of the Moon and Harmony of Dissonance, it's a new take on one of my favorite genres of games. Initially, I was slightly discouraged from buying it, because I didn't have a good gaming laptop and it wasn't on any of the consoles I owned- but with a new laptop and a release on Nintendo Switch, I've finally had the chance to play the full game.

With the new 1.070 patch, it significantly cuts down on the amount of backtracking required and eases travel through the game's areas. The game only has two major puzzles, both of which are required to progress, but the patch eases things up (for one, you have to count the number of objects in three murals in one area, and in the other you find a song you play on bells in a tower to open a gate)

Personally, I find the mixture of set pieces and corridors to be a wise choice. There is some variety in the game's generated maps- it has enough differences and variations to feel new, but enough consistency that if you know what to look for, you'll have little trouble navigating around. You can mark areas of interest on the map, and an area where there's a chest or a breakable crate will always have a dot, though it may take just a little bit of looking to find what you're looking for.

Overall, it's a good game, a wonderful example of a Metroidvania, and an excellent throwback to the days of Castlevania on the GBA. I'd recommend this game to anyone who liked those games, as well as Symphony of the Night. The class system you unlock after the first playthrough is similar to Circle of the Moon's, in that it changes your starting stats, items, and growths, as well as a few other features, such as the Mage class recharging MP at save shrines.

8/10 - I think it was a little short, personally, but otherwise it's an excellent game, and a wonderful metroidvania.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980449859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 279, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1575908768}
review:
Approx 1 hour impressions- the pixel art is beautiful in the outdoor areas. Once you move into the mines it quickly becomes very generic 2D Indie Platformer stuff. 

The game follows a lot of the SotN Metroidvania conventions but in the most generic way possible. Rooms are designed by the devs but the way they are put together is randomized making even the early part of the game feel like a slog with no rhyme or reason to anything. Story is very bare as well, at least up the point I played. You're a knight in training with no personality and you get sent out to rescue some people. 

The story seems to be mostly told through dense writing that you find laying about rather than dialogue. 

Controls seem okay at first but there's a certain sluggishness to your actions that make it very hard to be precise. The backdash is awful, and jumping just seems off. It's tolerable but we've all played better. 

And I guess that sums up the game, but I have too much on my backlog to put up with tolerable for very long.

review:
Enjoyed the first half of the game. The second half requires you to think where to go as you'll have to revisit areas. Can get pretty frustrating. The major problem with this game is the item drop rate. You can have high luck, and still not get one of the two items after 100 kills.

This game rewards players for not rushing monsters. Once you study their attack patterns, you'll be able to kill them (and farm them 100+ times for the item) without taking damage. There's not much incentive studying bosses though, can just tank through them with full hp or potions if needed (and they don't respawn in story mode).

review: Excellent Metroidvania gameplay, well-tuned platforming, good visuals, great music--tons of fun. Definitely channeling Symphony of the Night in the best way, right down to the backdash, the equipment system, and the bestiary. The system of slowly freeing more and more NPCs for the town a la Dark Cloud/Terraria/etc. is also very engaging. Great stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993263474', 'num_games_owned': 825, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1575836450}
review:
It's good enough, but it's never great. Every aspect of the game; from the music, to the story, to quality of life stuff: it's all just kind of ho-hum. I wanted to like it, and I wanted to finish it, but 6 hours in, I just kind of wished I was playing a better game.

It's probably not fair to, but I received this with Blasphemous in a humble bundle, and it's impossible not to compare the two. While there's clearly a higher production value with the other title, and I admire the effort put forth by little indie developers, that game just screams with atmosphere, originality, and polish across the board; while this one never at any point made me think "Oh, that's neat". I really wanted to discover something new that might redeem the experience, but every time I unlocked a new ability, or rescued another townsperson, I couldn't help but think I'd seen this done somewhere else before, and done better.

With the recent reviews being more favourable, I was optimistic that maybe whatever issues giving it a mixed rating had been resolved. I think the creators have their hearts in the right places, and they're just getting their chops with this underwhelming love letter to classic Castlevania games. I really hope they're able to learn from the comments and use the profits from this game to make their next project better. It teeters on the brink of a recommendation, but the more recent positive reception the game received feels a little misleading, so I won't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030733557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1576744658}
review:
Despite being pixel art, this game is beautiful with a decent sound track.

Delve deep into a mine to save members of a small village that have been kidnapped by horrible monsters. Gather new equipment, spells and skills to traverse the mines while saving the villagers to unlock the various stores in town.

A nice take on an old format.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010633497', 'num_games_owned': 649, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1575833990}
review: Highly recommend if you enjoy metroid-vania style games. I recommend only playing on hard however, as it was a fully satisfying experience that I do not believe normal or easy can grant. Having to memorize each monsters' attack pattern and fully utilizing your platforming skills are important, and it's satisfying to master that. My one complaint would probably be that the arena in the keep did not have a save-point. And my favorite experience about the game overall are those moments where you find something or do something important and have to scramble desperately for a new save-point to not lose your progress.

review:
Por ahora no lo voy a recomendar, acabo de matar el primer boss sin ningun problema aun sin poder jugar bien con ninguna de las 3 armas que encontre, ya que resulta que tiempo de ataque y la animacion no cuadran, otro punto negativo es la esquiva, de que sirve poder esquivar si no esquivas xD, o sea es que resulta que atacas y no puedes darle rapidamente a esquivar para ir hacia atras, al final acabas golpeando y saltando hacia atras en vez de usar lo de esquivar.

Estoy en el segundo boss que es un gusanito y no hay limones de matarlo sin que me de un golpe, porque entre me atasco por culpa de las puertas xD, que vaya genio el desarrollador con la colosion, pues resulta que no puedo esquivar todos los ataques porque el de lanzar el moco no me da tiempo a verlo venir y si no lo mato perfecto no me da un arma o item unico, porque si, el desarrollador se queria pegar unas risas y venga vamos a poner en dificultad normal que para cojer el equipo del boss tengas que matarlo sin recibir ningun golpe.

No se, llamarme loco, pero si quiero un desafio no pongo el juego en dificultad normal, pero nada por lo visto a la hora de dise√±ar las cosas los desarrolladores no tienen en cuenta eso.

En el hollow kinght el tiempo de respuesta de todo es perfecto y no me atasco por malas colisiones, por no decir que matar a los boss en una segunda vuelta no es obligatorio ni hay nada que suponga un reto obligatorio para desbloquear algo.

Acabo de matar al gusano sin que me de ningun golpe y el item unico que me da es inferior a lo que ya tenia, lo siento pero yo paso de jugar mas.

review:
I really wish i could recommend this game.

I was really into it on the 1st area, but the 2nd one ended up beeing a frustrating dissapointment.
The fact of locking gameplay progression in an ARPG behind a puzzle, which turned out to be bugged on my seed was a huge letdown.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014445799', 'num_games_owned': 990, 'num_reviews': 325, 'playtime_forever': 1105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1576331165}
review:
Realmente no s√© si recomendar Chasm o no. Este t√≠tulo pretende ser un juego de aventura que toma mec√°nicas de los metroidvania, especificamente de Castlevania Symphony of the Night.

Si os preocupa que el juego sea un rogue-like pues no lo hag√°is, lo √∫nico que tiene procedural es la creaci√≥n del mundo y este se mantiene constante durante la partida. Lo que puede hacer que este juego no se sienta como una experiencia plenamente Metroidvania es que el mundo se siente divido por etapas, en un momento estas en unas minas y posteriormente luego terminas en unas catacumbas, luego en un bosque, sin una aparente cohesi√≥n. 

El acceso a ciertas √°reas est√° limitado por la resoluci√≥n de puzles (y no solamente habilidades como es usual en el genero), no son complicados pero el juego asume que es lo suficientemente obvio o que estas tomando nota de los lugares que has visitado para evitar que andes buscando sin sentido en donde est√° la clave para resolver el puzle.

Lo que he detestado m√°s hasta el momento es el backtracking, ya que ciertas habitaciones tediosas de pasar debido a su dise√±o. Por ejemplo, hay una habitaci√≥n que es un corredor de 3 pantallas de largo llena de enemigos algo tanquetosos, a veces uno puede ignorar los enemigos y salt√°rselos, pero en otras, est√°n acomodados de tal manera que un enfrentamiento es inevitable. A esto encim√©mosle que la variaci√≥n de enemigos por etapa no son muchas (3 a 5 tipo de enemigos por √°rea), y que hay enemigos que son muy similares en su comportamiento (o solo es un cambio de skin).

La curva de dificultad tambi√©n puede ser extra√±a, en las primeras 2 etapas siento que escala bien, pero luego empec√© a sentir que las siguientes etapas presentaban picos irregulares lo que me hace pensar que el juego esperaba que llegar√° con m√°s nivel hasta ese punto... a s√≠, el juego maneja sistema de experiencia de manera similar al juego en el que se inspiraron.

Gr√°ficamente me parece muy bonito, tiene una decente animaci√≥n y ambientaciones buenas. Por alguna raz√≥n, el juego a veces sufre de ralentizaciones, no son muy a menudas y tampoco muy graves pero molesta un poco dado que se trata de un juego 2D.

El sonido est√° bien, nada que quejarse, quiz√°s que los loops de algunas canciones son muy cortos y se pueden ponerse cansones.

El final del juego esta "pachuco" (decepcionante) para todo el esfuerzo invertido.

Pero bueno... lo importante es, ¬øel juego es disfrutable? yo dir√≠a que s√≠. La duraci√≥n de su campa√±a es de alrededor de 7 horas y el nivel de reto que mantuvo tomando decisiones para cambiar mi equipo, ver c√≥mo pod√≠a eludir zonas molestas y que atajo tomar para reducir el tedio de la exploraci√≥n. Como motivante para rejugar, el juego te otorga una calificaci√≥n al final para que intentes de mejorar tu run. 

Dado todo lo anterior y que Steam no posee una calificaci√≥n neutral, le doy manita arriba porque el juego hizo algo para no dejarlo botado.

Esta es la semilla de mi primera partida y con la cual hice esta revisi√≥n, por si la quieren intentar.

review:
A good dose of nostalgia but unique enough to stand apart in a sea of side scrollers. 

You can bind the attack of each hand to each of your triggers (giving you this awesome halo 2 duel wielding effect), you have a cool back dash feature and the jump mechanics are tuned perfectly to give you the feel of this light footed bad ass!

The daily and weekly challenges, ability to share world seeds, and the fact that the devs actually listen to feedback gives me a sense of community that it feels like companies like Bethesda are trying there best to destroy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977188730', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1575216951}
review:
Metroidvania aspect was a bit of a disappointment. The game forces you to backtrack and what not but it is mostly linear. You must fight the bosses in order etc and complete areas in a relatively linear order. There is not really much to explore. There was on one occasion had a mini-la mulana-like puzzle. And the only other puzzle in the game was pretty lame. 

The game having a random generator to create the rooms is interesting but doesn't really add anything to the game.

Combat system is reminiscent of Castlevania especially with backdash mechanic. Not a huge fan of but the movement feels fluid throughout most of the game.

The weapon types were pretty much the same with the best one clearly being the one with a wide swing / overhead attack. The entire game is based around the combat, so at least killing mobs required some finesse instead of button mashing. Most enemies you have to dodge an attack before attacking. With sparse save points it forces you to learn monster patterns and actually play safe instead of running forward and attack like some platformers games do - just rambo through trash mobs. Combat can get a bit boring though if you like using different weapons / builds when there clearly aren't any.

The boss fights were well designed for the most parts, though your giant hitbox can be frustrating to get used to when you've played precision smaller hitbox platformers.

Some of the movement mechanics felt a bit clunky especially on the last boss fight, unable to parachute after double jump.

Ok, so why I give the game positive review? The game overall has ~70% positive ending up at mixed. I was able to play the game and beat in ~9 hours on hard mode, but I enjoyed my experience. Typically, I rate/enjoy games solely on the gameplay / combat and not on things like customization, graphics, story, etc.

Some of the negative reviews are stupid such as little save points. There are plenty and you have consumables. The drop rates are fine and the only time I had to grind a bit was to complete one of the early meat collecting quests in the first area after clearing everything else in the game.

In short, as a metroidvania, this game is pretty bad - below average. As a platformer, probably mediocre or slightly above average. The positive review is more of a means to boost the game's rating a bit. I had negative expectations going in but it definitely does deserve higher than the 68% it currently has. Most important thing is that I enjoyed it.

review:
Chasm es un metroidvania de aspecto cl√°sico, desarrollado por el estudio independiente Bitkid tras cinco a√±os de arduo trabajo.

Inspirado en grandes exponentes del g√©nero como Metroid, Diablo o Symphony of the Night, Chasm se presenta como un juego de acci√≥n y plataformas en 2D, aderezado con un componente de aleatoriedad en sus niveles. El t√≠tulo nos lleva al Reino de Guildeon donde asumiremos el rol de un joven aspirante a caballero que deber√° viajar a un rec√≥ndito pueblo con el objetivo de rescatar a sus pobladores y eliminar a las fuerzas del mal all√≠ presentes. Si bien su premisa no es de lo mas original, como as√≠ tampoco lo es su concepto de juego, Chasm se deja jugar y resulta ser adictivo, puesto que ofrece varios incentivos, tales como misiones secundarias y decenas de secretos, que nos obligan -en cierto modo- a explorar los entornos en profundidad. A nivel jugable estamos ante un juego relativamente desafiante tanto en sus combates, en especial contra los enemigos comunes, como en los segmentos de plataformas. No es que sea un juego implacable, pero en mas de una ocasi√≥n nos mantendr√° al borde del asiento, deseando llegar con vida a la pr√≥xima sala de guardado. Respecto a lo procedural, los niveles de Chasm se generan de forma aleatoria, haciendo que cada partida sea diferente a la anterior. Claro est√° que no es un juego perfecto ya que tiene sus pegas, como el hecho de que los jefes finales sean bastante f√°ciles, que no haya demasiada variedad de objetos o que muchas veces terminemos vagabundeando sin saber donde ir. Sin embargo Chasm es una propuesta solida, tradicional y desafiante para quien busque una alternativa en el g√©nero ¬°Recomendado!

Lo Bueno:
+Un metroidvania retro de pura cepa.
+Secuencias de plataformeo desafiantes.
+Su simplicidad lo hace muy divertido.
+Apartado gr√°fico bien cuidado.

Lo Malo:
-La banda de sonido pasa desapercibida.
-Los jefes no suponen un desaf√≠o.
-No aporta nada nuevo al g√©nero.
-Desequilibrio en la progresi√≥n.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977095309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1572769073}
review: So, this is a good game, I'll say that first. But I would buy it on sale or if you really need a Metroidvania hit. Maybe some of the things I dislike will get patched, but I doubt it. Despite the supposed selling point of "seed-based Roguelike randomization," replayability is low. The controls are clunkier than you might expect from other 2D Metroidvania platformers - the "backstep dodge" does not have priority. Against enemies that you would want to use it against, it instead guarantees you will get hit, making it worthless. Overall a fun experience... Once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044323937', 'num_games_owned': 1417, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1562574625}
review:
[h1] My Journey with Chasm [/h1]

[u] My departure [/u]

I searched for a game that remind me of the good old Castlevania AoS and other Metroidvania. I played a lot of them, and I stumbled upon Chasm.


[u] The journey [/u]

In the first hours of my gameplay experience, Chasm was really fun : exploring the Mines, killing monsters, looting... The levels was sometimes hard and you are always looking at your health. But then I looted a special weapon (a quality drop if you want). And then it began.

I was overpowered. And it was at that moment that all the good parts of the game were sunk under all the bad sides : the quests, the levels proceduraly-generated that could (I don't think is still the case today) block you, clunky jumps...


[u] The arrival [/u]

Chasm is a good idea, a good little game, but not the Metroidvania you are looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037774804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1040, 'last_played': 1570488558}
review:
Chasm is a good platformer, not so sure about that RPG and metroidvania part though. I was kinda deciding where the thumb goes, but it would be unfair to give this a thumb down. There is seemly a lot of work behind this. The pixel art is beautiful, for me that was the game's best feature. Really, I'd go hiking to that garden level. The music was good. The jumping and hacking and slashing was good too.

It's really just those RPG elements that drag it down. The metroidvania aspect also didn't quite work out for me, but I may have just gotten an unfortunate randseed, although the important powerups are sort of fixed and often when I finally got them I was like "mmm thanks I guess.. but not really as interested anymore".

Otherwise I played on hard, which presents decent difficulity, just about right I would say.
All in all, if you can turn off the numbers for damage, do it ignore the stats and then you get to play a really nice platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014524389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1570391469}
review:
For a game that has such mixed reviews, I enjoyed it quite a lot. I played it from start to finish on Hard mode, got 100% of the map, rescued all the villagers, and got a ton of interesting items that change the way you play.

If you like platforming action games, light RPG elements (Items & Stats), and are a fan of Metroidvanias, then I recommend this game to you without qualms.

Now, to address the downvotes and negative reviews. I suspect a lot of people didn't like the randomized world, lack of a unified 'castle', and perhaps negatively compare the game to past giants that happen to be classified as Metroidvanias. If you keep comparing games to [b] Symphony of the Night or Hollow Knight [/b], it'll be hard to enjoy or recommend anything moving forward.

As a longtime fan of Metroidvanias, having played the ones mentioned above and most of the ones released in the past 22 years, I found the game enjoyable. Is it going to blow your mind if you've played the giants that have been released in the past? No. Will it give you a tight and enjoyable game with awesome art, animation, and classic SoTN-esque combat? Yes.

If you're reading this past October 2019, give it a buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018916385', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1663951106}
review:
This game has some qualities you might like from the prospective of a metroidvainia, but I strongly advise you to look elsewhere for your enjoyment. The prime reason for this is that the game developers clearly have no respect for the player's time in this game; from the general design decisions with level and area design, to enemy drop rates, to their handling of deaths. 

The movement and combat in this game are very stiff. To be fair, this seems to be intentional and maybe further item upgrades will make movement less awful, but I doubt it. Item upgrades won't fix the slow and stiff combat system that feels like a chore to engage in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198883395917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2089, 'last_played': 1679720938}
review:
This game deserves far more credit than it is getting. I'm assuming that most of the bad reviews are coming from people who just don't have much experience with metroidvanias, RPG's, or retro video games in general, because they seem to focus mostly on things like not getting items as often as they want to, or that they have to grind for some experience to progress at some point and say that the pacing is terrible or it's too hard.

The pacing of this game is perfectly fine and I never once felt that any part of the game was unreasonably difficult or too drawn out. At worst I may have had to grind a few rooms maybe ten times to gain a level or become familiar with an enemy's move set. For anyone who thinks this game is too difficult or complicated, please do not play some of the more popular metroidvanias currently out there, like La Mulana and Environmental Station Alpha, in which you have to accidentally stumble upon heavily encrypted secrets, some with no indication whatsoever, just to progress halfway through the game, and enemy cheap shots and instant kills are the norm.

I've spent about 21 hours playing through this game because I liked it so much that I wanted to complete all kinds of extra tasks (ended up with 17/20 achievements for my first playthrough) instead of beating it when I could have at probably about half that time. I've been playing video games pretty consistently since the mid 80's when I got my first Atari (and NES shortly afterward) and I've played through a lot of games since then. Metroidvanias are generally my favorite types of games, with Castlevania Symphony of the Night probably being my favorite game of all time, which I think this game has a lot in common with, as well as non-metroidvanias like Diablo (particularly the first one) that Chasm also shares some similarities with (loot drops with randomized enchanted items, one despondent town with a procedurally generated dungeon that increases in difficulty the further you descend, etc.). I think the complaint department here must not have played these hugely influential predecessors much, or at all, from the things I'm reading and also my experience with the game.

While this game may not be as sophisticated and epic as some of it's influences, it is a solid (albeit rather simplistic) metroidvania that takes clear inspiration from some of my favorites in the genre. Though the game focuses a lot on action and typical dungeon crawling elements, I actually quite liked the periodic bits of story line, NPC interactions, and lore that you discover along the way, as light as it may have been. And I only mean light in the sense of not having much dialogue and the like, not light in the setting/atmosphere. The atmosphere of this game is pretty consistently dark, just how I like it, though you do get bits of humor here and there and a beautifully rich color pallet and art direction. I would say this game plays more like SotN than anything with a charming art style more reminiscent of Momodora and an atmosphere that, too me, was just as dark as these and also reminded me a bit of Diablo I at times.

If you are on the fence about this game and have experience with the things I've mentioned here, don't just listen to the naysayers. I think you should try it for yourself. It could be newer gamers with little experience with this sort of thing, or just a couple of bad opinions that set a trend, but I think that it's one of the best purchases I've made on Steam out of about sixty games so far, most of which being metroidvanias or retro style games. I really hope that more people do try this game because I truly believe it deserves far more credit and I really hope the devs come out with more stuff like this in the future. I for one would definitely support them. Oh and one other thing. If you would like to try the map that generated on my recent playthrough, the seed is 13460422. Game on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069811828', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 66914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48947, 'last_played': 1682974253}
review:
After almost a thousand hours of game play and countless runs, this game only gets better over time. The world is mysterious and interesting, the characters are simple yet charming, and the monsters are cool and fun to fight. I've played many Metroid-Vanias including SoTN, Hollow Knight, Dead Cells, Rogue Legacy, Time Spinner, Momodora, Touhou Luna Nights etc. but Chasm remains my favorite. The endless replay value is untouched by any other and with the new Arcade Mode featuring competitive play my infinite Rogue-Vania dreams have come true.

The art, combat, music, pacing, maps, shortcuts, seeds, modes, random loot, and controls are all damn good. It feels like Rondo of Blood at times with how precise your inputs need to be in order not to get punished but the pay off is learning how to cancel animations like a God. Back dashing after attacking is the key to avoid being hit very much like SoTN. Each weapon has unique timing and cancel frames/mechanics so it teaches you when and how to commit to an attack. Chasm is very challenging to become a master at. If you can't deal with learning the art of combat you will be punished. 

If you're getting punished too often join the discord and the vets will teach you how to play better. Strats tips and tricks are all available and given often to new players. Check out the guides on the forum and delve into the endless maze that is Chasm.

Discord: https://discord.gg/Gstss32

author: {'steamid': '76561198070064665', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1566059977}
review:
[h1]I simply can't recommend this game to anyone, it is just a waste of time and money.[/h1]
[olist]
[*][b]The plot:[/b] has no depth at all and it's boring.
[*][b]Gameplay:[/b] the character is slower than the enemies, the platforming is poor, since there are venom pools in every single map.
[*][b]Enemies:[/b] the sprites are good, but they spawn in the edge of some platforms, which makes impossible to the player to land on it without getting hit.
[*][b]Soundtrack: [/b] it is just boring, each map has its own track, but it keeps looping, so you will listen the same music over and over again.
[*][b]Graphics: [/b] the pixel art is amazing despite the poor gameplay.
[*][b]Level design:[/b] there is a lot of empty rooms as it is a procedurally generated map, which makes exploration pointless.
[/olist]

I'm still trying to beat this game but i don't think i can take the boredom.

review:
Chasm is a very good game, it has a lot of good aspects and some bad. Overall, I recomend it.

First of all it has very good graphics and animations, it has a very big map with lot of secrets to uncover and enemies to slay, it has nice characters, it has good combat and movement mechanics and it has accaptable number of weapons. Also, enemy diversity is quite high. 

My only complain is the temple. There is a area called the temple in the game, there is like 14 teleport spots in the temple and game is not telling you, which teleport spot is teleporting you to which. It would have been a lot better if they've added collors to each one.

Lot of people are complaing about the mechanics, esspecially the walljump mechanic. I totally disagree, all mechanics are very good, even the walljump. They are a bit hard to get used to but once you do, they work very well. They are actually more precise than the mechanics of ''Ori'' games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032540115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 843, 'last_played': 1565401660}
review:
Chasm is a charming experience inspired by the likes of Castlevania with a mix of rogue-like due to procedure generated levels, which increases the game's replay value. The graphics are very well made, with detailed pixel art and two options of soundtrack.

Combat is very easy to grasp, being very responsive, but hard to master. There are various types of weapons which can suit the player's gameplay style, as well a magic system which can become busted really fast and make boss fights a lot easier. There is also a dedicated dodge, which I honestly would even forget it existed as its use is very limited; it is not as useful as in Symphony of the Night, as it doesn't allow for animation cancelling.

Much like other Metroidvanias, you are gated from accessing other areas and secrets until you get a specific ability that empowers the player (called artifacts). You can also rescue NPCs in the dungeons, which will often give sidequests, and some of them are also shopkeepers.

The game has a quite high difficulty curve, as healing items are very limited at first, although save points do replenish the character's health. Enemies have specific patterns, making combat more engaging than simply hack'n slash.

My issues with this game lies in the RNG-based system, where enemies have specific drop rates on items and even weapons, but due to the limited gear and consumables to increase the LUCK stat, some items can take ages to drop, meaning you can miss a lot of stuff unless you know specifically what you need. Gold is very limited and hard to come by, and many items sold by NPCs are limited.

Overall, this game is quite good, despite its flaws, which prevent it from being great. While it is not a long game, it is not short either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985925754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1340, 'last_played': 1565503687}
review:
Charming and fun, with an overall feeling that something is missing. 

I watched this one through kickstarter and had a lot of interest in getting it as soon as it was released on Steam. When it finally hit, I was in the middle of another game, so I didn't rush to buy it. After that the reviews started coming in and people were not kind.

I think the initial wave of purchasers were kickstarter backers and other folks who had been watching the progress, and I don't think it lived up their expectations. I can't quite put my finger on it, but something let them down en masse.

I finally caught up and decided to pick it up on a slight sale.

Overall, I think they did a wonderful job. The graphics, music, animations and characters are all very good. Charming. The scenery is exactly what I was hoping for. Caves, dungeons, lava, spike pits, and all sorts of monsters.

The movement and keyboard controls feel great and I had no complaints in that regard. It felt like it translated my moves from my brain through my hands to the character very well.

The save points are dealt out strategically and they like to tease you a bit. The first time you go through an area, you feel like you are begging for the next room to be a save point. I liked that. They never pushed it too far. Just enough to torture you for a bit.

The enemies are all quite beatable, once you study their attacks. You probably won't make it far brute forcing everyone in the game, but for the most part they aren't terribly difficult to figure out. Loot drops are not overly generous and sometimes you get something like a weapon that isn't as good as what you already have. You can sell items you don't need anymore eventually to a friendly townsperson.

You have access to both melee weapons and some magical attacks. In the end I used both but definitely relied on my physical weapons much more, with one small exception. I used one particular magic spell when fighting bosses and it helped me a lot. I'm not great at these pattern based fighting games, and I used every trick I had at my disposal.

One note that I didn't realize would have an effect on my playthrough. Because the map is 'randomized' when you start, there is no official walkthrough that will get you through with 100% accuracy. There is some info and a walkthrough out there, but it seems like the rooms get swapped around. Still, you probably don't need one. I was just stuck at one point and didn't realize I had missed a room entirely. 

In the end, I enjoyed the game quite a bit, and got over 20 hours for a 100% (rooms and treasures) completion run on Normal. I'm not convinced I would ever replay it. It might not have the most compelling story, or the most imaginative platforming action, but what it does, it does well. It's tight and fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976760251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1639, 'last_played': 1636510668}
review:
+ graphics are gorgeous
+ precise retro gameplay
+ good amount of enemies
+ good pace and fair length

82/100 -> Get it, if you like Metroidvanias, pixelart and retro gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067910620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1650051112}
review:
Recommended because it scratches that metroidvania itch. Be warned that its appeal is probably limited to hardcore fans of the genre. 

The question the game tries to answer is "Can a metroidvania be procedurally generated?" It turns out that it can be, but really shouldn't be. Some areas in my first instance are just long slogs through enemy infested rooms, platform challenge rooms give out crappy rewards, save rooms are in strange and inauspicious places. Some things demand a human touch.

The platforming is a decent challenge and leads to some interesting decisions about managing health and risking damage. I give the platforming an "A". Challenges build confidence and then cruelly take advantage of that confidence. The dev is a great talent for platforming challenges. Its only too bad that the platforming segments are sprayed haphazardly across the game's world.

Combat is easy to learn, somewhat difficult to master. Each enemy has it's own rhythm and it's up to you to use jump/dodge/attack combos appropriate for the enemy you're fighting. Timing moves and dodges are where the real challenge is at. The combat system as a whole is nothing groundbreaking but what is there is understated and accomplished. 

Overall this is an entertaining game but falls short on the big promise of the metroidvania genre; rewards for exploration and curiosity are generally not worth the time. 

I give it a "C+". Wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978593149', 'num_games_owned': 1648, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1564896833}
review:
This is one of those games that I wish I could put as Mixed. 

It has great promise, but the limited number of room types and level layouts really make for a rather dull second playthrough. 

The story is rather bare, although it provides enough to get you through the game. The art is nice and clean, and the music is pretty good.

Movement feels weird at first as you immediately lose all momentum when you stop moving forwards. Thankfully the game rarely demands that you utilize this, so it mostly just feels a little odd. Sadly there are no really special movement upgrades apart from the normal wall jump, double jump, swimming, and ledge grab. I feel a few more mobility upgrades could have sparked some more life into the game. 

Combat is decent, although I would have preferred a bit more options when it came to difficulty considering replay is part of the appeal.


Verdict: Wait until a decent sale before buying.

review:
If you are an old schooler and you loved the 16 bit Adventure games like Act Raiser, Demon's Crest, Super Castlevania, Symphony of the Night, Magical Popful Mail, etc... then you will love this game. It draws you right in and you can feel the love from the developers for those old games. It has difficulty modes (which is more than I can say for Hollow Knight), deep puzzles that take a bit more thought and a tight control. The progression is paced VERY well. 

SIDE NOTE: I'm not sure what all the negativity about this game came from. I got it recently so maybe they fixed any issues? But I was delighted when I finally got it. Don't believe the negative hype. If you are a fan of this genre you will love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999376568', 'num_games_owned': 12684, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1564587404}
review:
Here's the thing: one of the main features of the game -- its procedurally generated map -- is almost irrelevant to the experience. Yes, a second playthrough will look somewhat different from your first, but you'll be finding the same powerups in the same areas in the same order to overcome the same obstacles, and once the map is generated then the ten-hour gameplay experience is set in stone. This isn't a Spelunky or a Rogue Legacy, in which the procedural generation directly and constantly impacts the gameplay; this is a straight riff on Symphony of the Night.

But what a straight riff on Symphony of the Night it IS. With its detailed and fluidly animated pixel art, expansive collection of weapons and accessories, and interesting roster of enemies, Chasm will be worth playing even after Konami finally (hopefully?) brings Symphony of the Night to Steam, and deserves to stand shoulder-to-shoulder with the best Metroidvanias on the platform. It's just a bit of a shame that its most noteworthy feature doesn't affect much, and I'd love to have seen what the Bit Kid team could've achieved if they didn't have the millstone of procedural map generation tied around their necks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993762967', 'num_games_owned': 1073, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1563737119}
review:
tl;dr: Mediocre Metroidvania held back by a number of (still solvable) design decisions and poor pacing (due to the procedural nature of the levels).

I backed this game on Kickstarter in 2014, and while I don't regret it, the final product leaves a lot to be desired. I kinda enjoyed the time I spent with it, but despite being procedurally generated, I can't ever see myself returning to it. Let's get into it:

THE GOOD:

+ Great spritework: The art in this game is really nice. While the levels can feel a bit samey after a while, the monsters all look great, and the townspeople are memorable. The boss designs are likewise pretty cool, and their attacks are well-animated.

+ Decent controls: I don't have any real complaints here. Heavy weapons with a windup do require the Castlevania jump-and-slash technique for full control, but generally jumping and such worked well. See 'pacing' for problems with power-ups.

THE OKAY:

? Decent soundtrack: Not award-winning but it worked well enough. A bit forgettable, but it doesn't get old or repetitive, which is important.

? Arcade mode: This utilizes the procgen world design to dynamically build daily and weekly challenges, starting you at base stats and seeing how far you can go through each room (no backtracking) for a high score. Kinda neat.

? Adequate story: Nothing special, but I did like the idea of being a knight-in-training that isn't automatically treated like dirt. Following the researcher's footsteps and notes as he explored the ruins to learn about the Big Bad was also kinda neat. No complaints!

THE BAD:

- Pacing: The levels are procedurally generated, which means there's no way for the developers to properly pace the game's rewards, action segments vs. downtime, ensure regular access to save points/hub shortcuts, etc. One of the defining characteristics to a Metroidvania is its movement-granting power ups, but for me they all came in the last third of my playtime in rapid succession, meaning the first 10 hours were less enjoyable from lack of steady, incremental improvements. Double jump was the LAST ITEM I got!

- Procgen levels: See above, but additionally you'd only notice if you replay, which I don't intend to do. A lot of emphasis was put on the world generation, but it doesn't impact a given playthrough. If the world reset in areas as you played or as punishment for dying, it would've had a much greater influence and maybe made the game more interesting.

- Random drops: This is a HUGE problem. Every enemy has a set loot table, with one "common" and one "rare" drop (in addition to occasional gold and gems), but drops are incredibly scarce. Just getting a dude to drop its common item took me a good 20-30 tries of grinding, just to see what it had to offer. The luck stat doesn't seem to have any impact. For people who enjoy grinding, this is absolutely atrocious.

- Random loot: Uuugh. Every non-consumable item has a chance to drop with random buffs on it, which is nice, but this often led to a random drop absolutely outclassing every item of its slot for a long time, above difficult chest puzzles or purchased/crafted items. This further exacerbated the pacing problems mentioned above, when a random orange ring from five hours ago still beats long-running quest rewards.

- Too much loot!: There's a ton of weapons and no real variety between them. Sometimes you'll get a very special weapon (a sword that instantly unlocks a foe in the Bestiary for example), but otherwise why do you need eight spear-attack weapons that do 1 additional damage each tier? This happened to Bloodstained, too, but at least most of the low-tier weapons could be crafted into higher tiers. Not so here. Also unlike Bloodstained, you can't favorite items, so switching gear means scrolling through a huge pile of junk or selling everything.

- Some consumables needed for quests: I *hate* this. "Shame you used that Venison to heal a few minutes ago, because I need THREE of them, and drop rates are garbage! Have fun!"

- Obnoxious pickups: A bit of an oddball, but a constant problem. Breaking lamps causes them to occasionally drop money pouches or mana orbs. However, the money pouches always drop at an angle, and lamp placement means these usually fall off the sides of platforms. If they just dropped straight down, they'd be far easier to collect, but in some rooms every single lamp's drop will plummet to the very bottom of the area. As for the orbs, they fly toward the character but can be easily dodged, meaning you've got mana-replenishing heat-seeking power ups orbiting around you instead of flying straight into you, so you have to stop and wait. Just, why?!

- Single-purpose power-ups: Three of the eight items - the diving gear, the translation book, and the lantern - are only needed for 2-3 screens and are then useless for the rest of the game. The book is especially bad, since it's handed to you one room before the door it translates, and even then the actual key item is a boss reward! At least the lantern makes a couple dark areas claustrophobic with a limited light range. Otherwise these three items are event flags and nothing more.

There are a number of lessons for what *not* to do in a Metroidvania here. I didn't hate the game, and I wish I could set a milder review score than "Not Recommended", but it wasn't really that fun, especially in comparison to titles like Bloodstained. I'm really sorry, Bit Kid, I really wanted to like this! If there's a Chasm 2, I'd Kickstart it all over again and hope the lessons from the first round were learned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097569582', 'num_games_owned': 2522, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1569470946}
review:
By all rights, I should love this game. It has all major elements that I look for, including:

- Metroidvania
- Looks like Momodora series games
- 2D platforming
- Different load-outs?

However, the awkward controls, f-you game mechanic and enemy/ledge placement, uninspired storyline, and clearly un-remarkable characters (protagonist included) all make this a bad experience for a player.

PIck this up in the $5 range, but spend more at your own risk. I know that I wish I'd waited for this game to be cheaper, even though I bought this during the summer sale.

I PAID $13 FOR THIS FESTERING HEAP?? GEEZ. Feels bad, man.

EDIT: I absolutely forced myself to finish this game. Why? Because I wanted to be absolutely certain that I could say the following.

This game is the very worst game I have played in 2019, in 2018, in 2017, and possibly back to at least 1986. It is FULL of f-you jumps, f-you enemy placement, f-you layout (generated, yes, but the algorithm doesn't allow for certain rooms to be where they should), spaghetti-legs platforming, "let's try to farm a thing forever" mechanics, rubbery controls, crap wall-jumping, unimaginative weapon selection, useless combo skills for the few weapons that have them ... the whole game is some sort of enormous f-you to anyone who plays it, AND the price-point is around $10 too high. At $7.99, well, it'd still have a fantastically-bad value proposition, but $19.99 can get you a really good game, or half of a downright amazing game. The $7.99 price-point is where this game should be, as I am casting an official vote of "no confidence" in the developers here. They have made an un-fun exercise of "f-you, because reasons," and there's no humor in it.

:sadkitty:

author: {'steamid': '76561197989895733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1562733711}
review:
Consider me a connoisseur of Metroidvania games.

1. This is a real one. You have to navigate the 2D maps to gain abilities to access new areas.
2. These include things like wall-clinging and scooting under narrow passages.
3. There are cool boss battles.

Chasm has a sort of Diablo-esque structure, where there is a single main village you keep returning to from deeper and deeper into the dungeon. As you play through, you rescue villagers that can offer helpful skills or items in town. They also offer side quests to unlock more cool stuff.

Sometimes the game feels artificially long. Like they just make hallways extra long for the sake of adding playtime. Then I learned they are procedurally generated. Which I don't care for. I think the devs could have thought of a layout for the game, rather than making it random. But the rooms are handmade, just connected randomly.

There is a variety of weapons, enemies and evironments to keep you busy. There is stuff hidden around the maps, too.

Overall, it's a solid Metroidvania. Better than most of the new-school/old-school retrovania stuff on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076340527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1402, 'last_played': 1691201005}
review: I've been watching this game and bought it on sale. I grew up playing platformers since Atari, NES, and SNES, so I'm familiar with "Metroidvania" style games. Honestly, I'm not so sure why it's been heavily criticized. I played this on normal difficulty from beginning to end, and I have to say, I enjoyed it. You get exactly as it is advertised. You can't make direct comparisons as the game is not supposed to copy the experience of former popular titles. It is inspired by those older games we used to enjoy playing. I've also read review complaints that there's not enough complexity to the game play which in my opinion, complexity doesn't always mean better. In fact, simplicity can go a long way. I felt there was enough mechanics in the game to make it interesting. I also like the fact that they randomize the levels when you start a game ("seeds"), so your game play experience can change. Like Metroid, you unlock new skills such as wall climbing, edge clinging, double jump, sliding, gliding, etc, as you locate "artifacts" in the world. You can also purchase magic abilities which uses up mana points similar to Castlevania. You can level up and use scrolls to improve a few basic attributes. There's also an array of weapons, armor, and accessories to accommodate your play style. There's a pretty decent lengthy roster of enemies, each with their own respective AI for you to learn from and overcome. I've played about 23 hours of this on my first go-around simply because I wanted to explore every aspect of the game, unlock every item, save every villager, etc, but you can speed run this game if you wish to. As an older player, I dont have much time to invest in games, so I appreciate that it's not overbearingly long like some RPGs, there's a fair amount of save states in the game, and they include challenges like Mortal (die once and you have to start a new game). All in all, I appreciate this game for what it is. Level design is really decent for me, and the graphics and play feels like I could be playing an SNES title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198321740054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1646639399}
review:
Chasm is a decent-enough Metroidvania, for those who are looking for something more laid-back, exploration-heavy and with RPG systems like Castlevania: Symphony of the Night and the portable-console entries (like Aria of Sorrow) - however it fails shamefully at its main selling point: being also a roguelite.

First off, balance is brutal. I play games on Hard mode by default these days and I find Easy mode on Chasm to be [i]extremely difficult[/i] - sure, you can grind your heart out for experience and gold and go back to town all the time to restock on items to make your life easier but in a game that is already on the top tier of grind-intensive [i]and[/i] backtracking-intensive, the idea of doing even more grinding and backtracking is a major turn off for me. My last playthrough I found a "legendary" item fairly early on and, two hours later I still had it as my best-in-slot despite finding many new weapons and I was still getting my ass handed over to me (on Easy)!

As a roguelite, it's trivial to come out with a dozen ways to make it better: many rooms repeat multiple times (even in the same seed!); many rooms are static; meta-progression is static; "acts" are always the same (as are the enemies in them); items are very limited so the only form of horizontal progression to farm experience and gold to spend in town (which means failry long round-way trips)...

The biggest sin though is that there is really no reaosn to replay the game! There's no playstyle variety to try out in new playthroughs. Areas and progression being static (other than their layouts) means you've seen it all first time already. You build your town piece by piece depending on who you encounter in the dungeon but your town will largely end up looking the same each time, while vendor items are plentiful (and possibly static) so there's basically no strategy or theory-crafting to do.

... and the backtracking! Oh my god! I don't mind backtracking in something like Symphony of the Night because not only the game being gorgeous means I get to know and relate to each area and out-of-reach places effortlessly (which is next-to-impossible in a game with random map layout) but I also am always making some sort of horizontal progression - Chasm does this too with gold drops but since you will be backtracking to areas way below your current level, those are minimal and while I guess gold and the [i]extremely rare[/i] food drop do amount to something, experience gains are negligible even though lower level enemies are not much easier to fight and avoid damage from. (There's a lot more to say on backtracking later on too).

Speaking of avoiding damage, every type of enemy except a couple of the easiest ones require [i]absolute precision and instant reaction-times[/i] to avoid getting hit by (as do some of the platforming segments). Even on Easy, a veteran player will do better trying to avoid damage in a Dark Souls game than here. It often is OK because the game is built around this and you can afford to take some damage, even a hit from every enemy you fight - but with the random layouts and rooms with many enemies, I sometimes find myself completely out of health and nearly dying even after only a single room with heavy combat after I've come back to the dungeon with full health (did I mention I was using a super OP weapon too last time [i]and playing on Easy[/i])?!

Food will restore your HP but even on Easy you need every single one of those (and also maybe a scroll of summon) to survive boss fights, so if you've thought you could use health drops to heal yourself while exploring the dungeon - congratulations, you've already lost and don't even know it yet! Healing means going all the way back to the nearest teleport room (which can be multiple combat-heavy rooms away), then you enter the teleport room, then you teleport to the first area's teleport room, then go to the save point (which heals you) and then all the way back to where you started at - this can take up to 5 or even 10 minutes depending on where you are and the random layout the game created for the level. There are also more convenient in-level save rooms but I rarely ever find myself near one of those when I need to heal.

On top of the extensive backtracking you will be doing to heal or go to town to use the shops, the much, much worse and time-consuming type of backtracking you'll be doing is to find a key item in a previously-unaccesible area of an earlier level. As your map functions are minimal and teleport rooms equally so, this will often mean exploring half of that area's map all over again until you find which of the several rooms has the item you need to progress the game (and was impossible to reach when you were here originally). This easily means that half of the time you play, you are making progress while the other half or more is you re-exploring old areas, killing enemies for next-to-zero horizontal progression as mentioned, until you find the one needle in a haystack that will have the progression item to continue playing the game. 

Oh my! You don't know which level the next item is supposed to be in? Well, good luck, because now you have to repeat the process for every single level you've played before too! Maybe you will get lucky and waste only half an hour of gaming time if you guess right first try!

How hard would it be to make it so you had only to backtrack inside a given level, with only optional bonus items on earlier levels? How hard would it be to have a NPC that sells hints ("You are looking for the Lantern? Someone said they saw it on Floor 2 of the Mines")? Chasm couldn't bother and has no respect at all for your rime.

If you are a huge Metroidvania (and in particular Castlevania) fan and buy Chasm at discount (70% off), it might be worth one playthrough - other than large amounts of dull, time-consuming backtracking and pretty high difficulty even on Easy... it's not a bad game: the controls and graphics are decent; there are a few areas to explore with many enemy types to fight; the RPG systems are serviceable... however if what made you interested in this title was the "procedural generation" Bit Kid proudly mentions to you as soon as possible and you expect a lot of replay-value out of your purchase, you are going to be making a huge mistake by spending any money on Chasm.

For those looking for 2D platformer roguelites, I will 100% suggest giving Dead Cells a try before this. It's not a metroidvania, it's much faster paced, it's got terrible meta-progression but it's infinitely better than Chasm as a roguelite. Even being that different, there is no reason to try Chasm before giving it a try.

Also, for free, Super Metroid nowadays has [url=https://randommetroidsolver.pythonanywhere.com/]a randomizer with features like door and escape randomization[/url] and [url=https://github.com/LagoLunatic/dsvrandom]all the DS Castlevania games have one with full map layout randomization[/url].

https://store.steampowered.com/app/588650/Dead_Cells/

author: {'steamid': '76561198172087829', 'num_games_owned': 657, 'num_reviews': 190, 'playtime_forever': 2472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2472, 'last_played': 1548042792}
review:
This game deserves a mixed review.

Pros:
1. The combat system is simple and easy to get a hang of.
2. Decent amount of weapons and spells.
3. Stunning details of background.

Cons:
1. The rout of the game is quite boring.(Not much platforming.)
2. The loot is luck-based and quite unrewarding.
3. Pseudo-intertwined world. (Imagine in Dark Souls 2 SotFS one moment you are in the barren Earthen Peak, the next moment you are in the scorching Iron Keep, just by taking an elevator???)

What really bothers me a lot is the loot system. If you like hunting or even farming certain enemies to get a specific, strong weapon, then this game is not for you. Situations will go on two paths: if you are lucky, you can get a super strong weapon with any sort of blessing which helps you butcher through the rest the game; if you are unlucky, on the contrary, you won`t get anything useful, or even worse you can get a weaker version of your current weapon. Maybe it's just me being the unluckiest player to not get anything rewarding. OK, fine. But what about the chests in the game? The contents seem to be randomly generate. I do not like the idea of me going through a ton of traps, enemies, and platforms just to get a weapon which is worse than the current one I have. My guess is that the developers want the chest content to be random whether than fixed for the sake of multi-playthrough. Most of the metroidvania have a fixed content in the treasure chests so the player can choose whether to go after them or not. The randomness provides some sort of surprises which rewards the player willing to explore again. The perspective is innovative and interesting, but in reality the execution does not work well, discouraging even.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092008137', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1660377725}
review:
Completed this game on the Nintendo Switch and then noticed the version is out of date so purchased it for steam. I enjoyed every moment of this game! It is as close to Castlevania (Symphony of the Night and Aria of Sorrow) as you are going to get at the moment, and lately I have been trying out many different metroidvania games, none even come close to as good. The fact that the map is different each time you start a new adventure is a pretty awesome idea, and keeps the game fresh as you start anew. I really did enjoy this one and all of it's challenges. I played the game on Hard (haven't tried the other lessor difficulties) and the game begins at a simple pace and then spikes with difficulty. Thus forcing you to have to improve your reflexes, which I enjoyed very much. Each enemy has a new way of attacking, causing you to have to learn a new way to evade and attack! This is certainly something this game has over Castlevania. One thing I think the game could really use is a New Game Plus! That way all your effort isn't lost when you play the game again on a more difficult level while the maps rearranged. Another thing the game is lacking, which was really annoying for me, is the map doesn't give you a percentage of how much you explored! I really wish they would add that in. It only appears on the file screen, why not include it on the map?!
Well, other than those small little issues, the game is fantastic and at a fair price. If you are fan of Metroidvania games like Symphony of the Night or Aria of Sorrow, I would certainly give this one a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049169914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1649616685}
review:
Waw! Where to begin?

There were many mixed reviews around launch which got me holding back. But it's been getting updates after updates and recently they added over 60 new room variations and improved the backgrounds. They even added a chiptune alternative soundtrack!

So I figured now could be a good time to try it out and gosh was I surpriced!

[list]
[*]The art for the environment are very well done and all the rooms are cleverly built. I get serious nostalgia from Donkey kong country and Castlevania on SNES. The rooms are randomized for each seed. Some rooms have appeared twice but I never saw that as an issue, since they look so nice, and the dungeons are huge anyway. This could have been an issue before though, but the recent update which added over 60 rooms probably fixed this since I have nothing to complain about.

[*]Combat is top notch! Every type of weapon has a different playstyle. Some reviews are mentioning that the game can be won by spamming attack and dodge but that must have been at launch or they only played the 10 first rooms. There are so many variations of the enemies and all of them require different tactics. You won't succeed if you think dodge will help you throughout the game. You must use different melee and magical weapons in order to stand a chance.

[*]Progression on hard difficulty (can't comment on easy and normal since I started with hard) is very nice. Every new weapon or ability you earn feels like a big improvement. Level ups come quite often but they never seem overpowered. The stats improve more from what gear you have equipped. When you have mastered an enemy (type) another more difficult appears which require a different tactic and you are forced to adapt to the new playstyle required to defeat them. This makes the game feel fresh all the time since you can't run through the levels with the same tactics.
[/list]

I'm playing with a controller on hard difficulty, and I have died a lot. I've completed about 50% in 10 hours. After you have finished you can try on another difficulty. There are 5 difficulty levels, hard being in the middle. Then there's an arcade mode with daily and weekly challanges. I would say they are pretty similar to rouge-lite since you have only one life. In the main game you can reload a save point as many times as you like of course.


As I mentioned I'm about halfway through one runthrough on hard and I have nothing really to complain about. Everything is just so well polished at the current state. You really notice how much effort the developers have put into this game. I wish Starbound would have had a combat system and enemies like Chasm.
