review:
I do not usually write a lot of reviews, but for some games, I end up expressing myself.
Chasm, after several years was finally delivered.
I really enjoyed the experience presented, following the development so far, it is noticeable that much care was deposited in the project.
The inspiration in Castlevania SOTN is clearly visible.
For me the game brought a very nice nostalgic aura of how the games were made in the 90's.
I recommend to more mature and non-casual players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020000880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1603, 'last_played': 1535439789}
review:
Warning: there will be some spoilers.

This was a game that I backed long ago. After playing early demos of this game and following development updates, it sounded like this game was really going far, and I was totally psyched, regardless of the timely development.
Unfortunately for me, I must have read too much into the hype, as I expected so much more from this game.

Story:
While I like the overall theme and plot, it just seems like the story was rushed along, feeling like a lot of great opportunity was missed. There were times when I expected the scholar to give me some hint on what needed to be done, but nothing like that was provided, so I would wander around until I found something new that only triggered NPC text that was of no use to me (other than trying to add little to the barely existant story).
Even saving the townsfolk seemed mostly like just accidentally stumbling across them.

NPCs:
Speaking of NPCs, once rescued, they mostly provided little to the game. Buying and upgrading magic as well as buying potions where the only really useful NPC functions. The blacksmith offered quite a bit for a beginning player, who will unlikely have the funds to buy anything useful. I found that by the time I had money for any gear, I already had comparable or better stuff, so I only actually used him for selling old junk. Even after completing his side-quest, the items he provided were weaker than things I found in the areas where you would collect ore, so by the time I could craft anything, I already had better.

Gear:
Much was said about gear in the previous section, but to further elaborate, most gear was quickly replaced by something better. There were only a few items ever worth holding on to

Mini-Games:
There ar a few tiny mini-games, one that is rarely seen that could give you a permanent boost or nerf. Due to the rarity, I simply avoid playing. I am sure most players would save before hand, and retry until they won.
The slot machine requires timing and only rewards money, which for me was not important enough to play.
Finally the matching game provided a free opportunity to get tokens to play the prior mini-game. As simple as it is, it seems like there should be some sort of penalty for losing, but no.

Replayability:
While the map is procedurally generated (sorted), I feel like this game does not offer much into replayability due to the linear progression.
The various attributes are psuedo-randomly incremented in a way that generally gives you a balanced character, so you can't easily play a magic build or a fighting build on different playthroughs, unless you simply restrict yourself from using certain equipment or you like to save and restart until you get the right attributes, which is too boring for me.
The only big choice for we was using the bird hat vs the sword hat. I may do a sword hat playthrough to see how it stacks up in comparison, but probably not.
The game offers quite a few levels of difficulty, but it just wasn't interesting enough for me to want to push myself through.


Overall:
The game was a major let down to me as a big fan of the genre, a software developer, and a backer. It did not grow much since early demos, many things in the game seem to be pointless novelty and halfway through, I began having to push myself to keep playing instead of being excited to progress.

I have had to rescind prior recommendations to friends based on early expectations and can only recommend purchasing if on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012221863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1534146608}
review:
Its a different kind of Metroidvania, procedurally generated in parts and its been on the in development cooker for years. Heck, its been on my wishlist since what? 2013? Or before? I forget and digress. As is, its a decent game, with nice spritework and good music. Can't say if its got more or less replay value yet than a non proc.gen. game, but that aspect is one I'm less fond of. I do like the backgrounds, the Gardens and Catacombs really look good. The mines are a bit meh, but the Keep is fine.

My main gripes though are that the bestiary is done lackluster and the controls are not nearly as tight as they should be. Especially in a game with vertical/horizontal jump parcours and spikes of doom involved, your controls need to be tight. Here you sometimes really come up just too short simply because the controls are just a tiiiiinny bit off. The bestiary is barebones, a descriptor of the monsters is sorely missed and having to unlock the entries by killing random numbers of foes (and getting drops before they show up on it) feels like a chore without real reward.

Other than that though, a very enjoyable game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999105832', 'num_games_owned': 610, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1625, 'last_played': 1547839565}
review:
I backed the crowdfunding campaign eons ago and finally received... an adequate game. That's my overall impression of this game after one playthrough (and a bit into the second): It's perfectly adequate with a few caveats.

I'm gonna tl;dr the basics first.

Graphics: Serviceable, somethimes downright pretty. Never ugly.

Sounds and music: Reasonably evocative. Not chartworthy but they do their job.

Controls: Precise and responsive, just as they should be.

Gameplay: It's okay. Combat is a bit SOTN-style (backdash doesn't cancel but you can attack and backdash simultaneously),  platforming is good.

Weapons: Bog-standard. You got a variety of swords, whips, big weapons etc. with slightly different behaviors. You also get spells, effectively Castlevania sub-weapons that you need to buy to unlock. Pretty expensive but useful throughout the game.

Areas and enemies: Reasonably diverse, both visually and gameplay-wise.

Now for the more uniwue bits:

One big theme of the game is scarcity. At the beginning you are chronically poor and even later on a health potion is a significant investment. While the game does not exhibit Dark Souls levels of "git gud" it does expect that you get better and rely more on skills and proper judgement to stay alive rather then constantly downing health potions. (This did not stop me from facing the last boss with far too many health potions after throwing all my money at the potion vendor.)

Also, health is a scarce resource. You can only regain health through healing items (expensively bought or found as semi-rare random drops), by resting at a save point or through one very risky late-game weapon. If you want to stay alive it's critical to keep an eye on your health and judge whether you can keep going or should return to the nearest save point. This massively affects gameplay.

While this scarcity mechanic can sometimes bog the game down I like it. It's definitely a matter of taste, though.

The other big theme is randomness: The game uses hand-crafted rooms in a randomized arrangement. This was a really cool idea a few years ago and has since been shown to have some serious caveats. On the upside this means that subsequent playthoughs of the game will feel reasonably fresh, on the other hand the world isn't terribly cohesive and a bad seed can make the game quite a bit more tedious. A completely hand-crafted world might have made the game a better metroidvania but I can live with the increased replay value as a consolation prize.

All in all I think it's a decently good game. Does it measure up to titles like Super Metroid or SOTN? Not really. But is it worth playing? The fact that I started a second playthrough right after completing the first one would suggest so.

I can't give an unconditional buy recommendation but if you can stomach the game's quirks I think you'll find it to be a solid entry into the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970837233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1537596048}
review:
So I have mixed feelings on this game.  On the one hand its a new metroidvania - platformer which I really enjoy. It has a decent story, multiple areas to go with a nice map system similar to Super Metroid.  Its a cool idea where its a randomly generated map and so some of the experience will be a bit different each time you play the game.   I like that you can get different weapons, items and upgrades as you find the different towns people that are missing within the mine.  The pixel graphics are great! i really appreciate the work that went into it.  I like the variations of enemies in the game expecially the last half of the game.

Some of things i htink need improvement - 
* Music - While its not bad, it seem repetitive and unmemorable
* Character changes with items - if you swap out clothing or a weapon, there is harly any change in appearance if none at all on him
* Non Varied combat - Some weapons are slower because of girth or weight which makes sense (big broad axe vs basic sword) but there is nothing for increasing speed or different abilities within that weapon for futher enhancement
* Money  - it can cost a lot for some items.  Most of the money drops are between 5-10 gold which takes a long time to accumulate and can feel a bit grindy

This game has been worked on for many years and the artwork, style and story shows the work it went into it.  I just think some of more detail parts should have been thought through a bit better.

Rating - 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197982759518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1294, 'last_played': 1626222266}
review: For me, this was absolutely worth the wait.  I've seen a lot of negative reaction to it because it isn't SotN, and as someone who isn't super into metroidvania games (mostly because I'm awful at platforming), Chasm was great.  No, you can't cancel animations using backdash.  So if you *NEED* to be able to cancel every animation ever, maybe don't pick this game up.  That being said, the controls feel very good to me, and provided you're actively thinking about what you're doing (and not charging in headlong like I do), you should be able to dash, jump, and stab your way out of any situation.  The music is entertaining, but some tracks wear a little more than others (Mines, I'm looking at you.)  Definitely worth the wait for me, and I hope you enjoy it as well!

review:
Honestly guys, Chasm is a good game. Was it my favorite game I've ever played? No. But it was good enough. The mechanics were well thought out, the game play was fun, the art and music were gorgeous, and I enjoyed my time with it. I'm not sure if I'll go back and play it again right away, and I probably wont 100% it, but that doesnt make the game not good. 

People need to learn to accept that no game is going to be able to live up to every expectation you have for it, and thats [u]okay[/u]. Go in to chasm without too many expectations to weigh you down, and you will enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991130847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1533889100}
review:
Avec son kickstarter l√©gendaire, Chasm a longtemps √©t√© l'un des metroid-like les plus attendus de sa g√©n√©ration. Et environ 6h apr√®s l'achat day-one, une petite d√©ception est malheureusement au rendez-vous.

Fonctionnant comme un Castlevania Symphony of the Night, Chasm vous met dans la peau d'un h√©ros devant parcourir diff√©rents lieux tout en √©radiquant la population de monstres s'y trouvant et en montant d'exp√©rience. Tout comme avec Alucard, la mont√©e de niveau consiste simplement en une augmentation de la vie et des caract√©ristiques classiques du RPG (attaque, d√©fense, etc...). Il est √©galement possible de s'√©quiper d'armes ayant toutes un feeling diff√©rent, et de diverses pi√®ces d'armures. A la fin de chaque monde, on trouve un boss pas tr√®s difficile et une porte vers un nouveau monde, ce jusqu'√† la fin. Le jeu est assez court et sauf si vous cherchez √† faire le 100%, il n'y a pas √©norm√©ment de rejouabilit√©.

La particularit√© du jeu est de proposer des mondes se g√©n√©rant al√©atoirement √† chaque nouvelle partie, comme n'importe quel bon rogue-like qui se respecte. Honn√™tement, je ne vois pas trop l'int√©r√™t d'un tel syst√®me, √©tant donn√© qu'une mort signifie un retour au menu, et que je n'ai pas envie de recommencer le jeu tout de suite :p. De plus, la g√©n√©ration proc√©durale am√®ne un peu toujours les m√™mes motifs qui rendent la progression dans les diff√©rents mondes tr√®s similaire.

Le c√¥t√© rogue-like se voit √©galement dans le fait de devoir secourir des villageois emprisonn√©s √† diff√©rents endroits. Chaque villageois lib√©r√© d√©bloque de nouvelles possibilit√©s dans le village de base (boutique de magie, forge, etc...), mais il y a finalement peu de choses int√©ressantes. Le forgeron notamment est un peu inutile.

C√¥t√© graphismes et pixel art, le jeu est par contre magnifique. Chaque ennemi est unique et l'animation est excellente.

Bref, m√™me s'il tente des concepts int√©ressants, Chasm reste tr√®s classique, et manque beaucoup de... charme. L'aspect rogue-like aurait m√©rit√© d'√™tre pouss√© plus loin, l'intrigue est vraiment ras des p√¢querettes, et il manque un antagoniste principal charismatique. Un sympathique metroid-like, mais pas vraiment la claque qu'on attendait.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989204592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7558, 'last_played': 1591208997}
review:
This game is not for everyone clearly, but I think it is fantastic.  There are definitely flaws but it doesn't change the fact that this is a great game.  This is an old-school metroidvania in the vein of SotN, but actually challenging.  The game has mortal mode if you are into perma death (I am) but it can also be kept off.  It also has 4 difficulty modes and having just finished a mortal hard run (the second hardest mode) I am looking forward to trying nightmare.

I would say that there are a few tricks you must learn if you are going to enjoy the game, so if you are finding combat to be too slow and clumsy feeling, read a guide about basic techniques.  Namely, attacking just before you land after a jump, attacking during a backdash, and attacking immediately after pressing jump.  These things keep you mobile, while just standing there and attacking things will get you hurt.

Pros
The art is gorgeous and  the music is great.  The combat is fun (once you learn those tricks), and rewards patience and knowing when not to over-commit.  The platforming annoys some but I think it's perfect.  Most is pretty easy but every once in awhile there is something hard (like the swinging platforms) to keep you on your toes.  The developers are actively improving the game as we speak. Challenging in harder modes!

The cons
The advertised random generation is lackluster but this is only a problem if you are playing in mortal mode.  The crafting and purchased items are mostly a waste of time (mostly).  There is no guide or even hint that tells new players how to fight effectively.  The beginning feels like it goes a little slowly without any upgrades.  There is a lot of backtracking (although I enjoy that so not necessarily a con)  A couple really good spells make the rest seem worthless

None of these cons ruin the game imo.  I already feel like I got my money's worth with hard mode, and I am super excited to do it all again in nightmare.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026984521', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1684975953}
review:
I play this on Vita (it lives!), bought it on Steam just to support the team and tell you why this game is clearly awesome by giving an example of something I experienced recently while playing‚Ä¶

So I just unlocked the double-jump and wasn‚Äôt sure where I was supposed to go next.  But I figured that‚Äôs okay, there‚Äôs rooms on the map that I marked, I‚Äôll just adventure out and find those rooms and see what happens.  First I went back to town to buy some potions, then I checked my gear to make sure my weapon was doing as much damage as possible.  It was now time to go exploring, so I head out and started pwning fools in 2D (the floaty dudes in the green cloak that throw fireballs are clearly amazing).  Eventually I find an item that I think I might know what I do with AND I should be able to find the area of the game I need to take it to without too much trouble AND just maybe it will unlock a new area or ability.  The main concern now is [i]WHERE is the nearest warp room?![/i]  So I check the map to see that it‚Äôs kind of far away.  It‚Äôs far enough to where it‚Äôs going to be a little adventure getting there, which is what I signed up for and is clearly awesome so it‚Äôs whatever.

Within Chasm is a lot of stuff I want to be doing in a video game.  I‚Äôm looking forward to finishing this run and trying again with a new map. Thank God someone has finally made a Diabloesque Symphony-of-the-Night-like.  Leave no lantern in The Keep unbroken.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035601826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1317, 'last_played': 1537760776}
review:
Really enjoying Chasm so far. It's a very solid metroidvania and is worth a buy. I'm playing the game through on hard and it's a good challenge. I think people that are aware of it's development time judge it far too harshly. I can't think of many things that live up to 5+ years of hype. Judge the game for what it is now, not for its back story.

Things I like: 
+Combat is fun and engaging
+Different  RPG weapons and drops from monsters will remind you of SOTN
+Art style and quality
+Difficulty 
+Platforming

Not a fan of: 

Item pacing: There are often long stretches before discovering new gear or etc.  I know it's generated but I wish the points of interest could happen much more often. I'd be OK with monsters not having as many unique drops if it meant finding more chests and hidden stuff. 

Hallways: The game seems to have many rooms that are simply a long hall way where you fight guys. These rooms don't feel creative but simply reskins that can be used in every area. The only excitement they really have is stopping me from making it back to a save point. To be fair there is a formula behind the code that tries to break up certain rooms so your not doing the same thing twice.


Summary: Get the game and enjoy it. The world is better for having another good game in this category. It might not be breaking new ground in every area but do you honestly care? If you are a true fan like myself you could play a hundred games that were a shadow of what SOTN was and still be hungry for more. I'm glad I purchased it. I probably will pick the game up again in a while and try another run. However, even if I did just the one, I would still be very happy with my purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151422310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1169, 'last_played': 1533779399}
review:
The game has beautiful animations and backgrounds. Gameplay is fine if somewhat uninspiring, but there are too many flaws for me to recommend it.

There are several fetch quests which because of drop rates require grinding hundreds of the same monster type.
The highly vaunted replayability of this game isn't really much to speak of.
Combat and magic options are disappointly limited.
Crafting with the blacksmith is a complete waste. By the time you find sufficient materials to craft an item, you will have already found a superior item in the caverns. So that feature is essentially functionless.

Could have been so much more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031510167', 'num_games_owned': 1615, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1533783456}
review:
This game is a mastercraft of a metroid-vania style. Procedurally generated map makes for a unique environment to explore each play-through. 

This game is not for the light hearted or clumsy. If you are not skilled. You will have a hard time. Puzzles can be forgiving but combat is rather precide. this makes for a more enjoyable experience in my eyes.

Different weapon styles and magic selection provide ample options to fit your fighting style and tactics.

Game progression is a tad hit or miss. Some areas you may be stuck on and you must backtrack to a missed corridor to find an upgrade off the beaten path and then backtrack again trhoughout areas with pickups and intersections you could not previously trek.  Thankfully the game does offer a teleportation hub of sorts with shortcuts to make this slightly more easy

Game mechanics respond well to keyboard and controller. no sticky movement or ridiculous sliding further than you wanted to go, when you fall off a ledge, it was your fault, not the game.. Menu selection is fast and intuitive. game minimap makes for finding chest and suspicious areas you could not access extremely simple (the hardest part can be getting there) and the magic and upgrades make for a very enjoyable experience throughout.

Glitches bugs and crashes.  Periodically the game will darken for me but it always picks up where it left off, this is a seldom event so I consider this forgivable. I deliberately push games hard, and run multiple apps in the background to see how the game responds to alt tabbing and sharing computer resources -  This game has not yet crashed for me.

The art, the writing, the lore, the characters, the music.. They all work together to create a very immersive environment and the animation of the characters and enemies. to the ripples in tapestries as you pass them. 

This game deserves your attention and it deserves your love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087782404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1533697282}
review:
First i have to say that i don't understand most of the negative Reviews. Yeah, the hitboxes are in some situations strange, but when you practice well and learn how the enemeys algorithm works, then you can chase them easily to death. The negative thing, what i can totally understand is the backtracking. sometimes you have to run through all stages to find the room which unlocks the new level/area for example. The difficulty of this game is average (i beat this game on normal Mode) and have not so much frustration points.
But overall  i had a lot of fun with this 2D-RPG game. The 2D-Graphics looks pretty nice to me and the playstyle is improveable but also acceptable. Dont make the mistake to compare this game with more faster 2D games like Dead Cells, because then you will be dissapointed.
So play it, enjoy it and get the satisfying feeling when you defeat the last boss.

I don't understand why the Catacombs puzzle was gimped in a patch - that was one of the better parts of the game so far. I am really enjoying it, anyhow. Lots of people seem to be complaining about it. I don't know. I put a lot more time into this than Dead Cells so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981328872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1511, 'last_played': 1533741885}
review:
Really great metroidvania! Beyond the nifty pixel graphics, the usual large maps divided into sections, each with a unique environment, the many items to find and the bosses, the great originality of this game is that with only a couple of exception, every single enemy in the game has one or two specific attack patterns that you will need to learn and overcome if you don't want to get destroyed. 

This simple mechanic, combined with the unusual fact that enemies and destructible in the game will very rarely drop any kind of life, will make you much more careful when fighting! The game is pretty well balanced in my opinion, and I had a really great time playing! I finished the game in hard, and it was challenging without being impossibly difficult :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197999489350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1655842571}
review:
I kickstarted this game around 5 years ago, and then forgot about it until it was released.  I enjoy it a fair amount, but the UI needs some help - When you first start the game, there's no indication of how to progress the dialogue, and if you're playing mouse/keyboard, you'll be pressing every single button until you find the right one.  Also, there is no key on the map, so it'll take a bit before you figure out why one room is highlighted in red vs orange and why a grey dot exists in a room.  Why does the game-provided dot look the same as the one you can put as a player, which by the way covers up the game dot which could provide useful info?

I'm happy I kickstarted it, I feel like the game is very enjoyable and I'll continue playing it, but I don't enjoy having to figure out the interface, I just want to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008497915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1533689587}
review:
Finished the game today, and my save said I had explored around 95% of the map.  Easily the most disappointing release of 2018 for me.  The art work is absolutely incredible, but every other aspect of this game is either frustrating or completely forgettable.  

The combat is clunky and at times infuriating.  Each of the weapons feel mostly the same and they all feel like their reach is far too short.  Movement feels sticky because there's no way to interrupt attack animations.  You are cemented to the ground when attacking.  When you put clunky combat with sticky movement, you end up feeling cheated when an enemy hits you.  Most of the enemy attacks are telegraphed well, but since you're stuck in an animation there's no chance to react.  This ends up reducing combat to waiting for an enemy to attack before you can poke it once then retreat.  Since enemies at your current level typically take 4-5 hits to kill it turns the entire process into a slog.

The exploration aspect is usually the highlight of a metroidvania, but not here.  Get ready to back track through rooms that all look exactly the same.  Again, the artwork is incredible but when there's little to no variation between rooms it starts to get stale really quick.  The dungeons feel simultaneously huge and completely empty.  You'll end up clearing the same rooms over and over again.  Got a new ability?  Welp time to go revisit the other locations so that you can pick up a couple of gems and food.  Back tracking through a dungeon to see what new areas have unlocked should feel exciting but instead you're rewarded with a chest full of items that drop from enemies.

Games like Hollow Knight and Guacamelee raised the bar for the genre.  Chasm lacks any sort of real personality and completely missed the mark on basic things like combat, itemization, atmosphere and memorable moments.  Save your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077028653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1533704121}
review:
A Metroidvania for gaming purists.

_PROS_
- Unbelievable spritework. Even subtle animations like flags waving when you run by them left my jaw on the floor.
- Progression just slow enough to feel like you're earning every level and power up, without being too grindy.
- Good ambient music.

_CONS_
- Lacks depth in a lot of areas. Items, Combat, Enemies, Etc. Found myself using the basic sword-type weapons 99% of the game.
- Traveling can become a major chore.

Took about 10 hours in-game to beat on Hard. 
This won't "wow" most gamers, but it's a well-above-average Metroidvania.

review:
pros - great spritework, animations, and music. Enjoyable gameplay, but punishing if you're bad.
neutral - combat can be frustrating if you don't utilize frame cancelling with jumps and attacking while back dashing.
cons - can get repetitive due to similar rooms right next to each other. No major landmarks on the map make the world feel less connected and exciting than it could be. (think a giant tree with the garden in it or an exterior to the keep.)

Overall a fun, but short metroidvania experience. 8/10 for me, but getting an unlucky first seed could change your experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004237076', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2408, 'last_played': 1679437130}
review:
Chasm gets a hard "Pass" for me. It feels like there's absolutely nothing original or close to original about Chasm. It's a great example of how taking gameplay elements from what you like, smashing them together, and releasing that, isn't how you get a good game.

I backed this game after playing and enjoying the demo years ago, looking forward to where they took the development. After playing through the whole game to 100% to get the complete experience of what the developers built, every single drop from every monster and all, I'm coming away from the experience feeling like absolutely no one played the full game, start to finish, before release. I know that can't be true, and there must have been people who did. I want to know what they think, honestly. I don't get how this game was released like this.

I'll try to piece it out a bit. Visually? Chasm is damn pretty at the best of times. The art and overall feel of the environment is really neat. Sound-wise... I don't have any complaints, but I wouldn't listen to it if I wasn't playing. It's servicable. Story.... you're probably not playing games like this for story. So I can't give it a yea or nay on story, since I came in not expecting much, and got not much. Which is fine. Chasm is a game you're likely going to play on the basis of three things: level design, exploration mechanics, and combat.

Spoilers possible beyond here.

Chasm is on the procedurally generated (proc gen) train like a fair number of games have tried on for size recently. Its world is generated from a seed at the start of the game, which you can randomize or put in manually. This mechanic felt like the whole thing the developers wanted to focus on and emphasize as Chasm's "thing" at some point in development. I'm positive getting a system to generate levels like Chasm does was hard work. Post-release, it feels like a pair of handcuffs that should have been taken off a long time ago. A big part of why Chasm didn't work for me is their proc gen doesn't seem to do enough. Having to randomize only certain parts of the levels really doesn't leave you with much meaningful randomization. Levels wind up having the same core rooms and layouts to avoid breaking the flow of the game, with randomization being left to the arrangement of the non-essential rooms. If you have two points, point A and point B, and you change the way you get from point A to point B, you're still starting and ending up at the same place every time. That being so, your paths between A and B should be different enough to be exciting. I'd say the paths between core rooms in Chasm are anything but exciting. There were multiple times during my playthrough where I felt the journey across the level was void of anything but long hallways with a couple enemies. 

Having one randomization, at the start of the game, also feels like a severe limitation. A constantly shifting labyrinth sounds like a nightmare, but having the game generate new layouts while you're playing, on death or progress, might have been an interesting experiment. Not to say the devs didn't try that at some point. As it is, the proc gen and getting it to work properly likely ate a lot of development time whenever changes were made to the rest of the game. If I were a publisher working with the development team of Chasm, I would have had them scrap the system to make the core game more enjoyable. It's difficult to know what inherently is planned for the player to do and what is left up to the generator. If the proc gen was removed from Chasm early on, the developers would have been left with the task of creating a single, cohesive world with which they could fine tune along the way, giving every player the same world. I'd argue the only purpose of giving a game like this proc gen would be replayability.

Platforming action games rely on giving the player a multitude of different abilities and methods of exploring the levels within the game. How you explore the world and how it feels is just as important as the world you're making. If the world is intricate, complex, and varied, but the player explores it the same way for 10+ hours, there's going to be a sameyness to the whole experience. The back dash is the only ability you start the game with. It's likely to be the one you use the least among the active exploration mechanics, as it's slow, and tends to put you out of range of most enemies by using it. Back dashing really isn't remotely viable against most enemies in the game, with a handful of exceptions. The slide is a slide, and it's the fastest way of getting around. The ledge grab is fine, but the wall jump coupled with the ledge grab is where problems arise. The input for using the wall jump is the same as how you grab a ledge, and it takes priority over the ledge grab until you're locked to a ledge. Which means, after getting the wall jump, grabbing ledges is *less* easy and *more* frustrating than it was before getting the ability. You'll be fighting with ledges on occasion through the rest of the game. 

The final ability you get is the double jump, and it's really the only breath of fresh air in the game, at all. Exploration actually becomes really quite pleasant after getting it, since you can chain the double jump into your wall jumps to climb any vertical surface very fluidly. The fact it's handed out at the end of the game is truly a pity. Should the game have been designed around having the double jump from the start, the levels would have to be entirely different to compensate. However, the game is so much more fluid with the double jump, I wonder why the developers wanted players to experience their levels without it. Everything before the double jump starts to grate on you. Platforms are placed excruciatingly close to the limit of not being able to make the jump, very frequently. If you've ever had a moment in a platforming game where you remember "Oh, I have to make this jump from the very edge and jump as far as possible in order to make it", that is about 70% of every jump in Chasm. It gets painstakingly aggravating to have to approach every jump consciously from the edge of falling off. It doesn't make the game difficult. It makes Chasm an exercise in bugging the crap out of you when you have to redo a simple jump puzzle because you let off the jump button before you should have. On the whole, until the double jump, exploring Chasm is pretty droll. You have very little speed with which to trounce around the levels, and you'll be doing a *lot* of returning to previous areas. Sometimes it's a reward you literally don't need or already had, and sometimes it's the only path remaining in the game where you can proceed.

The combat is teetering on the edge of irritating, but as it is, it's just confusingly unbalanced. Melee weapons have only several types, and basic straight swords are all that you'll be looking to use. Everything else is either too slow, has too short of a range, or just can't output damage as well as a sword can. Magic (mostly the classic Castlevania subweapons with a mana requirement) is either somewhat useless, or completely broken and better than any other weapon you can possibly find in the game. The knife at level 3 is more like a knife shotgun, and at 1 mana, is the unrivaled king of efficient and safe damage in the game. It has infinite range, three projectiles, and a very short limit on how long before you can cast it again, enough so that you can spam it and kill anything before it has the chance to respond if you have enough Int. I honestly wonder if the developers knew just how good the magic knife is, and intended for it to be the best weapon in the game. If so, why even have all the other weapons at all? 

I've got so much to say about this experience that I've run out of space. Other people have discussed more of the problems with Chasm. If I haven't convinced you, seek those out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198212947615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1746, 'last_played': 1690394751}
review:
This game is great. The soundtrack, gameplay, items and so on. There's something here for everyone, completionists, RPG fans, Metroid fans, Castlevania fans, and fans of video games in general. I still want to play this game after beating it, try different difficulties, perhaps a newer build for my character and find new items. Would recommend, 7.5/10

I think everyone's forgetting that this is an indie studio's very first game, and when I take that in mind it's impressive considering the budget, experience and team of developers they had and the outstanding product created.

Gameplay: Somewhat repetitive, but the different weapons and armor and such allow it to evolve along with the evolution of the level of the character. Pretty standard and predictable but still simple addictive fun. 7/10

Soundtrack: Probably the best part of the game, when I was in the final boss room and the music was swelling and building, I was on the edge of my seat. I love how each biome (Mines, Catacombs etc...) has their own monsters and music to acompany them. Easy 9/10

Plot/Characters: Easily the worst part of the game. NPCs are rather basic and lack deep character and the story is very very basic. You're a soldier who has to rid a mine of monsters and a dark spirit named Ulak who...fuels the monsters power? Yeah that's not very well established, but I'm not here to nitpick. 6/10

Nitpicks? Uh, my avatar isn't holding the specific weapon I have chosen nor is he wearing the armor I have chosen. This is a  *major* problem, and one I was hoping they'd have fixed from the demo. It heavily undermines my investment in the story along with my suspension of disbelief. Also the story is super bland and basic, many of the games aspects such as exploring *every* part of a biome to get the next artifact to progress through the game can get extremely extremely tedious. Many other small things held back my 100% enjoyment of the game.

If a developer is reading this, I heavily suggest they allow new items to edit the avatar's appearance, maybe have an escape in a very strong Metroid reference (come on, the whole game is a Metroid/Castlevania reference), and er...let the map be more optional instead of having all of it be obligatory to progress.

The end of the game was great, but when rocks started to fall, I thought I was going to have to run out of the mine like Metroid's ending avoiding boulders while jumping on platforms to escape. But, that would've been how I would've ended the game, for what I got, it was still great.

Overall: For 20 dollars, this game is worth every penny. When the game ended and I got a bronze medal for my completion of the game, I felt like I *needed* to play the game again, get better at it and do better and get a better medal like silver or gold or something. Also I'm hoping to join the speedrunning community of this game. Enjoyably standard yet classic environment and story, fun yet repetitive gameplay, tense boss fights, great finale, and overall...

A great game that's a lot a lot of fun.

Overall Score: 7.5/10. Would recommend for all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990194469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1533666938}
review:
I love pixel 2D games and have played classics such as Megaman, Finla Fantasy 1-6, Castlevania, etc. so this should be no brainer for me, right?   Well, it's hard for me to recommend this game as it is at current price.  The core gameplay is fairly good but the procedural generated world need more work.  There are far too many repetitiions of long hallways filled with enemies and evne worse, platofrming sections that are just a variation of small blocks, few enemies and hazards that are all essentially identical.  Maybe I just got a bad seed but that's doubtful.  The game did get much more enjoyable toward the end after 4th area once I have acquired all of mobility abilities.  I wish those abilities were given at the beginning, would have made it much more enjoyable.  

The combat is solid but could use a bit boost in speed and having an ability to dash cancel out of your attacks would make it play better.   I got some nifty hats that summon a combat pet but often just replaced them with a better gear.  Would have been nice if the stats on those scaled up as you level the pets.  By end of game, I had too much gold and little else to spend on so I just brought like 20 potions and steamrolled the game.

I would definitely wait for a price drop or give it a pass for now until new content get added.  $20 is hard to swallow for this and I doubt I would enjoy replaying this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985598837', 'num_games_owned': 928, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1534685318}
review:
[h1]Update one[/h1]

There is a bunch of tight platforming and it honestly can just be horrible.

Later on in the game, there are very tight jumps that can nearly stunlock you to death.
The knockback in this game is unpredictable and the [spoiler] glider [/spoiler] is horrible to use.
([spoiler]You can use it once per jump, and only if your character is moving downwards it will work. So far okay, but it gets used up if you are using it while moving upwards, even if it is 1 pixel away from the highest point.[/spoiler])

Platforming overall in this game isn't fun. It's incredible precise to a point where you have 3 or 4 frames to react, if at all.

I dealt with a lot of bullshit in this game, but the late Keep is just horrible from a design perspective. The sparse checkpoints and the incredible expensive warpscroll makes it the more atrocious.


[h1]Was waiting for this game for a long ... really long time.[/h1]

And I was at most points also really ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about the 'alpha'-access mindset of the development team.
When I say ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• I actually mean a fair mix of bitterness and a lot of frustration.

The not met deadlines, the silence, the ability to buy into alpha access.
Where the alpha players didn't even have to keep the information for themselves, leading to youtube videos on the topic etc. (i.e. speedruns)

The way to long 'polishing' phase of the game.
The development team name switcheroo.

There are so many things I want to say about this development team and none of them are in any way good.

To me, they seem greedy, badly organized and don't care for people that backed the game to little to get alpha access to even write emails telling them that the game is released. (I found out by luck that the game was released.)


[h1]Now actually comes the review part of the game[/h1]

Is it good?

It's okay, that's all I can say.
It lacks interesting combat, has many frustrating moments, is filled with bad enemy positions on a map, leading to tedious waiting and the storyline isn't the most interesting.

Is it as good as the old Metroids?

Depends. There are fewer secrets, less hidden things.
There is a bunch of backtracking, and much of it isn't even optional.
The map is small enough to do so, but still the rewards ... are underwhelming at times.

Overall I would say it feels okay in the map department.


Onwards to upgrades and equipment

That is the worst part for me.
With one item set, the game feels nearly unfair hard. Enemies deal tons of damage, you are permanently on the edge to dodge damage, what can be impossible due to a bad map.

Then you find an armor and ... you actually walk right through the same enemies, taking one damage.
Making them less challenging and more annoying or frustrating, since you get knockbacked all over the place.

In the beginning, you will achieve said items when you leave a section allowing you to rush it.
But later on, you can get mentioned items more early leading to a section filled with damage sponges.


So why do I recommend it?

It is decent as I mentioned. The game has really good moments, but the game feels overall ... unpolished.

As an example, you can attack leading to a full animation of a swing. During this animation, you can't do anything.
You can't even use the dodge ability (backdash).
On the other hand, if you start to backdash, you still can use the sword attack.

This feels to me like different persons made a decision, leading to contradicting game-design.

And the attack animations aren't really good. I would say the attack animations on the ground feel terrible.

If you jump, it feels way more fluid and agile, but standing there being locked out of control for half a second is just terrible.

Also jumping or other forms of dodging are way more useful than the backdash. Rendering it useless to me.

This game is flawed, feels exhausting and infuriating at times. The long duration of the "Game Over"-screen doesn't help to relieve that feeling.


But I still recommend it, if you already played Owlboy, Axiom Verge, all the old Metroids etc.

16$ is a fair price tag for the game, and as I mentioned the game is really decent at some points.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

Is this a must play?
No, not at all.

Would I recommend it to a Metroidvania lover?
Yes, if he needs a new game and has already played the other well-known games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995292528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1533653968}
review:
It's rare that I give a game a negative review. Even if I don't like it, I won't slam it - I understand that a lot of hard work goes into making games. And maybe this is just because I as so excited about it, but I found Chasm underwhelming to the point where I couldn't really enjoy it. 

Without spoilers - I love Metroidvania games, and this game was missing a lot of what makes Metroidvania games great. It's got exploration, but every bit of backtracking you have to do feels tedius, and makes the backtracking you'd usually WANT to do in a Metroidvania game, to find every single secret, nearly excrutiating. The game doesn't move fast enough to warrant the massive amounts of walking, and fighting the same enemies over and over again, that the game contains. 

Every time I thought I had found a cool secret, an optional part of the game that made me feel acomplished for discovering it, it wound up being mandatory, and I wouldn't have been able to complete the game without it. The few secrets I did find held nothing interesting or special. I'll admit, there's one or two secret areas/puzzles I didn't quite finish, because again, I couldn't bring myself to do so. For an eight hour experience, this game felt so much longer. 

Chasm isn't without its merit. It handles very well, and each enemy is exciting to learn how to fight... at least until you figure out how magic works and use it to make every encounter a joke. Even the final boss was just a few potions and some spells away from defeat. Now, I was playing on normal not hard, but the difficulty shouldn't be coming from how big the damage numbers are, it should be coming from how the enemies act anyway. 

It's a decent story with a decent system, I just wish the game felt faster. By the time I got the full range of mobility your character will ever have in the game, it felt barely tollerable to move around with ease, and the game was almost over. It felt like a chore to finish the game. And if a slower paced Metroidvania with lots of backtracking is your idea of a good time, you'll like this game. But I can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039605368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1682408630}
review:
Castlevania SOTN is my all time favourite metroidvania game, so I'm gonna compare everything to it.

- The combat isn't nearly as responsive and fast paced as I would have hoped.
- The backslide is very, VERY slow. In SOTN, I used it all the time while fighting, and it was very rewarding. In Chasm, I just jump or run in the opposite direction because it's faster. It's a useless move and not being able to use it properly just ruins the satisfaction you get from evading an attack just in time.
- The jumps are so non-intuitive is almost painful. The falling part of jumping is too fast and too slow at the same time, and I don't even know how to explain this. It just doesn't feel good and/or natural.
- The only weapons worth using are the swords. Heavier weapons are too slow for the damage. The same can be said about lighter and shorter-ranged weapons.
- Everything, and I mean literally every single move seems to have some sort of hard delay/cooldown. If this was intended, I don't know where the devs had their minds.
- Save rooms are very bad positioned. Sometimes they are too close together, and sometimes you die just trying to find one after a lot of searching. 

I really want to change my review and hope the devs fix at least some of these issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065524265', 'num_games_owned': 46, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1390, 'last_played': 1543544640}
review:
I was waiting for this game for a long time. I will give positive review but im really loking for patches and changes. Core is fine and game have big potential but there is so many things to improve and make game way more enjoyable. The main problem for me is reckless Backtracking. Walking 20x times through same rooms isnt funny or challenging imo. Random map is useless in this case, becouse its not replayable for now. We want more condensed gameplay. Hand crafted, smart map could be much more better.

Pros:
+Awesome artwork.
+Ok music.
+General mechanics like exp, stats are fine for me.
+Boss fights are challenging and rewarding if you are going for "non-hit" reward.
+Monsters, bestiary.
+Items.
+Minigames and puzzles.
+Some secrets.

Cons:
-Backtracking and walking without a goal to find some random useless things.
-Fight system (in mid/lategame you can just spam knife spell without even seeing enemies and still kill everything).
-Looting system is not enjoyable.
-Wall jumps are unintuitive.
-Every sidequest is just "find and bring".

author: {'steamid': '76561197981062188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1533607499}
review:
This game had so much potential but threw it away with some quesitonable game design choices. Nothing felt rewarding, every treasure you find after gaining access via a new artifact was usually equivalent or worse in stats, it made almost every side quest meaningless. 

The combat also felt lazy and repetitive, most magic was unused because of the fact that gear scaled one way or the other, I did not feel any reason to build hybrid when the most effective damage was from your weapon in which you could only default swing and nothing else. 

Graphics and music were beautiful, no complaints there.

Aside from these issues the biggest one is how it felt to move around the map, it was extremely taxing to save or travel to a treasure since it took multiple portals/screens every time you wanted to do anything.

If I had to give it a rating it sits at about 4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197960452964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1536313141}
review:
Chasm is a love letter to titles such as... well... Metriod and Castlevania. Looking like it's straight from a 16 bit console, the pixil graphics are of a quiality I wish more of my SNES games of old had. 
The layout of the dungeon is randomized, sort of. Think of it as a card deck shuffled. Each "room" is a card, but with the deck shuffled, they're in a diffrent order/position in the overall layout. Enemies may drop money, an item, a piece of gear, or (most often) nothing at all. 
As you find villagers in the dungeon, shops, etc, will open, letting you spend to get better gear, spells, etc. 

Gameply is fun, with a difficulty that is variable to suit the player, yet the controls are simple and easy to grasp. 

Overall, an A+ game, and I hope to see DLC with more dungeons, monsters, gear, spells, and great fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982089199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1183, 'last_played': 1533615208}
review: Reluctantly, I must give Chasm a thumbs-down.  Chasm has beautiful pixel art, but the gameplay is repetitive and  boring.  The combat is unsatisfying -- the enemies are samey -- basically just copies of one another -- and they have extremely simplistic attacks.  You have to play the same areas over and over again, even more than a typical metroidvania.  The music is okay but like the rest of the game, repetitive and uninspired.  The game lacks many quality-of-life features which further adds to its frustrating nature.  Unfortunately the rogue-lite nature doesn't add anything to the game... It takes many hours to complete, and the notion of playing it again, just with the rooms laid out differently, is unappealing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991200082', 'num_games_owned': 1592, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1659125095}
review:
Castlevania: Symphony of the Night (SotN) is my all-time favorite video game. Given how much SotN clearly inspired elements of Chasm, I can't help but feel disappointed at some of the flaws in Chasm that come as a result of the developer having missed the point of what makes SotN's formula work as well as it does. It's a shame, too, because there're some very good aspects of Chasm that end up suffering due to the game's flaws.

Chasm's protagonist controls quite well at the start of the game, and anyone familiar with SotN will notice an immediate similarity between SotN's controls and Chasm's controls, right down to the default assignments of the face buttons. Alas, while Chasm does allow you to equip two different weapons at a time, one of these weapons takes the form of a spell. These "spells" are little more than Castlevania-style sub-weapons, however. While this seems like a logical approach to take to ensure some variety in combat abilities, I found myself not using spells very often and wishing that I could simply equip a different normal weapon that had better reach than one of my faster weapons.

Now, while the controls are generally fine at first, you start to run into some problems as you accumulate new abilities in the form of artifacts. You eventually get a glove that allows you to hang from ledges, thus allowing you to scale walls that have ledges scattered up and down them. You later get climbing gear that allows you to wall jump, also granting you a Mega Man X-style ability to slowly slide down walls, which in turn makes using the aforementioned glove far more touchy and tedious. Furthermore, you'd expect having these two items to open up a lot more areas to you, but the developer only allowed them to "work" together in the strictest possible sense, resulting in blown expectations when you take the time to return to a previously impassable area and find that it's...still impassable because the developer had no imagination in realizing how well these two items *should* work together.

Getting back to the wall jump...and Mega Man X, for that matter, the wall jump in Chasm feels TERRIBLE. In addition to it feeling downright unintuitive to use in general, you'll find that very few areas that require the wall jump are laid out in a way that makes it comfortable or satisfying to use. Too often, you'll find that platforms are spaced in such a way that you still need to grab ledges, which - as I mentioned before - gets really tedious once you have the wall jump (due to the aforementioned slide).

That's okay, though, because you'll eventually get a double jump. Problem is, the double jump just makes it all the more apparent how bad the wall jump is. Functionally, you end up with something akin to the Mega Man X wall jump once you have the wall jump and double jump in Chasm, only it's far more awkward to use because the protagonist is trying to get away from the wall with each wall jump, only to double jump back toward the wall while gaining less height than you'd actually want due to your character jumping back and forth like an idiot.

So, I mentioned before how the game continually blows your expectations. You know, this wouldn't be so bad if Chasm wasn't laden with backtracking. Look, I'm a huge fan of games like this, but the distribution of save rooms and teleporter/cave rooms in Chasm is HORRENDOUS. Yeah, I understand that Chasm's dungeons are procedurally-arranged, but it seems as though the algorithm doing this just intentionally lays rooms out in the least-convenient means possible. This wouldn't be so bad if you had an indication as to WHY you couldn't proceed past certain points in the dungeons, but Chasm lacks any means of marking multiple map squares with symbols to remind yourself what you might need to get further in those areas.

Speaking of progression, Chasm even fails to generate much in the way of excitement when it comes to building up the protagonist. Gaining levels doesn't have the impact that it should on its own, and you'll likely find one or two weapons for sale in town that're "good enough" and settle for those for 3/4 of the game, because anything dropped in the dungeon just feels inferior to anything you can more easily get your hands on. Furthermore, there seems to be too much of a focus on swords, with there being very little reason to use other types of weapons unless you just want to be different and underpowered. Even worse, the drop rates from enemies are ridiculously low, and Chasm seems to take inspiration from some of the worst Metroidvania-style games in existence by making many of the drops consist of crafting items that have very limited use. (And the stuff that you can craft is pretty much trash. Yay!)

Now, it probably sounds as though I'm really down on Chasm. When it isn't seriously disappointing me, though, I do find myself enjoying the combat on some level, and I have the enemy designs to thank for that. The enemy designs in Chasm are quite good, and you'll find yourself gradually having to change your tactics as you become more powerful, making your newfound strength (usually from equipment, not levels, sadly) feel all the more substantial. At first, you'll find yourself having to let enemies attack so you can exploit their recovery time, often having to do this several times in an effort to avoid damage. If you rush things, then you'll take a lot of damage at first. Once you get better equipment, though, you'll find that being more aggressive will make combat pass more quickly, but you'll still need to be careful and precise with your attacks.

Overall, I'd still recommend Chasm, as long as you go in with the right expectations. It's got some serious issues, but it's also very satisfying if you have the patience to tackle combat properly. Just be prepared to be disappointed. A lot.

review:
Honestly, I backed this game when it was on kickstarter and I had a lot of fun watching the development progress through the years.

Unfortunately, this is not quite what I expected. For a metroidvania game, it does ok, the formula works, but its downright shallow and boring at times.

Really, really hard to recommend this game given we have so many other incredible titles for the same price tag. As much as I can respect the effort put in making this game, I cannot in good faith recommend it to other fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026950092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1533252733}
review: I really don't understand the mixed reviews of this game. I really enjoy it.  The gameplay was fun although the dash was kinda slow and useless most the time. The music was really hit and miss. The one thing I don't like about the game is the fact that when they said procedurally generated I thought that meant that not only the rooms but some of the items and weapons would change during each playthrough. I was hoping to have a new adventure with a new character build during each playthough but this is not the case. In all honesty the randomly generated rooms are really not necessary. If you like Castlevania SotN then you should enjoy Chasm (though it is not as meaty) at least until we get Bloodstained Ritual of the Night.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082730311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1603625234}
review:
I personally like this game so much. I like the soul in it and I do find the gameplay pretty good. It seems crystal clear that the developers have XP and Currency glitches in this game. Some of them works, Some of them does not. Still, to me it is a solid good game ...

- I love everything. Art - Gameplay - Audio - Minimized story line - Retro feel - Metroidvania feel (which needs to be more practiced in my opinion) 

- The reason they got mixed reviews is that the calculation/Design  of the XP system and the currency in my opinion. 
I want to share my experience  : 

I personally found myself dealing with a puzzle in the game which was so fun but I got so much XP while solving it.  When I solved and moved to the other part of the map, my character was too strong for the mobs which made game a bit easy. Plus collected so many drops and coins during puzzle so that I could buy nearly everything from vendor too early. 
I was about to finish the game and sorted out that there had been an extra items option for the blacksmith section. Plus figured out what Tokens are for in the end. 

All in all, I enjoyed every part of it. Especially Boss mechanics are awesome.  
The overall Skill and currency design needs improvement .
Still I love Chasm and I do not think that this game deserves bad  reputation ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198148002569', 'num_games_owned': 647, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1671145807}
review: So far I have played this game for a few hours and let me tell ya, it is really awsome! This graphics are gorgeous, the gameplay is addictive, and the animation is superb. I don't understand why some people are giving this masterpiece hate. I was looking for a solid metroidvania and thats exactly what I got. This music is wonderful and the story is pretty good so far. I love the incorperated rpg elements aswell. There are many complaints over the procedural generation of the dungeons but I find it fresh. Granted the game procedurally generates a map for your current game and assigns it a seed number, so unless you start another game it won't generate another map. If you want to keep your map during another play through, just type in your seed number. I think its implemented well. One complaint I have is that when I run the game using my Nvidia GPU on my laptop the screen goes black, I have to use my iGPU. GeForce Experience doesn't detect the game anyway, but I would like to record and stream this so if anyone has a solution let me know! With that issue in mind I give this game a 4 out of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003429416', 'num_games_owned': 1783, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1999, 'last_played': 1682998206}
review:
So, Chasm is if you took all of the good parts of most Metroid games, Steamworld Dig, and some of the other Metroidvanias and made an amalgamation of all of those games and then put some polish on it.  I'll try to list the pros/cons but I'm sure I'll be missing some.

Pros:
----
- Seeds can be shared so you can race your friends or see what they liked about their seed, or try to beat your own time on the same seed.
- RPG style leveling up brings a nice touch as sometimes that extra level will help.  But it won't make the huge difference because...
- Gear is important and not having the right gear can turn an easy area into a difficult one.  This makes the gear progression feel better when you see your DEF jump from 10 to 20, or attack jump up by 10 points.  It can help.
- It doesn't feel procedurally generated.  Aside from a couple of repeat rooms, many of the rooms are standard castlevania style, vertical corridors climbed by jumping, long stretches filled with enemies, etc.  But it's stitched together masterfully.  And the handcrafted parts of the game (small bits), and rooms that need to be inside of certain areas, can feel very interestingly thought out.
- Weapon types are varied and have stronger versions (including boss weapons that have special effects) as you go along.  That leather whip you got will be weaker than the bone whip, which in turn is weaker than the thorn whip.  If you're willing to farm for it (there's a bestiary online) you can essentially play the entire game with one type of weapon.  There may be some gaps in time where your weapon will feel weak because a new one hasn't dropped yet or isn't available til a later area, but it is possible, I think, I haven't tried every single weapon class only runs, but it certainly feels that way.
- Metroid style progression is there and progress feels slow but it's more powerful than at first glance.  For example being able to grab ledges opens up a ton of spaces, and it doesn't feel like it until you're going back over the maps.
- Devs are very responsive on discord, and take feedback and hopefully will be releasing patches to make the game even better.
- Some of the secrets are pretty tough to find, fortunately you can get help with that later.  I put this as a pro because sometimes it's way too obvious in games.  Sometimes the secrets in this game can lead to entirely new areas, or shortcuts between zones.
- New area means new tiers of enemies, weapons, and drops to collect.  Believe me when I say that you can easily go to later areas and farm weapons and such and they will be drastically more powerful than what you can buy.
- Crafting is simple so you can get back into the game if you've been lucky with drops.  Some of the armors will keep you pretty set for an area.
- Two Familiars (One if you weren't a backer I believe) means you can have a floating companion.  It takes up the headgear slot, which is a bit of a ding against it, but the help they can provide is nice.
- Build your gear your way - If you want high STR, DEF and CON, you can do that.  If you want to stack LUK, you can do that.  If you want to be a jack of all trades, you can do that too.  There's plenty of gear to make this possible.


Cons:
----
- No new game plus.  Want to try out your friend's seed?  Level 1, No gear, final destination.  That being said the devs have mentioned making a new game mode, so we'll see as the game gets patched.
- Unable to edit map markers to say what they're for.  You also have to be in the same room as the marker to add/remove it.  This is being taken into consideration as well I've heard, so it may be patched.
- Unless you know about quest items for NPCs (well, where to find them) you can miss out on some pretty powerful gear.  There's no hand holding in this game.  Your best bet is to explore everywhere.  Or use a pre-defined seed that has a walkthrough.
- Drop rates are pretty low.  Even with the tweak recently.  That makes progression with weapons feel slow at times as sometimes the only way to obtain the next tier in a weapon class is through drops.
- Backtracking followed by limited save points feels like too big a risk for too little reward.
- No "Fast Travel" except back to town, so you can't save a location and warp to it or warp to checkpoints or anything that you've made.  It would be nice considering how sprawling some of these areas can be.

Personally, I love this game.  Minus the few cons I've listed I think once a few patches on a freshly released game like this come out, it'll skyrocket in popularity.  The devs are already talking further content and taking feedback into account.  I'd say it's solid 8/10 material right now and could be looking at more later.  I'm recommending this game.  Hopefully others will get it and come up with more feedback to talk to the devs about on discord so ideas can be considered and added if the team agrees with the direction.  

If you've been looking for a metroidvania recently, this is a good one.  The things it reminds me of while playing make me smile out of nostalgia and to see that some things don't change in this genre.  I hope this helps make the decision for someone, as we'd love more players, as it's a relatively unknown game (Googling anything for Chasm is a nightmare thanks to it's name being shared across multiple other games in quests or it's name or names of places, etc.)  and having more players talking on the discussion boards and discord.  Hope you enjoy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044270025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1533525230}
review:
I've been looking forward to this game for years. Nothing can live up to that amount of anticipation and Chasm is no exception. However, there are areas where Chasm shines like the Watchers' light. (Spoilers below)

Bit Kid's biggest mistake is not doing nearly enough to differentiate itself from its main inspiration: Symphony of the Night. SotN is a masterpiece and the gold standard of -vanias for a reason. Chasm's gameplay is unfortunately a lesser clone and in many ways just serves to remind the player that SotN's mechanics are more refined (for the most part). Games that are clearly an homage are best when they still innovate and introduce new mechanics instead of simply cut-and-paste. Tom Happ's Axiom Verge exemplifies this even though the game's style more closely resembles its inspiration than Chasm does. AV feels like someone took Super Metroid and added a dozen of unique mechanics that help it stand out. It reminds the player of Super Metroid while not making them wish they were playing it instead.

Chasm's art is gorgeous. Dan Fessler has made some of the most fluid sprites I've ever seen. Every enemy shares a consistent style that evokes different reacions in context. The early enemies seemed innocuous but endgame enemies were horrifying. The environments were jawdropping and the parallax is incredible. As someone who has experience in pixel-art, this game is among the best I've ever seen (and that includes the 16-bit era).

The pacing of the game suffers from a small roster of abilities. Navigation was not fun until I unlocked the double jump ability in the second-to-last area. I understand why this is the case (thematically double-jump is the most exciting of the given abilities) but it really should have been introduced earlier. The player doesn't feel any more powerful until near the endgame which is breaking a fundamental rule of good metroidvanias. Enemy design picks up in the midgame and becomes much more fun. One of the biggest flaws gameplay-wise is the balancing of different weapons. The only weapon that beats any whip is the final sword. The whips have so much utility in terms of range that every other weapon is simply inferior. They either need to be nerfed to do like 5 damage, or the other weapons all need a serious buff.

I came across several bugs that have no business being in a shipped game. A repeated one featured the walljump ability where I would slide down a wall into the ground and be teleported up like 20 pixels every 5 frames until I was back above ground. And another occurred in the Boneworm bossfight where I was actually teleported to the top of the room where I could just see my legs. I walked off-screen to the right, was placed in the next room, went back to the bossroom and the fight started from the beginning again. Also not having the files in order at launch is a rookie mistake that needs to be pointed out.

The proc-gen was impressive and lead to an organic feeling Metroidvania layout. Horizontal rooms repeating is not an issue but a couple distinctive vertical rooms repeated in obvious ways. Unfortunately the proc-gen was marketed as the defining aspect of this game and it was so well done that I hardly noticed it.

Overall, Chasm has major flaws that prevent me from recommending this game to everyone. For Metroidvania heads, however, it is a rewarding experience by the end because of familiar mechanics and immaculate spritework. 6.9 / 10 lmao

author: {'steamid': '76561198025434777', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1533079959}
review:
I recommend this game with only one real caveat: its length.  I enjoyed all of the game.  Did I think certain parts could be bettered?  Yes, some of which have been mentioned in negative reviews, such as enemy placement and variety.  However, with each potentially negative aspect of the game, including the example I just described, it's really not bad because those moments are fleeting.  Continuing with the enemy example, as soon as I started to think, "This enemy keeps showing up and I don't consider it interesting or difficult anymore," either new enemies showed up, the scenery changed, or a new challenge presented itself.  I realize I did not back this game, but as a common consumer, many of the complaints I have seen mentioned in the negative reviews strike me as nitpicking and/or expecting too much.

There are things such as how I feel like the randomization of room order doesn't really give me incentive to play again without other goals, but I chalk that up to my opinion and am not going to rate this game poorly for something like that.  Besides, the randomization is good because it forces you to play the game for yourself instead of looking up help.  To reiterate, I think their design choices are solid and don't detract from the game.  That being said, I come back to what I said about the game's length.  I beat the game in approximately eight hours, and that felt very short.  Games can always be improved, and if new content or a Chasm 2 comes out, I look forward to positive advancements, but generally speaking, my only complaint is that I wish it was longer.

Long story short, I definitely recommend this game, just be prepared to be done with it faster than you'd like.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960270054', 'num_games_owned': 2270, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 1521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1521, 'last_played': 1533505935}
review: Despite it's flaws, it's still a fun game. Sure maybe Chasm could've been a lot more, but it is a fun metroidvania. The procedural map generation is a bit silly as there's not much reason to replay the game. The save points and quick travel are too few and far between. And the backtracking is hard to figure out as there are pretty much no hints on where to go. I feel like all of these issues could have been resolved with some proper playtesting. Still, if you can get beyond all that, it's pretty fun to play.
