author: {'steamid': '76561198006597505', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1533485361}
review:
Chasm is a mostly-solid Metroidvania that‚Äôs often made frustrating by its procedurally generated map. It demonstrates the inelegance of procgen in a genre that benefits greatly from precise and skillful map design. The map introduces a level of inconsistency that throws the game off balance; difficulty seems to spike and drop randomly, and some of the most interesting systems take far too long to become rewarding.

Pros:
+ Art and music are generally enjoyable, and it stays interesting longer than you would expect for tiled maps
+ Different areas are reasonably spread out, and none really takes too long to complete
+ At its best, backtracking for missed secrets is just as gratifying as in handcrafted Metroidvanias
+ RPG elements can be fun to experiment with

Cons:
- Procgen makes the map inscrutable, and denies the player any sort of intuition to help them find save points
- Difficulty often manifests in just long stretches of enemies to claw through with ever-dwindling health and supplies
- Lots of the weapons you'll find don't feel any different from each other, and magic attacks don't really feel meaningful until after they're upgradeable
- Occasionally, parts of the foreground really blend into the background, making it hard to see the path forward

???:
-  Combat feels a lot like Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, which is decent but not as modern as I'd have liked.

Overall, it really could be a pretty decent game‚Ä¶ if the map was layed out in a way that worked and I didn't need complete luck to find my way between save points. The mechanical guts of Chasm aren‚Äôt incredible, but they‚Äôre good. They‚Äôre sturdy and classic and consistent, and they‚Äôre bundled with RPG mechanics that create a couple of worthwhile vectors for customization.
I wish it hadn‚Äôt felt the need to be constructed on top of a procgen algorithm, because a well-made, handcrafted version of Chasm might have been a solid 8 out of 10.

Ultimately, however, it lands more in the 6 out of 10 range. And that‚Äôs not bad! If you're really itching for a Castlevania-like, maybe pick it up despite my advice. But I don't think I can really recommend it when other games out there can scratch this itch much better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004062176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1533418599}
review:
100%ed it. Loved it! This game scratched my itch for old school Castlevania-style platforming. The 16-bit style pixel-art is gorgeous and the music is catchy. The mechanics don't get too complex but most of the upgrades you get fundamentally change how you move around the levels, which keeps the platforming fresh throughout. I found myself gravitating towards whip weapons (for the range) and not using the backdash at all, but still found the combat to be enjoyable and not too challenging. The story kept me intrigued right up until the end where, there final boss was a bit of a let down (though the rest of the bosses were great). 

I Kickstarted this and couldn't be happier with how it turned out. I will definitely buy and play Chasm again if it makes it to Switch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989513924', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1533464682}
review:
Chasm executes the classic Metroidvania formula to a very solid tee. It has everything you could possibly want from such a game, but not much besides. 

This isn't necessarily a criticism, but for those hoping for an evolution or spin to the Metroidvania formula - this isn't it. What the game does do, however, is deliver enjoyable platforming, combat and exploration mechanics with RPG elements.

As is echoed by a lot of reviews here, the procedural generation of the game is slightly redundant, and only affects the game minimally. This isn't really a rogue-like, as an average playthrough will last about six or more hours, meaning unless you are speed-running the game at a high level, you are unlikely to replay often enough to really appreciate the procedural aspect.

Regardless, if you are looking for a solid and playable Metroidvania, this is definitely it. However, if your patience for by-the-numbers Metroidvania games is saturated at this point, then you may want to think twice before putting your money on the table. Otherwise, there is plenty of fun to be had and it's a thumbs up from me.

If you want to see the gameplay in action check out Chasm's Indie Tale - https://youtu.be/DUEx-soNW74

author: {'steamid': '76561198007055259', 'num_games_owned': 705, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1533485250}
review:
Chasm is a decent game, but it doesn't live up to five years of expectations.

If you are considering buying this game, know that there are many better metroidvanias out there. Ori, Hollow Knight, Guacamelee, Axiom Verge, the Shantae games or even the classic Super Metroid to name a few. Then again, if you're already familiar with those, Chasm has little new to offer.

The pixel art is the only standout part of the game. Everything else feels a little too average. Functional, but lackluster.
Controls are responsive, but there are a few things, such as arbitrary recovery frames on backdash (you can just jump to cancel the recovery frames so they serve no function), and walljumping which feels sluggish in general.
The combat lacks depth. Most of the enemies follow the same general attack pattern with a few exceptions here and there. I like the boss designs, although by the end of the game you can mostly ignore boss mechanics and brute force your way through with upgraded magic and consumables (on normal difficulty).
The loot is boring, but it does what it needs to. For the most part you just get slightly higher stats than previously with no other effects. Weapons are not balanced at all; everything that is not a sword either hits too slowly or has too little reach.
Sound effects are great for the most part. The music is kind of ambient and fits the areas well.
Backtracking is pretty obnoxious, a lot could be fixed about it by making the Warp Scroll much cheaper or by offering an alternative way to teleport back to town when you're not in combat.

The randomization of the map serves little purpose as it stands. Playing through the first two areas for the second time I couldn't even point out the differences. Because there only seems to be one variation of the key progression rooms, there are only a few ways to place the room so that you can enter and exit it in the intended way. This coupled with the fact that items don't significantly affect gameplay make the actual differences between playthroughs very minor.

Overall, a positive experience despite the complaints. The game plays well enough and it seems very polished, even if some features don't feel fully realized. I hope there will be patches to address some of the lack of replayability and iron out some of the movement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975059341', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1533869713}
review:
Mediocre bordering on bad.  The concept is good - procedural generation Metroidvania - but the implementation just doesn't cut it.  There are too many instances of bad controls (walljump, backdash, attack time) getting in the way of an enjoyable experience to recommend, especially at full price.  Wait this game out, see if the devs push updates, and it might be passable; otherwise there are plenty of better titles in the genre out on Steam.

Sidenote: this is maybe the first game I've seen with "excluded from Family Sharing" that wasn't a MMO/pure online title.  Not a big deal personally, but definitely another little kick while it's down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069950030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1327, 'last_played': 1533915039}
review:
I enjoyed playing through this game. The gameplay mechanics and art style are very well done. But there is a bit of a lack of overall depth, however, and a few nitpicks drag the game down a little. 

PROS: 
‚Ä¢ Pixel Art looks great
‚Ä¢ Combat controls are tight
‚Ä¢ Platforming/Movement is also tight
‚Ä¢ Enemy/Boss Design, Variety and Animations are mostly good
‚Ä¢ Level Design is fairly decent, and easy to navigate. The procedural generation worked fine(no badly connected areas)
‚Ä¢ World Design is varied and everything looks great as well
‚Ä¢ I didn't have a problem with the # of save points as there are also several shortcuts that can quickly take you back to town where ypu can save as well.

CONS:
‚Ä¢ There are dozens of weapons, but only like 6 types that boil down to only about 3 attack styles
‚Ä¢ Loot feels a little light(I saved up money and bought a weapon in town that I ended up using for the majority of the first 3 worlds)
‚Ä¢ The magic weapons/spells are a little lackluster, they are servicable but they're all available to purchase from the beginning of the game and you don't find/earn anymore through exploration or defeating enemies
‚Ä¢ The procedural generation is probably not necessary.
‚Ä¢ Backtracking can be a bit tedious
‚Ä¢ (This is mostly my fault) There's an NPC that gives you a quest to dig up some stashes in the world, but I never found them until I finally figured out that the "dig spots" were what I initially thought were slabs of rock that required some kind of explosive ability, so I never opened them until very late in the game despite being able to for quite a while. I think if they just made the "dirt pile" an interactable thing instead of requiring you to equip the shovel as a weapon and use it on the "slabs" the issue would not have occurred, but I think it's mostly my fault as I just forgot about the shovel and assumed they were opened with something else I'd get later.

CONCLUSION:
I think it's a very solid and well made game that has some minor problems and could use a little more depth. 7/10
I beat the game in about 12 hours as I played at a very slow pace and did a fair bit of grinding and did everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026912947', 'num_games_owned': 551, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1154, 'last_played': 1574982322}
review:
Excellent game. There's something unique about this game: venturing into a huge maze not knowing which way is the exit at each playthrough. Unlike what the big reviews say, this game may take inspiration from Caslevania but then it spins in its own direction with the abilities which are unlocked during the game. Add great pixel art, especially in the backgrounds, and some unique touches like fighting off a Wendigo and a huge Wasp, and classical action platformer elements like wall jumping, locked and hidden areas, and interlocking corridors and you've got Charm. The musical score is enjoyable and very thematic.

I must say that initially the random enemies get on a slow start but as the game progresses they become a little more standard in terms of AI. I have a few gripes about how character movement plays as at some points I wished I could be able to sprint through the corridors since getting from one area of the map to the other trying to find where I was supposed to go next seemed too much. Also I wished there was more than one attack animation and wanted to be able to spam the attack button at some points, but I guess this is the nature of the beast. If you're into games like Valdis Story Abyssal City, you might want to give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977080970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1533481165}
review:
I've been eagerly awaiting Chasm for since its Kickstarter and...it's just a huge let down. The world is bland, and the story even blander. Everything just seems half baked. The Hub is slowly populated by characters you can rescue and each have their own sidequests you can complete. But...why would you? Many of the rewards offered by completing these quests are pointless, and I found myself not caring what happened in the hub and rather just getting through the game to complete it. Compared to other Metroidvanias, Chasm has very little personality. It controls rather well, but with its story being so incredibly basic and uninspired, there's not much else to hang onto.

Even the boss battles are just bland. Compared to SOTN, there is little sense of danger and the dungeon itself doesn't mesh into a cohesive environment. The procedural generation adds very little to Chasm, other than a sense of randomness where  it should feel like a well designed, living place.

After waiting for five years, it's depressing to see the finished product be so light on personality and soul.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000662987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1533481010}
review:
I've been waiting for this game for years, and I'm sad to say it's a bit of a let down. It's not bad, but it gets boring pretty fast. The procedurally generated world doesn't really make sense. It doesn't reset when you die, and your characters gains abilities that unlock new rooms in old areas. This means you're left wandering aimlessly around looking for the correct room, and it's just not fun. I'd be able to see past all of this if the soundtrack was good, but unfortunately it's the only truly bad thing about the game.

+ Great art
+ Good writing/character design/story
+ Good controls
- Mediocre gameplay
- Really bad music

author: {'steamid': '76561197984682842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1533405011}
review:
This game is really close to being good, but I just can't recommend it. The randomized map ends up making the world pretty bland and a chore to backtrack through, very little is added as far as new mechanics with combat/platforming so the sense of progression is fairly lackluster.

There are plenty of other games similar to this that do a better job of emulating its predecessors while also setting itself apart in some way. This is just Castlevania with less going on. For $10 I wouldn't have been as let down, but this just seems a bit empty for the pricetag.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996079355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1533461561}
review:
Like everyone I've been waiting for Chasm for a veeery long time, and so I bought it straight away even though I saw it had mixed reviews. I decided I would read the reviews after I'd finished the game, to not affect my opinion of it.

After I was done, I was honestly stumped. The game is great, perhaps even on the level of a classic. 

The art is perfect throughout, with beautiful backdrops and fluid animations. There are a large variety of weapons, spells and unlockable items that help you traverse the levels. There are also plenty of side quests from the various villagers that you rescue from the caves, and it feels great to slowly have the village come to life on the surface. Chasm gets the progression system right; it feels like there is always some new thing to find or some new item that will allow you to get past a previous obstacle, and all the while your character is getting stronger. There is also a DISGUSTINGLY large list of enemies in the game, all beautifully animated, all of which have different ways of attacking the player and a few that require that you mix up your strategy to defeat. In short, Chasm is chock full of great stuff to uncover.

So I came back here to finally look at the reviews. A lot of gripes I disagree with, while other complaints are valid. I'll offer my opinion on some common complaints here.

[b]The game is boring[/b] - I strongly disagree. Chasm kept me hooked for basically 10 hours straight, disrupted only by needing to sleep. Some have said that the levels are samey and full of the same enemies, and while I agree the levels could be more interesting (will address later) I felt like the enemies were introduced at a pretty good pace. I found that by the time I had got used to fighting a particular enemy, a stronger version or a completely new enemy would be introduced. With all of the quests I constantly found that I had something exciting to head towards. The only concession I'll make in this area is that some of the enemies were way too easy, sometimes being attackable from out of range with no reaction. Due to the level layout this isn't possible in most cases, but there were some minibosses which were entirely killable with this method. If an update changed anything, it would be to at least have enemies aggro if you attack them from far away.

[b]I don't know where to go[/b] - Again, I feel like this isn't a reasonable gripe. There were a few times that I got a bit lost, but when I took stock of all the quests I had and also looked at the map, I would always find some place I hadn't looked or something new that I hadn't done. I felt like the game lead me but didn't hold my hand, and I never had to look up where to go next.

[b]The procgen/roguelike elements barely come into play[/b] - I agree with this. Because of the longform nature of the game (the whole playthrough will take around 8-10 hours) permadeath isn't a thing until you finish the game once (and then it's basically masochist mode). The random generation of the levels is also minimal, just using preset rooms, and perhaps sacrificed design for not a lot of return. This may have also been disappointing for a lot of players who were searching for a roguelike experience and got a Metroidvania instead. I feel like this isn't a big deal if you manage expectations, but I can understand how this may have affected reviews negatively.

[b]Spells/weapons are bland[/b] - This I sort of agree with. The spells are interesting in their own right, basically offering different kinds of ranged attacks, but the first spell you get is leaps and bounds more useful than any of the others. Once you upgrade it (which you can do rather cheaply and early into the game) it becomes more powerful than even any of the melee weapons. It's also cheaper on mana than anything else. This kinda ruins the fun of choosing between different spells for different circumstances. The balance is less broken on the weapon side. Different weapon types basically offer different attack styles (axes do a chopping motion over the head, swords slash further but only right in front of you, etc) but they didn't come into play that much. Most of the time you just want the strongest weapon and good timing attacking while jumping.

So while the game is not without its flaws, I feel like the pros heavily outweigh the cons. I strongly recommend Chasm for fans of Metroidvania style games and action platformers. It's not a roguelike! If you can manage expectations around this point, and also take your time to progress and uncover your next goal, you'll have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996896861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1534173331}
review:
Chasm is a direct throw-back to Castlevania: Symphony of the Night and it plays like a Lite version of that game. If you enjoyed C:SotN as thoroughly as I did then this game will be fun for you. Many of the moves are very similar to identical, spells, the way you swing weapons, etc. (cutting this list short so I don't spoil anything for anyone). If C:SotN was a masterpiece, and I would argue that it is, Chasm is a well done game.

As it stands on it's own it's a fun new metroidvania game that will keep you jumping and slashing for hours. It would be an excellent game to use to introduce young players to the genre due to the leveling system allowing you to back off of harder areas for a while to gain the edge you may need. Plus they're generous with save-point placement up until the final few zones.

At the time of writing this review I have just beaten the game on normal mode, and I plan to jump into hard mode. I'm having a bunch of fun playing this game and I would definitely say it's worth your $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050163735', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1044, 'last_played': 1663610238}
review:
I only found this game early 2017 so I haven't been waiting for years, I've never played any Metroid or Castlevania game, and I played on easy difficulty, so this review is written from that perspective:

Music and Sound: 
Audially and visually, I found the game appealing. I sort of played as long as I did because the visuals were so satisfying, and the music wasn't bad enough to make me not want to play. I even found myself humming along to many themes by the end. 

Boring Rooms: 
Some rooms feel a bit empty, but I don't think this is a negative point. It happens in almost any game, unless the team goes to extra effort to cram every inch with action. Sometimes blank or slow areas have an enemy you need for your bestiary, a secret hidden in the wall, a magically hidden chest sitting in the open, or are designed to build a sense of progressive tension. 

Procedural Generation: 
I think some reviews are particularly critical because the reviewers know the maps are procedurally generated (in terms of room arrangement, not the rooms themselves). I don't see it as constructive to be so critical. Sure, the devs could tighten the design over time, but I presume they would be well aware of whether that needs doing or not. It didn't break the game, or subtract from my overall experience. 

Warp/Save Rooms: 
I don't know if it gives you extra warp/save points on easy, but I found the spacing just fine. Sure, it was a bit of a trek to get from place to place, but I think that's the point; you learn the procedurally arranged maps as you traverse them. If you don't want to go through maps a few times over (which isn't too tedious on easy) then maybe this isn't the game for you.

Guidance: 
There are definitely many parts where the game doesn't tell you where to go. It's up to you to mark any positions of interest on your map. I even drew some maps by hand for my own reference. The fact that doing so improved my experience is a good thing, in my opinion. The game doesn't hold your hand in this sense. You need to think. Got an item and not sure what it's for? Have you seen a slot in the same shape as it? Is it referenced in any of the journal entries? Sometimes you need to do the thinking and searching yourself. I liked that. 

Weapons: 
I found reviews saying certain weapons are superior to other weapons. I don't think it's this imbalanced. There seems to be spear, sword, two-handed, whip, and dagger-type weapons. I couldn't find any powerful whip or spear weapons, but I have an end-game option for the other three, which I actually switched between depending on the situation, and found each to be useful in its own ways. 

Spells: 
Honestly, I got the magic knife thing, levelled it up, and bought not a single other spell. I opted for high attack and defence instead. Can't say much here. The magic knives served me just fine. 

Combat: 
Again, I played on easy, but I found combat to be satisfying by the end. I ignored the dash button after the first hour or so of play, but I don't see that as a point against the game; it's common to not use a particular button, skill, or feature in almost any video game. Combat itself was easy enough for me to be able to plough through rooms if I needed to, and challenging enough that I had to think for a moment before approaching particular foes so I knew the most efficient way to dispatch them. Just my cup of tea. 

Controls and Movement: 
Just needs getting used to. I'm really not used to platformers, but I think I became quite good at traversing in every direction by the end of the game. If you're having trouble finding the attack animations too slow, find other ways to attack, such as hopping/jumping and attacking to get through the animation quicker, or pressing attack right after pressing dash to do both at once. 

Characters and Story: 
Don't expect to be immersed and invested. The story and characters are shallow, but it doesn't pretend they're going to be anything but shallow. Just go along for the ride, and take what it gives you. The game seems to be self-aware. Don't take it too seriously. 

Motion Blur: 
Weird, but unnoticable once you start playing. 

AI: 
Some enemies at the start make no effort to attack you. That's no secret. They wander back and forth, or sit still, or climb around platforms. You'll find enemies that try to pursue you before your first hour is up. 

Platforming: 
A bit frustrating at times, but not enough to make me anywhere close to stop playing. I just kept trying and made sure I jumped right from the edge and held the button as long as I could. Obviously becomes much easier once you get all the artifacts. 

Overall: 
Get it on special and set your expectations to medium. The game rewarded my effort, thought, familiarity, and exploration. I got almost 18 hours out of it (filled bestiary, found every mapped and hidden room, and got every chest, but not every item) and I'm happy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996550335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1685216331}
review:
I just beat this game on normal, and I gotta say, it exceeded my expectations, and I don't think it deserves some of the negative reviews I'm seeing here.

For background, I'm an Igavania fan, and I've even just recently re-played through Castlevania SotN, Aria and Dawn of Sorrow, and Portrait of Ruin.  This game is essentially a new take on the same formula that made those games great, plus a pretty good procedural level generation system.

Key Points:

Gameplay:
While the entire game is procedurally generated, you're given the option to specify a seed when you start a new game so that you can play through the same exact world multiple times.  The actual level generation is certainly not as breathtaking as a hand-crafted world can be, but it's good enough that the game is still very compelling, and adds an extra bit of exploration every time you start a new playthrough.

I only beat the game on normal, and I will say that I found the difficulty to be a tad on the easy side.  Regular monsters and navigating through the levels can be a challenge, but I think there was only a single boss fight where I wasn't able to beat the boss on the first try.  I'm going to play this game again on hard and see how much more of a challenge that becomes.

Combat:
A lot of the negative reviews are saying that they can't stand the combat.  While I will agree that it felt a bit off at first, I believe this was due to the fact that it's extremely similar to the combat in the Iga games, but with enough slightly timing differences that it threw me off (especially the dash).  I found myself adapting to these changes fairly quick, and eventually it no longer was a complaint.  Overall, the combat is basically what you would expect if you've played an Igavania (similar weapon thrust / swing animations), so if you didn't like the combat in those games, you won't like it in this one either.

Graphics:
Top notch pixel art.  I'm a huge pixel art fan, and even dabble in it myself, so I know good pixel art when I see it, and this game has some of the best I've seen, hands-down.

Music/Sound:
I personally thought the songs were decent, but ultimately forgettable, and certainly not as catchy as the songs in the Igavania games.  The sound effects are well done, but nothing particularly special.

In summary, if you're an Igavania fan (SotN, Aria/Dawn of Sorrow, etc), then you'll probably love this game too.

EDIT:  After thinking over it more, this game does lack a bit of the depth and hand-crafted feel of other Metroidvanias.  However, I would definitely still definitely recommend this game to any fan of old school style platformer/Metroidvania fans, as it's still a reasonable ~20 hour playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976577562', 'num_games_owned': 1298, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1533253827}
review:
I pitched in for this game on Kickstarter ages ago, and watched it with passing interest over the following five years. I almost thought it would never actually get completed at times, but here we are. Is it the best Metroidvania I've ever played? No. Does it really reflect five years worth of dev time? Maybe not. Having said that, I enjoyed the game from start to finish, and don't regret plunking down advance money on it all those years ago.

I completed my first playthrough, and will probably give it another run sometime in the next few months to try and clean up those last few achievements. The gameplay isn't really anything new or unseen, but the art is particularly gorgeous. It's a good way to spend 6-10 hours, if you're the sort that enjoys Metroidvanias, and the randomized level design should help keep it fresh for at least a little while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980333161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1534320721}
review:
Here my review for Chasm:

8 bit grafic is nice, Music is okay.

You have a town hub and rescue people from the dungeon as you explore deeper and deeper.

You find new ways to travel around inside the dungeon. Like a gauntlet to grip corners or a gauntlet to slide narrow corridors or a double jump.

All rooms you find are handcrafted, the layout of the dungeon is randomly generated with each game. 

Enemies are relatively easy at the beginning get more difficult further into the game. For each enemy you need to learn how to beat them. Sounds harder then it is. You could spam everything with ranged attacks.

Different weapons have different ranges. Knives have shorter ranges then the long sword or the whip.

You can build your character by equipping items. Those come in two flavors. Melee and armor and magic plus magic ranged attacks.

The bosses are relative easy. I am not the very best metrovania player, but i still managed to beat all bosses except the last in Hollowknight, i have no problems to beat the first three bosses in this game on normal. -> balanced difficulty.

Dungeons involve some backtracking to explore the parts you could not access the first time.

Monster give xp and you level your character. You can outlevel content and make things easier that way by grinding. But the next area will still give you new challenges. 

It is good game, if you like Metrovania games it is good and fun to play.

Thanks for reading, have a nice day.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983190864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1989, 'last_played': 1552624731}
review:
I almost feel dirty writing a negative review, but sorry, I have to. The devs seem like nice people and are respectful at all times, even when people complain angrily on the forums. I want them to succeed. Problem is, I put down $50 on the kickstarter half a decade ago, got a short demo, waited forever, and then to my dismay I can't recommend this game. If I see a major patch come out and things have changed, maybe I'll come back and adjust.

-The music is mostly awful. The town theme is great, and there are a few others, but the mines theme is atrocious, for example.
-Movement between 5 different maps is a pointlessly obnoxious PITA.
-The procedural generation makes everything feel disjointed and spread out, not fresh.
-The maps are big, but feel empty. There are a bunch of custom jumping puzzles and stuff and each individual room was hand-designed, but overall you're going to see the same 3 enemies in the next 20 same-color rooms, and most of the loot you find will be disappointing.
-Save points are too spread out, IMO, especially considering they designed every single enemy you face to require several hits to kill and the weapons all have short range (except the Elven Blade).
-There is basically no guidance on where to go next or what to do. Once you get to, say, the Gardens, you've got several maps to keep track of and you hit a point where you wander aimlessly for hours exploring every nook and cranny to find the ONE ROOM on some other map that will progress the game. Literally hours in my case, on two occasions.
-The weapons are bland as hell. It doesn't matter that there are 8 swords or whatever in the game because they all have exactly the same behavior. There are a couple that have a special property, but only the Elven Blade changes how you confront enemies.
-The loot, at least until you get close to completing the 2nd map, is largely a huge let-down. I used my starter weapon on the second boss fight because the single other weapon I found was worse. Once you get to around that point, however, it does improve as you find more stuff and can start to customize your kit.
-The spells are a let-down. They're not spells. They're just the special weapons from Symphony of the Night, basically. If you were thinking spells as in Aria of Sorrow, nope.

One good thing about the game is the pixel art. It's consistently fantastic. Sadly, you stop paying attention after 20 rooms of the same thing, so it diminishes the impact. 

Shutting the backers out of the design process entirely was a bad idea. Lots of the frustration people are having with the game right now could have been avoided had the developers let people give feedback as they went.  Now it's kinda too late.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059488692', 'num_games_owned': 2040, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1533362061}
review:
I'm a bit of a metroidvania nut, so take that into account. If you like the genre in particular, you're likely to derive more fun from this one. I enjoyed this game. It's a bit on the shorter side, but procedurally generated levels should add some degree of replayability. I'm hopeful the devs invest a bit more time for some features people have asked for like a New Game + or some additional content, because there is a lot to expand on here.

Pros
+ The art style is beautiful if you like pixel art. A lot of really likable character and enemy designs.
+ I found the game length to be a plus. It's a little bit too short at ~8-10 hours of play, but I'm a busy person and a game I can beat in a little less than a week hits the spot for me.
+ Procedurally generated levels work surprisingly well. Maybe this is just the seed that I got, but I was surprised at how logically laid out the levels were, how balanced the enemy progression seemed, and how well placed items were.
+ I didn't have nearly as much of a problem with the controls as some people have. There are slight hitches and delays in control, but I found it to be part of the experience and just how timing worked in this game.

Cons
- There is a certain amount of sameness to the levels, and there will be a couple of parts of each area that leave you thinking, "Wasn't I just here?" The vertical rooms with crawlers are the most repetitive.
- Weapon balance issues. The sword seems to be the best weapon for timing and balance. I tried using some of the other weapons, but I found them to be much too slow to react to most of the enemies. The game design puts timing and health preservation at a priority, so you feel every missed swing. Magic also becomes much more overpowered as the game progresses, and I found myself much less likely to use weapons at all when I had a ranged magic attack that did 150% the damage of a weapon hit at virtually no mana cost.
- Enemy progression. As you move on, boss fights actually become much easier since you are more able to simply wade in and do massive DPS and say "screw it" while just soaking up enemy attacks.
-Some bugs. A surprisingly large number of sub-bosses are happy to sit at the edge of the screen and let you blast them with magic until they die without putting up so much as a peep. If at least a few enemies attacked once they took damage, that would fix this issue.
- Still just feels a bit short. Again, I listed this in the pros, but if you're expecting an epic 80 hour game this is going to disappoint. If you take it for what it is, it's quite nice, but at $20 I can understand why people would want more content. This game doesn't live up to Hollow Knight - but again, if we're all being honest, HK is criminally undervalued at $20.

That's a longer list of cons than pros, but I find the positive points to be more important. Overall, I have zero buyers' remorse for this game and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it with the above caveats. If the devs have the commitment that those who worked on Stardew Valley and Hollow Knight have had, this could continue to become a better game over time. The procedural generation adds to replayability, and it would be easy to further extend that.

7/10 Solid but with some warts, big potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071634639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1533470675}
review:
Chasm clearly takes its inspiration from Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, but builds upon it with procedural level generation. Unfortunately, whereas Castlevania: Symphony of the Night was a masterpiece of 2D platforming, action, roleplay, and exploration; Chasm is not. The procedural content generation doesn't fit the metroidvania elements and instead of adding replayability, it makes the first playthrough (and any thereafter) very boring. Some game systems have been implemented half-assedly, such as magic, story, zones, movement in general, and even upgrades that make you able to reach new areas. Acquiring new parts to any of these does not feel rewarding as it doesn't really tie well into the game. Furthermore, movement abilities such as the wall jumping feels terrible compared to how other games have implemented similar systems.

Perhaps had this game come out 4 years ago, as was originally planned, it would be hailed as one of the better metroidvania games.However, while Chasm was in perpetual development other games have done what Chasm set out to do much better and more importantly: much sooner. Chasm is therefore an unfortunate but big pass for anyone except the most devoted metroidvania lover who may derive some enjoyment from the game solely because it is metroidvania game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047095783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2369, 'last_played': 1660275354}
review:
Chasm is not innovative, it's just another simple game in the metroidvania genre, it's a decent game to buy on a steam promotion.

Art is incredibly beautiful, the best thing in the game.

The controls have the standard castlevania symphony of the night, but a little slower on the issue of moving and attacking. 

Enemies are predictable and have one or two movements, which repeat themselves.

As a fan of metroidvania I do not regret having acquired the game, it is more a title for collection.
But some things frustrated my experience in the end.

 -  Text and more texts, collecting pages from the story seems to be just an artifice to explore the whole scenario, or complete an achievement of what really tell you about the game world. The story is not bad, it's just poorly executed. They could introduce flashbacks and cutscenes for example, in the bosses or when finding some intem importte, it would help in the immersion of the world of the game.

 -  Rescue personages. It may seem like a futile remark, but I fell into disbelief as I drove through corridors filled with strong enemies to rescue a person trapped in a cage and that someone would come home alone with no weapon or armor. Without being disturbed by the moments of captivity and risk of death. One or two sentences repeated in the dialogs. No character is well built to empathize with the player, and easily fall into oblivion. Rescuing people is one of the protagonist's motivations and has nothing memorable or rewarding when performing the task.

 -  Disposable items. There are standard rooms with platform challenges, with precise jumps to reach a chest with an item at the top. And many points on the map with isolated chests in hard access. So much effort to find a lower item than you already own. the best items are bought with the gypsy, and are more useful than the more expensive items in the game.

Chasm is not bad, it gave me a good time of entertainment, but it lacked to create a good atmosphere and to polish a little the gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004563134', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1245, 'last_played': 1566974008}
review:
Chasm is a Metroidvania game with a little bit more focus on the 'vania'. The player starts off with very little by way of mobility and no magic, and by the end of the game has typical mobility upgrades that allow them to traverse and backtrack to progress through the story as well as save optional villagers and do optional sidequests. It also features an EXP system that gives levels and stats and a town full of villagers to purchase magic, potions, materials, and other things. 

I had heard that it had a lot of roguelike elements in the game, and  if people are solely looking for a roguelike game, this is not going to be the game for you. Randomization appears to be, based on a playthrough and a half as of the time of this review, critical locations that are set in the same spot with tiles to connect them pulled from a pool of appropriate ones. In the grand scheme of things this means that over all variation is still fairly small, and I haven't really encountered much by way of difference with the exception of unlocking a few villagers in a different order. It does change the gameplay somewhat, but I wouldn't really call it a roguelike. The permadeath system is only unlocked after beating the game once, wherein the player can opt to play on a one-life mode similar to Hollow Knight's Steel Soul mode.

All in all, I enjoyed the experience. The game took about 10 hours to finish, and I suspect it could be done easily in about 6-8 if the player is willing to eat food rather than backtrack for savepoints like I did and they don't focus on doing most of the sidequests or getting all of the map like I did. 

The gameplay was fairly fun. I enjoyed the controls and only had a couple of sections where maneuvering felt awkward. The bosses had enough variations that they were interesting, though I think the game's balancing leaves them a little on the easy side and the mini-bosses are a bit of a joke that can be easily cheesed by throwing daggers outside of their aggro range.

TL;DR - I enjoyed the experience and enjoyed the controls, with the occasional bit of clunky platforming. There is enough enemy variation to keep it interesting, though mini-boss AI is a little silly and bosses feel a little on the easy side. The game does not feel remotely like a roguelike, but it is a nice metroidvania. It doesn't particularly feel like it excels at anything besides possibly the villagers and sidequesting which aren't something I see often in metroidvanias, but it manages to not feel particularly poor in any area besides being able to cheese at your own discretion. You might want to wait until it's on sale, but if you really need a metroidvania to play, this will scratch the itch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032609880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1533185845}
review:
Before I begin, I want to go on the record saying that Chasm is not a bad game.  A bad game is one with faulty mechanics, poor controls, bugs, glitches, etc.  A bad game is a game that fails to deliver on its promises.  A bad game has a terrible plot.  A bad game has something wrong with it.  Chasm has none of those issues.

Chasm's mechanics work fine, and the controls are tight.  Chasm delivers on the promise of a rogue-like metroidvania title.  Chasm has a simple, and perhaps somewhat cliche, but solid plot.  There is nothing actually wrong with Chasm.

This all makes Chasm a decent game.  Decent, but not great.  It's a mediocre but servicable platformer, and I fear that mediocrity is a result from the premise itself.

This game tried to be Hollow Knight and Dead Cells at the same time, but honestly should have stuck with one or the other.

Lemme explain.  Chasm is a game that takes several hours to beat, and each new playthrough will have a randomly generated map.  But unless you're going to be doing a speedrun, or a no damage run, or whatever, there's really only two maps you'll see: The one you get for Normal Mode, and the one you get for Hard Mode.  There's no real incentive for multiple completions on this game.  If the game had permadeath and unlockable upgrades for each playthrough, I could see justification for the Rogue-Like map generation feature.  Instead, the whole feature kinda feels wasted, and that it might have been better to have put all that effort into creating a single larger, more expansive and more impressive map.  Instead, it''s a procedurally generated map, and it feels like the game suffers for it.  The full maps feel too big for a Roguelike, but too short for a Metroidvania-style RPG.  Neither fish nor fowl nor good red herring, the game tries to be too many things at once, and fails to be any of them.

The enemy variety is kinda low, compared to many Metroidvanias, as is the number of bosses.  They all have a pretty basic attack and movement pattern, and you'll rarely ever aggro more than one or maybe two enemies at a time.  Combat isn't necessarily challenging, but small mistakes result in taking damage, and given the distance between save rooms, that damage can add up, especially combined with the fact that most mistakes in platforming end up with you taking damage as well.  There's a lot more focus in this game on platforming than on combat, and there's a few jumps that will require perfection, or you'll take damage.  Worse, perhaps, is that navigation feels incredibly linear.  The unlockable upgrades are received in a very straightforward ABC pattern, and the bosses are faced in a similar fashion.  Worst of all, perhaps, is that there doesn't feel like there's much in the way for exploration: Side paths tend to be a couple of rooms with a treasure chest at the end of a platforming section or a small puzzle, or just one room with a couple of destroyable crates.  That's it.  And the overwhelming majority of those chests will contain only a single item of widely varying usefulness or quality.

And then there's issues that are outside of the Roguelike nature of the game: Item prices are way too high for a game where money is a random drop, and in the early game money drops seldom and in small amounts.  Having basic magic spells cost 300 to 400 Gold when you're usually getting gold in 5's and 10's almost feels insulting.  You'll usually get larger drops from crates, but those aren't common enough to justify high prices.  While most purchasable items are not required to progress, things like magic spells, new equipment, and especially potions are almost cruelly expensive, yet ironically help make combat easier, so they definitely make progression easier.  Chests with good equipment are few and far between, so a player will most likely be saving nearly all their gold for new weapons and armor until they unlock the blacksmith's ability to forge new equipment, and then will likely be using their money to buy potions.  Healing item drops, while not uncommon, don't give much in the way of health, while purchasable potions offer major heals, but are almost too expensive to justify use outside of a boss battle or the most desperate situations.  Worse, perhaps, is the fact that save rooms are very far apart, and enemies always respawn right after you leave the room, so backtracking is just as painful as forward progress.  So, if you're nearly out of health, have no health items, and are a long way from the last save room, you have two options: Hope the next room you go into is a save room and risk dying, or use an expensive warp scroll to escape.  That's if you have one, of course.

It's a shame: In terms of core mechanics, Chasm is a solid game.  If they'd spent the years it spent in development making a single larger, more sprawling map with a better economy and a wider variety of enemies, bosses, and items, this would be a great game.  But by making this game a Rogue-Like Metroidvania RPG without the major elements that make Rogue-Likes, well, Rogue-Likes (Permadeath with unlocks each playthrough to aid future runs), or that make a Metroidvania RPG entertaining (a large, sprawling map with plenty of non-linear exploration that reaps great rewards), the entire project was doomed to failure, and it is a testement to the team's ability as programmers that they were able to turn this into an exercise in mediocrity when it would have been a garbage fire of shame and failure in the hands of a lesser dev team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037372051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1533337857}
review:
A solid metroidvania sadly hamstrung by the only thing that makes it unique.

If you're a metroidvania enthusiast and you want some maps to explore, some items to collect, and some enemies to fight, then Chasm does all of that just fine. It's never exceptional at those things, but it gets the job done without much much frustration or any gamebreaking flaws along the way. Where Chasm genuinely does shine is in the art and animation department. Visually the game is gorgeous. The pixel art is colourful and varied, the animation is smooth as heck, and it's all accompanied by some catchy music that's pleasant to listen to as you adventure through several different environments and biomes.

What really drags Chasm down is unfortunately the way it uses procedurally generated levels in place of hand-crafted stages. Certain key rooms are properly designed, but they're all connected by repetitive, samey combat corridors and vertical shafts. The intent here was to make the game more enjoyable to replay, but sadly it has the opposite effect of making the level design so bland and forgettable that I find myself with no desire to revisit it. This is compounded by a rather sparse amount of save rooms and teleports, making the hefty amount of backtracking the game requests of you something of a chore.

When it comes to its core mechanics Chasm is, as mentioned, relatively solid. Not great, but still decent. Your character responds smoothly enough, and attacks are telegraphed fairly. Some of the mobility upgrades you obtain are a little clunky in their responsiveness, and the lack of any kind of pushback on your attacks makes the dated problem of "enemies walk into you when you try to hit them" something of an annoyance, but these things aren't by any means gamebreaking. Bosses are alright, if a little bland and forgettable, and the item and town progression elements are a cute, if somewhat shallow extra. The game's story is straightforward and generic, but it barely intrudes on the gameplay, so it doesn't hamper the experience either.

Chasm is one of those metroidvanias that ultimately feels like it's a little too enamoured with Symphony of the Night to find its own voice. Had it come out ten years ago (or perhaps when it was first pitched as a Kickstarter project) it probably would've been regarded as a very fun and neatly designed entry into the genre. Unfortunately metroidvanias have evolved significantly since those days, and simply doing the same things SotN did doesn't quite cut it any more. Now we have games like Hollow Knight and Ori and the Blind Forest to look up to as the monarchs of the genre, and when stacked up against its modern counterparts Chasm falls significantly short.

In terms of difficulty and play time, I managed to 100% the map and town completion in eight hours with only a couple of deaths. This is one of those games where the difficulty is largely determined by how many consumables you buy/grind to sustain yourself (again, much like SotN). The main challenges you'll find will be self-imposed ones, which I personally don't have a problem with. Cheesy tactics can overpower most encounters in the game, but Chasm's combat wasn't tight enough for me to want to fight everything 100% fairly in the first place.

Despite the negative sentiment to a lot of this review I do still think Chasm is a good game worth playing. It's just hard to sing its praises beyond the quality of the art because it doesn't really define itself through anything new or interesting otherwise. If you want a game that does a lot of the same things Symphony of the Night did, you've got it right here. It plays decently, has lots of nice flavour fluff, and it looks and sounds great. But if you want something new, fresh, and genuinely fantastic to play, then there are much better options out there in the metroidvania genre right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062072478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1534025303}

If you're looking for a great metroidvania, you're in the right place.
9/10

Buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071721589', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1533138891}
review:
Chasm isn't exactly a terrible game. And even though there's things to like, I find myself, in my head, pretty much counter pointing every pro I can think for this game with even bigger cons. 

The major issue and question, though, is: Was it worth the wait? Honestly, no, it wasn't.

This game took 5 years since being Kickstarted. Not inherently an issue in of itself, but the thing that stings is that they clearly spent most of this time "perfecting" random generation in level design, which is honestly a completely wasted gimmick.

This game all in all is a bog standard Metroidvania. It lasts for anywhere from 10-15 hours. Having random level design is pointless because there's just no use for it for 90% of people. This is a one and done game. I will never see the reward for such a gimmick, and likely not many others will either. And the randomization isn't even all that great. The progression stays the same. You'll face the same bulwarks and item acquirements. It's like changing the furniture in a room. It's just not all that interesting or meaningful.

Time should have been better spent on the mechanics elsewhere. Item and RPG mechanics are slight. And dear o lord the backtracking. The fact that the devs think a one time warp scroll for 500 G is acceptable just shows the lack of thought put into this as a whole.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001183911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1533399417}
review:
While the game is quite good looking and the animations are really smooth, the gameplay is so stiff and sluggish that it really bogs it down, there's so many questionable design descisions here, like why is gold so scarce? Why do most of the shopkeepers have such an actual limited inventory of items that can be sold out? Why can you not restore MP when resting at savepoints? 
For a game that's been such a long time coming I'm sad to see it turn out as mediocre as this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022792180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1117, 'last_played': 1533245050}
review:
I only recommend the game because i did have fun playing it but it's just not worth the 15 bucks wait until it is like 5 bucks.
Super mediocre game in all aspects, you really feel like that game was meant to release in 2014.

It's a 10-12 hour game, depends if you do bosses without getting hit.

[h1] Negatives	[/h1]
[list]
   [*]Combat is the most basic stuff you can imagine, fighting enemies boils all down to dodge their attacks get some hits in then repeat until the enemy is dead.
    [*]For all the weapons you get there are only a few animations (some have a different colour), for me that is a missed opportunity that you really only have 4 animation types for all weapons.
   [*]Magic is whatever is only used 2 out of 5 or 6 because they are just that much better (maybe there are some builds that use the other ones)

   [*]The backtracking is annoying and most of the time useless, it's not fun to just run through corridors of meaningless monsters to just find something that you don't even need. 
   [*]The jumping mechanics are sometimes weird.
   [*]The world most of the time doesn't feel dynamic or fluent because you just have a corridor where you meet 1 monster.
   [*]The combat is really not that fun, as said it's more dodging then make a few attacks.


[h1] Positives [/h1]

  [*] Nice artstyle
  [*] music is ok
  [*] if you try to kill all the bosses without getting hit you have a challenge (except the last boss because fuck that path to him, also he is the only one that felt like a hard fight)


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
 That was my first 2D metroidvania and i did enjoy playing it most of the time but there are so many things that are just OK
The game is really just ok, a bit overprized for what you are getting since i don't think it has any replay value if you don't try to speedrun it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003605473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 96, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1712346021}
review:
This is a MetroidVania game, and it's hard.  Other than it's difficulty, I have no idea why people seem to dislike this.  Sure, the story is minimal, so far, but it doesn't have to be an epic every time - I'm more than intrigued by the basic premise.

To be fair, I got it WAY cheap on sale and I didn't Kickstart it.  It sounds like it went through some Development Hell, looking down below.

Still, if you just want a hard (and that's on Normal!) MetVan game, I'd easily recommend this.

Notes:
- I am only about 25% of the way through the game on Normal difficulty.  It's hard.  Not like Darkest Dungeon or Dark Souls or anything, but it's hard.  Expect to die a lot.
- The procedural generation is an interesting idea, even if it's not something you REALLY need to have here.  It's not a roguelike, after all (though maybe a "roguelike" option for the REAL masochist...?).
- Upgrading your equipment (not counting spells) looks to be one of those "no longer a thing" things.  Methinks they should find a way to return that function to the game.
- Learning Scroll upgrades a random stat.  Idk if there's any "single stat" or "choose a stat" items, but...that'd be cool.  Also you can buy Learning Scrolls from the magic gypsy lady, but they're expensive.
- My first villager rescued was the magic gypsy lady.  Acquiring the Magic Molotov spell was very helpful in the early portions of the game.

~@~EDIT~@~

I forgot to mention this, but the music is beautiful, especially for the town.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157649124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1533332849}
review: This game is pretty ok. I don't think it is worth twenty dollars for as little content as there is. There is replay value due to the procedurally generated maps, however that only really effects the placement of key areas. The hit boxes for pretty much everything are a bit wonky. The controls are not great. They often don't register correctly and can cause some huge head aches. This was also another problem I had with it was that on normal there is little to no real challenge beyond the controls. The story is ok, I guess. It's nothing too special. I also wish there was an sort of customization. Even the different armor you equip doesn't show up. The only item that shows up is your weapon. Despite all of these the exploration and puzzle solving are actually very fun. trying to find the answer to puzzles hidden within the different areas with your only real clues being what was written in journals is an absoulte joy. I like that it has mechanics that have you going back to previous areas. I would recommend this game if it is on sale and or if it has a massive update to address the issues it the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993640121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1533237643}
review:
A really beautiful game, definitely love the sprites and environments.  Movement and controls feel great and very responsive, and while a few jumps were annoyingly tight, the platforming was fun.

Unfortunately, however, combat was just a huge turn off.  As so many others have said, it just feels clunky and awkward the way you're locked into a ground attack unable to cancel by jumping or using the back dash. Your attacks do little damage and also lack hitstun, so you're completely open to attacks while stuck in these long attack animations, and most of the enemies I encountered that don't just ignore you or attack from range do so by rushing at you.  You have to adopt a pattern of baiting an attack, jumping in for one hit, avoiding the next attack, repeat.  Add to that your low total health, the damage enemies do, and the scarcity of recovery items, and combat quickly became a chore I did my best to avoid entirely.

I get that the idea is for you to learn enemy patterns and time your attacks, and I can understand that the devs wanted to make the game challenging, but maybe advertising as being inspired by hack n slash dungeon crawlers isn't the best thing to do when you have a combat system like this.

I've seen several reviews that mention something along the lines of "if you liked SotN" or "if you love Igavanias" that this is the game for you, but as a long time veteran of the genre, who still loves and replays several of those titles to this day, I don't know that I would say the same.

My gripes with the combat aside, I do think the game is worth checking out since those things might not bother another player as much, if at all, although I do feel that for the price tag there are better options out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156142503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1533394165}
review:
Chasm has it's ups and downs. It's not a perfect game, by any means. Just gonna do a list of pros and cons, and talk about things I like and didn't like.

Pros:
-The core of the game is fun. Platforming, combat, everything feels very precise and methodical, and it feels good to get good at it.
-A perfect difficulty. Not too hard, not too easy.
-Tight controls. I rarely feel like my character didn't move the way I wanted.
-Loot and RPG mechanics
-Reminds me of Symphony of the Night
-Boss designs are fun
-Enemies are varied and all act very differently.
-Art is pretty great

Cons: 
-Procedural generation. It feels out of place here. Why did it have to be generated? To try to drum up replay value? If you make a really good game, the replay value will be there. Just look at Symphony of the Night, still being replayed to this day.
-In some ways, the combat is very annoying. Unlike SOTN, when you attack, you are locked in that animation a bit longer than you think you would be. You've swung your weapon, done the damage, but it essentially gives the enemy enough time to smack you. So, you can't hit them until you wait for them to miss you first. This turns into a game of running towards them, baiting out an attack, and then swinging, and then repeating that process until they die. For a game like Dark Souls, this style of patient methodical combat makes sense, but in a 2D RPG platformer? Not as much, and sometimes it's quite irksome, especially with my next point.
-The backtracking. It's worse in this game than any metroidvania I've played. Get ready for hours and hours of backtracking through the same levels because you got a new powerup and missed this one area back on level 1. I know SOTN (my main comparison) had some too, but it didn't seem to take nearly as long as it does in this game. I have 6 hours in the game, and I beat the second boss, and the rest of my time has been spent backtracking and running around.
-It's pretty fucking cryptic sometimes. Now, don't get me wrong, I like games that don't hold my hand. But some stuff is just plain confusing. For instance, I backtracked for about an hour to go to an area that was extremely difficult for my level. I made it through, but all I got was a hat. A bird hat. A level 1 bird hat. I have no idea what it does. It summons a bird if I wear it, but the bird does nothing. So, I went to an altar that needed a feather, assuming I needed the Bird hat. It did nothing. So, I wasted around 2 hours achieving nothing but confusion.
-Really annoying enemy placement. See, the AI in this game can be kind of douchey. As soon as they notice you, most will just shuffle towards you as close as they can, and try to attack you repeatedly. Unfortunately, this can happen if you're on a seperate platform. They'll go to the edge of the other platform, and just swing at you repeatedly. So, your options become A. Spam magic at them until they die, using up a chunk of precious mana. or B. Jump and take a hit. It feels really bad, since you didn't do anything wrong as a player. The enemy was just on the tiny platform you need to jump on. And what's worse is some of these enemies have projectiles, and will just shoot you, making jumping over near impossible without taking a bunch of damage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036447031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1649028570}
review:
7/10
Only played through once so far, so I'm not sure about the seeding or randomness.
Played using xbox360 controller. Pretty smooth controls using always jump attacks.

It was fun for the ~11 hours it took me to do one full playthrough. I was very impressed by the art style, the smoothness of the platforming and the combat, and the joy of exploration and discovery. The pacing of upgrades is satisfying and leveling up through experience feels like a reward and never like a grind.

My criticism lies in the illusion of variety. There are swords, clubs, whips, knives, punches, a spear, etc for weapon types, but I mostly stuck to "club" swinging weapons because of their large hitbox area. Using only jump attacks negates the downside of their slow attack rate.

The magic attacks I never really used. It was just easier to hit things with my unlimited club than to use limited ammo magic attacks that dealt less damage.

It was also a little disappointing to find so much useless equipment. Often the best part of finding a piece of armor is that it sells really well so I could buy more healing potions.

Not a "must play" but if you're bored or if it's on sale, then it's not a bad choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014887968', 'num_games_owned': 482, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1535336706}
review:
I honestly can't understand all the bad reviews.  I'm absolutely loving every minute I spend in this game.  At the time of this writing, I'm 10 hours in and I'm only on the 3rd major area (of six or eight?)  I've been taking it slow and farming enemies for rare drops, which is extremely enjoyable for me.
Peoples' primary complaint is the combat and "same-y" looking rooms.  Well, the combat in the first area *was* a little weak, but as soon as I got to the second major area, the combat has been just fine.  It's an old-school style metroidvania with old-school style gameplay and there's absolutely nothing wrong with that.  As for the same-y looking rooms?  Each of the areas is pretty huge, but there are a variety of different areas.  
If you have played any dungeon crawlers then that is what this game feels like to me:  a metroidvania *dungeon crawler* with RPG elements.  It's a smaller package than something like Hollow Knight.  That's fine by me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062778687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1676166831}
review:
I rarely if ever write reviews, but i felt i should here. I've played many metroidvanias, from super met to hollow knight, and despite the mixed reviews, this is a good game. 

the control style that people are complaining about is basically an intentional throwback to SOTN, not because of lazy programming or bad design. the random generated levels arent bad at all, either-0- the game is somply old school style, with limited ways you can attack and move around. if you hate old school style controls, give it a pass. 

But for those of us who enjoyed SOTN a lot, this combat style is extremely satisfying. Give it a chance. It's weird and jumpy but so fun.
It befuddles me that people are being so harsh to a clearly old-school style game by raging at the almost exact duplicate of SOTN controls. Also, although generating the environment differently every time has its drawbacks, it forces each player to find thier own way and renders most of the internet hive mind guides useless, which essentially forces players to experience it as gamers did before guides on the internet. To me thats 100% worth any repetitive environments. and they really arent that bad.  

Bottom line: This game is a love letter to SOTN set in a beautiful medieval world. Learning the now-unique(in the modern era of vanias) control scheme is just as fun as exploring the not-too obviously (but sometimes a bit) proceedurally generated world. If you loved SOTN, youll enjoy this. If not, you may like it anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042106251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1541984567}
review:
I'm enjoying it so far.

TL;DR
Music: It's alright, decent. Sound in general is also pretty standard/good.

Graphics: This is my kind of style, I love pixel art and I think the animation is well executed.

Gameplay: Overall, I really enjoy it, as a fan of pretty much any Igavania title, it gives the right vibes. It has a little La Mulana mixed in, which I don't mind.

Setting: I like the atmosphere. Areas get a little same-y.

Level design: I think the level design is fine. I read some people find it "uninspired", but I don't mind them. Maybe I got lucky with the procedural seed. There are some okay trap rooms and platforming, but I found them unfrustrating. It might be worth mentioning I'm playing with a keyboard.

Controls: I think the controls suffer a bit, but I'm getting used to them and find them tolerable, if clunky. The lack of animation cancels are a moderate annoyance, which I will now rant about.

Rant:

One of the best parts of SotN's controls was how responsive they are. Chasm really locks you into animations, you're committed to attacks in particular, and their cooldowns don't feel good.

If there's anything I'd like to see in an update, it's these:
- Ability to backdash out of a swing recovery. Some animation canceling for movement, please. It feels terrible how rooted you are.
- Ability to grab ledges in spite of an air attack. Again, animation canceling. Let ledge grabs and other movement tech take priority over the damn attack animation, it feels awful.

All said, I'd still recommend this game.

I'll revisit this review as I make a bit more progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069241055', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1533099456}
review:
After several years in development, I expected a bit more out of this game. Enemies missing recoil of any kind, NO AI on the trolls at all, questionable platforming areas, scarce savepoints (combined with randomly grueling enemy spawns), repetetive gameplay and enemy attack sets.. There are just much better games on the market, since this spent its time (maybe a bit too long) in development. This missed the mark, but only just barely. It could have been good without the strange game design choices. large humanoids with weapons should just ignore the player character - most of the time i played I was only ever getting hit when the enemies frustratingly walked into me- and then just continued on their minimal path.

I just was really hoping for more. Something with gameplay polish to match the beautiful design. This feels untested and not quite meeting it's potential. I hope they fix the AI and combat. I hope they add more items/magic.
I'll check back in to see if updates come through and maybe then I'll give it another try - but 45 minutes in I just was frustrated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965843676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1533358175}
review:
Chasm is a game that I have followed through its many years of development. I'm a sucker for pixel art and Metroidvania-style games. I wasn't aware of the procedural aspects of the game until fairly close to release, however, that is a non-issue as far as I am concerned. 

On the whole, Chasm is extremely mediocre. Spell variety is limited. Exploration is a chore. Combat is tedious and boring. If Chasm had come out 5 years ago, it still would've been an underwhelming experience. The charming art style and presentation isn't enough to cover up incredibly dated gameplay. I can't think of a single thing that Chasm does that hasn't already been done, and been done better. With recent offerings such as Hollow Knight, it seems odd that an extremely formulaic, unoriginal and monotonous game took so long to finish. 

The story presented is extremely confined. Color palettes swap occasionally, but the game takes place solely in samey-looking tunnels. Combat is an exercise in tedium - wait for an enemy to finish it's telegraphed attack, jump in and attack, then retreat, rinse and repeat. There is no character development to speak of. Backtracking is an absolute chore and every single new power requires you to traipse through dozens of samey-looking rooms to find the one room that is now accessible with your new power.

While the game has different seeds to make use of the procedural world generation, I just don't see the point. Rearranging the samey halls filled with the same braindead enemies to look in samey-looking rooms in different locations to find the items to move forward sounds less like fun and more like busywork. If the game had been a single, unique world [i][b]or[/b][/i] completely procedural, the game may have been a little bit better.

All in all, extremely disappointing. Fan of the genre or not, your first hour is identical to your 8th hour. Skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004569928', 'num_games_owned': 963, 'num_reviews': 282, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1533248885}
review: Chasm is beautiful. The animation and pixel art are some of the best I've ever seen. The story is well told. The combat is great, with varied enemies and chunky hits and damage numbers. As for the core gameplay though, Chasm is good, almost great. Unfortunately, the design gets bogged down by the procedural generation. Rooms will repeat, and overall the world just doesn't have that designed, thought out feel to it. It's fine as it is, but it's just not great. In my instance, it was fun to explore initially, but then when it came to backtracking it was a massive drag as the map did not facilitate that well, especially in the end-game. To get to some areas I'd have to fast travel to a spot and then just walk for what felt like ages, and then you had to have spent a large amount of money to be able to fast-travel back to the hub if you didn't want to trek it all the way back. That said, I still feel that it's a good Metroidvania that's definitely worth the price, and I'm really excited to see what this studio does next now that Chasm is finally done. Hopefully I won't have ~5 years to build up my expectations for the next one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142139249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1533250324}
