review: I was really hoping for something more Roguelike, instead of Metroidvania. Metroidvania would have been fine, but then it doesn't really do that well. Combat feels off with weird decisions made regarding weapons. Like you can swing your sword horizontally, or at a slight downward angle that doesn't seem to hit anything that a regular attack would. No overhead swing, so bats and other fliers are hella annoying. You gain levels, but they just increase your numbers without having a significant impact on the game. Lots of backtracking, mobs respawn after leaving the room, allowing you to grind XP if you are boring. Personally, I am getting more enjoyment out of Dead Cells, Vagante and Wazhack, so I'll go back to them. If you really want to play another Metroidvania then this will probably get you by.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998051734', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1533126179}
review:
[h1]The Short Version[/h1]
A decently good, if short Metroidvania that potentially offers more replay value but lacks some polish in areas. If you like this genre and don't mind ignoring some blemishes you could definitely do worse.

[h1]The Long Version[/h1]
Do not go into Chasm expecting a modern day Symphony of the Night or even anything close to the quality of modern Metroidvania classics like Axion Verge or Hollow Knight. Chasm is definitely not playing in the big leagues with those titles. Overall Chasm is still a fine game with some quality presentation and the procedurally generated aspect of it's dungeons that give the game some additional replay. 

This replay value may be hindered though by the fact that it's not an exceptionally long game, nor terribly hard to accomplish everything in your first playthrough. In just over 7 hours I 100%'ed the game and began playing on Hard mode but found it to be a less than pleasurable experience. 

Production value is well done on both visual and audio fronts but likely won't be something anyone remembers years from now. The music runs on a constant loop for each area and given how backtrack heavy Chasm is the tunes make begin to wear on the player's patience.

The biggest negative to the game is the sluggish controls; especially in combat. In particular the backward dash button might as well be unbound for how worthless it is in the current version since it cannot animation cancel from an attack but jumping away can on most weapons. Weapon and spell balance leaves a bit to be desired as well with most spells costing more they further down the purchase list they are with no really good reason. For instance the Magic Shield spell (which is actually a defense field of whirling diamonds) costs 10 mana to cast and mana does not regenerate naturally.  Meanwhile a lv3 upgraded Magic Knife spell throws a spread of daggers across the screen for 1 mana and is hands down the best spell in the game for all occasions.

[h1]The Final Verdict[/h1]
Chasm is worth your time if you enjoy the Metroidvania genre and need a fix. Just go in with realistic expectations and you should be solid. 

Solid 6/10: Above average, but just barely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075026050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1533925153}

Items also do nothing to the visual aspect of the character as well.  Where did all of the development time go into? no one knows.

review:
I really wanted to like this. But heres why i don't rate it. This game has nothing new, other then seeded maps. It is basically a Castlevania clone but not as good. Throwing axes are the same, potion the same, sword swings the same, dodge is the same, pet is a bird not a bat (the same). I feel like I am playing a re skinned game. 

Its just a cash grab imo, if these guys dreamnt this up they are unoriginal. Dissapointed!!!! And definetely not worth the price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065109208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1533119333}
review:
The bad:

Short lived game. Lack of save points discourages extended exploring. Furthermore, potions are difficult to come by because they are tied to gold which is difficult to obtain. Slow character movement makes back tracking feel like a chore (I am aware of Speed Potions, but you can only buy them using gold.)

Uninteresting enemy designs, and some enemies are frustrating to fight i.e. Skeleton Knights in tight corridors. It keeps blocking and its difficult to get a hit on them.

Soundtrack and story are passable. 

Certain spots which should have a save room nearby do not have them (see below.)

The good:

Getting a equipment item from a enemy was exciting, the art is fantastic and the controls are responsive and tight.

Improvements that can be made:

Boss rush mode, increases replay-ability.

Place a safe spot just before the Final Boss and Arena.

Have a artifact which gives super-speed instead of the potion.

A secret boss in hard mode would be nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970333126', 'num_games_owned': 723, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1533114464}
review:
It looked really promising with a lot of potential, but there are a some things that will annoy you.
The [b]combat[/b]: Even though there is quite a nice variety of weapons, anything that isn¬¥t a sword or a whip isn¬¥t really viable. With fast, shoirt ranged weapons like daggers, you¬¥ll get face-checked constantly and take a lot of unneccessary damage. One-handed clubs are similar to swords, but with an extra delay at the end of each swing which doesn¬¥t justify the little extra damage they deal over swords. Two-handed weapons are so slow that you get punished for just using them.
Overall, the combat doesn¬¥t feel fluid at all.

The [b]progression[/b]: I played my fare share of metroidvanias, but I¬¥ve never gotten stuck so many times as in Chasm. For example: One riddle requires you to memorize certain details on mural painting scattered throughout an area. The first time you see these paintings, you most likely won¬¥t pay much attention to them, until a page from a book tells you, that you need these for a three-digit combination. Now have fun remembering where these rooms even were...
Probably half of my playtime was me wandering aimlessly around the world looking for something that I might have missed.

review:
A very high quality castlevania-esk game; be warned, this means that some of the clunk of the old school have made their way into this one. Can still highly recommend of course, solid adventure.

Negative reviews seem to be people expecting something that they didn't get. I've been noticing a lot rather good games getting what is essentially review bombed by fickle folk. It really is a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005291794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1533099162}
review: Weapon reach is small, and as far as I got you are completely reliant on RNG for better weapon types and upgrades. Space between saves feels too long, and often I would die just before next save location and have to spend the next 10 minutes replaying exactly what I just did. After a point, you can't go back to town as far as I could tell, and I had no warning before getting to that point. Combat is very hit - dodge - hit - dodge - hit for each enemy, and for the ones with larger health pools, gets a bit redundant. First boss was pretty fun, so maybe there is a good game if you are willing to wade in deep enough, but If there is, it should be from the start.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986818569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1533100091}
review:
If this game had come out 5 years ago, it would be a classic by now. All that extra development time does not really show in the finished product, though, and Chasm is easily outclassed by more recent games in the genre. 

It's a real shame, as I have been waiting eagerly for this game for a really, really long time. 

The combat is clunky and poorly thought out. Platforming ranges from annoying to frustrating. Exploration is monotonous and tedious due to most hallways being enemy tubes that take you to either another enemy tube or one of the few rooms with verticality. Save points and shortcuts are about as common as boss fights, and if you end up low on health after 30 minutes of exploration without a potion, you better hope you don't die backtracking or kill mobs until you level up or they drop food.  The story is not particularly noteworthy and feels like it was added because video games should have a story.

The worst part is that it's not terrible. It's just not good. Each of the above flaws just amplifies all the others until the game is just not fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004661129', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1533111181}
review:
Alas, I have finally beated the game and can now review my playthrough.

The game is not great. 

It is good.

If you have been spoiled by Ori of the Blind Forest or Hallow Knight, chances are, you may be disappointed.

Chasm takes from Metroid and Castlevania: SOTN but feels more inspired than rather than grown upon.

As I played through the game, I often was telling myself that this game can be so much more.

The gameplay can be clunky and I believe that's being held back by its progression system that by the time you finally reach the end of the game, your character has developed enough to improve upon the gameplay slightly.

As someone said, this is a Castlevania SOTN Lite.

And if anyone is wondering, it seems like an average playthrough is about 10 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032465049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1533063859}
review:
I've Bought Chasm when it was still gathering support on kickstarter, and I've been waiting Ever since for it, here is my review of it:

Pro's:
- Game rich story keeps the game world together pretty well.
- The music is beautiful.
- The Game has beautiful pixel art in the environment, each zone is unique in some way.
- Chasm combat is divided into 2  main branches, Melee Weapons which will require different use and gameplay.
    And of course, Magic - which works like it did in Castlevania - you gain mana by collecting mana orbs and cast spells 
    based on your mana pool.

Con's:

- Game art as much as it is beautiful in environment, it seems to me like enemies were not matched up to par with the environment quality.
- Game Story is not gameplay though, Game platforming consists of nearly Pixel-perfect precision required to jump across platforms.
- Combat mechanic is recycled through mobs - Mainly it will consist of 3 steps ( Baiting Attack -> Dodging -> Attacking while enemy recharges).
- Alot of skills are counter intuitive, and you will find yourself struggling
- Even though there is leveling system, you posses no power of actually adjusting your build.
- The Game advertises for Metroidvania, however it does not seem like pure one, if anything this is more Rogue-Like.
- Big Nono for this kind of game is that sometimes if you wish to progress with tasks you might find yourself Farming mobs (For example for one quest, [spoiler] for vension or in general for mobs to level up [/spoiler])
- The game lenght isn't anything special, it requires alot of backtracking which extends the gameplay.
- In Lategame once you upgrade your spells you will find yourself suddenly switch to the magic oriented spells, as each enemies dont posses different gimmicks to themselves, [spoiler]you  will most likely use highly upgraded knife throw which still costs 1 mana and does as much damage if not more than your highest melee weapon - but at safe distance[/spoiler]).


In short; I Feel like the game isn't what it was hyped to be, if the game play was done well it would be a great game to enjoy, however there is alot of balancing issues and recycling which is blatantly obvious.

If I were to recommend something that would be - wait for fixes if they will come, and wait for sale for this game, in its current form its not worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025055510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 852, 'last_played': 1533105782}
review:
I'll open this with I really want to recommend this game and wish there was a thumb-to-the-side option. This review was written playing against versions 1.01 to 1.02c. I don't totally recommend it right now, but I'll check in in the future and hopefully update my review then!

---

The art is wonderful, I enjoy the areas and the design and I keep coming back to the game because I'll be damned if I don't beat it after all the frustration! I've reached the final area and have my thoughts/opinions pretty well collected.

This game _will_ punish you if you're not precise. Combine that with almost-but-not-quite platforming mechanics and you have a pretty frustrating experience. But when it's fun, it's _fun_. I've really enjoyed myself playing this game. It's posed a good challenge, even though sometimes it feels like I just got lucky enough to hit certain platforms, thanking God I don't have to unlock that chest again.

So on to specifics:

- Art: killer job. Love love love this.

- Music: Also good, no complaints here.

- Weapons: the range of attack on most weapons is way to short for my preference. Most of them (swords and clubs) are also only directly in front of you, so when attacking arial enemies, you often have to put yourself in range to get hit (which is really frustrating). Whips ended up being my favorite weapon because the hit box is slightly above your head and extends really far in front of you, often outside of the hit range of most enemies. The claymore is similar, but way too slow. Weapons are either powerful with short range or slow. Whips have great range and hits-per-second but are underpowered.

- Movement: Late-game platforming abilities need some tweaking. The wall-climb mechanic and parachute feel very rough. Many of my frustrations surround these two. Honestly, I would be super happy if they were removed from the game in their current state. You have to be super intentional about hitting the A button, otherwise you'll jump off a ledge when you don't intend to. I Also would have loved the double jump much earlier in the game. You don't get it until the 5th of 6 areas.

- Magic: Early game I tried a bunch of them and they were all pretty disappointing, except for the Magic Shield. It's _very_ handy and melts tougher enemies when buffed correctly. The Shuriken is thrown at an angle that feels useless (up and to the right at a 55 degree angle or something). The ax is literally thrown and hard to use against enemies that move (which is nearly all of them late game). The Boomerang is "ok." The Shield is great when powered up to level 3. It does great damage if you have the proper armor (25 for me at the moment).

- Health: I won't complain about this too much because that's part of the challenge of the game, but you definitely have to manage your health well. Horde those coins to purchase potions and pray enemies drop health items so you don't have to run across the map every so often to save and recharge your health.

- Map traversal: This is really annoying. Things are pretty far apart and it can be a pain to traverse the map to get where you need to go. Part of the problem is combat and having to be really precise and making sure you don't get hit. It gets _much_ easier when you've leveled up quite a bit and going back to areas meant for when you were lower level because you can one-hit most everything, but when you're exploring a new area and everything still takes 3-5 (or more hits) to take down and they hit just as hard, it makes getting through 4+ rooms quite challenging.

- Movement: I really wish the back dash was more usable, but the halt after swinging a weapon can be too long to get in and do what you need to do.

Developers: if you're reading this, you really have done a great job. I'm a Kickstarer backer and really believe in the project. I hope you hear this and find things you can tweak because I _super_ want to keep playing this game. The diversity of enemy types, maps, bosses, etc, have been great. There are just some annoyances that can be improved. Thanks for all your hard work!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067352416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1533851316}
review:
picked this  up a bit  on a whim ...  downloaded it, booted it up, and was shot in the face with full blown retrro  happiness.
As someone who grew up on the NES and the SNES i remember  all the ups downs and skills needed to  deal with overbearing situations where the controls arnt  "fluid" the odds are stacked against you, and everything just kinda wants to  kick you in the d**k repeatedly until you stop twitching , but you come out of it forged with skills  and reflexes todays "triple A" games cant compare to ... and thisfantastic little gem delivers that in all its heart wrenching gut punch glory, a Vania style game in essense but with originality so that it dosent really look like anyhting else but at the same time.... you still feel... familier, grueling bosses, simple controls that require you to use your head to dodge instead of just mashing a button, and a story that starts simple but turns deep before you realised what happened make this a game ill reccomend to anyone who asks , in short.. if youve never touched anything older then a PS3 or Xbox360 stay away from this game as your liable to break a controller, for the rest of us retro junkies :its the SNES game i didnt know i wanted

author: {'steamid': '76561198046314459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1583153059}
review:
Not finished the game as of yet, but so far I'm having a lot of fun and it breaks my heart to see the overall reviews sit at "Mixed". 

I went into the game knowing little to nothing about it and couldn't have been happier. A lot of people are going to underestimate just how retro the gameplay of this title is. Fighting enemies isn't a fast and slick affair, but more about remembering movement patterns and striking at the right moment than it is about reflexes. This gives it an almost arcadey feel for me, which is just perfect for what I was looking for. In this regard it is a lot closer to titles like Castle In The Darkness or Odallus than it is to Ori And The Blind Forest or Hollow Knight. And as much as I love those two, I prefer my gameplay a bit more on the classic side and Chasm provides. Plus in Chasm I never feel like I'm lost with dead ends everywhere, just like I felt when playing Castle In The Darkness, which I prefer over the "where the hell do I even go" of many other Metroidvanias.

The story is well written and a nice little mystery so far, but never gets in the way which is highly welcome. I don't expect a novel, but a platformer instead and don't want to sit through endless cutscenes, so I'm happy that what's there is  as good as it is, but also that it doesn't keep me from playing. 

Combined with a not too easy, not too hard (playing on Normal, with both Hard and Easy being available) challenge overall, and very nice platforming this is so far certainly one of my favourites this year.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988113155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1557334133}
review:
I wonder if the negative reviewers are playing a different game? I'm scratching my head, because Chasm is a pure Metroidvania, and a damn good one, better than most in the genre. It must be young vs old in the review section, because If you like older Metroidvanias, while it's not SotN 2, Chasm is the best around. I'm an older gamer, and I've played them all, and I really like the old school look and feel of this game. 

I have recently played Hollow Knight and I like Chasm much better. Hollow Knight bored the s*** outta me as it's focus is on exploration while offering scarce upgrades, one weapon, and non-existent level progression, a sin in a Metroidvania made post SotN. 

Controls in Chasm are tight, combat is simple fun that includes sub-weapons pulled right out of Castlevania, and loot is hard to come by, which makes finding it more exciting. I am playing on "Hard" and the game is providing a good challenge for me, not frustratingly hard, but not a cake-walk either. 

8/10 so far and more than worth the price of admission. Not a backer btw, but the game has been on my radar since I played a demo of it on a Game Stop's PS4 about 4 years ago. The full release has not disappointed me.

Keep in mind that about 90% percent of the negative reviews have played under an hour, as with most Metroidvanias, majority of the fun lies in the mid to late game, when you've unlocked more weapons, abilities, floors, etc...

author: {'steamid': '76561198067976167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1533522296}
review:
7.0 Hours in: Same, but I kind of start feeling the procedural level geneartions takes away a lof ot charm from the game. It lacks "soul" in that manner, I prefer a hand made map than procedural, or at least the way they're generated in this game. Everything else is ok though, combat is fun, items are ok, story is good, sounds are a bit weak and it seems there are missing sounds yet. Grahpics are top notch and music is good too!

3.4 non-stop hours into the game and I'm amazed of it. It's just fantastic, the combat is precise, enemies are varied, movement is responsive. Art direction is beautiful, the color palette is really colorful. Every sector has it's own personality thanks to the music an art assets.
The music is great, it ambients every sector well.
Sound effects could be more juicy/punchy few of them are weak or too soft IMO.
Too early to give a score but so far I'm enjoying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965551808', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1470, 'last_played': 1533285712}
review:
It's a pleasant little game. It has excellent pixel art, tight controls (I was using a wireless gamepad), and standard metroidvania fare. The beginning can feel a bit sparse, but I had a great time just speeding through the tunnels until my next big obstacle, whether it be environmental or combat. It has a gearing system where you can equip items you buy or find (main weapon, offhand item, armor slots, and accessory slots). There are tons of items in the game and a bestiary that records enemies you encounter after a certain number of kills. The game follows a new recruit on his first mission in pursuit of becoming a knight. He's tasked with getting a mining town back into operation. Hence, you have to dungeon dive. You search for people (whom unlock town features), kill enemies, collect gold, equipement, minerals, scrolls, and food, gain new abilities, and follow the story of an ancient tribe.

I'm looking forward to seeing this one through to the end. $20 might be a bit steep, but I think it's a charming game for $15. Either way, kudos to these new devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004096811', 'num_games_owned': 6461, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1594316482}
review:
CHASM is an incredible Metroidvania capturing everything that makes a good Metroidvania game. Especially the retro games that help create the sub genre we all know and love. On top of that the percedurally generated worlds make for a welcome feature so that when you come back to play the game a second time you can choose a different seed that you previously played before giving you a new experience, or play one of your friend's seeds. 

The combat is also pretty amazing. All the weapons and spells perform different from one another giving you a wide variety in style. Want to be more agile and have better control over your character with faster attacks? You can do that by choosing the right loadout. The many of items you find while playing really add to the feel of the game. Not counting once you get into the upgrading and crafting systems of the game or finding some of the artifacts.

The pixel art. OH MY GOSH! The pixel art is incredible! 

I have had the pleasure of playing the game over 2 years while it was being developed having gotten my copy of the game from the devs. It has been one hell of an adventure watching, experiencing the game grow. 

I do hope this game gets the attention it so very well deserves. It is very much worth a full price purchase. GET IT WHILE IT'S HOT (aka on Sale)!!!  (Full Review coming soon on TheDrastikMeasure.com)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038834385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1533093654}
review:
I usually really enjoy the Metroidvania style of game, but I can't recommend this one. Everything about it is slow and repetitive. Your attack animations are super slow, which means it takes forever to kill enemies. On top of this, the enemy attack patterns aren't interesting (some just walk left and right and sometimes bump into you), so there's no fun strategy to combat. The map is slow and repetitive too, with too many long rooms that make you fight one easy enemy at a time, then later make you backtrack through the same easy enemies.

Also, they advertise that the game is procedurally generated, but I don't see why that's a desirable thing for a Metroidvania. I was only planning to play it once anyways. It's not like a roguelike where you play through the game over and over again and the new layout actually means something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024997189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1647903789}
review:
Sluggish gameplay & overly predictable and unresponsive enemies. What a let down. I was really excited for this game to come out as it is almost exactly like a game I played as a child.

Update:
After completing the game I decided to update my review. Chasm has a lot going for it; #1 is absolutely beautiful graphics. Wow. Incredible. It's also a fun metrovania-style game with some classic mechanics and powerups. But, the first few hours of gameplay are extremely slow. Everything is unessisarily far away and enemys seems blind and unresponsive. You can literally walk around them, they move from point a to point b and do not interact with you at all. Halfway through the game you're tasked with retracing all of your previous paths and struggle to remember what small thing you noticed in what small room. A few time I just gave up since it was too annoying to retrace my steps and I busted out a walkthrough (I know, lame). The music is horrendous. Turn it off before it makes you insane. So. Fucking. Repetitive. The difficulty settings are out of wack. Hard is almost impossible, especially with how far things are apart. And easy is essentially invincibility. The enemy's never drop anything good. I get more cash breaking lanterns (which turns into one of the most tedious and some-what enjoyable parts of this game after a few hours). All-in-all, if you're really into games like this, I would recommend it. But in general, wait for a deep discount.

TLDR;
If you're really into Metrovania-style games this is a great addition to your library. If not, skip it until it's at a deep, deep discount. Play on easy, turn off the music and use a walkthrough to enjoy the beautiful graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063326440', 'num_games_owned': 1904, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1546658821}
review:
This is an amazing game that I have been enjoying thoroughly. From the art to the gameplay itself. It's a great homage to Castlevania with its own setting and art style, and thankfully, unlike 90% of Metroidvanias on steam, it leans closer to the vania part rather than the metroid part. Equipment, loot drops, leveling up, etc. It's all stuff that I've wanted from a metroidvania game for so long. 

As for the procedural generation, I was worried about it beforehand, but my experience in game has assuaged my fears. The world does feel deliberate, and I'm enthralled by the numerous areas.

Highly reccomended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012125853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1533507054}
review:
Seed generated metroid-vania that doesn't feel generated. If that sounds like something you'd want to play this is the game for you. 

Chasm is a great looking, tight feeling action RPG in the vain of Symphony of the Night. All the mainstays are here: backdash, after images while running slow, hats that summon familiars, candelabra smashing. You can fairly early on (at least in my first run) get the option to buy "spells" which are without a doubt weapons close to our hearts - if you know what I mean. The game scratches every Symphony itch!

While I wholeheartedly recommend the game it does indeed have a few flaws. The backdash does not cancel your attack making it somewhat useless. Monsters can boil down to two groups: minding their own business and beeline to you the moment they see you. Beware snakes! Magic energy can take its sweet time getting to you and if you switch rooms any uncollected magic chasing you just dissapears. 

In 5 hours of gameplay this is honestly all I can recall being wrong with the game. Everything else is tight, well thought out and just feels good. If you loved Symphony, if you want an action RPG or if you just want a good looking retro game this is the game you are looking for!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041320369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1533781045}
review:
Disclaimer: I recieved this game as a gift from my cousin, but he paid for it. Also, I have not played a lot of this game, but I feel like I know where it is going. 

I like the art, music, and general aesthetic of the movement animations. I do however think the font is a little annoying to read. But the real problem as many people have said is the pace of combat. The backdash has little use because you have to wait until the any animation is done before you can use it and it has a start up, so you are better off jumping away from your enemies. Some people think it is okay to have slow swinging animations because it promotes planning out your attack. I think that is a poor excuse for clunky controls. I think the aerial mobility and the general movement is very fluid, but the attack animations/ dash animations just lock you into animations for too long. Whenever I am running around and only need 1 hit to kill enemies, the game is genuinly fun and fluid, but reaching an enemy that takes more than one hit feels like a chore. I wouldn't mind if the animations are shorter (which makes it easier for all skill levels) or if there are animation cancels that are useful (better for more skilled players. But as it stands, it feels very clunky. Some people say that this game doesn't have to be like SotN and I agree. I also enjoy old NES platformers, but this game was clearly designed with more fluid controls in mind with how the characters move and it just feels short of that when in combat. All it really needs is for the ability to interupt long animations or to just in general have shorter animations. The landing cancel is nice, but there needs to be more options.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059604523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1573285534}
review:
Well, this was a let down for me. Two big issues that really stand out thus far.
1. 90% of enemies have no sort of recoil, so you are trying to sneak your short range weapon just close enough to hit without getting walked into
2. Your ground attack is useless, you will spend 100% of your time air attacking if you want to swing with half the speed and thus not get hit.

Minor grievances include, unimaginative magic system, I get that you want to pay homage to Castlevania, but everyone else has already done it, add something new.

I have counted 9 or 10 enemies with the same dash forward overhand swing attack, why waste the sprites, should have just recolored the same enemy.

In general the visuals are okay for me, not super inspired, but they're fine. The music is rather lackluster as well, I think the Catacombs is the only track I really got into, and its still quite spartan.

Hard mode is definitely challenging, but I'd rather it be for the right reasons, I'm fine with dying in a handful of hits if I have tools to timed dodge effectively, or at least interrupt the opponent. A dodge roll of some sort would be vastly more intuitive than the slide back manuever, which is vestigial in most cases.

I'll probably slog my way through to the ending since I've invested several hours, but I don't see myself having any incentive to replay.

One final comment, please try to think of something more exciting for a boss to drop other than +3 max health. After killing seven bosses at this point, that doesn't even add up to one more hit worth of health.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960369063', 'num_games_owned': 770, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1460, 'last_played': 1533373383}
review:
Chasm is a solid metroidvania with charming and well-animated art and a unique map-generation gimmick, but broadly uninspired mechanics.

Its unique claim to fame is procedural map generation that unless you purposefully use the same seed value, ensures everyone will get a unique layout with different enemies, loot, etc.  While this sounds very interesting in theory, in practice the room pieces that are used to build the levels are going to feel broadly similar even when remixed somewhat, mostly due to identical ability progression.  It is an interesting novelty that feels like it has much more potential than the game makes use of currently.

The core of the game is very much inspired by Igarashi's Castlevanias, Symphony in particular.  It nails certain aspects lacking in other titles that try to emulate those games, such as weapon and item variety.  Control responsiveness is somewhat low due to a tendency to lock the player into animations and limited jump and backdash canceling, but once the timing is adjusted to, feels solid.

Ultimately, I enjoyed my time with Chasm.  It has some minor flaws, but the overall experience is still satisfying and worth your time if you are a fan of the genre.  Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147432127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1533089344}
review: This game is a huge disappointment and perhaps a scam for me. I bought it because it was supposed to be procedural generated. I have play one hour and I have asked to my wife to try it in a new play. She did and nothing had changed... The same rooms, the same stupids monsters who will not attack you when you will hit it, ... no changes, no differences, no procedural generated dungeon. After that I read the first review (made by IGN) the game will become procedural when you will completely finish it and only after that... What a scam!!! If you seek for a good metroidvania play "Hollow Knight" or wait for "Bloodstained", if you seek for a good rogue like play rogue legacy but not this shit called "Chasm".

review: Quick little review after about 2 hours. I just beat the second boss. I'm not very far, and this isn't a very developed opinion. This looks like another game designed for speed runs but this time its random speed runs. As a metroidvania so far though its pretty fun. I'm just not sure where all the cool stuff to do is. So far magic seems pretty bad and so do most weapons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017603563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1533191280}
review:
+ Beautiful 8 bit graphics
+ Well composed soundtrack

- Backtrack heavy. Most of the times you get to explore 6 new rooms till you get the next tool to proceed in the next area or just end up with gear that is weaker then the stuff you can find in the area you backtracked from.
- Terrible drop chances. You get a bunch of quests that ask you to kill a certain enemie. Devs boasted about a playtime of 6-10h and with me spending 50min on getting 4 items for a single quest makes that statement more then just ridiculous
- Walljump controls combined with the parachute are bad
- Many rooms have enemie & trap placements that lead to unavoidable damage.
- Bare-bones combat, later on with frustrating enemies that have a 50% block chance or a 100% block chance against your abilities. 

I feel like Bit Kid Inc. hung themself up on the promise of a procedural generated expierence that should increase replayability but there's no real reason to play it a second time. The goal of "get tool A to proceed in area A to get tool B to get to area B to get tool C to return to area A to get tool X to proceed in area B" won't change and not even a shift of map structure or room will overcome the problem that is the unrewarding backtracking in Chasm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004093168', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1533079242}
review:
Hard to say something that has not been said. To add they could pretty much scrap the leveling mechanic, unless you do some ungoldy amount of grind you will be in the level x floor that the developers want or "balanced" for, the mobs in any new area give especifics amount of xp to abruptly stop leveling and you progress pretty much trying as hard as you can to avoid the unrewarding combat and get to the next save point/item/POI. 

I don't know if this has something to do with the random factor but the item spawns are way to rare for a metroidvania game, i'm in the second floor of the second area of the game and still only have 2 weapons with a very unrewarding fighting style (A: stay close and do "high" damge B:stay a little distant but to low damage).

I followed this game for years and this just add up in the dissapointment, maybe it needed a little more time in the oven.

review: Chasm is a wonderful game with familiar Castlevania-game-play influences and a unique flare that sets itself apart. The game does a wonderful job of making you interested in the world right from the begining by giving you dribs and drabs of the lore, but doesn't drown you in it. If you enjoyed games like Castlevania: Syphony of the night, and Wonderers from the Ys III, you'll thoroughly enjoy this game. Others will find this game's charm inviting and enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029166602', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1230, 'last_played': 1534666955}
review:
Classic Metroidvania gameplay heavily inspired by Symphony of the Night and the Metroid series.

This is a game that rolls a seed at the beginning and then you keep that seed the entire game. Much like a Randomizer. This is not a roguelike in that every time you die it re-randomizes everything. This game is a metroidvania with items and backtracking and fun and exploration. Not just murder murder murder fast fast forward forward. it is chill and fun.

Feels very much like I'm playing an SNES version of Symphony of the Night w/ the ability to mix the layouts up every time I want to play again. 

This review is more in response to the negative reviews of people who haven't progressed past the first zone, because I feel sorry for anyone who reads those less than one hour of playtime reviews and doesn't pick up the game because it's a treasure.

Yes, the first enemies in the game don't have attack animations. This is called a difficulty curve. So new players can learn how to many from easy enemies to harder enemies over a period of time. The first enemies in SOTN were zombies that surprise surprise, didn't have any attack animation. Oh, what's that? The most highly regarded metroidvania in the world has enemies with no attack animation. My word! 

The same goes for the first boss having easy to read tells / not a lot of variety. This again, is just called difficulty curve. Pretty standard or used to be. Not every game needs to focus around murdering the player horribly at every opportunity.

If you want classic metroidvania action in a beautiful retro art style with classy sound and tunes. Grab Chasm. Play game. have fun.

If you want to more roguelike permadeath lots of resets and  progression walls, this is not the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972346426', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1533082919}
review:
I just didn't have fun here. After dying repeatedly in the second area for 2 hours, I gave up. I could do alright in the game if the drops weren't so stingy. All that time, and I only got a single weapon drop. I felt extremely underpowered for the zone.

I see what they are trying to do here. The soundtrack is great. The pixel art is really good. The moment to moment gameplay is not bad. It just turned into more of a slog than I wanted.

If you want to play a metroidvania, you have lots of better options.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994455302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1556945719}
review:
I honestly can't believe the negative reviews I'm reading. Did people even play the game for more than an hour? If you're someone like me who loves that classic SNES feel and Metroidvania type games, you will probably love this. It has some of those classic old feel mechanics. If you die, you have to reload a save. No retry button or respawn point. You're character kind of sucks in the beginning, but thats how it should be to get meaningful progression. Just a guy and his short sword and knife projectile exploring the caves. Sometimes you'll have to backtrack, or avoid enemies that fighting would be dangerous. It gives a survival feel without being overly difficult.

This is a real SOTN/GBA Castlevania successor with replayability. Apparently if the game isn't immediately Wither 3 or Dark Souls, then it is trash. My only nitpick being the music has been a bit underwhelming, but that doesn't detract from the gameplay.

Solid 9/10 so far. IF you like SNES games, pick this up. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025192613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1105, 'last_played': 1540646222}
review:
I kickstarted this game back on 5/11/2013, and I've been mostly keeping up with the updates as they came out.
I played the early alpha way back in the day and loved it, and I beat the game on normal the day before it released.

After all of this, I can say without a doubt that this is a true "Metroid-vania" done right. The amount of polish and detail in the game is great. For $20 you can't go wrong picking this up.

Overall: 90/100 (Tentative - Once I finish my Hard Run, I'll update this with a final score).

Pros:
- Platforming feels great, ESPECIALLY after getting the [spoiler]double-jump ability[/spoiler].
- Combat can be really fun, especially when getting some cool new weapons.
- Plenty of unique weapon types to mix and match for certain situations.
- Lots of little secrets, and loot drops.
- Looks amazing, sounds great.
- The random-world generation is done phenomenally, honestly feels like someone hand-crafted it and it wasn't random at all.
- Difficulty on normal feels just right. (I'll update this later once I finish my hard run).

Cons:
- A few of the tracks can get a bit repetitive, but I wasn't annoyed by any of them.
- Some of the loot drops (unique items) can be insanely rare (in my experience).
- Depending on your seed, the world generation can be a bit of a pain to backtrack through.
- A few things could use a bit of extra info on what they do or the limits of their ability etc. (Some of these were fixed before release, so it could always change).

author: {'steamid': '76561197970406584', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1533080421}
review:
What was the point of spending two years in beta? Far as I can tell, the only changes from beta is that they added a short, pointless intro and made the game worse. 

I'm looking at you, worm boss. Why did you remove the goddamn cling points and add one-pixel areas that you could bonk your head on, completely foiling your attempts at dodging? In beta the boss was relatively intuitive and decently fun to fight. Now it's nothing but a mess of poorly-telegraphed attacks that require pixel-perfect timing to dodge. 

Also the combat feels as slow and dull as it ever did, which people also complained about when it was still in beta, but apparently no one on the dev team cared.

When I'm avoiding your enemies rather than fighting them after playing for only a few hours, that means they're not fun to fight, that's a failure of design. Every enemy is pretty much just a dull slog of wasted time because they have one trick, over and over, that you have to respond to, over and over, for like half a minute just to kill some random goon unless you're super overlevelled for it.

I could wait for you to try and patch this, or I could uninstall your bad game, accept that my money's wasted and spare myself any further frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115016174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1533077569}
review:
I'm really sorry but this game is boring as hell.
I really wanted to like it since I am currently finishing Hollow Knight and I wanted more Metroidvania awesomeness in my life.
Sadly, this is neither Castlevania Symphony of the Night nor Hollow Knight.
The levels are desperately empty. It really feels like this kind of amateur GameMaker games but with ultra-polished graphics.
Sadly, graphics are not enough for a game to succeed and combat is way too basic to fill the level design void.
Also, the story is not engaging at all. Maybe it would improve some hours into the game but most likely it will not.
The music is not bad, it's just generic and not thrilling at all. More like relaxing easy-listening. Not the kind of thing you expect in a supposed Metroidvania.
Nothing in here that will engage you to play for hours.
The thing is, this game COULD have been very cool: the graphics, movements and technical aspects are great. It is lacking in the gameplay department. It needs better monster IA (right now they are REALLY dumb), more variety and quantity of them and an actual carefully crafted map that makes you WANT to know more and explore!
In the hour I have played, I saw at least 4 times the exact same screen but with slightly diferent monster positions.
Return to the drawing board guys. This game could be so much more...
The gameplay doesn't do justice to the graphics.
Really disapointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131079130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1533046965}
review:
Well, I was really excited about the release of this game because it seemed really gorgeous visually and a pixel art metroidvania with rogue-lite elements sounded amazing to me given my taste in games!  (Dead cells, Hollow Knight, Rogue Legacy, Binding of Isaac). 

The sad part is I feel really misled.  All the trailers I saw for the game and even the pictures on the steam page show really amazing sprawling and inspired art-work.  But 90% of the game is the caves underneath all the gorgeous scenery, and its all procedurally generated, so it doesnt have a polished artistic feel to it.  It feels very.... seems like some corners were cut.  

Aside from that, the combat was very shallow, and the "RPG elements" were weak at best.  There is no space for alternate playstyles or builds, its just basic weapons with no special moves or attacks, and very generic magic spells which feel dull and flat.

I was very ready to love this game and devote the next 2 weeks to it, but if you come to this game expecting depth, go somewhere else my friend, cuz its not here.  Go play Hollow Knight or Rogue Legacy.   

It kind of makes me angry to be honest, because everyone is always trying to rally for the little man and cheer on the indie devs and shit on the AAA games.  But games like this that feel half-assed and 6 years in the making I heard.  I mean thats no excuse, and I can't give that a pass.  Also, when the game released, it didnt have an exe.  file.... lol it was literally an empty folder.  Go check the dev's twitter if you dont believe me.  I was willing to write it off but it wound up being a canary in the coal mine.

TL;DR  Art in main part of game is procedurally generated and lackluster, combat is shallow and stiff, and most importantly the game is BORING!  

I was ready to love it but I can't :(

author: {'steamid': '76561197960270050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1917, 'last_played': 1656370958}
review:
Full Disclosure: I'm a KS Backer.

Chasm is designed basically to simulate the general feel of SoTN and the GBA/DS Castlevanias with a bit more precision platforming and some procedural generation of the map from premade pieces (similar to what Enter the Gungeon does).

That includes the whole control, look, and feel of the game. Backdashing, lock frames at the end of attack animations (promoting jumping/short hopping to get extra hits), backtracking through previous maps when you get new movement abilities, etc.

There's not really a lot of wrinkles to it. There's a full range of equipment slots (weapon, magic, helmet, chestpiece, two accessories), consumable items, levels with stats, a main hub you can recover and purchase supplies at, and the overall "world" is broken up into several unique biomes that loop back on themselves into a central teleport hub for each and have connections to the other biomes within.

I enjoyed it a lot because that's basically exactly what I wanted. All the other 2d Metroidvanias/Metroid type games all kinda scratch a particular itch (Axiom Verge for example basically literally being Glitchpunk Metroid) and this one fits right in there. You want really nice sprite art, tight controls, and the Metroidvania-style gameplay loop of exploration/backtracking/risk (i.e. getting to another savepoint before dying)? Chasm fits the bill. TBH this game screams to be played on a portable because it's easy to pick up and put down, the length is just about right (~8-10 hours), and the game doesn't overcomplicate itself.

If you want my gripes as someone who played a bunch of earlier builds (did you know this had a Dark Souls thing going for a while?):
-For some reason the Mines theme was redone like a half a dozen times and the release one isn't as good as one of the earlier themes IMO (Sorry Jimi, for some reason I kinda liked the chanting in the theme a couple versions back)

-The loot table could use some sprucing up and needs to be tiered out a bit more. I got a lot of really samey stuff about halfway into the game that was a wash for what I already had equipped. White chests are kinda underwhelming and should give gear + additional loot IMO

-Quest items for some quests don't seem to hardly exist. The kitchen one is the worst.

-Few too many long hallways, little too much forced backtracking through them resulting in usually you being kinda overleveled at the end if you're trying to fill your map mostly out.

-Monsters don't always react to being hit, so once you upgrade your magic knife spell you can basically cheese a ton of enemies.

-Bosses/mini-boss difficult feels insanely random. Some are really hard to no-hit, some you almost can just stand there and just mash them to death. Final Boss looks really great but is not very hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969871885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1533071493}
review:
Pros: 
- Game looks pretty, that's about all I can say positively about it. 
Cons: 
- Movedment is very slow and unresponsive. Makes combat a bitch when you know the enemys pattern but you can't dodge out of the way cause your so damn slow.
- Hit registration is laughable. If 2 enemys overlap you only hit 1 of them so the other will hit you.
- Gas clouds everywhere. Feels like the developers intentionally left little things everywhere just to kill you slowly, forcing you to replay the area. 
- Combat is terrible. You touch anything you take dmg. Enemy has knife in front of him, yes I should take damage. I jump behind him walk up and touch his back, damage. Makes no sense. For some enemys it makes sense but if you dodge behind a large enemy you get stuck in a damage loop that you can't get out of unless you just run away. Hate this mechanic in games forces you to play a poke and run style for everything. 
- Like others have mentioned when you die you don't feel compeled to fight anything so you're just run past everything cause that shit is boring as hell. 

TLDR movement isn't great and that bleeds into everything. Combat is terrible with a poke and run style too it. Don't buy, give it more time to improve. I may try again in the future but for now it's being refunded :/

review:
Positive:
+ The townfolk was nice
+ The enemy design is where the game really shines

Negative:
- For a game with such a focus on combat, movement and attacking doesn't feel as tight as I want it to feel. Hollow Knight does this way better.

- The crafting/enhancement system is loveless and shallow
- There's a shortcut system which isn't terrible, but tedious. Instead of giving you another save point, you have to use this system to get back to your hub, because [i]there[/i] is a save point.
- You'll learn way to much stuff which you do with A. I don't want to spoil movement abilities but having so many of those on A makes your final movement capability feel surfeited instead of flexible.
- Why did nobody of the devs acknowledge how bad the implemented wall jump is?
- Way to short, even for 15‚Ç¨.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070952861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1583681356}
review:
So I knew about this game a few days ago, so I checked some gameplay and surprisingly I was very impressed....
So I decided to give it a try as soon as it's available and I wasn't disappointed.

I'll start with the pros:

+Enemy design: there's about 50 or so common enemies and meeting a new type of enemy every time felt really great, wanting to learn their patterns and attacks and figuring out how to counter each one felt really great.
+Art and music: not much to say here, they just fit perfectly.
+Puzzles: even though there weren't a great deal of puzzles but it kept the gameplay interesting unlike your typical dungeon crawler.
+Metroidvania experience: your typical metroidvania feel, backtracking didn't feel repetitive and kept throwing new discoveries so it won't feel useless.

now I'll be talking about things that might differ from person to person, though in my book I call them pros

+-Combat: It's right that combat doesn't feel fluid specially when you're attacking since your character is stuck in his place, but I'm pretty sure that's a design decision. When you attack you should think about the consequences of your attack. Should I attack? or would I get countered by that specific enemy?.
+-Platforming: It wasn't the greatest aspect of the game but it wasn't the worst, an alright platforming experience.

now for the cons

-Trial and error feel: Some parts, later in the game, were definitely a trial and error. for example, going in a dark room where I needed to climb a long wall using wall jumping where there is two chainsaws going up and down on both sides which you can not see definitely needs many deaths until you get the timing right. Also, this brings me to the second cons which is....
-Wall climbing: it's just a ******* inconsistent angry inducing skill. I couldn't make this skill to work and it drove me to the point where I just mashed the bottom and hoped for the best. it even ****s up your normal platforming sometimes.
-World design: It's true there's different areas, but they just felt like re-skins with the same layout.
-Save points: Going into a new room and seeing that it's connected to 3 other rooms and going in and out each one and hoping for it to be a save point isn't that fun, it's not a game breaker for sure. But, the urge to check every connected room before proceeding and hoping it's a save point is a little bit overwhelming.

Last thing, about the price of the game. I didn't start a new game yet so I'm not sure about the replayability aspect, but it's definitely a polished game and delivers a 10-15 hours for the first playthrough.

Verdict: A good metroidvania rogue-like game with minor issues, I'd recommend it to a friend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172627674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1637478596}
review:
To begin with, I liked this game a lot, really. 
Pixel art is great, I loved how the artist draw the forest, the mountains, but the caves look pretty... ordinary. And I'm afraid that most part of the game take place in the caves. Anyway it makes process of coming back to the village more awesome - finally me and my character can breath some fresh air ha-ha.
The plot seems to be interesting. In any case dialogs are well-structured and funny to read. I can't say the same about the long notes but it seems that there are only "not necessary" information there so it's okay to skip it.
Music is fine, nothing special, but it doesn't annoy.
At firs I thought that the game is too easy but I was wrong. When I find myself in the cave with the skulls I finally saw the "Game Over" screen for the first time and then made a run with almost zero HP to the next checkpoint. I want to say that developers put the checkpoints to the perfect places they should be. Level design is good, backtracking is not annoying, the only thing that made me feel myself really uncomfortable - repetitive tilemaps. Too many rooms were build with the same objects, but it's not a serious issue.
All in all Chasm is a good game to play if you like metroidvanias, good pixel art and challenging gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977146636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1533150454}
review:
Sadly Chasm is hard to recommend.
I had it on my list since they announced it, didnt back it on Kickstarter though because i dont do that for several reasons.
Since then it underwent many years of development.
I dont want to sound mean, but i honestly ask where those years went as its quality seems not reflective for the time invested.
Well developing a game is hard work that takes time especially when being a small independant studio. 
I get that and it is a finished game at last instead of another title spawned into Early Access.

But when i played the prototype once back then when it was fresh, i felt that the concept was much better than what i played now. 
It felt like a 2D Diablo with randomness and i liked that a lot.

I normally dont do reviews that early, but after 4-5 years or so waiting for it, i feel like i even will refund it and have to give people an honest opinion. 
I dont see light at the end of the tunnel for this game for the following reasons.
Some of which were named already and i didnt even pay attention to those points (although reading them thinking it couldnt be that bad) until i noticed them myself.

One major point, that is rather many points in one, is the Backtracking.
I cant remember it that good but i dont remember that backtracking was a negative thing in the Prototype. 
For those scratching their head or not knowing the language well enough, Backtracking means that you have to move the way you just went back to do important gameplay.
Clearer phrased this means that after you went into the dungeon and cleared several rooms, collected gold and experience, you want to get back to town to buy items, better weapons and do other stuff.
In Chasm there is no convenient way to do that, instead you have to clear all those rooms you just went through backwards again.
Which takes quite a lot of time, as there are also a lot of platforming sections to do.

I dont know whether you were transfered to town after death in the Prototype, however, it would be a really good idea for this version of Chasm.
As it is now, the game is a simple "you restart where you saved last time"-game. 
But even worse, you are thrown back into main menu instead and have to load your last save which then spawns you where you saved last. 
So even time is wasted. 
I dont get why you just dont lose a bit of gold and experience and spawn back at town.
Just mentioning, you cant save whenever you want, instead you can only save your progress at specific rooms with statues.
You know, Bonfire-esque, just bad.

I further dont get why i have to move back to town by hand, sometimes quite long ways. 
Why not giving me a portal option or even offer Town Portals at Vendors like Diablo?
The way the game does Backtracking feels tedious. 
That is because it does spawn the enemies right where they were, once you move from one room to the next.
Since it isnt a continuedly flowing game, you will kill the same enemies at the same spots over and over, when moving back and forth. 
Their positions and types arent even randomized to at least give variations. 
And their presence isnt impacting enough so it might cause situations super unfair to the player. 
Which means there is no real reason to not have randomized enemies and enemy locations in most rooms.
But because of the way dying works by spawning at the last savespot, it is even worse than the quite similar title Hollow Knight, which does slightly the same just not as bad.
Honestly i feel like Hollow Knight is the better Chasm.
In fact it is exactly like Chasm, just with more character, more polishing, more content, more story and not as many flaws.

Boringness in Presentation:
Chasm is also one thing, not really interesting, or in short, boring.
Its quite boring to look at, its boring to listen to. 
Items will NOT cause any change in appearance, at least till now i havent found that they do although equipping different items.
The music is absolutely horrible and tedious. 
The game played one track for the starting location, then one track for the village, then one track for the whole dungeon. 
ONE track for the area you are going to spend hours in.
No switching for bossfights. 
No switching for specific and unique rooms, no switching just to provide variation.
I can, at this point, only assume this will change later. But even if, this isnt enough. 
Which makes presentation not satisfying at all. Certainly not 4+ years development satisfying.

Controls:
The controls and hitting of enemies, the responsiveness and platforming are also not feeling smooth.
Its not that anything of that is super bad or that you cant get good at it, but it feels not well designed and accomplished.
While typing this, i  ask myself why there arent different attacks for each weapon.
Equiping other weapons will cause different attacks (although no different animations) but each weapon only has one attack type. 
It would have potential there.

I often enough was damaged because the controls are too sluggish in connection with what i had to do.
For exaple: 
There are enemy types that do a charge attacks after a brief pause of animation.
So you stand infront of them, hear a sound that indicates that they will attack after half a second of charging and then they attack with a sudden swoop forwards. 
Problem is, if you attacked first, then you cant evade because the delay between your attack and  the moment until you are allowed to perform a jump forbidds that.

Which means you have to bait your enemy into an attack, then wait for that to happen before doing your first attack. 
Not only does that stop and interupt your gameflow, its also unfair when you get damaged because the game is unflexible. 
Further it means that combat only allows one tactic to make it successful and doesnt allow a more dynamic way to do it.
It takes away player agency this way.

Resum√©e:
I had high expactations when waiting for Chasm. 
I waited many years. So much happened in that time of it being developed and i had as much hope for it, as i had in other games that were done in such a long time. 
Like Owlboy.
But contrary to a game like Owlboy, i couldnt notice the long development time here.
And contrary to a game like Hollow Knight i cant recommend it.
If you like the idea of Chasm, get Hollow Knight.
If you want a touch of randomness and more RPG elements with stats tweaking, leveling up and item looting, then get Vagante instead.
Vagante even has multiplayer (also online) which is quite a rarity in this genre.
So there are two really well done recommendations that take the place of Chasm.
If you already have enough of both games and search for more, then Chasm is maybe worth a look for you, although being a noticeable bit worse than Vagante and Hollow Knight.

Im sad Chasm cant deliver. 
Its an ok game it seems, but nothing special. 
Certainly not "i waited 4 years and longer for it"-special. 
What a let down, i really didnt expect Chasm to become a game i wait until i get it in a Humble Bundle for approximately 2$. 
I thought this was a no brainer purchase. Sadly its not and before you buy it you should play both of the mentioned titles.
Doing so will just leave Chasm appear blant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968402771', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1533061396}
review:
I've died many times in this game but don't get me wrong, this game isn't hard in any shape or form: is just plain boring. Many times I'd see myself just trying to run past the enemies (and would get damaged by trying to do so)  because fighting them feels more like a chore than anything else.
The procedurally generated aspect of the games brings nothing to the table and just adds more on the feeling that everything feels like a chore. Depending on the seed you get you may find yourself fighting 2 to 4 rooms of enemies on a narrow corridor and getting nothing at the end of it. If that wasn't enough, you still have to revisit many of these rooms in order to get chests you couldn't otherwise access because you didn't have the necessary spell/item/skill to do so. 

The combat is uninspiring and boring. You have your regular straight attack, an air attack which is your basic attack in air and most weapons have a crouch attack. The only weapon I've found that has a different attack pattern is the club, which attacks in a arc. Besides that the only difference you will see in weapons is damage and a minor difference in range and attack speed. There is no directional attack and no special attack so most of the time you will pick the weapon with the most damage output, not one the suits your playstyle (because there isn't any).

The pixel-art is nice, but the only place you will see it at its full potential is the city. The dungeon rooms are dull and empty looking, usually with a ok looking background and your usual chandelier hanging from the ceiling. From time to time you may bump into the rooms that are necessary to progress the story and those are a little bit better looking. Overall, the looks just feels empty and, like something is missing.

If you are die hard metrovania genre fan you may find some amusement playing this game but in my opinion it is an average game at best and a boring, mind numbing experience at worst

author: {'steamid': '76561198005072824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555, 'last_played': 1570942391}
review:
If you managed to miss this game since it was first Greenlit on Steam and for some reason expected the second coming of Symphony of the Night, you are going to be disappointed. 

However, if you've been following it for years and knew it was always going to be an action-adventure with RPG and roguelike elements, Chasm is certainly all of those things, and a good game as well.

Great graphics, decent music, solid progression and pacing, and well-designed enemies and bosses.

However, if you simply do not want a game with roguelike elements like procedurally generated environments and want something more elaborate and polished, this isn't the action-adventure RPG for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035204335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1703997827}
review:
Downloaded and played for couple hours before bedtime. This game is all that I expected for a side scroller. I love the super nintendo ish feels graphics or perhaps a game boy advance like graphics you can say, nevertheless it does bring back memories of the metroids and castlevania games I've played during my youth and still am. I had problem with the controller not responding correctly but that soon was fixed when I turned the controller on first and having it plugged in, (PS4 controller) I still haven't figure out what's wrong with the Xbox One controller which only allows me to jump and cancel and back dash. Anyways! this game is awesome in my book and I've already purchased it for the PS4/Vita bundle.

The controls are easy to use, nothing complicated so anyone can pick up the gameplay just fine. The animation is as expected of a side scroller which is beautifully done. the UI for character menu has an easy layout that you can find what you're looking for, a beastiary that keeps track of what monster drops for grinding craftable items or loot (they unlock after you kill a certain amount of the same monster type) 

I like the idea of random generated seed which is done everytime you start a new game so when i finish my current game I plan to play again. now i haven't beaten the game yet so I don't know if there will be a game+ which is a concept where you take everything from the previous game and carry over to the new one. if there is, kewl! but if there isn't that might be something to add in the future.

since it feature random seed generation, I'm hoping to see a map editor in the future (if possible) 

I recommend this game for anyone who love side scroller games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019166869', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1533016008}
review:
I am a huge Metroidvania fan. The exploration, the art, the movement. It's all incredibly fun when done right. Unfortunately, I feel Chasm misses the boat on a very key thing that makes a game a very strong "modern" Metroidvania.

[b]Combat[/b]: The combat completely lacks fluidity. Ther best way to explain it is that the frames of your character moving and making contact on the enemy seems... slow? Something just doesn't click. The animation lasts too long, forcing you to be hyper critical about which attack you're willing to make. The dodge back mechanic suffers from the same thing. As soon as the animation finishes, there remains this awkward couple of milliseconds where you're just waiting. That same "frozen" animaton state exists with the sword as well.

I think if the combat had just a touch more fluidity, I'd be completely down for this game. I'm also a little uninterested in the whole "procedurally generated" levels that many Metroidvania's are going with. Take your artists skill and make it static. Let them throw all of that passion into a handful of very delicately created levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043198608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1569754136}
review:
I've been waiting for this game to be released for about 4 years already. Imagine my excitement when I visited the Steam Page and saw the notice: "Avaliable on 31 of July". Gaaaah! Longest two weeks of waiting and voila! Instabuy.

This is metroidvania. The "dungeon" you're exploring is generated each time you start a new game. I can't say how different each run will be yet, but so far - the generated world gives me challenge I've been waiting for.

I'm kinda missing weapons and armors, or "souls" dropping from enemies - you know, right? Soma made us like the abilities from enemies. 

You start as a plain soldier with a sword and through your journey you have to save people, who will return to abandoned town and repopulate it (You know the drill), unlocking new shops and gear. And you keep crawling down to the root of all evil.

The controls are not fantastic, but good. As other folks stated here - the backdash feels a bit stiff. Jumping and navigating feels great though.

The combat is just what you expect it to be - good. So far I've met just one boss and he was quite easy, really simple pattern.

What can I say? Just buy the thing, it's definetly worth your attention. Even if it happens that replayability is not that good - you will remember your first run. I do hope that developer will add more over time (like boss rush mode, or some dlc's).

And meanwhile it deserves:
8 Belmont wannabies out of 10. Would loot carrots from monsters again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070704054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1533524888}
review: I remember playing the demo on PS4 at stores several years ago and after no word from the developers about progress, I had put the game out of my mind and let it sit in my wishlist like a long-forgotten note. I was surprised to see that the developers announced that they're finished and oh, boy, was the wait worth it. This game definitely falls in the Metroidvania category and it's incredibly enjoyable so far, not to mention the replayability with a different randomly-generated seed for each save file to keep the dungeon generator fresh. Fans of the original Metroid games, Castlevania, or the contemporary games Axiom Verge or Shovel Knight will enjoy this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966385727', 'num_games_owned': 997, 'num_reviews': 288, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1533056257}
review: Requesting a refund.  Remember thinking this looked like it had potential when I first saw it ~4 years ago.  Very boring.  Same layouts over and over, music gets old quickly.  Gameplay is like Symphony of the Night but nowhere near the same level of passion or intent, the procedural element of it gives it a warehouse-production feel.  I genuinely felt like I was going to fall asleep multiple times while playing this.  Grab Castle in the Darkness instead, the gameplay is a lot more engaging, the music is more inspired.  It's also a lot cheaper, which is another sticking point with this release - it's way overpriced.  Disappointed for sure because I wanted another quality Metroidvania experience, but you can't force fun, and this isn't fun.  Another solid option is Teslagrad, yet again lower cost higher quality, though it's more puzzle than action.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112219279', 'num_games_owned': 696, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1533055122}
review:
Wtf? From the trailers and visual direction this game looks great, and I thought I was going to love it during the opening interactions. But then you get to the meat of the game by entering a randomly generated mine to fight enemies and everything changes.

[list][*]The enemies I encountered didn't have any fighting animations, they just bump into you.

[*]Some take more than two hits but they have no knockback animation so you have to get super close to them, swing, and then dash back instantly because they'll just keep walking into you.

[*]The first boss I ran into didn't even move, he just sat there and had two special fighting animations.

[*]The NPCs you can save are in comedic cages with levers, all of them...

[*]The platforming felt jank and I kept trying to jump again before actually landing on a platform because the animation is weird and makes it feel like you landed before you actually did.

[*]There seem to be a lot of pixel precise jumps, especially around annoying enemies that crawl around the entire platform.

[*]The music is repetitive.

[*]The combat and enemies are repetitive. The combat allows for no stratagic approaches, just get close, swing, dash back, or if its a flying enemy jump and slash.

[*]The enemies dont seem varied at all, I fought the same goblin like 15 times at the start before seeing new enemies.

[*]The scenery in the mine is very samey.

[*]Your character sprite has a weird motion blur that you cant turn off.

[*]The combat and movement felt sluggish.[/list]

It was like a mix of dead cells and rogue legacy but 10 times worse...

Also, wtf?
