author: {'steamid': '76561197970584939', 'num_games_owned': 1257, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1833, 'last_played': 1533178224}
review:
Note: This is a review for the beta version released to Kickstarter backers before the full version. Some changes may occur between this and the release version.

Chasm's a game I've been looking forward to for a long time. I love Metroidvanias, I've been interested in procedural generation for a long time, and I adore moody retro pixel art -  Chasm has all these things and more.

The gameplay is basic, but polished - you hack and slice your way through randomly-generated and respawning rooms, fighting bats, rats, trolls, kobolds, then later fighting through an undead horde, a poisonous garden, and other locales. The Metroidvania-ness is there - you keep exploring 'til you hit a dead end, then you backtrack to find a way around it. You unlock teleporters as you go, which makes traveling around the map a lot quicker.

You find different equipment as you play, be it from monster drops or by purchasing it in town. Different weapons have different swing speeds/animations - a heavy 2 handed axe takes longer to swing than a dagger, but hits in a large arc. Weapons also have their own graphics, though armor does not - your character looks much the same at the end of the game as he does at the start.

The map generation works. It doesn't feel randomly generated, but it also lacks some of the fine tuning non-random Metroidvanias such as Hollow Knight show. The art is gorgeous, but some map seeds can generate multiples of the same room (though usually only 2 or at most 3), leading to some less-than-perfect exploration. Still, for a seed-based map system, it's one of the best I've seen so far.

The combat is great. Hits feel nice, and you honestly feel like you're a better fighter once you get used to the controls. At the start you will get hit by every other enemy, but towards the end you will be jumping and dodging around, landing blows and retreating before the enemy can counter you. Enemy difficulty ramps up towards the end, but I didn't have too much trouble once I found some good equipment.

Healing can be a hassle - enemies do not drop health ups, leaving save points as your primary source of replenishment. A death wipes your progress since your last save and kicks you back to the title screen. Enemies can very rarely drop food (and you can buy more later in the game, but the cost often outweighs the benefit), but your primary source of health will always be learning-to-not-get-hit. Much like combat itself, it was a hassle at the beginning of the game but quickly tapered off once I learned how combat and the game itself works.

Bosses are great. Fun experiences, unique designs, challenging fights, and almost always come with a savepoint mere moments away.

Storyline is pretty basic, but there for those who care to look. It's delivered via optional note pickups. It's nothing mind blowing, but it gives a nice insight into the lore, and is backed up by the again-beautiful pixel art.

Music was fine, I do not find myself humming the tunes but I also did not get frustrated by hearing the same tracks over and over.

The game has a couple of unpolished gimmicks - a bestiary that fills in as you play, a basic crafting system that uses rare ingot drops, a potion you only use in a couple of rooms, exp/defense/money shrines that are often completely useless, but these might be polished more in future updates, be they before release or after.

As far as updates, the devs have been working their butts off since the beta was dropped - they have already fixed a plethora of bugs, and I'm sure they'll keep polishing at least until the game drops on the 31st July.

Overall, very recommended if you like Metroidvanias with fantasy pixely settings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970770898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1633376006}
review:
I bought the game when no reviews were available. I played the whole day and had a ton of fun!
Beautiful art, fluid animations, combat is fun (even if its a bit clunky), levels have a lot of different bits and pieces that make it feel unique with every new room you enter. Finding townspeople and improving your character is fun, solving puzzles is great... I was expecting this game to be around 80-90% on Steam when I checked back.

When I came back, this game was getting trashed! (mixed rating with below 70% as of right now)

So, what went wrong?

In my opinion this game commits two sins that are probably keeping it from being great:
First one: no originality. If you've played many Metroidvanias, this game literally has not one single unique idea to offer. Absolutely every mechanic, weapon, enemy etc in this game is copy&pasted from other games. And I mean every single one, even down to the art and boss fights.

Is this a reason to downvote it? Some players might think so.

I think the worst sin this game committed was releasing the exact next day after La-Mulana 2 released. No wonder you have a tough crowd when you release with such extremely well crafted competition.

If someone is reading this, hoping for a good time with a Metroidvania in the style of the good old classics with a modern face-lift, I say don't worry too much about the review score and give it a bash. If you're not enjoying yourself after 2 hours, just refund the damn thing ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198001984708', 'num_games_owned': 834, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1533018886}
review:
Started playing this and immediately I'm reminded of Castlevania. Movement is largely the same, as is attacking. The stats and equipment screens are basically lifted straight out of the SOTN and later games. The magic spells you can buy are copies of classic spells, including the Axe, the Knife, and the Molotov (Holy Water). You can smash lanterns for loot, and enemies burn up in flames when they die.

Unfortunately, it suffers heavily from long, drawn-out, and uninteresting corridors. The mines were incredibly same-y, and the following area wasn't much better. There, it took me upwards of 20-30 minutes to hit something unique and interesting, and it ended up being an excuse to spend 30 more minutes traipsing through a bunch of boring hallways.

I really want to like this, but it seems to have taken all of the base gameplay of post-SOTN Castlevania games, and none of the wonderful level design. I get that it's procedurally-generated, but honestly I don't think it works in this case. It doesn't help that the backgrounds are all pretty much the same within an area. It just ended up feeling like a chore to continue playing. Also, where are the varied weapon types? The only things I found in the 2 hours I played were a knife, a sword, a longer sword, and a longer halberd, all of which attack straight ahead in a line. Where is my big axe that hits overhead?

Guess I'll play La Mulana 2 and Bloodstained: Curse of the Moon instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992035667', 'num_games_owned': 1234, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1139, 'last_played': 1634922275}
review:
Early review is early, but I want this game to succeed because it's fantastic. 
After so long in development, many might ponder if it was worth the wait at all, and I can stoutly say it was. The game looks, sounds, and feels fantastic to play. It runs wonderful even on my potato (for reference, my terrible laptop can barely even run Enter the Gungeon and experiences choppiness on Hollow Knight, so...) and the combat, movement, and platforming are smooth as butter. 
The story is nothing to write home about, but it's engaging, and the overall gameplay loop of exploring, rescuing townsfolk, and reporting back was satisfying and fun. Map markers make backtracking much less cumbersome than one might think - simply mark your map each time you run into an obstacle and you don't have to stumble around blindly to find that one spot where you needed a slide or a higher jump. 
It should definitely be noted: This isn't a roguelite. There is a hardcore mode and the maps are procedural, but the game is meant to be completable first-go, equipment isn't as random as, say, Robot Named Fight, and I'm pretty sure the bosses you run into are set instead of pulled from a pool. I can say this as a positive despite being an enormous fan of the genre, it very much works to the game's benefit. The devs have stated they worked hard to make the map generation perfect and I daresay they've done pretty well - it never really feels samey or repetitive, so far, and the smattering of quick travel points and save spots are very nicely placed. Same with the villagers, who provide either narrative or gameplay bonuses to the main town (like shops). 
If you're looking for a metroidvania to fill the gap for Bloodstained, or even something new on its own, I can't reccomend CHASM enough. It's enjoyable, nicely crafted, and I might just buy some gift copies my next paycheck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044487151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1932, 'last_played': 1532458456}
review:
Chasm is a retro metroidvania with beautiful art and tight controls. The game uses some procedural generation to increase replayability, but every room is handcrafted, and each area is unique with it's own theme, music, and enemies. On your journey, you'll find a fair amount of weapons and items, and optional areas and quests. The enemy variety is impressive, providing an abundant amount of attack patterns to learn and conquer. All the achievements are very much attainable, and the difficulty curve is at a good level, but if you want to up the ante, there's a hardmode setting and permadeath setting available. You can also tell that the devs are very passionate about their game, not only because of it's quality and attention to detail, but on top of that, the devs actually listen to the community, and have implemented bug and balance fixes extremely fast.

Overall, Chasm provided me an enjoyable and challenging experience, and I highly recommend it to fans of the genre.

As a backer, I've waited 5 years for this game, and now that I've finally played it and obtained every achievement, I can say with certainty, that it's been worth the wait. Thanks Bit Kid for making a great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961218844', 'num_games_owned': 544, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 1611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1483, 'last_played': 1533607240}
review:
I've been following this game for years and I'm happy to say Chasm is a very smooth experience. The story is enough to make exploring every aspect of the proceduraly generated map worth it. The story is smattered throughout the levels so it's not an excessive amount of exposition, but still enough to string me along. I love the combat (it's rather satisfying) with its smooth movement and pattern-based enemies reminiscent of the games of my youth. Newer versions of old enemies come along and keep the challenge high enough as you progress to be entertaining bordering on frustrating until you can master the newer patterns. (Except Titan. That giant floating head can suck it, him and the ceiling spiders.) There are some difficult jump puzzles and a fair amount of backtracking, but progress can be made if you keep at it. I also don't lament this because the world can appear large, but once you've unlock specific short-cuts, the world gets a lot smaller.

Chasm looks great, plays smooth, offers a challenge and doesn't make me want to punch a kitten or crash on me. If you love Metroidvanias or Action/Adventures games, Chasm should be a welcome addition to your library. For me, this is a fair contender for Game of the Year.

I will add a link to my review when it lands.

review:
Video review for the procedurally generated metroidvania, CHASM. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q8Oax-JMTbw

In Chasm you will be exploring a stitched together map that is different for every player, expanding your home town, fighting bosses, and expanding your arsenal. This classic take on the genre will be right at home for anyone who has played Symphony of the Night or any of the three GBA Castlevania titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000043184', 'num_games_owned': 992, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1552316263}
review:
Finally a metroidvania game that actually plays like one of the games it was inspired by.

 Some people are upset over the attack frames deliberately slowing down your character. You see, this game seems to take the most inspiration from Aria/Dawn of Sorrow which had this very same quirk with the animations. These people probably don't realise you can actually jump and attack right before you land to cancel the animation entirely and do a quick followup. If you play the game for more than 30 minutes you can actually figure this out by complete accident.

Hollow Knight, Dead Cells and Rogue Legacy, these are all good games. However none of them attempted to imitate the style of castlevania, they were all going for originality.

TLDR: Chasm is like Axiom Verge. Just like how Axiom Verge was an amazing imitation of the pure Metroid style. Chasm imitates the actual combat of the Castlevania side of the genre. If you were expecting something fast paced like Hollow Knight then look elsewhere.

review:
So far ive only beaten 2 bosses but I am loving the game already. the story is intriguging. the procedurally generated rooms are a cool touch for a game like this aswell. I backed this game many yeas ago because I love metroidvanias and the beta was fun as well. it may not be for everyone but if you like this genre you'll love this game. I should also mention the music is great too, especially the town music. The game also feel a ton like SotN and i believe that is intentional, its almost like a loveletter to it.  

my only complaints with the game so far are the lack of controller remapping, and the lack of a user manual. I have no idea what some of the stats do.  hopefully these issues will be addressed with an update soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009290344', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1401, 'last_played': 1533039889}
review: Really liking this game. Reminds me of Ys III. Its not a Rouge like, i don't know why people keep comparing it to one. Every weapon looks different. Every sword has the same motion but looks different depending on the actual weapon. just like the little details like that. Whips turned out to be my favorite. Its not super Hard but i did play on normal so i can't say how hard, hard and nightmare settings are. When you die you have to go back to the last time you saved but every time it was my own fault for not being careful enough. so save often. its very much a metroidvania game in that new abilities send you back to older areas to discover new treasure and new enemies. I don't write a lot of reviews so i am really just writing what comes to mind, but like i said i am having a lot of fun and if you like metroidvania games you will like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993869948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1533033383}
review:
As a long time fan of metroidvania style games i was looking forward to Chasm. Been watching it on steam listed for ages and i finally get to play it for a night of fun....only to be met with disappointment. Terrible disappointment. It's had 5 years of development time and the end result shows that something has gone wrong in it‚Äôs development.

The gameplay is slow and clunky. That's two major sins in this type of genre there that can make the game rather boring unless it has ways of compensating for it somehow such as pretty scenery, interesting story or unique mechanics. Unfortunately you're stuck in an underground, procedurally generated cave that makes every room look the same with a story that‚Äôs...ok for the most part. It somehow reminds me of the early game of Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia with the missing villagers and finding them restores more features to the hub town. Mechanic wise it does ultimately nothing new other than the fact that the majority of it‚Äôs content is done by procedural generation but even then it drops that pretty hard by the fact that the core powerups are the same, along with it‚Äôs design generally being boring as hell to slog though. It‚Äôs been done before and better (A Robot Named Fight or Dead Cells for example).

Frankly I'm just not captured at all by the game. It‚Äôs tiring to play and doesn‚Äôt bring anything new to the table. If you want a more compelling Metroidvania then i recommend something else. Incidentally, La-Mulana 2 came out on the same day as this so i recommend that over this.

review: This is a great game if you love old style metroidvania games. Being able to equip different armor, weapons and magic is also nice and adds depth to different playstyles. Expect to learn the enemies attack patterns and adapt accordingly, health is far and few between. Super smooth pixelart animations and the music is very good, reminds me of old Diablo 1 & 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162752716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1590529011}
review:
I have been following Chasm since 2013 when me and my friend came across it. I have to say it was worth the wait. I absolutely love the game, even just walking feels very fluid. I am quite a newbie when it comes to metroidvania games because I have not played much of the genre so dont take my words as someone who has worlds of knowledge about games of the same genre.
 The gameplay is fun, it is not fast paced so anyone looking for a game where you can just annihilate hundreds of enemies in mere seconds should move on. The combat also isnt just hit and get hit till the enemy dies. It has a lot more of a strategic point where you need to really think your movements.
The death system is not too unforgiving, it really depends if you have saved your progress. If you just breeze through the game without trying to find an altar to save at,  you will lose all your progress. It really isn't that bad, I enjoy games having repercussions if you die because it forces you to think more when engaging enemies.
I have yet to touch most of magic, crafting, and other systems so I cannot say if it is any good, but from what I've played this game is amazing and fun in a lot of ways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076767333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1533023060}
review: I've only played 3 hours so far, but I felt compelled to write a review because I'm not enjoying the game. Many aspects of Chasm are good, but very slow progression as well as how punishing (and quick) deaths can be counter a lot of the good and sap my enjoyment of the game. Avoiding death isn't especially hard, but healing items are rare to come by without grinding early enemies for them or spending a significant amount of gold. It's easy to run out of healing when exploring news areas, and backtracking to rooms with save/healing points is very unfun to me. Progression in the rest of the game so far hasn't felt rewarding or enjoyable enough to compensate for the slowness, so I'm not excited to play more of this game, and I find myself wanting to replay something like Rogue Legacy instead. Maybe I'd be more into Chasm if death kept map progress and/or items collected since the last save instead of obliterating all progress made. My issues with the game shouldn't be a problem (and might be a plus) for people into treating every enemy seriously, but I tend to focus more on exploring and care little about carefully refighting enemies on a return trip through an area.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970326508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1618492170}
review:
Loving this so far - classic metroidvania feel.  I wouldn't really call it a roguelike - deaths respawn you at your last save point like other metroidvania games, but each run has some procedural generation for dungeon layout and puzzles.

Controls feel solid, and there's a decent amount of satisfaction gained from figuring out enemy attack patterns.

Sometimes metroidvanias feel a bit tedious having to go back through previous levels, but Chasm's use of RPG-style character and gear leveling inspires a bit of a 'badass' feeling as you stroll through previous levels to investigate previously blocked off areas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985387398', 'num_games_owned': 1153, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1711344337}
review:
Kickstarter backer at the basic tier. I've followed development for a long time but never got a key until launch. 

This game is good. Not amazing, but good. Maybe very good. I do have some complaints. 

1. It's a rogue like, so if you die you lose progress. Keep this in mind. I just had to quit because I lost enough progress to make me annoyed so I need a break. 
2. It's VERY polished. AALLLLMMMOSSST too much. This is the type of game where you have to have virtually pixel perfect platforming. You need to learn where the hitbox for a platform ends, even though the graphic extends slightly beyond the hitbox. There were multiple jumps where I thought that I would need some kind of air dash or sprint and come back later... but I'd try again and watch the feet of my character and I made it. I find this pretty frustrating, even when I make it. I'm sure some people particularly long for that kind of thing, but it feels like a relic of SNES games I used to rent only once from Hollywood video to me.
3. It's a bit simplistic for me. Very solid game, but a bit simplistic. The type of game I can just blow through for 20-60 mins but besides the frustrations, it's a bit of a bland, samey experience so far. This might change, but even finding the first movement enhancing skill didn't change much IMO.

Overall, I enjoy it and recommend it for around $15, which is what I paid. If you particularly like roguelikes, $20 is probably fair. Otherwise, maybe pick it up at -20%+ off. The art and music are very good, so experiencing those is worth that much at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016995995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1626400156}
review:
[strike]Initial impressions so far.[/strike] After a bit more time...

Pro: 
+ The artwork is awesome.
+ The music is good and non-intrusive.
+ It has the one-more-run feel.
+ Awesome developer.

Mid:
+- They may have been a bit too faithful to the Axiom Verge design - some of what I would consider to be its flaws seem to have been copied over. Others may disagree.
+- I intially found the character blur effect distracting but after some time you don't notice it at all. Nevertheless, it would have been nice if you could disable it.
+- The platforming mechanics need some time getting used to. Most of the games difficulty seems to lie here. For me it wasn't a smooth transition from other similar games.

Con: 
- The text font is hard to read so i just ended up skipping most of the text and dialogue. (EDIT: It seems to be more readable at low resolutions and in windowed mode)
- The combat isn't as fluid as I anticipated based on the design updates. The dungeon design is used to artificially make attacking enemies more difficult than it is (e.g. enemies appearing in narrow, no jump sections, holes, or hills). 
- The backward dash isn't as responsive as I would have wanted. You can't just use it, you need to plan to use it. EDIT: Backward dash seems to be a little more responsive now. 
- You make the most progress (e.g. by conserving health) when you just avoid troublesome enemies (e.g. mostly head level hovering enemies such as bats, jellyfish, wisp, etc.) and grind for experience on more straightforward enemies. Constantly avoiding enemies to make progress makes the game feel bland.
- The bosses project information on their attacks too early that it kills the thrill a bit.
- I have no problems backtracking in these types of games but on some levels backtracking can be really annoying, even when you've unlocked all the shortcuts.

Bugs:
- You're not shown on the map after you teleport.
- If you save the game while you're poisoned, you fully heal but the poison remains in effect. As you can heal yourself indefinitely until the poison wears off, there is no point in keeping the poison status after a save.

Verdict: Highly recommended to Axiom Verge fans. Caution to Guacamelee, Ori, Hollow Knight, Sundered, Dead Cells, etc. fans though at its price point it could be worth a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008436731', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1657411328}
review:
First Impressions: "2 Hrs in and I had to pee the entire time.  This game kept me holding it for 2 hrs."

8 hrs in: I really thought I was going to love this.  I just assumed that like with most metroidvania style games that things just started slow and had something great to build to.  Playing Chasm I never felt there was anything truly rewarding in completing each challenge.  I never felt strong enough to take on the next area.  Screen swap farming seemed to drastically drop (if not completely remove) item drop chance.  Exp gains are so small that farming any particular mob for level gains just seems completely out of reach.  Getting a decent amount of gold seems impossible.  You never have enough gold for potions, or other support items.  I've played every Igavania there is and this game just falls short.

Yes this game is like SOTN if you took 75% of the equipment and items out of SOTN, removed unique button combos for special weapon moves and hidden spells, drop the 32-bit sprites down to 16-bit, take out all of the breakable wall secrets, remove all voiced dialog and have virtually no meaningful story progression cutscenes/dialog...  Really, if you took all of that away from SOTN then yes, Chasm is a lot like SOTN.

PROS:
-Good Soundtrack
-Charming artwork

CONS:
-Rigid controls
-Challenge to reward ratio is terrible
-Lack of secrets
-Lack of meaningful character progression in terms of build or story

author: {'steamid': '76561197983822533', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1533018674}
review:
Chasm by its self is not a bad game.. its acctually pretty solid on its fundimentals ... issue i have with the game is the fact that it just does not feel fluid.. you get stuck in place during attack for far to long. .to the point where you have to jump and attack all the time to keep movement flowing ... and i mean even more so then the original Castlevania's. The enemy design and animations are simple.. even down to the first couple of bosses.. and the game is not really difficult so far... i mean i only have 31% of the map explored so far.. so i can't say for the rest of the game. Story is simple.. and not to bad or anything.... soo thats alright i guess lol?

I don't know maybe iv been spoiled with games like Hollow Knight... Rogue Legacy .. and Dead Cells... .. or the odd one like Dungreed ... but i just haven't really enjoyed this one.. even tho i really looked forward to it.

Still don't like that there is no middle ground rating system.. so ill just thumbs down .. i quess?

author: {'steamid': '76561198044513022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1634251957}
review: This game has come a very long way since I first pirated its Kickstarter demo a whopping 5 years ago. I have been so excited to dive into this and now that I've played for even a little while, I must say that this is blowing my expectations out of the water. The art style is executed so well that I spent the first few minutes fangirling over how good it looked, the controls (given that I can only speak for gamepad) are incredibly tight and responsive, the tileset flows surprisingly nicely for a randomized experience, and man I am just absolutely floored by the talent this team possesses. If you have any interest in this one at all, please do yourself a favor and pick it up. I guarantee you will not regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077430448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1108, 'last_played': 1656397345}
review:
Happy to finally enjoy the full release of this darling little gem. As a backer, I've enjoyed multiple pre-releases of this game, and it was fascinating to see the changes in action, and even now, the final version is quite a bit different from the last version I played. But I could always tell these guys had a vision and they knew what they were doing. The controls and spritework and backgrounds and animation and weapon selection were always extremely pleasant. The controls especially are spot on and feel better than any of the games it pays homage to from the 16-bit days.

It's a pretty straight-forward metroidvania. It knows what it is, and what it wants to be, and that's all there is to it. And I couldn't be happier. Everyone who "pitied" the backers be damned. I was never disatisfied, and I'm not at all surprised by the quality of the final product. Worth the wait. Thanks for all your hard work BitKid

author: {'steamid': '76561197988207874', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1533262156}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. I beat it, cover to cover. But it just has too many problems from the design up. 

tl;dr: The controls are deliberately stiff and the unique features of this game (random maps, etc) work against it rather than for it. 

The biggest problem this game has is the fact that the map is randomly generated, rather than hand-crafted. This leads to several issues. There are only a total of six unique areas in the game, and the last two you only ever need to go into once in the last hour or two of the game. So you'll be spending the majority of your time in the same four environments, constantly repeating. This makes things really confusing to navigate, as every room looks more or less like every other room. There are no landmarks or patterns that you can follow easily. This could have been fixed by having sub-areas, like having a section of the mine be covered in fungus, ore, or glowing rocks. Or if it was a different color. But this isn't the case. So it's very easy to get lost, and in a game that's primarily about navigation, this is a huge, huge detriment. The map doesn‚Äôt help this at all. The map is too minimalist for a game where it‚Äôs absolutely required, especially considering that because it‚Äôs random, there‚Äôs no intent, foreshadowing, etc. to follow. This makes the backtracking frustrating and tedious, since you‚Äôll end up going to the wrong place. You can technically ‚Äúmark‚Äù your map, but you can‚Äôt add any details or write notes on it, meaning that if there were two or three marked locations that are ‚Äútowers‚Äù, you‚Äôll likely end up having to go to all of them, since you can‚Äôt remember which one had what features. I don‚Äôt expect the game to add these details automatically, although many other games in the genre do, but even being able to write a little hand-written note on your map at areas so you could remember ‚ÄúI need to be able to double-jump or something to get up here‚Äù or ‚Äúthis area is flooded, so I need to be able to swim underwater to access it‚Äù, or even just ‚Äúdouble-jump‚Äù and ‚Äúunderwater‚Äù would have been profoundly helpful.
 
This sort of flows into the second major issue, which is that navigation on a macro level is a pain, but on a micro-level it‚Äôs a nightmare. Enemies respawn any time you leave a room, and your ability to bypass them for most of the game is limited. Meaning you have to fight your way through every room every single time you need to go anywhere, and the maps are large. This is made all the more frustrating by the fact that you never really get anything that makes you faster. You gain certain movement abilities involving platforming, which allow you to bypass certain platform segments, but the most useful of these you don‚Äôt get until the absolute end of the game, by which point you barely need it. But it goes even further: The platforming sections in this game are quite demanding, and failure often means completely restarting the puzzle. These are sometimes almost pixel perfect, and the controls aren‚Äôt responsive enough to back it up. However, get gets so much worse once you start getting multiple abilities that involve platforming. I found the wall-jump to be the biggest problem, as you automatically cling to walls you‚Äôre jumping towards, and then immediately start sliding downwards. This means that if you fall into a pit filled with molten lava, for instance, trying to jump out will likely leave you clinging to the wall and jumping back into the lava, or sliding down into it. The sliding for wall-jumping, by the way, is literally never used and is a pointless feature. Your down-slide Megaman style is also nearly useless. It‚Äôs required for a few sections, but it‚Äôs an awkward length and never once does it go the distance you need in one shot. This is a minor issue but it‚Äôs one that could have been easily fixed by either changing the length of those walls, or changing the length of your slide. I‚Äôd recommend the latter, for reasons I‚Äôll explain further below. You‚Äôll run into the same issue with swimming. When you get the ability to swim underwater, you mysteriously lose the ability to swim on the surface, meaning that crossing large bodies of water is a huge chore. Thankfully this only comes up in a handful of areas, as water is rare, but it‚Äôs still an issue that could have been very easily fixed by having diving be assigned to the dodge button.
 
Speaking of ‚Äúdodge‚Äù, the other reason why navigation point-to-point is a nightmare: The combat. The combat is so, so unfun. Your character purposefully has a huge delay after you swing your weapon, meaning any time you swing your sword, you‚Äôre left standing in place for half a second, making you vulnerable to attack. This is made doubly-damning by the fact that your weapon reach is usually abysmally short, meaning you have to get right up close to enemies, and then stand there after you swing while they react. The clever players will notice eventually that you have absolute complete control over your jump, meaning if you time it right, you can swing your sword and jump at the same time, allowing you to go in and out quickly, without having to deal with being stuck in place. I don‚Äôt know if this was by design, but based on how silly it looks with the sprites, I‚Äôm guessing no. However, because this is the best(well, second best, as you‚Äôll soon discover), it means that almost every weapon is utter garbage. Fist-weapons and knives have too tiny a hitbox to take advantage of this, and heavy weapons, such as clubs, spears, two-handed swords are all too slow to pull it off easily. Their swing animation and recovery is also so long that the slight increase in damage is radically off-set by the amount of attacks you can get in. So swords are your only option, unless you‚Äôre lucky enough to find a whip that does enough damage at your level to justify using it. You can try using the weapons along with your dodge, which also has a strange delay on it, but the dodge is so short that I never once found it got me out of the way of an attack. And you‚Äôre not even invulnerable during it, at any point. You also can‚Äôt block, which for a game mimicking SotN so strongly, that seems like a weird oversight.
 
But all of that is negated by the fact that the melee weapons all suck compared to the best weapon in the game: The throwing knife. It‚Äôs a spell you can get very early that never stops being the most useful thing you own. For one MP it shoots a knife with unlimited range out directly in front of you, and you can shoot them very quickly if you hit your targets consistently. And until you hit over 30 intelligence, the damage is 1:1 with it, meaning if you get say the Onyx Ring early, you can be doing a huge amount of damage very quickly. Even better, you can upgrade the spell to throw two, and then three knives. This means that halfway through the game you‚Äôll be throwing three knives for thirty damage each once per second. On larger enemies (like say, bosses), that‚Äôs 90+ damage per second. And because it has unlimited range, you can often kill enemies before they‚Äôve even seen you. There are a few late-stage enemies that I don‚Äôt know anything about beyond what their death animation looks like. A few of the other spells are useful in some situations for similar reasons. The Shuriken goes up at a 45 degree angle, which is useful for some bosses. The barrier spell utterly wrecks the last boss. The Molotov is useful against enemies that like to block frequently. If this sounds really boring and sterile, that‚Äôs because it is. You end up fighting a lot of enemies, and they‚Äôre all boring as hell.
 

(LOL my review of this was too long for Steam, so I guess I'll just link the full review here: https://pastebin.com/jzkt0FMX)

author: {'steamid': '76561197987424141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1532942480}
review:
Review in progress, I've cleared the first few areas.

Tight platforming, combat feels nice. Slow start to get you used to the game, after an hour or so the game starts opening up, the enemies become more interesting and you get more options in combat and movement.

The game looks great: good looking, non-lazy pixel art. All enemies look visually striking, and the levels don't feel or look procedurally generated most of the time.
I'll admit I haven't paid much attention to the music, but at least it's not grating right? What I've noticed seems fun and has a retro style.

So far, it's fun. I can't imagine the rest of the game getting worse; it keeps expanding further in terms of gameplay options and exploration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000630500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2556, 'last_played': 1639186581}
review:
DISCLAIMER: This review was written for a version of the game at the time of its release. Since that time (possibly due to pressure from the community) the developers have made numerous alterations (some say improvements, others argue otherwise) and I no longer know if this review can be considered accurate. Upon official release of the game, the forum was flooded with a myriad of complaints from players incapable of grasping some very simple concepts such as patience, exploration, back tracking and even practice itself (trying a jump more than three times). Revisions of the game immediately followed which included such things as puzzles being dumbed down, platform locations being shifted, and many combat and statistic changes, just to name a few. Personally, I think the game was fine as it was and did not need half of the changes that have been implemented. Please take this review with a grain of salt as it may potentially be completely outdated and/or obsolete.

---------

Chasm is an old style Metroidvania game that doesn't hold your hand. It has a number of different areas to platform and fight your way through, each with its own unique and beautifully crafted visuals, enemies and music. Combat is simple yet challenging, requiring a different tactical approach for almost every enemy in the game, but not taking long hours to master. Each area holds its own little secrets and puzzles, and comes complete with unexplorable areas that must be returned to later on.

Armour, accessories and weapons are plentiful, allowing for custom equipment choices and catering to a number of preferences in play style; keep your enemies at a distance with whips, or get up close and personal with short range, deadly knives. You even have a number of different spells at your disposal with which to dispatch the ever respawning monsters that stand in your way.

As you progress through the game, you will have the opportunity to acquire not only pages from books to reveal the history and lore of the game's world, but abilities that will both aid in your movement around the environment and allow access of previously unreachable locations.

Chasm has spent a few years in the making and that time has served it well. The beautiful and detailed pixel art is a timeless classic aesthetic and fitting homage to classic games of this genre. The music is easy to listen to and does not distract from the gameplay, instead, each score compliments its respective area and enhances the experience of being there. The areas themselves are extensive, but not overly so, and are procedurally generated using a large selection of rooms that prevent passing through them from becoming dull, repetitive and "samey". The environment itself is highly detailed and beautifully crafted, from a rocky mine to a lush, overgrown, underground garden, and even an old, ruined keep. There's plenty to see and do in Chasm, and just as much replayability. Challenge yourself to play a different way, or just do it all again to see a different layout of each area. You can even share your map seeds with friends and other Chasm players to share the experience of a specific layout.


And now for the negatives; there aren't many, but they should be touched on none-the-less.

The early stages of the game can be brutal and even frustrating at times, especially if you're not a particularly skilled gamer. Enemies hit hard and although they can be dodged with relative ease, it's inevitable that you will be tagged. Now, you might not think this much of a problem, but save rooms (which fully heal you) in Chasm are set far apart and in the earliest stages of the game, healing items can be scarce to almost non-existent. Dying early on will likely see you lose a good bit of progress if those hits manage to pile up, and with enemies respawning every time you enter a room, this can make going backwards to a known "safe point" just as dangerous as going forward into the unknown hoping to find another such life saver just on the next screen, especially if your life points are already dangerously low.

This becomes less of an issue as you get further into the game when you are eventually able to buy health potions and have probably picked up better armour. In fact, towards the late stages of the game, you might just find yourself caring less and less about those occasional taggings as you start to be able to just tank your way through even boss fights by chugging health potions and shrugging off damage dealt with your armour. This can be both a good thing or a bad thing depending on the type of late game experience you want. Some people prefer to retain the high danger challenge throughout the entirety of a game, while some enjoy the sense of growing stronger as they progress. Either way, you still can't ignore enemies entirely; becoming too reckless, no matter how much defence and health potions you have, can still see you meet your untimely demise.

The controls are very generous and lenient, allowing total control during jumps and falling, and feel smooth and fluid. You'll no doubt become accustomed to leaping through rooms with precision and confidence quickly, but in the later part of the game you'll gain an ability that will give you cause to readjust your parkouring manoeuvres. It's not a particularly bad thing, but it can be a bit of a curve-ball to those not expecting it and will take just a little getting used to, forcing the player to once again pay closer attention to their movement about the environment.

The only other negative I can think of is the drop rate. Almost every enemy has a couple of different items they drop, including weapons, armour and even quest items. On the one hand, the high number of enemies you will be leaving bursting into little flames on the floor would leave you with a very full and annoying inventory to go through if the drop rate was higher, but on the other hand, the low drop rate makes farming for specific items tedious and slow.

Overall, Chasm is a great casual game to play, and even something more dedicated if you choose to challenge Mortal(permadeath) mode. A lot of time and love went into the making of this game and it truly shines through. Despite the few negatives, as a whole, Chasm is a great and fun game to play and shouldn't be passed up by fans of the Metroidvania genre. If you want a challenging platformer with plenty of places to explore and lots of ways to slaughter monsters, I strongly recommend giving it a go.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993516952', 'num_games_owned': 904, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1533011709}
review:
Chasm is a humble igavania that is greater than the sum of its parts. After a dozen hours or so, here are some final thoughts (as a backer, I was given access a day early):

World Design: Chasm makes use of procedural generation for part of its world design, and while it does show, the repeated rooms and layouts don't become monotonous. Unlike a recent title I've been playing (Enter the Geungeon), Chasm doesn't make the same mistake of copy and pasting the same enemies to said rooms. That being said, there isn't much in the way of puzzles in the overworld, which is pretty disappointing. Also, there is very little to no interactions with the environment. There are dissovling platforms, but I would have wished for some more offensive tools the player could make use of. Also, while I did enjoy combing through previous dungeons after acquiring some powers, the map marker is a pretty pool tool in that you are not able to clear the markers unless you happen to be in the exact room where you first placed it. I would have liked the map to highlight certain "special" rooms that require certain keys to make backtracking less tedious.

Enemy Design: Easily my favorite aspect of this game. There is a plethora of enemies in Chasm, each with their own unique behaviors and looks. There is very little re-skinning to see be seen here and, at least for me, was a great driving force in my will to continue playing. I loved learning the tells, and attack patters of the regular enemies as well as the bosses. I played the game on Hard and I was encouraged to learn the enemy's patterns to succeed.

Itemization: Pretty disappointed to say that any loot you find and equip does not change your avatar's appearance, HOWEVER, weapons & upgrade rank are represented visually, which is much appreciated. A fire sword will have a red slash, a poisonous dagger will have a green slash, an upgraded Knife attack will have more momentum, etc. Given that there isn't a considerable amount of loot, it really begs the question why the team didn't make the effort (budgest constraing methinks). Regardless, not a big deal for me anyway, I place far more importance on the enemy variety.

Performance: The game ran flawlessfy for me, and I saw no real bugs or issues. However, I do find it highly questionable that environmental hazards DO NOT affect your enemies, even if they stupidly rush past you and fall into a lazer field, or a of lava. This inconsistency bothered me some, but not much.

Skill Progression: Again, Chasm is much more combat oriented, than puzzle oriented so most of the skills aren't super major in progressing in the game. I don't believe you ever need all of the skills to beat the game at all. Maybe there was some cut content that was meant to use some of these items (swimming gear, parachute) but I think the game would have been just fine without them.

Combat Mechanics: I definitely think that Chasm has a solid foundation for future titles. There is a committment to swinging blades that I really like. You have to be careful when you decide to attack sine some enemies relaliate quite quickly. Or you could level up your play and learn the jump+land double strike combo! I also appreciate the variety of attack animations, larger weapons have greater vertical reach, combared to the basic horizontal swing of the sword. This definitely helped my strategy in taking out the final boss, or enemies who happned to be above me. I never found much utlility in knives since they demand that you be extremely close to enemies. Also, I tend to not bother with most magic systems since I like getting in close and learning enemy behaviors.

Conclusion: While I was a bit down on the game at first, I'm happy to say that I had a great time with Chasm and found in it a pleasurable title that follows in the footsteps of the classic Igavanias. Speaking of which, I think it's high time I started Order of Ecclesia.


Congratulations team bitkid, you've made this backer plenty happy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198096427944', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 8928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5292, 'last_played': 1590758886}
review:
I bought the Gold edition of this game on July 15th 2014 for $45. I know because I still have the email confirmation written down.

I purchased Chasm knowing full well that it was in development hell and might never be released but I didn't buy it because it was a polished game, I bought it because it looked like something made by people who genuinely loved it. Granted, it's only a side-scrolling adventure with a handful of controls but it looks and plays like a dream five years in the making.

All I can say is that it has been and continues to be an enjoyable experience well worth the wait.

(It has been pointed out to me that my opinion of this game may be swayed by having played it for sixty-odd hours as it was in develpoment, however I stand by my recommendation.)
